description:
Cozy Noodle House located below the bookstore in the Japan Town Center.     The restaurant offers indoor and outdoor seating.  The outdoor is actually still inside the shopping center so there is a cover and you can bring your pets.


The menu offers a wide variety of ramen, rice dishes and other noodle dishes.  I ordered the combination which included the hot udon noodle and a small bowl of chicken curry donburi.   The soup broth of the udon is probably one of the best I ever had in the city.   Great for a cold San Francisco day or when you are trying to recover from a cold.....so tasty.     Same with the curry sauce over rice.....nice texture.

Love this place, 2 thumbs up for Suzu!!!!
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Came here after being disappointed that Marufuku upstairs closed off their waiting list last night. The wait wasn't too bad at around 10-15 minutes upon putting our name down. 

The quantity is prime here. I ordered the Kanakui. That fat bowl of ramen could have filled me up for two meals because I had difficulty eating it 1/3rd of the way through. The broth comes out piping hot so be careful. Not a huge fan of the noodles since it gives off a very instant noodle taste to it. The broth was mediocre and I did not really like the pork belly. Another thing that peeved me was that all of our eggs were hard boiled. Usually, ramen places serve their ramen with a soft boiled egg. This egg looked like it's been cooked three times over. 

Overall if you're looking to get full, this is the place. Otherwise, come earlier for the better ramen upstairs.
author: Elvis N.

description:
I would love to give you 5 stars BUT ...
Please change your lights to LED .
Seating under those low lamps is Hot as Hell .
( I requested 2 or 3 years ago )
Food is good and so is the service.
Love you !
author: The AssMan -.

description:
One of the better ramen shops I have eaten at. Visited here for lunch on Saturday and didn't have to wait long.   I ordered the Suzu ramen with miso broth.  

I enjoyed the miso broth.  It was very flavorful and warming on the cold day. The miso broth is better than other ramen places in the Bay Area. The ramen came with karaage chicken, fried gyoza, and corn.  It was packed with all three items.   The gyoza and chicken karaage were both flavorful.  I would rather have preferred the karaage and gyoza on the side than in the ramen. This would have preserved the crispness of the fried texture.

Glad to know that if in the area, I can come back for decent ramen.
author: Marck N.

description:
Suzu is consistently good. It has my absolute favorite combination of Spicy Soba Noodles in a miso broth. I add kimchee to make it even spicier.The Karaage Chicken as an appetizer and Goyoza are solid starters. 

I try and go on the early side as to minimize the wait. Service is always prompt & accommodating and the food is hot and tasty.

This is one of my go-to places.
author: melissa l.

description:
Ramen noodles upstairs was close so we end up here! Service was fast! Costumer service was fantastic but the food was salty and not good 
Im not picky but it wasn't worth it!
author: Neng A.

description:
Suzu Noodle House, the go to place when you're not willing to wait upstairs for 1+ hours. Came here on a Friday evening around 6. A wait for a table was about 20 minutes.

Not really much to complain about. There were only two servers working, our waters got refilled frequently, and our order came relatively quick.

All together, we got the mixed tempura, suzu ramen with miso broth, and kaarage curry. My ramen came out piping hot! I wish the kaarage and potstickers weren't places in the soup because they got soggy quick. The amount was enough for me to take home and have a second meal. The tempura was lightly battered and crispy, just the way I like it. I liked their assortment of veggies and they give more than most places. Didn't try the curry, but my brother finished it all!

Maybe it's good. Maybe people just didn't want to wait elsewhere. Nonetheless, it wasn't bad and it definitely is fulfilling, especially if you're really hungry.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Ordered the Cha Shu Udon with the Shoyu base which was just perfect. The broth was hearty but light (my favorite) and the Cha Shu was not too fatty, which I loved. 

The service was efficient, friendly and the food came out really quickly. 

Definitely coming back for more!
author: Kath H.

description:
We visited Japantown on a Monday and it seemed that most of the restaurants were closed. Without a variety of options, including where we wanted to dine (Marafuku), we came to Suzu despite the "warning" on the front of the Yelp listing. (I'd never seen that before.)

After a brief wait, we were seated at an outside-of-the restaurant table.   Service was pretty fast and after a quick decision, we ordered straightforward items - Karaage, Hayashi Chuka, Gyoza and Shoyu Ramen. 

The karaage (fried chicken) was pretty good though I prefer a bit more crispy cooked.  It is dark meat so it already has a pinkish hue but the flavor and texture made me at least wonder if it was still raw.  Overall, we ate it and were fine. :)     Gyoza were perfectly cooked and the accompanying sauce was tasty.

I only had a little bit but what I ate of the ramen, I was pleased!  The very generous serving wasn't overly salty, was full of veggies and chicken, and had enough flavor to standalone.  I scored everyone's veggie fritters too.  Those were a fun addition and reminiscent of a memorable lunch in Japan.   

Hayashi Chuka is a traditional summer salad in Japan that I've ordered, and made, countless times.  Like a lot of salads, the dressing has to pull it all together and this definitely fell short.  It was a let down.  Sorry.

So, we came here by default. Some hits, some misses.  Not really worth a return for this girl.
author: Heidi D.

description:
Got seated right away and it's about 1:35pm on a Tuesday! Ordered the Spicy Ramen with combo option and selected the Karaage. Karaage was good portion but not as crispy as most places I've eaten it at. Maybe because these pieces were bigger chunks. Spicy Ramen broth with miso flavor was spicy but not too spicy. It's at about the spiciness level that I can comfortably handle. I'm not sure if I liked the broth. Rather than a refreshing feeling while eating it, I felt like it was a little heavy handed on the flavoring. It felt thick but not physically if you get what I mean. Anyway, it had me feeling that I should have chosen shoyu flavor instead but that prolly would've make it taste too salty. 

Biting into the dish and sipping on the broth some more, I began to appreciate the flavor and texture of the broth. It balanced out the strong and succulent pickled bamboo flavor and evened out the sweetness of the pork. The bok choy was a nice touch of flavor that didn't over compete with the other ingredients because there were only two pieces (just enough). I love bean sprouts but only if they're cooked, so once my ramen arrived I immediately submerged them into the hot steaming broth. 

I guess if you come here with certain expectations then maybe you'd give this a bad review but if you cone here open to receive whatever is plated for you then I think you just might appreciate the complex simplicity of this particular ramen. There are no gimmicks attached to this one. She's straight up and gives no fucks if you like her or not. She comes as she is and its on you if you want to build a relationship with her. If you want to continue to learn the different ingredients about her that you may have missed or revisit certain ingredients that you were not quite sure of but will to give it another try. The maturization of your palate will be determined by how much you quell your insecurities about how much you know about what solid ramen tastes like and not what it looks like.
author: Glenn A.

description: Kinda made the mistake of not checking Yelp today because I was not super impressed by the food quality. It was busy though so I assumed it would be good. The service was kind of slow, but I understand because it seemed like there was only one waitress while there were a lot of people there. I got the Miso Ramen and it was very average, and I was disappointed that there was only half an egg and that it was already cooked. My brother got the sea salt broth and it was average too. It broth just seemed to lack a richness that I've had at at other ramen places or even i-Tea. So all in all I was a bit disappointed but maybe their other food is better or the soy sauce based broth.
author: Carlie C.

description:
Reliably decent food.  One of a few on our B list when we don't feel like waiting one hour just to get a seat at the other popular ramen house.  Suzu service is nice and accommodating.  We came in close to their closing time on Saturday.  They were full but was able to accommodate us with our stroller.  

We ordered Curry and Cha Shu ramen with a side of kimchi.  Curry ramen had good broth, plenty of ramen noodles, but not so much chicken.   Cha shu was just as expected.  Good broth and there's always never enough cha shu.  Kimchi was a nice side though not spicy enough for my taste.  

Overall Suzu is a good place to go where the line is never too long and service is nice.
author: Naty D.

description:
It's quite hard to fall in love with what this restaurant offers. We went here on Wednesday during lunch time, there was no waiting line at all. We ordered;

1. Seaweed Salad and House Salad. Pretty straight forward and very standard for each dishes. My disappointment was they diluted the salad dressing with water, to the point the salad itself was drenched and dripped badly when you lifted em' up with chopstick. Shouldn't the dressing texture be a bit thicker? Most likely I was eating the salad with 'soup' dressing, because it was so watery, thin and weak. 

2. Tsukemen with Spicy Broth with Chicken Karage and Veggie Fritter.
Not really a fan either. The noodle itself is an okay ramen noodle. Not too soggy or too chewy. They did well on cooking the ramen noodle. The soup though, wasn't flavorful enough. I ordered spicy broth, but tasted more like a regular standard broth. Chicken karage was an okay, but the veggie fritter was bland. I felt they didn't put enough seasoning on the batter. 

Will we come back? Probably not since it's not worth the money, and since it's located inside the Japantown Mall, they have other choices of restaurant to pick, or you can go outside the mall, and you'll feel find more choices.
author: Maureen M.

description:
Slow service. Ramen was honestly pretty terrible. I've never had ramen broth that was so diluted and tasteless. The noodle itself was decent, but the miso broth was so bland I had to pour loads of chili powder just to spice it up. The charsiu was overcooked and tough and way too chewy. 

Probably will not return again.
author: Christina N.

description:
On point with the skinny homemade curly ramen noodles.  Same shape as the dry top ramen packs but of course fresh made and cooked to a nice soft elastic texture.

Tsukemen - spicy miso broth more salty than miso flavor.  Karaage was on point.  Kakiage huuugggee...both made in house I believe...karaage is tricky as there are many brands of frozen products.  

Hiyashi Chuka - usually no fried accompaniments but this had karaage and kakiage again.  Sauce was a bit oily but didn't need to use much.  

Kakuni Ramen - lots of pork, fatty and tender goodness.  Miso broth was light but flavorful.  Hard egg, wish it was soft.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Came here for lunch and had a great experience:

1) We did not wait at all. Arrived around 1:30 on a Sunday and we were seated immediately. A group of people came right after us so we were pretty lucky. 

2) I ordered chicken curry with rice and it was delicious! The chicken was fried for just the right amount. The meat was tender and not dry at all! The curry was good, slightly salty. The radish went well with the fried chicken and curry. The acid definitely helped to soften the fat in the fried meat. The rice was cooked fine and went well with the curry. This dish was satisfying overall. 

3. The chicken curry also came with miso soup and salad. The soup was great, it was warm and not salty to my taste. The salad was refreshing. I enjoyed the sauce. It was sweet and slightly creamy, and did not overpower the fresh veggies. 

4. I also got the hot tea. The taste of the tea was faint; I mostly tasted hot water, but the tea was dark enough to pass. 

5. Despite of the warning from Yelp regarding its health inspection, I ate their food and my stomach was fine. As a matter of fact, my tummy was content. Maybe I have more tolerance for certain foods or maybe I just got lucky.
author: Eileen H.

description:
Broth is meh, and the noodles are definitely on the cheaper side. Quite thin and obviously store bought. If you're in Japantown and want some good ramen, you're better off looking elsewhere.

Come here if you want BASIC RAMEN.
author: Helen C.

description:
Pretty good ramen on the bottom floor under the Japantown bookstore! Suzu Noodle House is one of the ramen shops within the Japantown Mall, closer to the Fillmore side with pretty good ramen and hugeee plates of curry. 

Came with 2 friends around 6pm on a Saturday to only a 5 minute wait for an "outside" table. It's kind of nice because regardless of whether you sit "outside" or inside the restaurant, you're still basically indoors (aka not the cold). The outside tables are kind of nicer anyways because they're less claustrophobic though people to walk around the mall. 

My friend wasn't too hungry, so I ended up ordering  a Chashu Shoyu-Flavored Ramen ($11.25) with a extra small bowl side of Curry Chicken Rice ($3.25) for her...so pretty economical! The Shoyu Ramen was pretty tasty--The broth was light, warm, and savory, and the ramen noodles were cooked well. The only thing that disappointed me was the chashu--it was dry and not that flavorful, which made me extra sad because I actually paid extra for more of it thinking it would be better.

Other than that, service was pretty good. It was pretty packed by the time we were eating but we didn't have to wait too long to flag down a waitress. I noticed the low health food rating after eating here, but like other people, I didn't get sick I guess. Hopefully they are improving with cleanliness... Next time if I come again, I would just get the standard ramen (no more extra chashu) and maybe some curry to try. But there are so many other solid ramen places to try in J-Town, it might be a while before I'm back.
author: Clarissa C.

description:
Man I really wanted to love this place but my experience was so meh I don't think I'll be back especially with so many choices in Japantown. 

Came here on a Friday night and everywhere was packed. The wait for this place wasn't that bad. Maybe about 20 mins. The menu is pretty standard. They serve ramen, udon, and rice dishes. Our table ordered some of each. For a few more dollars you can add a don to your noodle dish. I ordered the beef udon hot pot.

The food came out at different intervals so we had to wait a bit. The ramen was the last thing that came out. My beef udon was not that great. The noodles, veggies, and broth were good but the beef was gross. It had a slimy film on it. I think it was supposed to be stewed in some sort of brown sauce, but it only made it soggy. The taste was even worse. It had a distinct freezer taste. I left most of it in the bowl and just ate the veggies.
author: Junella T.

description: Tried their veg ramen today with miso broth. It was pretty good. Our server was so helpful and patient when we were trying to figure out the veg options...Also had agedashi tofu for appetizer, that was really good as you could see it wasn't deep fried... lightly coated and perfect! I will definitely return to try other items on the menu.
author: Annique D.

description:
Got the meat udon and shrimp tempura udon . It was fast and the udon noodles tasted like store bought. Nothing impressive... wouldn't come here again for udon, maybe the ramen is better? 

I would compare this place to fast food noodles. Nothing fancy or out of the ordinary. They
author: Melanie T.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on a Saturday afternoon trying to catch the second round of lunch around 1pm. We put our names down and had to wait 20 min to get seated, but that's pretty typical for restaurants in Japantown on the weekends. 

I had the Nebayaki Udon and my boyfriend had the Ebi Curry Rice. 

Nebayaki Udon - You can get it with Miso (chicken and pork broth) or Shoyu (fish broth) I opted for the Miso hoping for more flavor. The broth was indeed very flavorful, maybe a little too salty at times. The portion size was on the small size but perfect for me. 

Ebi Curry (comes with miso soup and salad) The dish came with four large pieces of fried shrimp. The curry was a little too sweet for my taste but it was alright. The portion size was also perfect for him. Not the most amazing curry though. 

The service was very good. They had a lot of waitresses working this day so we were easily helped. I think this was overall an average experience. There's definitely better options in Japantown but this did its job.
author: Kelly N.

description:
Regardless of whether you like your ramen creamy or light, if made properly, either one could taste just as good as the other. I was down to try the much talked about ramen upstairs (Marafuku) but due to a dead battery, I lost my place in line. 

Suzu opts for a clear broth with neither the complexity nor the flavor to hold the dish up. I selected my broth - shio - a salt based broth that lacks any of the punches that comes with shoyu (soy sauce) or miso based broths. While my broth was definitely light and salty, it was also lacking in depth with barely any hints of the typical ramen components or flavor profiles. 

My ramen came with spicy green onions which likely would've helped the broth give it some much needed kick. Unfortunately, the spicy sauce neither enhanced the flavor nor did it make the ramen any better. It was there, along with a ton of green onions, which I can at least attest to tasted like green onions.

Next up were the noodles - thin and springy - but ultimately better suited to Chinese noodle soups. Ramen noodles tend to be firmer and chewier, without much bounce to the texture or the bite. These noodles would go well with wonton noodle soup, but I wouldn't pair it with ramen.

Finally, I was given a tough, chewy SINGLE piece of chashu in my soup. Talk about disappointed. At least there were vegetables. And the takoyaki was actually pretty good.
author: Edwin B.

description: The food is just okay. Not sure why there is always a line or why it is always packed especially when there are other ramen restaurants nearby. The broth is very salty with little pork taste and the egg comes hard boiled instead of soft boiled. It came with a single leaf of a vegetable and small thin pieces of pork. The ramen itself seems to be a prepackaged "fresh" noodle based on its texture. The health score of 73 that is subtly hidden should be an indicator as well.
author: Ernest M.

description:
*I went seeking love*
*kept looking outside myself*
*found it here inside*

Self Love - Japanese Haiku

I love things Japanese. From antique ukiyo-e to silk kimonos, from century-old bonsai trees to karate, from zenism to godzilla, from haiku to kawaii, and of course the foods! Japantown in San Francisco is one of my stops when I'm in the Richmond district. I love the shops, the aura, the restaurants. In Japantown you can eat almost anything Japanese, from low-grade refrigerator bentos to high-end sushi. It's always happening in J-town. So many choices, but one steady I have is a noodle spot located away from the other mall restaurants. It's on the Kinokuniya side of foot traffic, on the lower level next to the garden store. This little spot is called...

Suzu Noodle House

It's a comfortable little eatery serving classic udon & soba noodle soups, nabeyaki & other Japanese mains, like katsu, teriyaki, etc. I've been coming here for years and it's mainly because it's away from all the heavy foot traffic from the other eateries and it's probably the best bang for your buck too. I particularly love their combo specials. The specials consist of a choice of noodles and a mini entree. On my last visit I chose the house ramen in shoyu based broth & chicken katsu don over warm rice. Miso soup and matcha tea included too. The combo deals never fails me. Especially knowing I'll have enough yen for dessert elsewhere. 

Suzu Noodle House 

In a weird way you could say it's my semi-secret hidden gem in busy Japantown. It's never too busy here, unless it's movie night next door then you might wait. It also reminds me of my visits in Tokyo where many customers eat and go - so even if there's a wait it clears up pretty quick. Great spot for a solo ninja or a couple in adolescent love.
author: Eric R.

description:
Spousie and I were doing a J-town run to get some ingredients you can't just Instacart to your door, we needed food on our trip, and stopped in here. 

Spouse ordered the karage ramen, I ordered the Katsu curry. We started with takoyaki. Cause my affection for eating cephalopods is endless (sorry world). 

The flavors here were very punched up. The salt was very salty. The mayo was on super overdose. The sweet was very sweet. Is this an effort to cater to an american tourist type palate? I don't know. I would have dug things a little more subtle. 

The portions were generous, so, that is definitely to their credit. Again with the note about subtlety. YMMV!
author: Liss T.

description: One of my favorite ramen out here in Japan town. Flavorful and a good selection. I honestly think it's better than some of the ones around here with higher stars. Great quick service. Never had a bad experience here.
author: Anelita T.

description:
Never heard of this place but there was a pretty substantial line outside on a Saturday afternoon. I was with my mom and grandma and we were trying to figure out where to get lunch. I saw they had only okay reviews on Yelp and a food safety warning but figured it must be good if there was a line while other restaurants sat empty. 

We waited about 10 minutes and got a table by the kitchen. Their menu is pretty limited to ramen, udon, and curry bowls. I would not go here if you were not in the mood for any of those because you will be disappointed. My mom and my grandpa got ramen bowls and I got their shrimp curry. 

Their portions are HUGE. I wish we just shared a dish instead because none of us finished our orders. It was the biggest curry bowl of my life and came with salad and soup. They give you this really interesting deep fried pile of veggies that I've never seen before. Not even sure really what it is as the menu didn't list it in the description but I think it was onions and carrots. It also comes with my favorite Japanese pickles. 

Ramen bowls are also huge. Spicy ramen was not super spicy. Price is so cheap for the amount of food you get. Everything priced around $10.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
This place is located inside the japantown mall, which allows dogs. So you can bring your dog to the "patio" seating outside the restaurant, but it's technically still indoors because its inside the mall. But thats my big plus being able to bring your dog and not have to sit outside in the cold!

I tried the pork belly ramen with miso broth. The pork belly was really good and flavorful, they had a decent amount of pieces too. The ramen itself was just okay.  The noodles didn't seem handmade or fresh and the miso broth was realllyyy salty. The size is pretty good though.

The combo deal you can add a side unagi don for $5.25 is pretty good, I'm a huge unagi fan!

I don't think it's amazing ramen but its convenient and decently prized considering its inside the mall.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
For a spontaneous date in SF, the hubby and I ventured our way towards Japan town, a little spot in the city where you'll find sushi restaurants and ramen parlors galore, a multitude of cutesy knick-knack shops, and tens of delicious dessert places. The one thing I absolutely hate about this area is the ridiculously expensive parking, even for the metered ones. It costs $4 for ONE HOUR. Are you kidding? My poor hubby had to run out multiple times just to add a few more quarters.

Luckily, our lunch at Suzu Noodle House made up for it. Because we were going on a weekday, there wasn't too much of a crowd, but they did have a full house. The space itself is very small, so we opted to have a table outside (keep in mind the restaurant itself is located in a larger building, so it's not REALLY outside). The menu has a lot of variety in terms of ramen and the prices were quite reasonable.

The hubby chose Suzu Ramen with a shoyu broth that came with karaage (fried chicken), gyoza, and corn while I chose the Kakuni ramen with a miso broth that came with braised pork belly. Each ramen bowl is always served with green onions, bamboo shoots, BBQ pork, and half a boiled egg. For mine, I requested spicy paste on the side for an additional dollar. Our ramen came out in massive, black bowls with beautifully layered toppings. I will say that I was highly disappointed with the boiled egg, seeing a yolk that was fully cooked instead of that delicious golden ooze.

But the minute we both took a sip of our broths, our disappointment instantly melted away as our astonishment of how tasty the broth took over. After adding the spicy paste, my miso soup had a fragrant undertone that cleared my sinuses with every slurp. The pork belly was undeniably tender, but I definitely had to forgo those inches of fat. I'm sure my arteries thanked me for that. As for my hubby's ramen, his miso soup reminded us a lot of instant ramen, but in the best possible way. It tasted comforting and familiar without all that heavy salt. This was one of the few bowls where he actually almost finished the soup. Surprisingly, the skin of the karaage retained most of its crispy texture, although near the end it did get soggy, and the gyoza had a delicious filling.

We were both super full by the end of our lunch and practically had to roll ourselves out of there. We're sure Suzu Noodle House is always competing with its fellow ramen parlors, but with quality like this, we think it's doing just fine. In fact, it's probably doing great.
author: Quyen L.

description:
Went here awhile back with my girlfriend, who stopped me from eating a cockroach in my ramen, no joke.

I didn't pay for the meal and walked right out, naturally. Hope they got their shit together since then but I changed my mind after I walked by the other day.

Lol people should probably know that's a possibility when you dine here. I however, have no real hatred for them, I'm sure it was a honest mistake.
author: John W.

description:
Holy Moly!  I log in to write my review for Suzu and I get a pop up message saying they are in the bottom 5% for food quality/cleanliness... LOL but hey! none of us got sick so that's a win right off the bat!

I'm not a huge fan of ramen to begin with - I have yet to eat at a ramen spot that just blew my mind.  Perhaps I just don't have the palette to appreciate the broth or the noodles - I like eating top ramen as that's what I grew up on.  I ended up getting the spicy ramen and it wasn't even spicy.  The meat portions were pretty minimal so I was happy I ordered gyoza on the side, those were pretty big and flavorful. 

Nothing note worthy for me, not sure due to bias or because it really isn't all that good.  I expect savory when eating ramen, if I order spicy, I want to not be able to stop drinking water (but still taste my food), I want the noodles to be so good I can't help but slurp them then use my chopsticks to search for more at the bottom of the bowl.  Suzu did none of that but it did curb my hunger and the service is nice.
author: Nam N.

description:
I was having a huge craving for some spicy curry and my friend who resides in Japantown highly recommended Suzu Noodle House. He loves coming here whenever he's feeling lazy and doesn't want to venture too far for some decent quality Asian food. I'm glad he took me here because I really enjoyed every dish we ordered!

Between the two of us, we ordered a bowl of Spicy Chashu Ramen and the Chicken Katsu Curry. The Curry was amazing and best I've had yet in San Francisco, even better than Volcano Curry House in the Inner Richmond. I couldn't get enough and it was my favorite dish of the night. The Ramen was also tasty and good for a cold day in SF, but overall I got tired of it after a few bites and found the broth to be pretty oily.

I definitely will be coming back just for the Curry and perhaps will give the Udon noodles a try too!
author: MyTien P.

description: I ordered the Shoyu Ramen, which was very tasty. There's a lot of noodles leftover, but overall it's a very filling dish.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Loved it.  Had the udon with veggie tempura and added the chicken katsu.  We also ordered the gyoza and the Suzu style ramen.
The gyoza were large and packed with flavor but as others have also written, the shape is a bit odd.  Who cares though?  They were delicious.
I really enjoyed my udon and it's broth.  Not sweet at all but heartily flavorful.
The katsu was served over rice and was a nice addition as my choices were non-meat choices.  The sliced and breaded chicken breast was moist and full of flavor.
My "little brother" ordered the Suzu ramen and loved it--just a note here --it is presented in a miso broth.  And, it's a large serving--he is going to try something more soy based next time.

Service was great. We were seated and served very quickly.
Clap! Clap! Clap!
author: Thomas D.

description:
I only come here when the actual good ramen place upstairs is too packed. 

I gotta say I'm very disappointed.
author: Xiao C.

description:
I came here year ago with my wife and didn't really think it was all that but I know to alway give a second chance to a place of business even if it's just for Data 

I was so glad I did it is awesome we went to the movies and came out and it was cold and raining  so we ducked in Japan town and it smelled amazing so I said wtf let's try here again .

I had my 2 kids with me and they loved it as well .
That's always a good sign!


Had the spicy pork belly ramen  and I will be coming back at least once a week for the foreseeable future the broth was nice and rich lots of umami and the pork was almost sweet and falling apart!!

Ummmmmmm I am getting hungry now thinking of it !
author: Azikiwee A.

description: Food is delicious here. Especially the curry ramen. I'm sure it's delicious upstairs too, but I'm not waiting an hour for ramen. Order the noodles with a pour of sake. You'll be 100% pleased.
author: G T.

description:
There are a ton of ramen houses in Japantown and throughtout SF but Suzu is top notch!

For vegetarians/vegans, this place is perfect because they have broth options unlike many other noodle places in the city (usually only chicken). I like to order the miso ramen with kimchi and it is SO delish!

The parking is usually okay but can be a little tricky. It can get really crowded (the restaurant is rather small) but I've never waited more than 15 minutes for a table. Service is always awesome. Highly recommended!
author: Angela H.

description: Great place for noodles and soup. Vegetable tempura is also very good! Nice atmosphere too! Friendly staff and always make sure to seat you in a timely manner. A place I love to go with my mom!
author: Hannah E.

description:
Hopped into this place since it had a lot of reviews. There was a lot of open tables and I was seated immediately. 

I grabbed a miso ramen with pork belly and got an extra egg. 

The broth and the noodles itself were underwhelming however the add in's the Pork belly was very generous and flavorful. The egg was just average .

So for my   Broth/Noodles/Other ratings scale I gave it a 3/3/6. 

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay similar to lists I have for Boba.


Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod Ramen Rating = (Taste of Broth / Taste of Noodles/Taste of other stuff in soup) on a Scale of 1 to 10 (10/10/10) being the best score possible

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it. 

# 1 Marufuku Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 9/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *5 stars 
# 2 Mensho Tokyo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 3 Orenchi Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 4 Orenchi Beyond  *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 5 Ramen Parlor *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 6 Ramen Dojo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 7 Nojo Ramen Tavern *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/6/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 8 Yokohama Lekei Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/5/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 9 Ippudo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 10 Santa Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 11 Sobo Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 12 Ramen 101 *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 13 Ramen Shu *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/5/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 14 Suzu Noodle House *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 15 Slurp Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 16 Tadamasa *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/3 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars
author: Rod M.

description:
On a family vacation right now, and this was my first meal in San Francisco. I shared a potato croquette with my boyfriend and I ordered myself the spicy miso tsukemen.

Potato croquettee ($6)- as stated on the menu, it suppose to be creamy inside. Cripsy on the outside and more on a liquidy side inside.  Rating: 6/10

Tuskemen spicy miso ($12)- The bowl of ramen is served separately from the soup. You dipped the noodle into the soup and slurp it up. A pretty fun experience and kinda messy (kinda hard to pull the noodle out completely.) 
Rating: 7/10

The staffs were friendly, service was quick, you can sit inside or outside, and service charge is included on the bill. 

Overall experience- 6.5/10
author: Hillary N.

description:
Absolutely LOVE this restaurant! My kids & I drive up from Santa Cruz, CA on a regular basis just to eat at Suzu! If you love ramen...this place is a must!
It's fun location in the Japantown Center mall is a bonus. We always make a fun day out of it :)
author: jackie c.

description:
Whenever I come here, I think I actually spend more time browsing the wares at the bonsai store next door while waiting for a table than I do in the actual restaurant. But I don't blame Suzu for that -- it's a hole-in-the-wall with very limited seating and there's a bench next to the front door where customers can wait, which was very thoughtful.

But I just don't understand why people wait so long for Suzu when there are a plethora of ramen alternatives in the neighborhood. I will admit that I am a sucker for the suzu ramen, which comes with karaage (Japanese fried chicken), gyoza, and corn. Truthfully, when it boils down to it, I think the suzu ramen is just trying too hard because both the karaage/gyoza and the ramen would taste much better separately. The chicken and gyoza get a bit soggy in the broth and the broth suffers from the additional grease. The biggest drawback of the ramen here is definitely the broth -- everyone I come here with comments that it's a little too salty.

Suzu is the place for you if you want 2-in-1 ramen that combines your appetizer with your entree.
author: Amy C.

description:
Our party of 4 dined at Suzu for lunch last Saturday and it was...... okay.  It wasn't awful food, but I wouldn't call it the best.  
It simply satisfied our craving for ramen.... And also made my father-in-law happy since Suzu was his choice for an early Father's Day lunch.
To start, we ordered chicken karaage, gyoza, and mixed tempura.  We must have been starving because the four of us scarfed down those apps real quick!
As for our ramen, I ordered the Kakuni Ramen in the shio broth, my husband and MIL both ordered the Chasu Ramen in the shoyu broth, and my FIL ordered the Chicken katsu ramen in the shio broth.

Since I rarely leave my tri-valley bubble..... I was excitedly awaiting for this day to arrive because I have been badly craving ramen. 
Although I must admit that I was disappointed Suzu does not serve tonkatsu (pork broth), but that's neither here nor there at this point =)
I think my eyes briefly leaped out of my head when the kind server placed that big, steaming bowl of goodness right in front of me!  I quickly dipped my soup spoon in for a taste of the broth.... And...... it was all right.  
Obviously, the shio broth is much lighter than tonkatsu broth.... But I was, at the very least, expecting a bit of flavor.  The noodles were pretty good, and boy, I had plenty of noodles!  The pork belly in my ramen was tasty as well.

In short, Suzu provided a hunger satiating, but forgettable, bowl of ramen.  
The service is quick, the servers are friendly, and do note that Suzu is quite small therefore expect a wait during the busy lunch / dinner hour(s).
author: Marie W.

description:
The combo rice and ramen is awesome. ..reasonable price...tate authentic.

My ramen noodle is fresh made..the broth is very good.
author: Supawat J.

description:
Service is quick and portion size is adequate but it doesn't really matter when you don't even want to finish the meal. 

We ordered karaage and some pieces of the chicken were not fully cooked so they redid it. 

Dip ramen came with 2 pieces of karaage. Neither piece was fully cooked. The soup base seems to be watered down. 

For normal ramen the soft boiled egg was not cooked to perfection as can be discerned from the photos. Wasn't very tasty either.

Overall the quality of the ramen here is very low. Would not come again.
author: Tom P.

description:
I'm new to ramen and basically I had no idea what to order, the server actually helped me pick what to get, she was really patient and helpful. She recommended me to order spicy ramen with miso broth base, and it was awesome !!! I will come back. 

First time eating ramen soup and it was a success !!!!
author: Papus L.

description: 3.5 star. It's been almost 10 years since I've been here due to long line in the past but with all the new ramen places opening up, Line has gotten better. Their noodles are good and I like their broth but I'm more of a thick noodle pork tonkotsu fan. Still can't beat Dojo. I didn't like the cooked egg. I preferred soft/raw center. It's better if they put the fried chicken and potsticker on the side instead of in the soup making it soggy and soup oily.  Service is ok. 3.5 star.
author: Christy V.

description: Small cozy place to catch a quick Ramen before concert.  Food was fast and service good.  Ramen did not make my tastebuds jump; however, it was still satisfying on a winter's night.  Overall, if you want to eat and dash, this would be a good choice.
author: Lauren S.

description: I ordered the vegetarian ramen and the vegetables they used were really cheap. Egg plants, bean sprouts, tofu, cabbage, a couple tiny pieces of squash skin. Just because it's vegetarian it doesn't mean it has to resemble peasant food. They could've at least had mushrooms or corn or more unique ingredients. I added an egg to it; it was just a regular hard boiled egg with no extra flavor.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Sunday 130p. Not busy. Got the Miso ramen and it was honestly OK. The soup was pretty decent. It tasted pretty flavorful and not too oily. The only complaint I have is that they didn't use actually "ramen
" noodle.
For the price and convenience in location, this ramen is pretty good but honestly this place is definitely targeted to the eaters who are looking for comfort food of the Asian variety. I would recommend ramen foodies stay away as this place is not for you.
Overall, the ramen soup was good and thick and I enjoyed the dish. Decent sized serving as well.
author: Lin L.

description:
Location on the west side of the Japan town shopping center.

Order:
Shoyu ramen- okay, wasn't special. kinda blank in my opinion. I like mine to come with soft boiled egg and this one comes with hard boiled egg. The pork is not tender, it hard. 

Service, is fast but there is a service charge after 4 people in a group. Waitress has the i don't care attitude. 

Won't be coming back any time soon.
author: Sochietta K.

description:
Ramen slurping like Naruto! 

There might be a lot of other places in Japan town, but there isn't many that are open on Tuesday!   That means that if you want Japanese food in a Tuesday you need to find the short list.

This place is right inside Japan Center across the bridge on the first floor.  Basically smack across from the book store.

Totally delicious ramen.  We got two Suzu misos and promptly chowed down.  Egg, fried chicken, and just plain awesome.  We slurped until we couldn't slurp no more.
author: Ben H.

description:
I've been coming to Japan Town since I was a wee lad, and I've always seen this place as one of the most busy locations in Japan Town.  Even with that soaring popularity we never tried it out. Well that was rectified yesterday! 

You put your name on a list and hope for the best.  The wait wasn't that long, but depending on the list it can be a long wait, as this place isn't the largest.  Prices are fair, and if you love ramen/udon soup then this is the place for you in Japan Town. The sizes are huge and the quality is right up there with that of the soups of Tampopo.  Again, the place is really small so expect to bump into the tables next to you. 

Overall, it was  a great experience, and would probably try this place again at some point.
author: Benny H.

description: It's very busy here . Sometimes long wait sometimes very short it's depends on a day !!! Food was toot great.
author: Lili L.

description:
My parents and I had to swing by the area to pick up some Boba Guys for my sister's birthday boba bracket (it's exactly what it sounds like, guys. Think March Madness but with milk tea.) My mom was in the mood for something warm so I looked up ramen places close-by. Suzu Noodle House was the most affordable within walking distance (my daddy whines whenever we spend more than $10 per person), so we decided to give it a try.

Rating Breakdown:
0.5/2 Stars for Taste -- 
It was ramen. Nothing special. We tried both the miso and the shio ramen and the broths were just too salty. The egg was a disgrace. It wasn't molten in the middle, it was just half a hard boiled egg. The only saving grace was the noodles, which were perfectly chewy and delicious.

0.5/1 Stars for Value --
It was $10-12 per bowl, without any add-ons. I thought this would be a steal, but for the portion size (small, topping almost non-existent), you're really better off paying $2-3 extra and going somewhere else.

1/1 Stars for Customer Service --
We put our names down on the waitlist but were pretty much seated right away during lunchtime on a Friday. The waitresses were polite and efficient. We also overheard one very diplomatically tell the boyfriend at the next table that his card had been declined. D'OH. 

No bonus star because there are tons of better ramen places out there.
author: Abby W.

description:
I had such hopes for this place, a friend said it's real good. I was super famished so I was down. 

I had the curry ramen and the karaage don. He had the octopus. The karaage started off so well, the first two pieces were awesome. The third piece I had tasted raw so I immediately spit it out. The meat was pink which is unacceptable because eating raw chicken can fucking kill you. 

The ramen was fine but not great. The curry tasted super weird. Eating that curry ramen messed my stomach up. I couldn't stop pooping that day. 

I also ordered tea because you can't fuck up tea. The tea, the water was thick...slightly viscous. Tasted hella off like sink water. The waitress gave us sink water to drink. Disgusting!

My friend tried to wave down the waitress so he can have a bowl of rice. She ignored us repeatedly and when she finally looked in our direction she was like one minute. When she finally came over, he requested a bowl of rice, she looked like she didn't want to say yes. She was a terrible waitress.

First off, serving people nasty sink water is absolutely disgusting. Second, serving people raw chicken is unacceptable. Do health inspectors still exist? If they do, they need to come here.
author: Madison Z.

description:
With so many choices in Japantown, it was really hard to choose a place, but the wait was not too long and looking into the restaurant, all the food looked good. 

Miso Ramen:  Portion size was good, but that was pretty much it.  The broth was salty and the ingredients just didn't taste fresh.  Veggies were wilty and the pork was a bit dry. 

I love ramen and this place just didn't satisfy my ramen craving. I will not be back.
author: Foodie B.

description:
Food:

Chicken Karaage shio ramen - good flavor to the broth tho not super hearty like some other places.  I did enjoy this though.

Kakuni rice bowl - with the ramen you can get a combo and that's exactly what I did.  Not a bad way to fill you up some more for just a few more bucks.

Service: friendly waitstaff and attentive.

Ambiance: it's a small restaurant but not super claustrophobic.

Overall: I'd come again.  This is probably one of the two I'd come to if I'm in Japan town.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
Hum....mop bucket next to the miso soup and prep area?..ewe

No drinks or water offered during meal. Chicken was raw-ish. 

Waitresses didn't refill our glasses until the check came.

Things to watch out for : we noticed our check was rounded off to tax 8.6% instead of the 8.5%. Not cool and was taken out of the tip.
author: Rater 1.

description: There are a lot of noodle / ramen places in Japan center, but this place wins the most diverse menu. I got the tempura and soba, which I enjoyed. The soba wasn't the freshest thing I've eaten but it was decent, considering that most items are usually sitting in broth anyway.
author: David Y.

description:
TL;DR okay ramen, would recommend somewhere else.

I was very excited about the dipping ramen (tsukemen). Unfortunately, it ended being a big disappointment. The noodles came with a whole big thing of fried onion, sliced cucumbers, sliced something red (probably radish?), bamboo shoots, 2 pieces of fried chicken, and a half a hard boiled egg. The dipping sauce didn't look fat (+1), but was very under flavored and really watery. I was not a big fan of the fried onion, but the rest of the toppings were okay. The most important, but the most disappointing parts were the ramen and dipping broth/soup. The ramen noodles ended being all clumped together and I couldn't dip them into the dipping soup properly. The broth was so under flavored, I ended putting half a jar of chili flakes in the soup. In the very end, I just gave up and poured the broth in the ramen noodles. It didn't really feel like dipping ramen, but more like regular ramen that got separated from its broth.

Also tried the chicken curry ramen, it was ok.

The layout of the restaurant is ok, kinda cramped. What bothered me the most was the low lamp right above the table. They kept on getting in the way as I was trying to get my stuck-together noodles out of my bowl. But, maybe, just maybe, there's a reason for those low hanging lights that I am not aware of.
author: Sophia L.

description: Decent ramen. Not the best. But not the worst. Service was a little slow, but I would still return whwn in the area. It's worth visiting Suzu Noodle House at least once to form your own opinion.
author: Peter C.

description: I went here because Marufuku had a long line and Hinodeya was closed. Big mistake! I ordered just a simple chicken and veggie ramen as I was sick and craving some hearty broth. First the quality and taste was blah, second I only ordered that and I wasn't paying attention until later but I got charged $28! Also my receipt wasn't itemized. Lastly a couple hours later my stomach got upset and was like that until the morning. I suggest waiting in line for the good places or just going anywhere else. Disappointed.
author: Rosie K.

description:
I got the pork belly ramen. The meat was dry in the soup so I would suggest getting the pork belly over rice for 3.25 on the side. My friend got this and said it was very tender.

My other friend got karage curry. Curry tasted like it was from those instant curry package. He also mentioned the karage was too tough and wasnt crispy after they drizzled sauce all over it.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Food was good. Service was very good. The music from the kichen radio station was annoying. I didn't enjoy hearing "I'm in love witch yer boddyyy" blaring.
A very small restaurant in a small mall with miss-matched chair seat covers.
The food makes it a 3 star but it is not a 4 star!
author: L. Sam R.

description: Soba, Ramen, whatever- always good!! Food is quick and delicious. Portions are enormous so come hungry and leave happy.
author: Helen R.

description:
I wished I had read the poor food safety alert before walking into this restaurant. I went there on a Thursday afternoon at around 3pm, and only a few people are seated. Despite that, service was slow. I asked the waitress if the cold udon comes with dipping sauce and she hesitantly answered yes. Then when another waitress brought the order, it was cold soba. I informed the waitress that I ordered the cold udon, not cold soba, and she seemed confused and she went to ask the original waitress, and then realizing the mistake, I heard her said, "$hit." 
The right order finally came, and the quality is mediocre at best. This is not worth $10.
author: Michelle L.

description: First time here with my buddy and everything tasted great. I liked the presentation the food was served on too. We had the takoyaki and the croquettes as appetizers and I had the karaahage curry and I forgot what my friend had but it was the special ramen on the back of the menu.
author: Donte J.

description: It's about a 3.5 but 3 stars is more accurate than 4. Their miso and salad are solidly delicious. The portions are huge. I really liked their veggie tempura (crispy, fresh) that came with the curry. The chicken karrage curry was yummy but not memorable. The sauce is definitely made from the blocks at the grocery store (I use them all the time to make curry at home). All in all about a $13 meal. According to my cousin, it's consistent, so it has that going for it.
author: Deborah C.

description:
I was up in the Japantown area, and due to bad planning, the place we had wanted to go for lunch was closed that day. We ended up just looking on Yelp for someplace nearby, and Suzu had the most decent reviews.

Suzu is located on the bottom floor of the West Mall. It was pretty much empty when we arrived, but there really wasn't anyone actively there to greet us. We stood around for a bit before someone finally came to seat us. Although I think one of the staff was on his lunch break.

We ordered:
+Cha Shu Ramen ($11): i wasn't expecting much, and it wasn't amazing, but actually was a pretty solid Ramen. The broth was pleasant and not overly salty. They also gave a pretty generous portion of meat. My one complaint was that they pretty much just threw in a stalk of bokchoy (or some related veggie) that was uncooked and pretty gross.
+Tempura Udon ($12.95): pretty standard udon, nothing too special.
+Croquette Rice Bowl Add-On ($3.95?): I appreciated that they had super cheap add-one available, which makes it good for sharing. However I wouldn't get their croquettes. The insides somehow managed to be a watery consistency, and didn't have much flavor.

If you are planning to eat in Japantown, I would say Suzu Noodle is one of the better options available.
author: Helen W.

description:
So I'm visiting San Fran with my boyfriend, and he says "OMG, we have to get dumplings while we're here!"  Open up the Yelp app, see that all of the good dumpling places are further away and say "will you settle for ramen in J-town instead?"  That's like asking a kid if they want a present on their birthday...of course the answer is yes.

I searched for the best ramen place I could find, and Suzu was at the top of the list.  I didn't expect it to be in a mall, and I also didn't expect the restaurant to be as large as my first studio apartment in NYC.  Oh, and I also didn't except there to be a wait at 3pm on a Monday.  We put our name on a list and were seated within 30 min.

Yes, it was worth the wait.  We started with the dumplings, which were really good.  I also got the ramen in a simple sea salt broth and it was delicious.  EXCELLENT place to go for ramen!  My boyfriend, who a die-hard ramen fan, just couldn't stop eating, and then started eating my food once I was done.  I would say that's a sign of a good restaurant!
author: Jeannine S.

description: Excellent, some of the best Ramen I have had in my 14 years in the Bay. Cleanliness was not an issue, despite poorer ratings on yelp. Will be back!
author: Chris S.

description:
My millennial mindset gravitates towards hip-looking places... possibly because photogenic ramen in a minimalist backdrop makes a good Instagram. (My willingness to pay $$$ for pretty food pictures is my downfall.) I thus did not have high expectations for Suzu Noodle House, a cozy traditional-looking noodle shop in the Japantown mall plaza, but it turned out to be a very satisfying dinner. And despite my biases, the menu wasn't all too oldschool; there were interesting items such as tsukemen and pork belly ramen.

Even though it's called a noodle place, the highlight of our visit was the CURRY. The flavors were nuanced with a blend of spices, overlaying a richly umami base with a creamy consistency. It wasn't too salty and didn't taste out-of-the-box; from my Japanese curry memories I think this rivals Muracci's and surpasses Volcano. It's also clever that they serve it in this curved bowl, because it allows the curry to mix well with the rice while the kaarage and vegetable crisp are placed uphill and don't get soggy. 

The fried items were Japanese comfort food indulgence. The kaarage was meaty (though I still find Iza the juiciest), and the vegetable crisp was a novel spin on tempura (reminded me of Korean pajeon/vegetable pancakes).

The TSUKEMEN came with the same delicious kaarage and vegetable crisp, but unfortunately nothing much to rave about beyond that. I was most disappointed by the dipping ramen broth, which tasted essentially like miso soup--I want to give the benefit of the doubt and say they mixed it up, because I would be flipping tables if they gave me miso soup for ramen broth. The noodles were alright, al dente but clumpy and somewhat bland... which obviously was not rectified by the non-ramen-broth dipping soup.

Service is quite efficient, and the food came out in no time. The downside is that the food only seemed lukewarm, so be warned if you're picky about steamy hot bowls of noodle soup (which is generally highly preferable in SF weather).

It's a small space and you can expect to wait during peak hours, but it's not as crazy as the ramen scene can get (*cough cough* Mensho). The waitlist moves quickly, because people tend to sign in and walk around elsewhere, and if you're not present they go to the next party down the list. We came around 7pm on a Friday night, a time that would typically be formidable in SF, and we snagged a table in 5 minutes.

As most of their items are ~$11-12, the prices are very reasonable. The total after tax and tip came out to $15 per person. We had actually intended to just take a few bites and take the rest home for leftovers, so that we could check out Fat Angel afterwards. For better or for worse, we couldn't stop eating the yummy curry, kaarage, and noodles at Suzu and ended up finishing our plates P: P: P:
author: Edna C.

description: Such a big bowl of yumminess.  The noodles were perfect texture, al dente, chewy, so elastic.  Veggies were so fresh.  Got some seaweed, 2 pieces of hot crispy karagee, 2 pieces of tempura of Japanese squash,  cucumber, salad with sesame dressing, with side miso sauce.  Comes with tea or water.  They even have non-caffeinated tea at your request.  This place is super small. Kitchen as well.  I love the ramen! And such a big portion.
author: Helen L.

description: There's a reason why my family hasn't come here for half a decade. I ordered the curry ramen with miso base. The first sip of soup instantly made me confirm how lackluster the food was here. I remember coming here when I was 18-19 and the food used to shine back then. It's lacking something and I've eaten many times a long time ago, but the taste and smell always lingers on customers taste palate. I suspect there was a change of ownership in the restaurant. Overpriced for what it is and won't be back.
author: Wesley K.

description: This was my first time eating here and let me tell you the ramen was delicious. I got the tempura ramen with the shoyu sea salt broth. The portion size was just right and it filled me up. The service was very on top of everything and even helped recommend what to get. It's a very small place so if you go during lunch be prepared for a wait. I can't wait for my next visit because writing this review is making me hungry all over again.
author: David P.

description:
Service: 
All of the staff here is very polite and friendly. Always greet you with a smile and brings you water or tea as they seat you. 

Food: 
Best Karaage and Tempura! I usually get their Nabe Yaki Udon with tempura on the side. (be sure to tell them this if not your tempura will be placed in the soup =soggy tempura) Their curry dishes are also very good, but they give you a lot of curry sauce and rice but very little meat. 

CON:
There are no substitutions. If you don't like certain food, you can only remove them but can not add additional. Like I wanted to replace the Eggplant tempura with something else and the waitress said no, you can only remove no substituting. So pretty much, take it or leave it kind of situation.
author: Cyndi L.

description:
Yikes! I was in the area exploring Japantown when we passed this placed and thought: Hey! Ramen sounds like a good idea.

I was in a group of four. We got there around 3pm on a Sunday and were seated within 5 minutes. Customer service was okay from start to finish. Our orders were placed and our food arrived within 10 minutes. My friends ordered the miso ramen and I had the spicy one. It definitely looked appetizing so you can imagine my surprise when I sipped the broth and was extremely disappointed. I hate to say, but it was essentially flavorless. I was drinking hot, oily water :-( Shortly after that, our waiter came up to us and asked us to pay because they were closing in 30 minutes. Mind you, they were still seating people. I felt rushed and left very unsatisfied with my meal left on the table.

I won't be coming back.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Given the current state of the ramen scene in San Francisco, this place is not bad if you need to satisfy a ramen craving. That's just why I took my mom here on Sunday afternoon and boy was there a crowd of people waiting to eat here! 

There were a bunch of parties ahead of us but thankfully the wait wasn't that bad, maybe around 30 minutes? The menu is quite extensive, with tons of ramen options, and also options for soba, udon, nabeyaki, and rice bowls!

My mom got the miso ramen and I opted for the Hiyashi Soba (cold noodles with assorted tempura and toppings). We also added on an unagi don and kakuni don to make both noodles a combo meal.

The food came out pretty fast and all the food we ordered was solid. I didn't find any of the food too special. The miso ramen soup tasted a little dull and the pieces of meat they added looked sad. My soba noodles tasted fresh and light, but again, nothing special.

My unagi don didn't come with too much unagi and it seemed they overcompensated for that by drenching it in sauce. My mom really enjoyed the kakuni don (braised pork or something like that) so would recommend that. Both dons were pretty small but I think they're supposed to just be a small little taste to compliment the noodles.

I used to come here back in high school whenever I went to Japantown - it was the go-to ramen place! But I do think the quality has gone down since then. I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come back here, but it does offer solid options for ramen, udon, and soba. The wait also isn't that bad, especially when you can walk around Japantown while you wait!
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
-karaage is not crispy and tastes like old fried chicken that would be normally used for orange chicken
-soup was ok but didn't have much depth
-the combo dons give you a ton of rice that you don't need and five pieces of meat 
-just wait it out for marufuku upstairs
author: Derrick W.

description:
So originally I probably would have given a 3 star but you will see why I decided to choose 1...as that was the only lowest available. 

Got the:
- Takoyaki
- Suzu miso ramen


1. Takoyaki was ok. The red ginger provided was too salty spicy, personally would prefer the ones that have a bit more tart and sweet too. Also never saw it served with green onions [which looked really old and dry]

2. Suza ramen eh. Never had "ramen" with gyoza and karaage[maybe as a side dish but not inside]. It comes with bok choy, corn, chashu, half an egg, karaage, and gyoza. So the gyoza was too soggy and ...tbh didnt really taste the filling inside. Karaage I thought was not bad, probably cause the gyoza already setting the bar pretty low. Chashu was ok too. nothing amazing. The noodles, personally, I would not call it "ramen" reminds me of when you go to hong kong restaurants and you order the wonton noodle soup. It basically was like that but a SMINGE thicker/chewier. Also bokchoy is usually in hk style noodles not...ramen.. Broth was ok too. Again nothing amazing but was a decent place for my friends and I to hang out for a quick meal. 

SOoo you ask why the 1 star? well , let. me. tell. you. cringes hard* So the interiors to this place is super tiny and their cashier behind the counter allows you to see the dishwashing area but not kitchen. Didn't think much of it and while I was waiting for a REALLY long time for the cheque, I was just watching this guy sloppily apply soap to the dishes and then put them in this rack of some sort [to be moved later] . To my horror, after he applied the soap, he picked up the rack and what was resting under it, was raw meat [pork im assuming] . He put the rack away and proceeded to , again , sloppily rinse the soap and water off the meat. dude. that is effin disgusting and unhygienic. The older lady who finally gave me the cheque , stared at me as I was signing it and I told her what I just witnessed . I normally wouldn't say anything but srsly that is so gross . Idc if you cook or wash it again later...soap and raw meat...should not go in the same sink - TOGETHER. When I told the lady, she gave me the impression of "what" and "ok and?"


No thanks man. Not coming back. Thank god no stomach ache for me since last night, but I won't risk it again. It makes me question other places but still....
author: Eva L.

description:
After being told there was a 90 min wait at a different noodle house, up the stairs from Suzu, we were told that there was a 10 min wait at Suzu noodle house.
Maybe not the greatest in the city but the service was good, the wait short and the ramen? Pretty darn delicious. I recommend the Suzu Noodle House for a good experience all around.
author: Al C.

description: Tried Their Katsu Curry over rice .. the Serving is Huge.. rice is tempting to finish but no....my roommate has the ramen.. boy did he finish it all .. the price is reasonable for SF
author: Donovan L.

description:
Delish. We prefer the miso broth with pork. Lots of chewy delicious noodles, good broth and good price. You may have to wait, but they turn their seats 
UPDATE to one star for failed health score for vermin infestation. SO GROSS! Will never eat here again.
author: Nancy R.

description: Really the worst Ramen I had. The soup flavor is weird, the meet quality is bad. Don't recommend
author: Yaping W.

description:
I just happened to walk by this place and really wanted food, but I'm happy I stopped here because it was good. The service is great with positive attitudes, and they really are good about getting through their waitlist fairly. You have to be there though when they call you! 

My family all ordered ramen, and it was decent ramen. The noodles have a great texture and are pleasant to slurp with the broth. The Miso broth is decent, but nothing special. I personally just wish they put more meat as well. 

It may be called a noodle house but my favorite thing was actually the Chicken Katsu Curry. It's served in a curved bowl, and there's plenty of curry to accompany the rice and cutlet. The cutlet is drizzled with a sweet sauce that compliments the curry. I also love that the curry is thick but not too thick of a consistency, so it makes you want to keep eating it. 

Overall, this was not a mind-blowing place, but I was still satisfied with the food, the service, and the affordable pricing.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Been here a number of times now and I think it's time for a review. 

Their ramen and udon is above average. This last visit, we had tempura udon and Ebi fry curry. The portions were better than most eateries here in Japantown, which IMO tend to go by Japanese standards, which tends to be on the small side. 

Our food came out rather quickly and everything was cooked to perfection. The tempura was crispy and not greasy. The curry was good. The Ebi fry had Tonkatsu sauce on it, which I felt should have been left off and put on the side. The salad and miso soup was delicious, just wish that the miso soup had tofu in it. Although the place wasn't as busy as it is in the height of rush hour, I felt that the service lacked, which is why my review is one star shy!
author: Micki M.

description: Ramen is pretty uneventful. The unagi was good tho and the octopus was decent. The ramen just was very mass made and not flavorful other than miso
author: Phillip T.

description: By far the worst ramen I've had in sf. I gave this place a second try and I got disappointed again. I've had their miso and shoyu ramen. They literally give you ONE PIECE of chasu pork... so cheap... the shoyu broth was nasty... rip
author: Kathy D.

description: My husband and I were so hungry the day we went in, we ordered a Suzu ramen and  a cha Shu ramen and I thought everything was supposed to tasted good when you're hungry but that's not the story here.  They are both mediocre, so if you're looking to have good noodles or udon, go somewhere else.
author: Yisha z.

description:
The food is tasty. I ordered the 9 dollars base noodles with pork. But it only has one piece of pork, which is too little. 

Other than that, I should say the Flavor is good
author: Yu Z.

description: I was glad to find a vegetarian version of ramen with tofu and assorted veggies. It was good but nothing to go out of my way for.
author: Leslie K.

description:
It's one of my go-to restaurants in Japantown. Most of the time there was no wait, but sometimes it was crowded when I walked by. Bunch of options, I've tried their ramen and my favorite has been nebayaki udon. Ramen was average, all I remembered was lots of noodles that I couldn't finish. Nebayaki udon has mixed vegetables and choice of meat served in a pot, with shoyu or miso base. I liked the variety, and the beef was marinated and very flavorful. Udon quality varied, it could be chewy or soggy. Also tried a little of karaage curry, generous portion with tempura vegetables on the side - pretty unique.

Their croquette as appetizer was pretty different from what I'm used to, it was mostly creamy. Wish they had this note on the menu.

Will come back for their nebayaki udon on a cold or windy day, it's not easy to find!
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Visiting San Francisco, enjoyed the ramen noodles and the broth.

This is place has a very long line because its in the heart of Japantown in the Japanese mall, but of all the ramen places this is probably the best. 

It has some unique ramen topping options, like fried dumpling, sweet corn and things like that. the broth alone is fabulous, rich, savory and just yum!! I remembered that my broth wasn't too salty but my friend ordered Suzu ramen and thought it was quite salty afterwards, so just be prepared to walk around with water afterwards.

Noodles are bouncy and delicious, cooked just right. 
Have visited SF multiple times and have made an effort to come out here each time. 

I have other favorites in multiple states but this is probably still numero uno for now, until the next time at least :)
author: Bonnie P.

description:
Excellent ramen!  My husband, who is vegetarian, can get vegetarian ramen, and I often get that because it is fresh, crispy, and delicious.

The baby octopus are great - but be sure you have several to share.  We love the tempura - vegetable AND shrimp.

This is our favorite spot in Japantown.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
This place is definitely on my do not go back list. 

Catered to tourists with tourist prices for ramen I can make at home for far cheaper and far better. 

Noodle quality is okay. Chewy, no bite. Seemed to be they all have the same noodles in different broths (correct me if I'm wrong). I got the spicy tonkastu, which was all chili oil no depth in taste. 

Not worth it in my opinion. You're better off boiling a bag of shin ramen and throwing some corn and katsu in it, it's cheaper and probably tastes the same.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I stopped in here with my husband for an early dinner. It's a small place right inside Japan Center, in Japan Town, San Francisco. 

   The atmosphere is simple, but clean. It's dim lighted and relaxed. There is a few tables and chairs right outside the restaurant, out in Japan Center. We sat inside. Our service was good, very friendly and efficient. 

   I found my ramen to be quiet good. I ordered the Curry chicken ramen with the Shoyu broth base. I loved it, even took the remainder home, which I seldom take leftovers. The portion was quite large, presentation very simple. 

   My husband, order their new special, I do not recall the name. It was a ramen dish as well, but with a miso base. The both was served separate than the fixing; noodles, egg, etc. He had no complaints about his dish. 

  We ordered the tako-yaki, as an appetizer, which was fabulous. It was very good, it was visually just as pleasing. We also ordered the mixed tempura, which I have no complaints about. It was battered correctly.  

   I would give this place a 3.5 star rating.
author: Krista B.

description: Service was awful, they were rude and offensive. One of the dishes had an ingredient I was allergic to (which wasn't stated on the menu) and they wouldn't take the item off the bill!
author: Michael L.

description:
I'm not the world's biggest ramen fan, but the ramen here is delicious. I had the daikon salad, which was fresh, as well as their famous fried chicken ramen.

Considering the quality of the food, the prices are incredibly affordable. Both my salad and ramen came out at the same time (very quickly even during regular lunchtime), but my ramen was still the perfect temperature after my salad.

The ramen was phenomenal and was paired with friendly service. Very large portions will prove more than filling.
author: Elijah B.

description:
This spot in the heart of Japantown is incredibly busy. The restaurant is small, so when my party of 8 arrived around closing time on a Saturday evening, we had to both wait and split up into two groups in order to be seated.
Suzu has a wide variety of ramen, curry rice, and other Japanese foods to choose from, which is convenient if you dine with picky eaters since there will almost always be something for everyone! The prices here are definitely on the low side for SF,  and you get what you pay for. I ordered the Suzu Ramen, and having never encountered ramen with fried chicken and gyoza as toppings, I was excited to try it. They ended up tasting like they didn't quite belong-- things were a bit soggy and appeared to be thrown on as just an afterthought. The broth, one of the most important parts of the ramen for me, was just average as well.
I would recommend stopping by if you're on a budget and looking for a filling meal around Japantown, but don't let expectations get out of control.
author: Amy C.

description:
Came to this place for dinner on Friday night and there really much people here waiting. We put our name on the list and like about 5 mins we got called. One of the thing that bothered me a bit was that the waitress seem to be in such a hurry. She called our name but we didn't sit right outside, but by the fountain area which wasn't that far away. She called her name and I waved at her then she just ignored us and thought we left. We had someone at our party ran towards her to tell her we are here. Lucky we've made it in time. 

After being seated the waitress gave us the menu and walked away so we browsed. She came back after like 10 mins and got our order. She brought our appetizers that we ordered. If you notice we still haven't gotten water yet. We had to wave down the waitress to get some water served to us. After that there was no refills at all. Luckily I had some water in my backpack so I just drank that. 

We ordered edamame, baby squid and I had spicy ramen with added corn for $1 extra. You can never go wrong with edamame. So this was the typical ones that they reheat. The baby squid was deep fried and delicious, by the presentation was a bit off. My spicy noodles wasn't really spicy. The broth looks scarier than it should be. It is very yummy. The noodles wasn't your typical thick soggy ones. It was cooked perfectly and had this chew to it. 

All in all this place would have had a 5 star rating if the staff was a bit more better.
author: Drew R.

description: I expected the egg for ramen to be soft boiled eggs but all of my family's bowls had hard boiled eggs. Noodles were nice but i also expected more from the soup. I ordered Miso Ramen and it didnt have that traditional ramen taste, rather other flavor overpowered the miso taste and i had no taste of the miso soup itself.
author: Nathaniel N.

description:
I've returned to Suzu Noodle House a couple times since my last review, which I wrote almost six years ago. According to Joseph L, this place has changed owners, but I haven't noticed a difference. It doesn't seem like this restaurant has skipped a beat as it's been consistently busy the times I've visited or passed by walking around Japan Center. You still have to write your name on a waiting list outside. A server will call your party when an appropriate-sized table is ready.

As mentioned in my previous review, Suzu is located inside Miyako Mall at Japan Center in Japantown. It's just inside the Post St entrance near Webster St, on the ground level. The restaurant is small with seating for about 30 inside and about a half-dozen outside (in the mall) at three two-tops. I wouldn't come here with a group larger than 4 to 6 people. Even a party of 6 could be pushing it. Note there's an automatic 18% gratuity applied for parties of 5 or more. Reservations are not accepted.

Suzu offers 17 different types of ramen, priced at $9.50 to $12.95 per bowl, and 4 different types of soba and udon noodles, priced at $8.95 to $11.95 per bowl. In addition, they have $11.95 nabeyaki udon hot pots. Nabeyaki udon is served inside a hot pot with ingredients like vegetables, tofu, seaweed, and egg. Aside from noodles, you can also get Japanese appetizers like agedashi tofu and takoyaki (fried octopus balls), most for about $6 or less per plate; various rice bowls (don) added as a side for $3-5 per bowl; and $10.95 plates of Japanese curry. Beverage-wise, a limited selection of beer, wine, and sake are available.

Generally, this is a quick, casual, and reliable Japanese restaurant. The food isn't going to knock your socks off, but it's been good every time I've had it. I consider it comfort food. This is one of my sister's favorite places to eat in Japantown.

I noticed Suzu no longer has "Tokyo Ramen" on the menu, but it could've just been renamed. Two ramen have been marked off the menu. I tried the "Suzu Ramen" ($12.95, their most expensive ramen) on my last visit. It comes with two pieces of karaage (Japanese fried chicken) and gyoza (dumplings) plus corn, greens, chashu (braised pork), and half a boiled egg.

You can choose the broth on any of the ramen. They offer shoyu (soy sauce), miso, and shio (salt). They do not have tonkotsu. I had the shoyu broth with my Suzu ramen and the bowl was A-OK. The ingredients were fresh and the bowl was filling. It was far from the tastiest bowls of ramen I've had, but it wasn't bad either. The pieces of karaage and gyoza were nice and big. I'm not used to having pieces of karaage and gyoza floating around in my ramen soup and it worked out better than I expected. The outside of the karaage did get expectedly soggy though. Ultimately, I was satisfied.

Since my original review, I've also tried the tonkatsu don add-on ($3) and it was delicious. It's a small version of tonkatsu (Japanese fried pork cutlet) with tonkatsu sauce on top, laid atop a bed of white rice inside a bowl. The tonkatsu was delectably crispy. It's kind of like schnitzel. The tonkatsu sauce is similar to Worcestershire sauce. Too bad they don't have a full-sized tonkatsu entree. I bet it'd be good.

My sister really likes the udon noodles served soba-style, meaning cold and with the dipping sauce on the side. The thick noodles are served on a plate topped with shredded seaweed with a tiny clump of wasabi. She's been getting this dish for years. You can get udon or soba noodles served hot or cold and with sides like tempura.

Service is speedy. Orders come out from the kitchen in a reasonable amount of time and waiting for a table still doesn't take more than 10 to 15 minutes. Restrooms are located around the corner, across from the toy store (Japantown Collectibles).
author: Daniel B.

description:
Place is tiny and service is fast. The ramen bowls are bigger than what the food actually holds but it is still plenty of food. The food came out so fast that it made me question the quality of the pork? Nonetheless, the pork tasted fine and it was tender.
