The broth wasn't as salty as Ramen Parlor or other ramen spots which was a bonus. But it also was bare minimum in regards to toppings compared to other ramen places. No seaweed, 2 baby bok choys, 3 pieces of pork, no bean sprouts (had to ask for on the side). 

I wouldn't mind coming here again for a quick bite to eat, but it wouldn't be a suggestion of mine if someone were to ask.
author: Jenna T.

description: I've been to many ramen places, and this by far was one of my favorites. I ordered the miso ramen and a side of Katsura don. The noodles were firm not soggy, and the broth was quite nice. However, it was a little salty in my opinion. Overall, this was a really nice ramen place in SF and would definitely come here again. Four stars.
author: Dylan L.

description:
I've been to Suzu several times and it's pretty consistently decent. Nothing stands out as being particularly delicious but it's not bad, either. The portions are large and the prices as fair. My favorite thing is the Suzu ramen with shoyu. 

I've definitely had better broth and noodles, but this place is quick and pretty cheap.
author: Vanessa D.

description: Who care Marufuku on upper floor, i dont. For me this place is better. Thier sea salt is the best
author: Akibarangers S.

description:
TL;DR: slightly disappointing ramen, underwhelming broth, good service, small space

Suzu Noodle House is a well-known and popular ramen spot in Japantown, but lacks the wow factor of a quality ramen establishment. The vibe and look of the restaurant adds to the feeling of Japantown, but I would research other options in the area for dining.

I came here with a group of friends on a Friday for lunch. There was a bit of a wait, but luckily, there's a lot of shops to check out around. I think one of the biggest problems this restaurant has is the space constraint. I felt very cramped during our meal. The service at this place is really great. The servers were attentive and cared about how our meal was going. All of our dishes came out at relatively similar times and really quickly.

I ordered the Chasu Ramen with Shoyu flavoring. My bowl wasn't all that special. I didn't find much presentation value out of it, even though that's not what I came for. My meal as a whole wasn't anything to write home about; it was just typical ramen. I was hoping for something phenomenal or more authentic. The chasu was flavored well and the noodles were plentiful. I feel that the broth was a little lacking in flavor or impact on the dish. I added chili powder to the broth, but I didn't feel it made that much impact. I would say I was a little disappointed with my meal, but it's worth a shot if you're looking for ramen in Japantown.

I feel as if I'm reviewing very negatively for a business that is well-known in the area. Take my opinion with a grain of salt, as ramen isn't exactly my area of expertise. I'm not sure if I'll be coming back to Suzu in the future. I hope this opinion helps your foodie adventures out.
author: Calvin T.

description: This is our go to ramen house. It never disappoints. Their stock and noodles are consistent and the flavors are tasty. I had the Karage Ramen w miso base and the chicken was piping hot!  My husband had the curry chicken ramen w shoyu base.
author: Lena L.

description:
I should have known after reading a previous review about someone commenting on the ramen barely having anything in it besides a ton of noodles!!! Literally, ONE THIN SLICE OF MEAT, TWO TINY BOK CHOY LEAVES (not even the whole bok choy for goodness sake), half a boiled egg, dried seaweed wrap and few bamboo shoots. So I guess if you order the cheapest ramen on their menu (shoyu, Shio, or Miso) this is what to expect. You've been warned!

Maybe if we would have ordered the other more expensive ramen, then it would have came with more protein. Still, this left me more annoyed and disappointed that I'd probably won't give this place another try.
author: Roxie T.

description:
After walking around all day doing tourist things with friends from out of town, we found this little gem and decided to give it a try. We were seated promptly with our group of 6, ordered and within 10 minutes, our food came out. 

I ordered the spicy miso ramen. It was super red in color so I actually was scared it was going to be too spicy. After tasting the broth, it was perfect! The noodles were perfectly cooked, the broth was super flavorful and not too oily like other ramen places I have tried.  I would have given it a full five stars except they only give you one tiny piece of pork, half of a hard boiled egg, one piece of bok choy, and barely any bamboo. Other than that, there were plenty of noodles and plenty of broth to fill anyone up. 

Left super full and content. As I'm sitting here writing the review, my mouth starts to water craving some more! Service was great too, super friendly and super fast. It is a smaller restaurant and can feel a bit tight in space but that didn't bother us.
author: an l.

description: By far one of my favorite places to get soba or ramen!
author: Anny B.

description:
The ramen here isn't going to blow you away or anything but it will hit the spot if you're craving it. I thought the broth was mediocre but the noodles were a perfect texture and the toppings were tasty. The service was friendly and quick and the place was surprisingly crowded during an off hour.

I got the shoyu ramen ($10) which came with pork, boiled egg, green onion, seaweed and bamboo. It's served in a huge bowl so prepare to come here with an appetite. My boyfriend got the suzu ramen with miso broth ($13). It came with chicken, gyoza, corn and the same toppings as mine. I wasn't a fan of the gyozas but the chicken was pretty good.
author: Linda X.

description:
Mmmm I really wish I could rate place by .5 increments, this place is a 3.5 in my opinion, however if I had to choose i guess it'd be closer to a 4.  Anyhow the place itself is in the mall and fairly small, when We went there was no wait so that's a plus.

We sat down and ordered a pork belly shoyu ramen and also a pork belly side combo, I know pork belly galore! The main reason why I'm giving this place 4 stars is the ramen portions, I truly believe 1 of their ramen feeds two people.  Now the ramen itself was good, however not spectacular, the things that stood out the most for me was the broth, noodles were a bit too thin.

All in all this place is not bad if you're not looking for the finest ramen in town but you just want to satisfy your ramen craving.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: Man, i was in a hurry and didn't read the reviews.. saw a 3.5 star rating on Yelp and thought it would be okay... boy, should I have clicked into the reviews... service was quick but this is probably one of the worst Ramen I had in a long time. Cha shui was like beef jerky, soy soup base was like water. To add insult to injury, clicked into Yelp review after the meal and noticed YELP actually warning its readers that this store got a bottom 5% on Health/Food inspection. Too a peek into the kitchen and wish I never went into the store.
author: Christopher S.

description: Ok. Truly truly, Japan towns food hasn't been known to impress already. However, this place was packed every time I swing by I thought for sure they are decent. Nope. Wrong. Their udon has no bite whatsoever. I'd thought they got the package from supermarket and MESSED IT UP! Save yourselves and go anywhere else with lesser wait.
author: Joy F.

description: Where do I start? Gyoza is under cooked (nuked) and when bitten into it a weird taste and smell comes out. Tonkatsu isn't crunchy at all which means it was precooked and just nuked warm for customers. The cooks must be chillaxing way too much if it's gotten such a bad score from the health department on top of not properly preparing food. They should rename this place to Nuke Noodle House as nothing tastes like it's cooked fresh on the spot. Good luck stomaching the gross stuff they try to pass for Japanese food here.
author: Ken K.

description: Found the best authentic Japanese restaurant in Japantown. We came at the right time! No line, dinner was fast which was perfect since we were starving. The miso base soup for my tsukemen was exceptional! Service was great!
author: Angie L.

description:
i love the ramen here! i get the shoyu broth with the japanese fried chicken and the chili to make it spicy! came here for a friends birthday and the wait was pretty long, but worth it. i mean folks wait longer for olive garden with no complaints, so... 
10/10 would recommend
author: Arianna A.

description: It's okay! If you're hungry and want some ramen, I wouldn't turn it down but it's not great by any means. Also the gyoza is made poorly and is mediocre. A little too pricey for the lack of quality but it's not bad!
author: Kyle D.

description:
All these years I've been going to Japantown and never tried this place. So I bring some soup lovers on a weekday so it wasn't busy when I came in. I don't really like going to a restaurant and having my entree be a soup but I changed it up and ordered some Tempura Udon. I seen a lot of complaints of how long it takes to get food here but it was fast for me. A good soup starts with the broth and I thought it was a little off. I didn't really want to eat/drink the broth. The noodles were good, but its hard to mess up udon noodles, but on the other hand the Tempura shrimp and veggies were delicious. So know I'm thinking to myself I shoulda just ordered Tempura by itself. But the pictures of the soup tricked me! My company ordered ramen, 2 ordered spicy ramen which wasn't spicy at all, 1 ordered a pork belly ramen and all 4 soups underwhelmed us. 

Maybe the buzz here is the prices on the food? I mean you can get a small rice bowl on the side for 3 bucks with a soup. You can sucker me with that offer.
author: Arron E.

description:
For the longest time I thought there wasn't any good ramen shops in San Francisco. That was until this month where I happened to hit two different ramen shops that I enjoyed, and this place happened to be one of them. I came here on a Saturday night and for a table of 3, I didn't wait longer than 20 mins for a table. 

Overall, I would rate the ramen itself a firm 4 stars. The bowls were huge, and the broth was good with the help of the spicy sauce. Only complaint I have is the chashu, where were incredibly lean and dry tasting. I ordered the spicy ramen and I was a little hesitant, because based on many reviews they mentioned that it was incredibly spicy. It only come in one spicy level, but I was able to get the spicy sauce onto the side and just add it into my broth to my taste. And boy, am I glad that I did that. I was given two different kinds of spicy sauce and I added less than 1/4 to my bowl and it was spicyy! To give you an idea, I usually order medium spicy everywhere I go. Additionally, my parents ordered a side of unagi don, and they said it was one of the best unagi don they ever had. 

Thanks Suzu for a good service, and a good meal that was able to meet my parents expectations and kept them from complaining.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Have you ever wondered what ramen the instant ramen was modeled after? Well this is it... or at least it taste like it.

The spicy ramen was $11 for a bowl of ramen with half of a HARDboiled egg, a white bakchoy LEAFLET, a SINGLE tiny slice of pork, and some instant ramen grade spices. What the hell did I just pay for?!! 

The croquette was super liquidy on the inside. Didn't have the texture of potato at all. They either overcooked the potato or overwhipped it, or both. The gyoza was too salty and they look like it was pan fried on both sides to cover up the fact that the wrappers were poorly folded. 

I suppose the only redeeming point is that at least the noodles weren't overcooked some of the times. :/
author: Tiffany G.

description: This place is good. More affordable for ramen. Rather than expensive prices. I like this place because they have quick service, broth is not too salty, they're very clean. They do not have restrooms, you have to use the ones outside in the mall which is a quick 1 minute walk to the left when you come outside. They usually have a shorter line than ramen Yamadaya down the street. Pretty good place for a small joint. It's on a corner and they also have outside seating which is basically inside the mall rather than inside their restaurant. Pretty good place to go if you're in the mall.
author: Derek P.

description: We figured you can't go wrong with ramen in Japantown! We were right. Fantastic flavours in the noodles, the soup, gyoza, kaarage and vegetables. Definite must-do if you're a ramen lover and visiting San Francisco!
author: Tony D.

description:
Rating: 2.5 (Closer to 2 though)

We were at Japantown and decided to try this place since we've pretty much tried every other place at J-town. First of all, there was a waitlist with a few people ahead of us. We were seated in about 10 minutes. We ordered spicy ramen, nabeyaki (udon noodles with tempura), fried baby tako (octopus), and unagi don. The spicy ramen was oily, nabeyaki noodles were ok but not the best, the octopus was way too greasy, and the unagi don's rice was undercooked. I would not recommend this place.
author: Jade C.

description:
I had the Suzu ramen which was good. I like my ramen noodles a little chewy so theirs were a little soft for me. The servings here are generous so I'm pretty sure you won't leave hungry ...  also the prices are reasonable.  

My wife had the vegetable ramen which was huge and she said that the taste was very good.
author: Edward M.

description:
Customer service was great:) the lady who worked there was really friendly and flexible with my request.
For food tho, I think they are just okay. It's not bad. You can get decent food but from Japanese perspective it's not the best.
But my friends (non Japanese) liked the food ;)
author: Katie T.

description: There aren't too many places in J-town I rave about, and this was about the same - had a good curry, but nothing stand-out. Generous portion of chicken; same with rice. Friends seemed to like ramen and various udon dishes. Perfectly satisfactory, but wouldn't go out of my way to return.
author: Shendi X.

description: Normally I'd give it a 4 star review but the broth is off and the service is terrible today
author: Andrew K.

description:
My boyfriend and I came to Japantown just kinda winging where we go, and I thought this place would be worth a try after looking at the amount of reviews it has. We got to Suzu Noodle House at about 11:30 pm and we were the second ones to sign up on the list. We sat near the stairs (that were directly in front of the restaurant) since the bench next to the restaurant entrance was full, but as we waited for our name to be called we noticed more people signing up and other people going in. I looked at the list and noticed my name was crossed off and they went through about 5 other groups that had signed up before me. I told the waitress who called the names and all she did was circle our name back. When she did call our name she said to us in the quietest voice ever, "Next time you should sit closer." Seriously? That was rude of her especially considering she didn't even apologize for skipping us. And it's no wonder we couldn't hear her because you could barely hear her from 1 foot away.
We ordered the ebi tempura ramen with miso broth, the cha shu ramen with shoyu ramen, and takoyaki as an appetizer. Service got bad and weird again when we got our food. First, they gave my boyfriend his order, waited a minute or so until the same waitress from earlier brought me what I thought was mine. Turns out she was about to give me a different table's ramen. On top of that they brought out our takoyaki (the appetizer I might add) last. The takoyaki was pretty decent considering it was my first time having it. The octopus inside wasn't overcooked or anything and it was nice and soft inside. The ebi ramen consisted of ebi tempura, one large piece of bok choy (just a leaf not even a whole bok choy), a few pieces of bamboo shoot, half an egg, and green onions. I expected the tempura to be soggy since it was in the broth but it was still pretty flavorful and the shrimp was cooked well. My boyfriend's cha shu also consisted of the same ingredients besides the meat substance. The cha shu was actually pretty soft but there wasn't enough flavoring in the meat. The ramen noodles in both of our orders could have been cooked a little more as it was a little too al dente to me. 
Overall, Suzu is alright. I've gone to cheaper places and ordered more "colorful" bowl of ramen where they included fish cakes and more than one vegetable. The lines get long here but the hype is kind over overrated considering the bad service I received and the mediocre-ness of the food.
author: Emily T.

description: I came here cause I was desperately hungry and left completely dissatisfied. First off service is decent. I ordered their chashu ramen and it was pretty bad. The noodles looked and tasted like Chinese noodles. The chashu was very tough and chewy and I did not understand the piece of half cooked bok choy thrown in there. This is by far my least fav. ramen place. I gave them three stars because their service was nice, but probably not coming back.
author: Sui N.

description:
TLDR: Not too bad for ramen in the jtown mall. I would return and order the tempura don again, crispy deliciousness. Very filling and the combo deal for a mini don is great. Cute little place at the edge of the mall.

Proportion of the ramen is much higher than toppings. I ordered the Suzu ramen combo + a mini tempura don. The Suzu ramen consists of corn, karaage, two gyoza, and 2 slices of chashu pork. I thought the gyoza smelled/tasted funny. Could not finish the ramen because there was so much of it but quickly had no more toppings. I also tried my friend's curry don, which tasted alright. The tempura is the reason why I would return. Maybe I was super hungry but loved it. Thought it was the perfect amount of flavor and crispiness.

Didn't have any complaints about service, as I'm seeing from the other reviewers below. The food came out quick and the restaurant was relatively crowded on a Wednesday afternoon.
author: Christina G.

description:
I had the shoyu ramen. Very ordinary and tasted like the $0.99 instant noodle. They also gave me ONE piece of old bok choy which was very odd. 

The chicken curry don is soaked with curry sauce. I felt like I was drinking a bowl of curry soup. 

The worst part about this restaurant is all their servers wear plastic gloves when they served you dishes! I understand the intention but it's actually not hygienic at all because the germs would just stay on the gloves. Not to mention how unappetizing it is!
author: Kelvin Y.

description: Ordered the Suzu Ramen which comes with a generous portion of ramen, char su pork, half an egg, 2 fried gyozas, and chicken karaage. The chicken and gyoza got soggy after 10 minutes, but we're good. The ramen was perfectly cooked al dente so it had a firm bite to it. I had the soy broth, which was also good. Overall, a nice bowl of ramen with excellent portions.
author: Barnaby W.

description: The portions are really big and I couldn't finish my bowl of ramen. The price is worth the amount you get. I got the veggie tempura ramen. It was really good but I recommend you ask for the tempura on the side. It is more of a veggie fritter than anything and is about the size of a hand. As I was eating it, it got soggy because it was sitting in the soup. The only thing that's small there the don you can get as part of a ramen combo.
author: Lexis W.

description:
Lots of people inside so thought I'd give this place a try. Nothing special and the time spent was way too long for just one bowl of soup. 

Made the mistake of asking to exchange a $1 for 4 quarters while paying the bill so I could feed the meter outside. One server was nice enough to step in when my original request was quickly denied with a simple no. Nothing else, just no. 

I now know why the line for ramen upstairs is so long.
author: Jim C.

description: Portions are large and chicken katsu curry tasted pretty good. But it was unbelievably hard to get a server's attention to pay our bill. More importantly, there was a cockroach crawling up the wall right next to our table and heads. Disgusting. Clean your restaurant!
author: Ian B.

description: Small hole in the wall in the middle of Japantown.  The soup bases tasted so good.  The corn addition to my ramen made the soup base unique. Ambiance was quaint and one of the waitresses were really nice and another didn't smile at all.  But overall service was good.  We ordered the braised pork belly ramen and the yuzu special.  The pork melts in your mouth and flavorful.  Must try!
author: Tania T.

description: This place used to be so good, but now it's just ok. They don't serve any tonkotsu ramen only shio, shoyu, and miso. The toppings are really limited now compared to before. They would give more and didn't have bok choy in it. The service is good, the waitresses are really fast and efficient especially when it gets packed for lunch and dinner. I wouldn't really go out of my way to dine here only if I'm in Jtown and it's the only thing open because usually ramen places close around 2-3 and reopen at 5 or so.
author: Korina D.

description: Does this look appetizing? The waitress is highly disrespectful and rude as she questions your choice to remove green onions (which they didn't even do). I'm quite disappointed as I received a watery, soggy, and one piece-meat filled ramen. The ramen itself is not terrible, but the waitress' attitude is horrendous. It seems that this place only received good reviews because of tourists. Do not recommend, never coming back.
author: Matt C.

description:
I walked by this place a few times and noticed it was always busy. It wasn't busy today so I thought I'd give it a shot. 

I ordered the mini chicken katsu rice bowl and the pork belly ramen. The rice bowl came out first so I started eating it. It was not good. You can tell they do not specialize in this dish. Next the ramen came out. I tasted the noodle and the pork belly and they were not good either. I didn't finish my food. I think I ate like 30% of it. And I am a guy who normally eats a lot of food. 

Basically the restaurant seems like it was opened by someone who had ramen and then went home to try to replicate it by guessing the ingredients and the cooking method. Like they were like "ok there are noodles, I'll goto Safeway and find ramen noodles. And ramen soup is made of soy so I'll pick up soy sauce and pour it into boiling water. There is also an egg so I'll hard boil an egg and throw it in." You get my point. It tasted really improvised. 

I don't think I will ever come back to this place.
author: Scott T.

description:
I came here on a Friday at around 7:30pm with a group of guy friends since we were in Japantown and wanted to give this place a try. 

The wait was super long (about 45mins). The server had us write our name on a clipboard and she called us in when we were ready to be seated. 

I decided to order the Suzu House Ramen and Unagi Don on the side. Our food came in about 15 minutes, which isn't bad considering that our group consisted of 5 people. My ramen was pretty good but I wasn't too crazy about it. Same goes with the Unagi Don. I guess I just had really high expectations for this place, especially after seeing how packed and busy it was. I tried my friends Kimchi Ramen and curry dish and they were both really good. I think I'll order either of those if I ever come back.

Anyways, 4-stars for this place because the food wasn't mind blowing and the service was okay.
author: Pariya N.

description:
It pains me to give this review as the waitresses are nice, patient when explaining the menu and fairly attentive. But the ramen is NOT GOOD.  We originally came to Japantown to try out another popular ramen place upstairs, but due to the crazy lines and our hangry state, we decided to look elsewhere and Suzu looked decent (from an initial glance at the Yelp reviews).  While the servings are pretty generous, they leave a lot to be desired in the taste department.

Down to the actual food:
- Chicken Karaage (3 stars): 5 bulky pieces of chicken that I was not entirely sure whether they were cooked long enough (would have preferred them much smaller) and the side salad was drenched in dressing.  A lemon slice on side would have been nice.
- Gyoza (2 stars): 4 pieces of super bland, oily, misshapen gyoza and weak dipping sauce.  Very likely that these were previously frozen.
- Ramen (miso): I'm a huge ramen aficionado, so I have fairly high standards.  The way I think of it, I'm downing something pretty unhealthy so I might as well really enjoy it!
-- broth (1 star): wow where to start. the broth was super duper oily and lacked any sort of flavor. I barely sipped any of it, and even the spicy sauce on the side didn't help.  You could look at the bowl from the top and see a thin layer of oil across the top.
-- pork belly (4 stars): the saving grace of this ramen place.  Unlike other places where pork belly is thinly sliced, this place had huge chunks of pork belly which actually really hit the spot.
-- noodles (3 stars): your standard ramen noodles, pretty chewy but nothing to write home about
-- toppings (2 stars) - comes with half of a hard-boiled egg, and that's it, all other toppings cost extra, whereas I'm used to other ramen places throwing in a sheet of nori or some sliced bamboo.  I ordered a shrimp tempura on the side which tasted like it was fried while frozen (soggy meat inside). 

I think this place tries to provide variety in noodles (hence the name) by offering soba, udon, and ramen, but doesn't really excel at any of those.
author: Mengo Z.

description:
One of the best places in Japan Town for ramen. I am a vegetarian but still a big fan of ramen and am always on the lookout for good ramen places especially in the chilly SF winters. I stumbled upon this place one day before a movie at the neighboring Kabuki. We didn't make a reservation but still got seated immediately and the food came out pretty quickly too. I like my food on the spicy side and they made it exactly to my taste.
The ramen bowl was huge and yet very flavorful.
Definitely a returning customer!
author: Charu G.

description:
Walking around Japantown and after walking through a bazillion cool little shops, we were getting hungry. There were a plenty food options, but we wanted something close and this place was right in front of us.

It's a small little place with a couple of tables inside and 3 tables outside. They have plenty of different ramen flavors and appetizers.

I ordered the Miso Ramen (came with literally 1 slice of chashu) and it was alright. The hours to follow my meal - I needed water!! I was super thirsty... 

We also ordered Gyoza as an appetizer. Uhhh... no. Seriously? It was all OILY! First of all, server came by with the plate of gyoza and that was it. She didn't bring any plates or anything else with her. "Sure, we'll eat off our little napkins here while the three of us eat this gyoza." I placed the gyoza on my napkin and tried to soak up the oil that was glistening on the outside. My napkin was half soaked with oil by the time I was done and the gyoza wasn't even good. I also couldn't use my napkin anymore.

End of story.
author: Wing L.

description: I wouldn't say I'm a ramen snob, but I know a good bowl of ramen when I see one! Unfortunately Suzu's ramen didn't quite live up to my expectations. I had a chasu shoyu ramen and although it did the job of satisfying my grumbling tummy, it left my tastebuds a little disappointed. I felt the ramen wasn't "authentic". When I say authentic, I mean that the broth has been brewing for 2 days and you just get this sense of richness with depths of flavor. Also, the toppings were nothing but a few pieces of baby bak choi, bamboo shoots, and an almost hard boiled egg. I feel like an authentic ramen shop would at least pay attention to the egg, to make sure they cook it soft boiled! The soft boiled egg is the best part! In all, the place was just OK. I would probably venture to other locations if I want a true bowl of ramen.
author: Amanda T.

description:
Whenever I pass by Suzu, there are lines out the door. I decided to finally try their noodles and came with high expectations.

I went at noon on a Saturday and was quickly seated in the outside seating area. 

My friend and I both ordered the Suzu ramen. I opted for the miso broth and the portion was quite big!

It came with 2 pieces of karaage, 2 pieces of tough to chew pork, a fried wonton, some corn and bamboo and 1 very small piece of vegetable. ~ $13

The flavor of the broth was average, but I liked the texture of the noodles.
author: Jasper L.

description:
My boyfriend and I are from LA so I'd say we're a bit picky when it comes to ramen, but hands down this was probably the worst ramen we've ever tasted.

Leathery-tasting chashu in a ramen with bland flavor and soft noodles... very disappointing.  I took a few bites and couldn't eat another.  Waitress seemed to know the food wasn't good and just smiled when we said we weren't that hungry.  We also ordered the gyoza (very large and extremely wet), and a 2$ ripoff of extra ONE piece of fried shrimp.

Honestly, we can't wait to get back to LA for good ramen.
author: Mary W.

description:
This is my all time favorite ramen place. Every time I go there, it is always a long wait. But since there are plenty of stores in Japan town that we can just hang out while waiting and after eating, it never feels so bad. 

I have been there for like 6 times now and I keep bringing my friends back. The service is very good. The prices are not cheap but the food is worth it. The snacks are more like so-so to me even if some of my friends say they are authentic. I love their ramen the most! All the flavors are super good! So just try out different flavors!
author: Stella D.

description:
My bf eats ramen here so we came for an order of Miso ramen. Since I'm not a big fan of ramen, i was prepared to order gyoza as my meal since ramen places usually don't serve much more than ramen. 

I was happy to know there was a variety of rice bowls here, and even happier to know that with your ramen or noodles, you could order an extra rice bowl with some meat for just $3.50! Ok, for most people that bowl of rice wouldn't be enough for a full meal, but I happen to eat less than the average American so it was perfect size with me,plus my bf shared a couple spoons of his ramen.

The rice bowl I got was the kakunidon, a bowl of rice with 2 big pieces of wuhuarou (the fatty pork belly, quite common in Chinese cuisine, i didnt know Japanese also ate it), some ginger, green onion and mustard. It was really delicious! Smelled sweet, since the sauce you usually cook this meat in has both soy sauce (salty) and brown sugar (sweet) and it was also very tender. I just wished there was more meat because I tend to avoid the fattier parts of that cut and then end up with too little meat.

The ramen was also good, my bf loved it because the broth was thick and rich. It comes with pork, green onions, bamboo shots and a boiled egg. He got extra noodles for +$2 and then couldn't finish it. Noodles were soft but firm, tasty as well. 

Service was attentive, the server brought a small bowl with the ramen because she supposed we were sharing it.

The bill came for $16.50 plus tip, pretty decent for SF. The only reason it's not a 5 star is - unfairly - that we still prefer the food in Japan x) 

Will come again if we're in SF and craving for ramen~
author: Mimi Y.

description: I'm quite a ramen snob and personally I think this place was awful. I was very surprised how this place got 3.5 stars on Yelp and had a lot of people waiting in line. It was my first time that I didn't finish my ramen. We ordered the tsukemen and shoyu ramen. The broth of tsukemen tasted like hot water with shoyu and vinegar, while that of the shoyu ramen tasted just like hot water mixed with soy sauce. The noodles were hard, pork slices were hard as well as tasteless, the bamboo shoots smelled weird, and worst of all: THE EGG WAS HARDBOILED. NO GOOD RAMEN PLACE SERVES HARDBOILED EGGS! Even the price wasn't bad for bay area standard I was still very disappointed. The service was quite unfriendly and slow as well. Don't come here if you want a good, authentic ramen experience.
author: Pitch M.

description:
We came to Japan Town for the Cherry Blossom Festival and the food here is so much better than what's offered in the festival. 

Husband was very happy with his bowl of vegetarian ramen. For vegetarians, there is only one choice of vegetarian main. But a few usual appetizers and side dishes to choose from. 

I could add on a small don to his entree and my pork belly don was so yummy! Well worth the $3.25 price! Shared a croquette and it was creamy and yummy.
author: Jen L.

description:
The ramen was delicious and I'm really happy they had a vegetarian option so I was able to eat here. One negative- all options with meat came with certain "standard" toppings included but the vegetarian one did not include these toppings and would be charged $1 extra to add any of them, yet the price of the vegetarian option was more expensive than the meat option. This was a little backwards to me. Service was great though and my waitress was very nice! 

Overall, I would come here again if I was in the area and didn't want to search for a new spot, but I would prefer to find another spot in the area that offers more for your money in their vegetarian options.
author: Shav S.

description:
Very satisfied with this restaurant!

What I like about this restaurant was that it had a waiting list outside so you could see yourself from the queue. My friend and I waited about 10 minutes until we were called.

The restaurant was small and quaint. Maximum capacity would probably be between 20-30.

I ordered the spicy ramen and received it quickly! About 5 minutes waiting time. When I tried my ramen, I was expecting the "spicy" part to be mild but hell no, it was spicy and I loved it.

Would definitely love to come back here again!
author: Aj C.

description:
This is my first time leaving a review, and I wish it was because I enjoyed the place. But frankly, my friend and I had such a poor experience I just want to warn other people not to spend their money, or at least be careful before doing so.

My friend and I both ordered shoyu ramen, karaage, and gyoza. But before even touching on the food, I just want to say that we put our names down but they seated two other people before us regardless. Then when we were seated it took at least fifteen minutes for them to even speak with us. The two people who were seated first next to us had their food before we even were asked if we want water. 

Then when we got the food, finally, there was a bug in my friends ramen. It looked like some kind of larvae squirming on the bok choy. It completely put us off our appetite, and even when we didn't finish what we ordered we had to ask for any compensation. The waitress said the fact they made a new ramen should be enough but she'll take off 10% total bill. On top of that, the food itself was very poor quality. The gyoza was not made correctly nor was the ramen. The pork slice was so tough to eat. I've had my fair share of Japanese food since I've lived in Tokyo for half a year and I'm half Japanese myself. This was a terrible experience, and I just had to share.
author: Serena K.

description:
I get the feeling that Suzu doesn't need to up their ramen game because they will ALWAYS get a steady flow of business. They are located right inside one of the main entrances to the Japan Center in Japantown. Small place with indoor and outdoor seating. The service is decently fast but the quality of ramen is so-so.

I ordered the Spicy Negi Ramen with the shio base. It was a good amount of food but did not really satisfy my craving for good ramen. The ramen that my friend got had gyoza floating in it which made me curious about whether or not that's a common thing. The idea of soggy gyoza makes my stomach turn.

Long story short, I would not come here again... though if you happen to be nearby and desperately crave ramen, I'm sure there are worse places you could end up!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
There's better ramen elsewhere in Japantown (Waraku, Ramen Yamadaya). 

My friend and I stopped by on a Wednesday afternoon around 4ish and were seated right away. Given the random timing, it's not surprise the restaurant was fairly empty. Overall service was nice and the staff was super attentive to the water level in our cups. As soon as we were almost done, someone would come by and refill! There were also already menus and utensils at the table, which is always nice. I don't know about you, but I hate being seated only to have to wait for someone to bring a menu.

The menu is pretty straightforward: appetizers, udon/soda, combo add-on options and ramen. No tonkotsu ramen here ): I ordered the mixed tempura appetizer ($7.90) and the spicy miso ramen ($10.95). I enjoyed the tempura more than the ramen. The tempura came out hot and crispy, and it's a pretty big plate! You get 2 of the following: shrimp, kabocha, broccoli, carrot, potato, and then 1 eggplant and zucchini slice. Yum! The spicy miso ramen was just an average bowl of noodles. The soup had okay flavor (there was a hint of acidity?) and a nice kick but nothing crazy spicy. There's a serious lack of toppings and the ones included were mediocre: one leaf of what I think was bok choy, half a hard boiled egg, a single sad sad slice of chasu, green onions, some bamboo shoots, and then a shit ton of bean sprouts!! I love bean sprouts but wow. So much. As for the noodles, they were good and al dente. They give A LOT of noodles. 

Given that there are much alternatives, I won't be back =/ Glad to have tried it and crossed it off my list haha
author: Doris K.

description:
Review for two people for early dinner on a Wednesday:
- got there at 5:45 on Wednesday, no line!
- ordered butter corn and pork belly ramen
- no meat in the butter corn ramen
- lots of pork belly, but leaner meat than expected

Haven't been there for over a year and their noodles are still spectacular. Nice al dente texture. Soup flavor is still the same as I remembered.

Comparisons:
- Ramen Dojo (San Mateo) still my #1. Their broth, toppings and atmosphere is amazing. Yes, there's a long line to get in, but worth it.
- Suzu is a close second if you're in SF/Japantown.
author: Mary H.

description:
Good ramen.  Good price.

Suzu Noodle House is what you expect from your standard ramen house.  A select of ramen dishes in various broth types, all at reasonable prices.  A variety of meal choices for those not in the ramen mood and side dishes to complement your meal are readily available.  The decor is simple and the service isn't anything special.  One note is that the chairs there were surprisingly uncomfortable, but that might be due to me sitting in the back of the restaurant up against a wall.

Suzu Noodle House is a good place if you need a quick and filling meal.
author: Nadav P.

description: Truly enjoyed it!  Not too salty and noodles perfectly thin & chewy. First ramen noodle restaurant we've tried in J-town and it did not disappoint.
author: Stitch B.

description:
Tried out Suzu Noodle House in SF Japantown last Sat 12/6/14 for lunch after going to the Swedish Christmas Fair.  Food is meh.

Ordered butter corn ramen w/ Miso soup.  Noodles aren't very good so that was a big bummer.  Half a hard boiled egg, some bok choy, and a thick cut of pork which was dry!  Skip it.

Order of gyoza $5.5 came after the ramen when I prefer it before.  4 gyoza only with some dipping sauce.  Tasted average, but I still liked them.

B. got a ramen too - he got something else, he didn't finish his ramen.

Total before tip was $29.80.  Charged it.

Bathrooms in the mall area.
author: Ann L.

description: Worst ramen in sf. Undercooked Yellow Chinese noodles. Extremely impolite on top. Too salty and massive MSG. BAD
author: Joel S.

description:
Tucked away in a small corner of Japantown's main shopping center, across from a shop that sells "NEAT ASIAN THINGS" is a small ramen restaurant that has veggie options!

Going around Japantown can be a chore when you're hungry and an herbivore, but Suzu not only has a great selection of ramen, but provides a vegetarian option as well!

They also can use the veggie broth for any Udon or Soba Noodle dishes.

The veggie broth with miso is actually quite tasty and I found myself wanting to slurp every last drop, even though I was super stuffed after inhaling the large portion of noodles that come with every bowl.

The restaurant is pretty small, with only 8 tables inside, and 3 more outside. Service is minimal, but courteous. 

Good to know that if I'm hungry and in the area, there's a great little place to dive in and have a quick bite!
author: Lanie L.

description: We have been having ramen here for near seven years now. Easy, within walking distance from Pac Heights down into Japantown. If you are going for a movie at Kabuki, then you should stop in here before, or after for some ramen maybe. Small quiet place, usually a small wait.. Just put your name on the chalkboard by the door. I recommend trying their deep fried prawns with a bowl of pork ramen!
author: Kirk M.

description: Amongst a lot of people and things I am on to the next phenomenon.......Ramen. So prior to having dinner at Suzu Noodle House, I had already had a not so satisfying bowl of ramen. Suzu definitely turned it around for me. It stays open relatively late for brothy, savory, noodle slurping goodness with a swig of Sapporo Japanese Beer to wash it all down, not to mention the price was right. Note to self: the waitress didn't know the difference between white and dark (breast/thigh) meat chicken. I asked her if the chicken was white meat and she gave a firm yes and it was dark meat....yikes!!!! (dark meat repulses me). However the broth and the egg made up for the confusion.  Aahhhh I am all about that Ramen life....
author: Stacie J.

description:
I've always seen the long lines at Suzu in the Japantown plaza, so I've passed on this place multiple times. However, I came here for lunch with two of my friends, right when it opened, and we were seated right away.

I ordered their chashu ramen. The ramen noodles had a good, firm texture. The chashu was tasty but a tad too dry. The broth was a bit lacking in flavor.

I think it's worth a try, but do be aware of the lines and try to go during non-peak hours.
author: Alvin W.

description: I like the Ramen here however, I'm always annoyed by the lack of awareness by the wait staff. Time after time I see them standing behind the counter looking at their phone or preoccupied with their task in front of them. Perhaps it's not during the rush and they are relaxed? I don't know.
author: Akio K.

description: Ramen was alright. However, their service sucks. I asked for an extra bowl multiple times from multiple waitresses. They never gave us the bowl until 15 mins later. No greeting with smile. Hiding behind the kitchen talking. Plus they weren't busy at all.I was able to observed the two waitresses gossiping about how there's one customer gave them very little tip. I understand that being in customer service would like to receive more tip but customer service do determine how much tip they get though. I hope they would understand that in the future.
author: Donna D.

description:
It's located inside the mall, and the place is a little small where you might have to wait for a while in order to eat... but you do have the mall to walk around... so, i guess its ok... just make sure you don't go there when you are very hungry, or else you may ended up eating other things instead... 
Ramen was ok... i mean i did have other better one... but i can't say they are not good or to par... the size is decent and presentation is pretty... if you are not too too picky about your ramen... this is a good place to go while you were walking in the mall and want to satisfy your ramen craving..
author: Dorothy L.

description: Solid 4.  Are you totes over Mifune?  Me too, this is my new favorite spot for Japanese udon noodles in Japan town.  Their broth is usually very flavorful and their noodles have just the right amount of chewiness.  Also if you're not a soup kind of person, their hiyashi udon is definitely a yum!  They are mostly known for their ramen but I'm much more of an udon girl, I like my noodles thick ;D.
author: Nina W.

description:
My boyfriend and I went for dinner at about 7pm on a Wednesday night. The place was half empty and a women told us to sit wherever we wanted. We ordered Ramen, Tempura Udon, and a Daikon Salad. As soon as the waitress took our order the place was packed with people. 
The food came out rather fast- about 10 minutes after we ordered! The ramen and tempura were great, but the Udon was just "okay" - the noodles were a bit bland.
The daikon salad was just chopped daikon and tomatoes- no seasoning, oil, or dressing. The bill came out to about $38. 
Minus a star because there were a bunch of fruit flies in the place which was annoying/disturbing.
author: A L.

description:
Arrived one evening on a random whim with a group of 4, and we waited maybe 10-15 minutes for a table. Service was decent, nothing extraordinary.

Spicy ramen was adequate and overall greasy, but still flavorful. Karaage was average. We were a bit disappointed seeing as we were in Japantown and all. My friend, who was born and raised in Japan didn't care much for this place either. We've definitely had better ramen back in SoCal.

Pro: free hot green tea
author: Michelle H.

description: Probably my favorite vegetarian ramen in SF! I love this place. Their veggie ramen is rich, filling, and just delicious. Their house hot sauce is also wonderful and goes great with the ramen.
author: Zozi S.

description:
Mmmm ramen. This is one of the better ramen places I have tried in San Francisco. It's a small little place inside of the Japantown plaza building, and prices range from around $10-13 dollars.
 I came in with a group of 4 on a Sunday afternoon, and they were able to fit us all in, surprisingly. I ordered the pork belly ramen with shoyu broth because I was feeling extra hungry, 3 of my friends ordered the suzu ramen, and the other ordered the spicy ramen. I really liked mine because the pork belly was cooked to a perfect consistency. My friends' suzu ramen looked good too with chicken karaage, and gyoza inside. The bowls were bigger than I expected, and all came with half an egg (my fave) and green onions, among other things. Service was good and attentive, and I would definitely come back.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Pretty decent ramen house.  It was busy and packed when me and my friend came.  I got the Karaage (fried chicken) ramen with a soy broth.  It was a classic bowl with 4-5 pieces of chicken (as big as an orange chicken piece from Panda Express) and some veggies.  The broth was tasty and salty (as expected).  4/5

The three stars comes from service.  Me and my friend sat in one of the outside tables and the waitress never came back after she gave us our food and water.  I know that it may be cultural, but even my Vietnamese people check on the table once.  It was difficult to get the waitress' attention, so we just ate and left. Eh.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Food: 5/5; Delicious. Nicely cooked noodles and veggies. 
Place: 2/5; Clean and well kept. A bit cramped and claustrophobic when busy.  
Service: 4/5; It was busy so it was slow, but good friendly service. 

Overall 4/5
author: Cesylie C.

description:
Let me start by saying this: COCKROACH..
THERE WAS A COCKROACH IN MY RAMEN.
I was halfway through my bowl before I found it.
She took it away and came back ten minutes later apologizing and offered to pay for our three ramen bowls while we were still to pay for our appetizers.
We did, and we left. She had me leave my name and number and "was concerned for my health." 
I really wanted to like this place. 
I'm never eating ramen again.

My follow up with the health department confirmed that they were paid a visit by SFDPH two days after my incident. There was evidence of recent cockroach spraying, but violations numerous enough to ensure they closed down for the night to correct them.
author: Robin B.

description:
WWas craving ramen after I just finished brunch and lukily enough ended up in Japan Town. Looked up Yelp and read some good reviews about Suzu so decided to try it out.

Came here on a Monday afternoon and the place was relatively empty. The ramen and appetizer came pretty quick after we ordered. I ordered the spicy miso ramen (was afraid it was going to be too spicy) and it came out with the perfect flavoring. It kicked my taste buds a little bit but in a good way. The broth was pretty flavorful and went well with the miso. Overall no complaints.. would definitely stop by again if I'm in the area!
author: David L.

description:
The bf and I were craving ramen, but since our fave spot was closed we decided to try Suzu. This place is usually packed when I walk by, so we decided it was as a good a time as any to go since there was no wait (on a Monday night).

I ordered the Cha shu ramen and my bf got the spicy ramen. Service was fast and friendly, and our food came out quickly.

Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed with the ramen. My broth was watery and had no flavor or depth. The noodles were okay, but tasted like cup ramen noodles. The chashu was a bit overcooked and chewy. There was little else in my soup. My boyfriend's ramen tasted exactly the same, except it looked like they had dumped extra spicy powder into it. It had more flavor than mine, but again lacked any depth.

Lesson learned: a packed restaurant doesn't always mean it's good.
author: Vivian H.

description:
The change of ownership and the decrease in quality of food doesn't appeal to me. I visit less often and when I do, I always forget to not to order the "beef" nabeyaki with the miso broth. My problem is the beef. It is this glob of slimey and fatty chunk of inedible"beef." I don't know about you, but I do not like the sweet and style pork style of meat in my broth. It leaks oil and it makes it look and feel disgusting. However, everything else in the bowl is delicious. But now I am just paying a extra for vegetarian style bowl of nabeyaki. 

Do not order the ramen here. Don't fall for the ramen trend here. They weren't originally known for this. 

The udon is my absolute favorite for the past 6 years. It's fresh and well, delicious. 

The line can still get ridiculously long for a small space.
author: Jess W.

description:
2.5 stars.

Definitely NOT worth the hype and long ass f*ck line.

I ordered the karaage ramen (with the karaage on the side) and he ordered the katsu ramen. Everything was just OK to us. However, I was very unhappy with my bamboo shoots. Hard. Rock. Slices. 

Overall, not worth the wait, too hyped up. I was sorely disappointed.


PS. they took their trash out through the front, not the back. While we were eating. Just sayin.
author: Leslie C.

description:
TLDR: Great deal for a lot of pretty damn good food.

I've been wanting to try this place for a while and I finally got to a few weeks ago. They have pretty much any type of Japanese noodle you could possibly want. We had to wait outside for a bit before we got seated but we used up the entire time trying to figure out what we each wanted. On top of all the noodle choices, you can also add a don to your noodle for just $3 extra. They had a bunch of different choices which made deciding that much harder for us.

I decided to get the Spicy Miso Ramen without a don because the noodle portions already looked really big to me. I'm glad I made that choice because I could barely finish all my food and everyone else who ordered dons ended not being able to finish everything. 

Prices were very reasonable, especially for the quantity and quality of food offered. I had read that the place was really cheap and I was afraid that the noodles would be really sad and lackluster. My one complaint would be that the Ramen I got had A LOT of oil in it. Probably mostly from the spicy oil. Next time I'm gonna try and get a nabeyaki Udon or Soba for a lighter option. 

Most noodle places only have one type of noodle and a variety of other dishes, but Suzu is truly very centered around noodle. Good place to go if you're an avid noodle lover (like me) and know that you want noodle bug have trouble deciding what type until the last minute.
author: Melissa Z.

description:
To start off: what kind of ramen place HARD-boils the egg?

OK, had to get that off my chest because it literally bewildered me and my husband when we first got our bowls of spicy miso ramen. We're big ramen fans, having eaten it in Kyoto, Tokyo, Austin, and NYC, and wanted to try some West Coast ramen. Obviously, we need to try LA's offering now after sampling what we thought was a decent SF location due to the long line on a Wednesday night and a local's suggestion.

The chasu was dry and extremely lean. The broth had no flavor and literally tasted like they had boiled water and dumped in a quarter of an instant ramen flavor pack. The noodles were overcooked and mushy. 

Overall, my husband said the best part of dinner was the Sapporo.
author: Britney Thuy T.

description: Best Ramen in Japan Town. I love the Miso broth and the Pork Belly is the best, I Highly recommend and take all my family and friends.
author: Andrew G.

description:
NOTE: I do not reside in SF. (wish I did though ha!)

I came here on my last day of SF with some friends -- I will say this. This place is a lot better than most places in Atlanta. SO GOOOOOD.

Why I gave 5 stars

- When the lady took my order - spicy kimchi tofu ramen, I told her not too spicy since my stomach can't handle it. She made sure to emphasize that - which I personally thought was great service. Most places will forget or simply get too lazy to tell the cook. 

- Taste: wow, delicious. Simply delicious. Ramen was awesome. Kimchi + tofu were very good too. Yummy.

- Location: I think it's in a great location. Other shops I saw were mainly desserts so eh. I was happy to see an actual food place. 

- Service: Nice lady - again she took my order very well and explained to me what exactly was great and decent in customer eyes. Our food also came out quickly. Restaurant was somewhat busy. 

- Size: the bowl was big. I barely finished it. Definitely happy I ordered this :D

When I come back to SF, I'd love to try this place again.
author: Rachel K.

description:
I love ramen, so I had to try some while I was in San Francisco... 

Small place. Since it's limited space, they got tables like right next to each other... 

It sucks having to sit with strangers like right next to you and hear their entire conversation... Luckily, people next to me weren't bad... but still...  Claustrophobic and hectic environment. 

The ramen was ok... nothing spectacular... I think it was pretty salty. I honestly don't really remember... I guess not that memorable.
author: Kiyo M.

description:
My family was visiting San Francisco, and I really wanted to go for some ramen noodles. I'm from Sacramento, and I enjoy a few places for ramen there... but I had high expectations for the ramen in SF. We were at Japan Town and selected Suzu because it had pretty positive reviews on Yelp and looked like a fine place to eat.

Suzu offered up a good bowl or ramen, but I have to say that there are places in Sacramento that can best Suzu. The food at Suzu is certainly good, but it's just missing a little bit to take it over the top and be great.

For dinner, we had three ramen noodle bowls and a small mapo (tofu) rice bowl. The rice bowl came first. While the portion was good for the price, the tofu was a bit heavy handed in terms of the taste. The tofu wasn't as silken as it should have been, and the sauce was a bit over-thick for me.

For ramen, we ordered the pork belly ramen, vegetarian, and wonton. I personally had the pork belly ramen, and I think it was the best of the three we had. The pork belly paired very well with the ramen. The bowl came with a hard boiled egg - which tasted fine, but I prefer the soft boiled gooey egg that other places serve. The ramen noodles themselves were a little al dente. They had a nice chew to them that was satisfying.

I had a chance to try both of the other ramen bowls. The wonton was good, but lacked the flavor punch of the pork belly, and the vegetarian ramen was a bit bland. It did seem to have the most ingredients in it though. We were surprised at how big the vegetarian ramen was compared to the others... in fact, it was so much we had to take it home in a to-go container.

In terms of service, Suzu was excellent. We were very well taken care of, and the servers were extremely friendly. The servers came at appropriate times and provided everything we needed with a smile. I cannot fault anything about this aspect of Suzu.

Overall, Suzu is a good place to get a bowl of ramen - I'd definitely go again, but I do think there are other noodle houses that can have a better bowl of ramen. If you find yourself in Japan Town and want some ramen, this might be your best bet!
author: Luke C.

description:
I came in a hot, fine Saturday afternoon when the store opened, and saw the pictures of what items they sell at their restaurant. Ramen, soba and was enticed by the Tsukemen. Tsukemen is ramen noodles accompanied with a deep fried vegetable fritter, 2 karaage topped with bamboo shots, pickled ginger, shaved leeks with a mild spicy miso dipping sauce on the side. I was so excited when I received my meal... it looks delicious and cannot wait to dig in.
So I was trying to get some of the ramen noodles and dip it. But I was having a hard time because it was so long, and decided to cut with my chopsticks. To no avail, I decided to put some dipping sauce onto the noodles. Mmmm... this was spicy but salty in a good way. Then ate the karaage - not too greasy and it was hot. Great filler and the chicken was cooked right. Then I mixed the pickled ginger, bamboo shots and some shaved leeks.It was becoming more of a smorgasbord of flavors... crunchy, sweet, savory, umami, sour, and spicy. It was getting to the point where my tastebuds wanted more. On my third bites decided to dip my ramen with the mild spicy miso. It was an amazing experience, and was definitely better in terms of food experience and taste.
Lessons learned: try to cut your noodles first with a soup spoon provided for you. Then dip the ramen noodles into the miso dipping sauce. Then eat the karaage and the vegetable fritter to have a more filling meal. This item was thumbs up = 3.5/5.
I also ordered the Kanuki - so it is a braised sweet soy sauce pork belly with a small dollop of yellow mustard, pickled ginger, and had some Japanese leeks on top. The braised pork belly was seasoned well. This was really great appetizer, and also a great side dish that can go with any ramen, tsukemen (in may case) or a rice bowl. The yellow mustard was first unusual combo because I said,"what is mustard doing here? That's an odd combination. So I cut up a small piece of the pork belly, and dip some with yellow mustard and little bit of pork ginger. I tasted and it goes well together. So the fatty and well braised soy sauce pork belly and the yellow mustard cuts out the fattiness and greasiness and richness of the pork belly. It also heightens my tastebuds to eat more of the tsukemen, and definitely goes well together. Kakuni is 4.3/5.
I was satisfied with my meal but thought they give you too much in terms of portion size. Sometimes, your eyes fool you how the food is presented, in terms of portion size. Later on you realize you cannot finish it. That's a bummer for me. A person with a small appetite but loves to try out new dishes and cuisines of discovering new food experiences and expanding a grand food experience whether it travelling locally, by region or travel abroad.
Customer service is 5. They really care whether your food experience has been met, and all of the servers are knowledgeable, nice. 5/5.
Ambience - it is a very small restaurant but they have outdoor seating. This restaurant fills up very quickly once it opened its doors. Wait times are 15 minutes or longer. 3/5. Otherwise, place is clean and organized. You can see the kitchen is small but very well organized. Food comes out very fast.
Suzu Noodle house serves ramen, soba, zaru soba, few rice bowls and interesting array of appetizers and tsukemen. They also have Sapporo beer, sake, hot tea and other cold beverages to go with your meal. I had a great experience trying out a new item which is tsukemen which is chewy ramen noodles dipping with a savory, umami and mildly spiced miso sauce. These are accompanied by a deep fried vegetable fritter which is nice and not too greasy. it was crunchy yet satisfying great with carrots, cucumbers and some taro. Then the karaage gave me a filler to eat with my tsukemen. The killer Kakuni is a sweet soy sauce braised pork belly that has been fried first, then braised with a sweet soy sauce. Then it served with a small dollop of yellow mustard, pickled ginger and leek shavings on top. This appetizer should be tried with your meal whether it is a piping hot ramen, soba, tsukemen or maybe a donburi. This dish was a game changer because of the odd combination of yellow mustard that is sweet, slight of horseradish accent with yellow mustard condiment and pork belly. it cuts out the fattiness and richness of the pork belly, and heightens to eat more of your complementing meal of the day. I would order this next time with either donburi next time. I enjoyed my time here, yet it was a satisfying lunch which is different. I guess I was remembering some moments watching Kodome No Gurume or The Solitary Gourmet, how the food taste so amazing. Relinquishing every moment of my food experience from Suzu Noodle House.
author: Jade M.

description: Got cha shu shio ramen for $11. Was average overall, although there was a decent elasticity and bite to the noodles. The egg was medium boiled and not soft boiled like I would have preferred. The cha shu couldve been more tender but by no means tough.
author: John W.

description: Ramen is quite good.  Karage was great and it actually went very well in the ramen bowl.  Also tried spicy kimchi and tofu ramen - also very good.   I think this place is under rated.  It isn't the best ramen ever but easily in the top 10% for San Fran / LA / Vancouver and not fair to compare to Tokyo.  But very good and easy to get a table.
author: Sean M.

description:
Suzu Noodle House is a wonderful little stop for noodles nested away in a corner of the Japantown Mall.

I've been here twice for lunch and find that this place typically gets pretty popular so stop by early to write your name on their waiting list! The restaurant is fairly small, but they have a couple of tables around the outside as well. I got to try both the chashu ramen and the special spicy tsukemen here. I personally find the ramen to taste better here as the tsukemen broth was slightly lacking in flavor and spiciness, and it tasted fairly similar to the ramen broth. However, the tsukemen came with a neat mixed vegetable tempura thingie that had nice crisp and flavor to it. The chashu ramen is simply great with all that great melt in your mouth slices of pork. The noodles are somewhere towards the middle of the scale of soft-firm ramen noodles and have a nice consistency to them. The only thing I wish they could change in their ramen is having soft boiled eggs rather than hard boiled eggs as that is the last step to take to make it supah sugoi! :3
author: Joshua M.

description: I got a shrimp tempura ramen soup, it was ok , a little bit too salty . Not the best noodle place in SF but not even the worst
author: Kira B.

description: Fantastic ramen dishes.  The Udon looked good too - it's just that I had to pick between the many tasty options.  I picked the ramen with Japanese chicken - the chicken comes on a side plate to keep it crispy. The broth was delicious as well as the ramen noodles.   The service is quick and attentive.  The place was packed.
author: Barbara P.

description: I've been here over a handful times now. Food is very consistent. I usually go for the chicken karaage curry or the cold ramen. Good and quick service, sometimes you need to sign up on the waitlist, but usually it's less than a 20 min wait. I come here for a quick dinner and always satisfied when I leave.
author: Alice S.

description: Packed restaurant with everyone eating noodles. Ordered the nabeyaki udon and it comes with tempura (shrimp, carrot, pumpkin). Wish they put the tempura on the side as by the time it got to my table, it was super soggy (ended up just taking the batter off). The broth was a bit salty and it was so hot from the cast iron bowl that it made my noodles taste more overcooked than intended. I wish the egg that comes in the udon/ramen was a softboiled egg instead of a boiled one.
author: Lauren K.

description: Had ramen, which I thought was good, nothing spectacular, nothing horrible. The broth lacks t that complexity that really top-notch ramen has, where you can tell that it has been cooked for a really long time. Maybe they do that, I don't know, but I crave that complexity that comes with ramen, and this didn't have it, tasting more like a somewhat salty if still good-tasting broth. The atmosphere was small and nice and relaxed, with a good touch of older wooden tables and such, which helped us forget it was in a large mall.
author: Ken L.

description: Just had lunch here, it was very good.  Vegetable and shrimp tempura very fresh tasting and brought to the table really hot, crispy coating, not greasy at all.  Vegie and chicken soba had lots of vegetables and chicken, very flavorful and not salty.  Service was quick and friendly.  We will definitely come back!
author: Barbara B.

description:
My best version of ramen in SF.

I've been here twice and had the Chicken Katsu Ramen... both times. Suzu is like a Japantown gem, it's a little ramen shop but with a long waiting line. The food was without doubt, good, tasty, and the noodle was soft and so chewy. For me the portion was too big, but I ended up finishing it anyway. Chicken was tender and cooked properly, but I just wish the broth could be made a little bit more spicy.
author: Annisa J.

description: I ordered the miso ramen with extra bean sprouts and a side of gyoza. Flavor-wise, the ramen broth was very savory, and the noodles very chewy. The gyoza was large and packed with flavor although I must say the shape of the gyoza was not esthetically pleasing as they were all of different shapes other than the typical crescent. Still, the flavor more than made up for it. Service was a little slow, but the ramen was delicious. I would eat here again.
author: Kenson K.

description: Well, first off, this was an interesting experience. We got 3 bowls of ramen, and two rice bowl add-ons. The waiters were all pretty nice! It took about 15 minutes for the food to arrive, and when it came, the food looked great! We started to eat, and it tasted okay. About halfway into the meal, we found a dead cockroach in the spicy kimchi and tofu soup. We were obviously horrified and disgusted, and immediately alerted a waitress. She came to our table and when we told her our predicament, she grabbed the bowl and walked into the kitchen. She was there for about 5 minutes, and we started to wonder what was going on! She came out and said that the bug must've been in the kimchi, which they buy from another seller. But kimchi is made out of vinegar, so a big couldn't survive in that, could it? So that is the reason why they deserve one star.
author: Sophie C.

description: Yummy! We came here right after shopping at Daiso and didn't have to wait too long for a table. Like many Japanese restaurants, there is a sheet at the door that you put your name and party size on, and then a server will call you in once there's room. Once we were able to get a seat, we quickly ordered sushi and it was delicious, and cheap! I didn't have any complaints about Suzu and I'm sure we'll return at some point next time we're in the area to do some grocery shopping for Asian ingredients. I'd definitely recommend it!
author: John B.

description: I got ramen here and thought it was gross. Worst then top ramen. The portions are huge and the soup tastes very Bamboo like.
author: Tina L.

description: Decent food, we ordered the spicy ramen and negi ramen. The spicy ramen has quite a kick to it, so be aware, but it tasted so good. The negi ramen is good balance of spice and flavor. Their plum wine was good, it was quite sweet, but I prefer wines that way, so enjoyed that too.
author: Shibani K.

description: This is the only noodle place at Japantown that requires you to wait for a long time. I've been here once and the experience is really great to me. The best part about this restaurant is that their signature ramen has gyoza in the bowl. This is definitely the restaurant that is worth waiting for!
author: Leo W.

description: I was trying to get to go salad dressing but those damn ugly nasty women were fucken rude. She said they don't have to boxes today, really ? What kind of restaurant have no to go box? They think they are working on the modeling or show off place. Listen idiot women's u are not working in the show place u are working in the restaurant. Be nice with your customers okay. Don't be nasty rude.
author: Yoki P.

description: The food was okay, I've definitely tried better ramen spots in the city before. I ordered the butter corn ramen and it was super salty. But this place would be good for a quick meal. I came here with my family for dinner and the customer service was horrible. There were 2 waitresses working that night and off the bat one of the lady was hardworking and doing a great job. But on the other hand, the other lady with glasses completely ignored us. Keep in mind, this restaurant is pretty small and if I speak up a little, I'm pretty sure the waitress can hear me. I've called here over several times to let here know we were ready to order and I could tell she heard me. But instead she hurried into the kitchen and I could see her rolling her eyes behind the curtains... the whole night the waitress was rude and lazy
author: Sally L.

description: I came here earlier with my brother and we both came to the conclusion that we thought the ramen overall was a bit bland. It wasn't overly expensive though, so I'm not too bothered about the food. However my brother wasn't even halfway finished with his ramen when we had the check brought to us--it must've been about 15 minutes after we got our food. There wasn't a line of people waiting either so I didn't really understand what the rush was. Unless it's a last resort, I'll probably try finding another restaurant to eat at.
author: April L.

description: If you like 1 piece of small meat in your ramen and a hard boiled egg and horrible service, then come here :)
author: Tim G.

description:
Excellent!
There on a strangely quiet Sunday morning and
Was very impressed with the quality and generous portion size
Anything fried(shrimp tempura,octopus balls etc)
Are well prepared they obviously know their way around the fryer and the Ramens are solid.
Service was fast and efficient.great place
author: james m.

description:
Prior to our last two visits (the most recent one just this past Sunday on June 23rd), I had rated this place as 4 stars for the very same reasons from other Yelper's review. 

However, after our last two visits, I have to notch off a couple of stars and rank them below par. 

Two main reasons:

First - 

They always get confused on who is next on the reservations list. Even when you marked your name way before other patrons, they always call patrons that have arrived way after you first. I understand that these patrons are a party of two, but couldn't you wait for two tables to open up and combine them together to meet our group? C'mon now! This doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure this flaw out. 

It gets frustrating to see group after group after group get tables knowing that you had been there way, way, way before them. This past Sunday, there was a group of five waiting patiently as their name was on the waiting list forever and they called a group of four that had recently arrived prior to them and they had to call them back as soon as the group of five threw a hissy fit. 

Talk about awkward. I would have done the same, too. 

Second - 

I can no longer order extra pork for my Ramen. Are. You. Kidding. Me?!

Why have a section of extra add-ons on the menu and exempt one dish? You mean to tell me I can order extra shrimp, extra noodles, extra etc.. except the pork. Where is the disclosure? You should at least have that written on the menu. For two bucks, I opted for the "extra" shrimp and what I got was one measly, overly fried, oily and dead shrimp tempura that could have substituted as a fly on my Ramen. This does not make sense for a Ramen joint. 

And now that I got my blood boiling and got me rolling, I'm gonna add a third reason:

That server with a snarly, b*tchy attitude. You shouldn't be working as a server and you have no skills in customer service. You are good at slamming orders at the guest's tables and you look miserable while you're there. Is it always that time of the month with you? Wow, you should start your own training program for servers on how to delicately offend customers and get away with it because you don't give a damn attitude. I know because you're still there.
author: John G.

description:
My manager and I came in slightly in a rush, we had a half hour to eat but didn't want to grab a ready made bentos on the other side of the mall (don't judge, we just knew what we didn't want to eat). We waited maybe 2 minutes to sit down, and let the waitress know we didn't have much time when ordering, and she didn't make us promises but she made sure our food came out fast. I don't know how much effort was made but just FYI it was appreciated. 

You may have heard of the food here already, or maybe you've noticed that they're always full up, but let me just confirm that the food is delicious. In a mall full of disappointment, Suzu is a refreshing oasis of decent flavor. My manager and I got the Tsukemen and Hayashi Chukka, respectively, and they were both fantastic  (I'm going off of what she said, I didn't eat any of the tsukemen).  My dish was flavorful and had a sesame based sauce to pour over instead of Ramen broth, and I got the karaage on the side because I'm a vegetarian, but it was refreshing and bursting with bright flavors. The tempura was perfect too! I wish I had time to enjoy it, but we cut it close enough.

It's also a bonus that the noodles are up to par (I mean, look at the name). The Ramen noodles in my dish were eggy and chewy and crinkly, just the way I like them. I'll have to come back for a complete analysis on the soba and udon :)
author: Astrid V.

description:
For a while this was our favorite ramen place in San Francisco. The food was consistently good, even if the service was inattentive and the wait was long. Because of the long wait, we hadn't been here in quite some time (well over a year). Therefore I felt lucky when there was very little wait just before 7pm last Saturday. 

Apparently the relative lack of wait is because everyone else had figured out what I learned that night. The food is not the same. The pork was oddly sweet and tough (not sure what cut of meat it was--but it definitely was NOT pork belly). The broth wasn't as rich. The noodles seemed more reminiscent of instant ramen than the homemade noodles they were known for. Also there were way too many noodles--eventually they made a giant clump in the bowl that I just ate around. 

I saw some other reviews saying that ownership has changed, so perhaps that explains the degradation in quality. Regardless of the reason, Suzu is not the place it used to be. I will look elsewhere next time I'm craving ramen in Japantown.
author: Travis H.

description: Loved this place! Very authentic! I ordered the meat nabeyaki udon and loved it! The soy broth was perfect! And the price was VERY reasonable!
author: Jodi M.

description:
I came here with my little sister and mother after a day of running around the city in the cold Fall weather. We were quickly seated and received our order of hot tea almost immediately; a great start to an excellent meal. 

My Mom ordered a custom noodle dish with hot soba noodles, miso broth and "lots of vegetables". She was delighted by how accommodating they were and how satisfied she was with the meal afterwards. 

I ordered the Suzu Ramen, delicious. 

My little sister received a little lesson in speaking Japanese by a lovely old woman sitting in a table adjacent to ours. 

A memorable and pleasurable experience overall. While it may not be the best Ramen SF, it's in my top five and you don't need to worry about bringing your free spirited 8 year old sister into the tenderloin.
author: Leland W.

description:
I don't know if they make their own noodles but their noodles taste really fresh!  They have the best ramen soup & come here as often as I can! 

Prepare to sit and eat because they don't have take out!
author: Mikky T.

description:
Probably the ramen store that has the longest line in Japantown.

The broth is nice and thick, and extremely flavorful. The decor is nice and cozy, and has a good japanese noodle house vibe. Definitely a good place to go if you are looking for a good ramen place.
author: Henry L.

description:
Came here to eat lunch with my parents after church. I remember this place use to be good when i was here couple years ago.

They give you tea once you sit down at your table

Have almost open kitchen and looks clean when you take look inside the kitchen. But the restaurant looks clean as well

This place is small so you'll have to wait at any given time but during the rush hour time, you have to wait even longer. But you can browse around the mall if you are willing to wait.

Service and staffs are so so

I order chashu ramen which cost 9.95. To me i thought the price was expensive cause the bowl is small, had an ok amount of noodle, had 4 pieces of pork meats, 1 half egg, and very few bamboo. Thought the broth was salty so i assume they might have put msg in the broth since its making me thirsty. They give a big spoon if you order chashu ramen. Other than that, food is only alright
author: Julie N.

description:
I LOVE the noodles here. They're super chewy, which I cannot get enough of. (see pic.)

The vegetarian broth is pretty awesome too - it's much more complex than others I've had in the city. So often, noodle houses around here perfect their pork and chicken based broths, but phone it in when it comes to veggie. Not this place! They don't skimp on the vegetables either! My recent bowl contained cabbage, bok choy, corn (an add on for $1), eggplant, and green onions. Coupled with the broth, it was awesome.
