My only two complaints:
1) They hard boil the egg to the point where the yolk is post-it note yellow with a grey ring around it. I strongly prefer a runnier egg, and for a $1, this was definitely not worth it for me.
2) They should keep sriracha on hand! I know they have chili powder and sriracha isn't traditional at a ramen house, but come on, this is San Francisco! We put it on everything!
author: Shachi B.

description:
Food (3/5): I got the basic ramen with extra bean sprouts, and my bf got the Suzu ramen, both with miso broth (no tonkatsu here!). The pork was a little tough to me, but overall I thought the ramen was decent. I liked the chewiness of the noodles a lot, but the soup was extremely salty. Even though I had like 1/3 of the soup and chugged water during dinner, I was still feeling dehydrated the rest of the night.

Service (4/5): Servers are really friendly, and food comes out pretty fast. It's a little hard to get someone's attention if you're sitting on the outside of the restaurant, though.

Value (3.5/5): Expensive for ramen but that's pretty typical in SF. Portions are big though!
author: Abby S.

description: A cute little place inside the Japanese mall in JapanTown that doesn't look like anything from the outside. I got the fried chicken ramen that I've heard lots about on Yelp and other blogs. I also got the spicy soup, which looks about 5x more spicy than it tastes. Don't let the colour scare you, it's just colour! I wouldn't say it's the best ramen I've had, but I definitely have never had fried chicken ramen before. A good place to stop by if you're walking around JapanTown.
author: Susie C.

description:
Pretty good udon and ramen place. I came here with my sister and I got the nabeyaki while she ordered the kimchi. The portions are large and I was definitely more than full after finishing my pot. They also put a lot of ingredients inside. I would go with 3.5 stars, but am rounding down since unfortunately the tempura was disappointing. The shrimp was tiny and so were the vegetable pieces. My sister on the other hand LOVED her kimchi udon pot, so maybe I'll try that next time. :)

Overall I think the price was decent ($15 incl. tax and tip) for the meal. I would come back again since it hits the spot on cold days.
author: Sophia H.

description:
I think I'm a ramen expert, if not that, at least I've had experience eating really amazing ramen for the last 4.5 years I spent in Hawaii.

The spicy ramen is really good, and it's actually spicy. I don't know if it's just me, but I've noticed that a lot of ramen places that offer "spicy ramen" isn't actually that spicy at all. But at Suzu, you get what you asked for and the spicy ramen definitely deserves it's name. 

The other ramen that was ordered was the karaage ramen and it was one of the best karaage chicken I've ever taste. Too bad it was only 4 pieces. Anyway, I enjoyed my meal and for the ~$9.50-12.50 range, Suzu feeds you well.. veryyyyy well. You get a lot of ramen, and if THAT isn't enough, make your meal a combo for an additional $3-5 and you'll be stuffed!
author: Denise L.

description:
I don't review a lot of restaurants but feel compelled to review this one. Do not eat here. 

Ramen tastes likes salty miso soup with thin hard noodles that you'd find in cup ramen. Chashu (pork slices) are rubbery and bland. Broth was lukewarm when it arrived at the table. I would honest to god prefer to eat a packet of ramen at home over this. 

Moreover service was particularly bad. Waitress gave us an unbelievable amount of attitude for asking questions about the ramen flavor. I don't usually ding restaurants for bad service at dinky little restaurants but this was bad enough to note. 

Avoid this place. Restaurants in the Japantown shop aren't very good, but this place was particularly bad. Very negative experience.
author: Daniel L.

description:
This place does not need another review on Yelp, but I must tell it as how I experienced it. I think the hype around this place comes from its location, right in the front of Japan center building.

I got the miso ramen ($9.50 good price I guess to SF standard) - comes with one slice of BBQ pork (not fatty, too dry), half egg (overcooked), some bamboo shoots. Maybe this is a particular style of ramen that I don't understand, but the ramen and the broth are literally nothing special. However, they do serve huge portions of ramen. I also got the karage don as a side $3.50, which was 3 small pieces of chicken over rice. It's not crispy, tasted like it's been sitting out. 

I would not wait over 5 minutes for this place when there are a handful of way better tasting ramen choices within 2 block radius (i.e. Waraku or  Yamadaya - I am not endorsed in any way by them).
author: Irene S.

description: Good place for ramen and udon. Probably will be my go to place for udon. The seating is limited and it does get packed do you might not want to bring a group of over 4 people here. I hope the quality stays the same and that the service always will be so fast.
author: Lily P.

description:
I was so let down by the ramen here. It wasn't inedible, just really not exciting and left me seriously disappointed. The noodles weren't great, the pork belly was mostly fat, and other than the half egg and a single leaf of bok choy it was pretty bare. I left without eating much of my ramen, that pretty much never happens. 

The restaurant itself was cute. Small and definitely cozy, but not awkwardly or uncomfortably so. The waitress was nice, service was fine. There were a decent amount of people in there but it wasn't packed. 

I love ramen so I was sad to leave feeling so let down by this bowl of soup. Maybe one of the other broth choices would have been better?
author: Shannon H.

description: Great Ramen or Udon/Soba noodles here!  Small restaurant but fast to order.  Customer service isn't the greatest as the waitresses don't say much.  But the food was good.  There's plenty other noodle houses to choose from in SF though, especially here in Japantown.  We might come back.  My husband is the one who is the biggest noodle nut, lol!
author: Rosie M.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! Food is great!!!!!!! Ramen is about 13$ the wait is 15-20 or 30mins. Food is worth the wait. The place is a little bit small.. they need to expand since their food is so great
author: Maria Mekaela C.

description:
Finally a somewhat decent place for ramen inside of JapanTown! Service was kind of slow but I don't blame them...they had a full house + a wait list which is pretty good for a Monday and only 2 waitresses.

For appetizer we ordered the takoyaki & it was great! Creamy when you bite into it then you can taste the octopus meat - chewy and well-cooked.

Curry ramen was a little spicy for my taste but it easily went away after a sip of water. Broth was flavorful and the chicken was tender; super yummy.

We also had a side order of teriyaki-don and ebi-don over rice. Crunchy and jam-packed with flavors; quite fulfilling considering it was only $3 extra with an order of ramen.

Overall, food here is not too shabby compared to everywhere else...sitting outside is recommended :)
author: Rose C.

description: Yuck.  I found the ramen soup inedible.  The pork was too tough to chew.  The tempura vegetables were one greasy lump of not-fresh tempura.  The miso broth was inedible.  A few attempted chews, some very unhappy bites, spit out everything I started.  The staff couldn't have been less concerned my food was inedible, and were happy to take my money.
author: Rob L.

description:
Dilemma! Le boyfriend wanted ramen but I wanted udon. What restaurant provides both? This place! I've tried their ramen before and really liked it but last night I was craving udon. As a first timer trying the udon here, I was pretty impressed. I ordered the nabeyaki udon and it comes with a couple of tempura veggies and one shrimp. I should've asked for the tempura on the side cause I prefer them not to be soggy (when it sits in the broth for too long. ) the broth was sweet and the noodles were soft and not super chewy. Perfect amount of cabbage and whatever other veggies they put in there (see attached photo). Le boyfriend got the spicy miso ramen and curry bowl (combo for an extra $3) he really enjoyed it.  The only thing I don't like is that they completely cook the egg.
It's a small restaurant so if you decide to come on a weekend, come early or prepare to wait!
author: naviee P.

description:
Seriously!! Do NOT eat here!!!!!!
The food are not fresh!!! The chicken and vegetables are stink...
author: Lily L.

description:
Tried the pork belly and miso ramen and there was nothing good about either. Couldn't finish the broth because it was disgusting. Noodles were hard and in a ball, most employees just sadly slouching with no smiles (until we paid) and slopped the bowls down in from of us. There is absolutely no love or any passion in this place. I've had Ramen in most major cities, this was a miss. 

edit: got home and both our stomachs were in a ball of fire. Sealed the deal, Definitely won't be back.
author: Michael M.

description: Visiting town for vacation and wanted ramen and we were seated quickly. However, when it came to paying, the waitress demanded that we give her a tip. Like she wouldn't let us leave until we gave her a tip.
author: Javier R.

description:
Pretty awful ramen shop. The noodles are hard and not chewy. They are more like egg noodles you find at a wonton shop. The shoyu broth had an unbalanced flavor. My ramen had one slice of chashu and half a boiled egg. Somehow both were cold. 

Service was quick.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
Since my first visit, I've been back multiple times.

I still recommend the miso nabeyaki udon! I've tried the chicken karage ramen, which was good was well, but a tad on the bland side. My friend had the spicy pork ramen and unfortunately he was disappointed in it. I tried a bit of the broth and it just tasted...off. Not flavorful at all. 

But minus one star because the past couple of times I've been back the service is always lacking. One visit in particular where I felt it was almost hostile. When they get busy it seems that they just want to flip tables and will drop the check as soon as you get food. Don't bother asking for water or napkins either because you'll get glared out. Sheesh!
author: Noelle H.

description:
Suzu has all-star potential, but their ramen lacks the oomph to bolster them into the ranks of Ramen Superstar (Dojo, Sozai, Orenchi)

Suzu doesn't mess around with Tonkatsu. They go for the OG shoyu/miso soup base, which is nice to see when everyone else be rocking the Tonkatsu. 

The ramen wasn't captivating though. It had good texture and the broth was good, but it didn't mesmerize me like the ramen from Dojo or Sozai. Another down point is that they do not use soft boiled eggs. That kills the Instagram picture, yadadamean?

Good ramen, but not the best. Also, avoid the Cheese Ramen. I swear it's the same as the original with a packet of Pizza Hut Parmesan sprinkles over it.
author: Ringo M.

description:
It's ok..

I would go somewhere else for ramen instead of here.

The ramen was filling, the broth wasn't much. There wasn't much flavor, only subtle flavors. So, if you don't like ramen that packs a punch of flavor then this is the place for you!
author: Hina W.

description:
The Takoyaki is good. 

The ramen sucks. 

The end.
author: Janice C.

description:
It's difficult for me to have an unbiased opinion when it comes to ramen because I've had ramen from Ippudo in NYC, and there's just no comparison. But my hunt for the best ramen in SF continues. 

This place is located in the Japantown mall, on the lower level and I visited on Saturday evening around 7 pm and the wait time was less than 10 minutes. The service is quick and the servers are cordial. There's inside seating and "outside" seating, and by outside I mean in the mall, not necessarily outdoors.

When it comes to ramen, I look for two things: broth and noodles. I'm not one who has high expectations about protein and vegetables; broth and noodles are the two elements I truly enjoy about ramen.

I ordered the Shoyu ramen with soy sauce broth. 

The broth wasn't memorable, nor where the noodles.The broth definitely  was lacking; I suspect that it wasn't marinated as long as it could have. The flavors weren't robust and to me it really tasted as if it came out of a jar. 

If you are in japantown and are looking for something fast, convenient and simple, give this place a try. Otherwise, if you are looking for something more memorable and special, I don't think this place with fulfill your expectations. 

My search for SF ramen continues.
author: She N.

description: This place is great when it's chilly out! The portions are huge and I was able to make another meal out of what I couldn't finish and took home with me. A little on the salty side, but that tends to be the case with most ramen dishes. I would love to come back here whenever I visit SF.
author: Lucy T.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend. We both got ramens and decided to split an order of the gyoza. The gyoza was clearly frozen and recently thawed. There was hot oil and water inside them and they looked pathetic. 4 sad, floppy gyoza for $5. The ramen was also very subpar. The broth was mediocre and the egg was overcooked. 

The service was also pretty poor. We were sitting outside and it was super hard to get anyone's attention. They forgot the standard toppings on my ramen, and never came to give us our checks. We had to walk up to a waitress and pay. Also, when they were clearing our table of the gyoza, the waitress took my boyfriends spoon and put it in his ramen bowl, while he was eating out of it. Very very awkward. 

Save your money - Japantown has way better places.
author: Katherine F.

description:
I've been trying to go to Suzu for the longest but there's always seem to have been too long of a wait or they were closing and wouldn't take any more names on the list.  

One Wednesday night, our party of two arrived around 8:45pm.  There were a few names in front of ours but we had only about a 10-15 minute wait. 

I decided to go with the spicy ramen ($9.95) which I found only average.  Suzu's standard ramen is typically served in a chicken and pork broth and LIMITED amount of toppings: green onions, bamboo shoots, 1 piece of pork and half a boiled egg.  In addition to the standard ramen, the spicy ramen came with chili pork slices and bean sprouts.  It seemed like only chili oil was added to my broth which took away the hearty chicken and pork flavor I was expecting.  The egg noodles were ok, not too chewey.  Though you're given a decent amount of noodles, the lack of toppings and lack of flavoring of the broth is enough for me to probably not return.

SERVICE:
I guess service here is a hit or miss.  Once our table was ready, a hostess called my name, walked into the restaurant, and kind of mumbled and walked into the kitchen.  My friend and I didn't hear her but proceeded to walk to the corner of the room to seat ourselves at the empty table.  Once we sat down, service was definitely better.  Those waitresses checked on us and made sure our water cups were filled.

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Credit cards are accepted
*Usual appetizers are offered (i.e. chicken karaage, gyoza, etc.)
*Udon or buckwheat noodle also offered
*Parking can be difficult to find but there is a lot next to Nijiya Market
author: Nicole S.

description: I usually don't write reviews, but I have to leave one for this place.   Absolutely the best Ramen bowl I've ever had! I had the Suzu Ramen Miso Ramen and it was spot on.   The dish was full of flavor!   I definitely recommend this place to anyone who comes to the area!
author: Ullanda D.

description:
I order noodles from vegetable ramen.  However, the contents mixed into a piece of chicken.
One should not have never to be a vegetarian restaurant. Meat and all together. I only cook and vegetables to Ramen is lifted, the vegetable ramen. Note of and I am sorry that I am not that can not eat instant noodles.  Separate to the value of 10 cents to contributing envelope.
We have leave a tip money separately. 

 Profane a vegetarian, finishing is not going again.

.
author: Jong Nam K.

description: Disappointing. Quality has gone down hill over the years. Used to be my favorite spot for ramen. Not anymore! Skimping on ingredients like giving you Bok Choy instead of Nori with your noodle! Who does that! The BBQ pork is dry and chewy and the ramen is soggy.
author: Wynne K.

description: So my friends and I just had this really amazing meal, and we had enough to cover the meal, but when it came to the tip we were out of money. One of my friends only had enough quarters to take the bus home. We decided to just ditch and hope the waitress wouldn't notice. About 3 minutes later as we're walking away, she comes chasing after us saying, "wait! Was everything ok?? You didn't leave a tip!" She kept staring at us until my friend offered up his quarters saying, "this is all I have." To which she just frowned, said "oh ok" and walked back to the restaurant. How did my friend get home? I'll leave that to your imagination.
author: Calvin H.

description:
Salty pork belly ramen in soy sauce soup, mushy beef in nabeyaki udon and tasteless butter corn ramen. Came here to eat with coworkers and we all left unsatisfied. 

Maybe we all ordered the wrong thing? But all I know is that I do not recommend the beef nabeyaki udon at all! The beef was coated with some kind of breading that felt like it was left in liquid too long because it was very, VERY soggy, even though that was the first thing I tired when I got it. The beef was also very salty too. Everything else in the bowl had no flavor. The soup itself was very bland. And that egg.... it was so over cooked for all three of us!

I've had a good amount of udon/ramen in my life, and this is by far the worst for me. Being inside japantown, I didn't expect the quality to be so bad. Not recommended.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Ordered the Kukuni (pork belly) with Shio (salt ramen) broth. Can you say DUH-iLL. 
Man, everything was dull. 

The broth was one dimensional. No depth, like a top ramen seasoning packet from my days as broke student. Only two leaves of bok choy as the veggies. The kukuni was so chunky fatty it left grease all over the broth. And the after taste left in mouth was metallic. Blech. 

The tea was equally dull, like bland water. (is that an oxymoron?)

Why this place is always packed is beyond me. 

The only interesting part was a homeless woman who appeared, after a customer left the table outside, picked up the left bowl and slurped it down and on her shirt in front of me. I almost puked.
author: Nik D.

description: Ordered the miso ramen here. Broth isn't bad and noodles texture was good. I think I may be biased though cause Hawaii has some awesome ramen places. The broth was good but didn't give me wow factor. Service was good here.
author: Rissa K.

description:
It's oh so delicious ramen! :)

Finally, a ramen place that I've gone to where it's not too salty. Yay! I've tried Tanpopo twice in the past & it was too salty. Mi amiga picked this place after checking on Yelp for a nearby ramen place since she was craving ramen & I was totally down for it since it's starting to get chilly now + I've got a sore throat so it'll be appropriate for some soup & noodles. 

I've always passed by this place whenever I would go to Sophie's Crepes (best crepes everrr) & it's always packed with lots of ppl. I put down my name & within 5mins we got a table outside instead of inside which is cool cause we got to ppl watch & not be stuffed up inside a small room. I got the Chashu Ramen which was soo very yummy! The noodles were bouncy (not-limpy), there was 4 big pieces of pork slices, half of an egg, bamboo shoots (I'm not really a fan of bamboo shoots tho), & a leafy veggie. The broth was the perfect balance of flavor. 

Makes me think of "The Ramen Girl"... We talked about that movie actually as we were enjoying our yummy ramens. If you haven't seen that movie, I totally highly recommend you make it as one of the movies to watch! ;)

For sure coming back again! :)
author: Amy C.

description:
MSG Alert!!!  After eating here, I experienced ALL the typical symptoms of my body reactions to MSG, heart palpitations, dry mouth, and unquenchable thirst.  I drank glasses of iced water to flush my systems why cursing at Suzu Noodle House for putting me through this discomfort.
If you like MSG in your food, go for it but for those who don't, you have been warned.
author: LY L.

description:
Came to SF for a little adventure and explored Japan central! Stopped by this tiny noodle shop even though yelpers said beware. It wasn't too bad!

Ambience (4/5): The noodle shop felt small and authentic. People around us were chattering about their day. The tables were a little too close for comfort, but not too bad.

Service (0.5/5): I would rate it a zero but at least the waiter took our order and called when we asked? Service was quick but absolutely unfriendly. She looked at us with disgust and disbelief when we asked for something and the only "thank you" we received was from another waiter on the way out. 

Food (3/5): Not the best, but definitely not the worst. Food came out quick and was really cheap with big portions.

Shoyu ramen: Soy sauce flavored. I liked it, but my boyfriend commented that it was a little too oily, I agree. Noodles were average, and the egg was not soft boiled but boiled completely. We ordered a side of chasu which was decent and a little sweet.

Karaage: Average as well, not too crispy. We asked for teriyaki sauce with it (to which the waiter said "huh?!!") But it was damn good with it!

Curry chicken don: Sauce was average, a little too salty. Not even a little meat... Strange...

Overall, would probably go here again if we were starving and it was in front of me. Other than that, I would try different restaurants. Waiters that hate life but fast and cheap service.
author: Tram B.

description: I always wondered why there is a line here. I always thought it would be like amazing and good, right? It's not. It's decent, and it's edible. There are so many other great ramen joints in the area. Sure this has the most variety, but variety does not equate quality. The soup is also below average.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
To be honest the visit to Suzu was kind of a disappointment for me. I had some expectation for their ramen and it was just OK.

I've been craving for ramen for some time so a ramen place in Japantown shouldn't be this bad, right? Well turns out the ramen was just not good. The soup was mediocre which in my eyes is the essential for a bowl of good ramen. The noodles were just too well-done that you couldn't really enjoy eating it. The toppings were still fresh and they were OK.

The service was also just alright. We got some attention but the primary engagement with the waitress was just when ordering and settling the bill.
author: Luqi P.

description: We came back again because we couldn't remember if we liked this place the first time. We were starving and wanted food now and we always see that this place is crowded so we thought ok let's give them another shot. First off the service is a little lousy, but it's an asian place and well you can't expect to be wined and dined however, anticipating needs are server 101 and they missed the mark in all areas from refilling water/tea to even getting boxes/check and I clearly see people on their phones, all bad. Then the food came out all at different times which threw off the pace for the both of us. And then the food itself was all not really that great tasting. I don't even know how to explain it but to me messing up ramen is very difficult to do. The egg was hard boiled, that's a no no for me. The noodles weren't cooked long enough and the whole dish just left little to remember. I don't think we'll be back anytime soon unless in desperation. I will say that it is a good price for food though.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Ramen Sheriff here. I gotta say 2 things about Suzu: SALTY and LONG WAIT.

The wait is almost as long as Ramen Dojo in San Mateo. The difference? Dojo is FIVE STARS and Suzu is TWO! The taste is maybe a 3, but the wait made it a 2.

WAIT: Sunday for lunch we waited for 45 minutes. Usually a wait means it's good, right? Not this place! Overrated. Probably just a long wait because it's in the infamous Japantown.

WHAT: various types of ramen, and from reading a bunch of the reviews during my lovely 45 minute wait, it looked like miso, tokyo (now called shoyu), tonkatsu, and spicy ramen were among the favorites. 

-- I tried miso [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gPUXFQkf4koX8CmWJR7wMg?select=3Fbqp51BPddALKvkLiU9EQ#k8G8yxv3qd8dQR-hJbTcYw], and it was ok, but a bit salty, as I expected from all the Yelpers. My routine was noodle, soup, tea. Noodle, soup, tea. Nonstop. My friend got the spicy ramen and said he liked it, but it was way too spicy for my taste. 

-- Noodles were a bit chewy, apparently the newsletter in the front of their restaurant (yes, I was really trying to entertain myself during the 45 min wait) said they make hand made noodles every day and hand pick their own bamboo shoots. If only their soup wasn't so salty! Work on that Suzu!! Yelpers think this place either has really salty or bland broth! 

-- Good note: order their karaage.  That was actually pretty good. 

-- I like how they give you free hard boiled (not soft boiled) egg and free tea. But tea is necessary since it's so salty haha

PRICE: $8-12 depending what you get. Miso ramen was $8.95, spicy ramen was $9.95. 

WORTH IT?: No. In SF area, I would recommend Saiwaii Ramen for their spicy garlic miso. But best ramen in the bay is Ramen Dojo. Check out my Ramen list! After all, they call me the Ramen Sheriff! ;)
author: Raquel Y.

description: This place is always busy and I figured it was due to good food but now I think it's only because of the convenient location. I had the Spicy Miso Ramen. I was so disappointed! It lacked salt entirely. Generous serving of well cooked noodles but only one piece of pork in proportion. The hard boiled egg was overcooked (see green ring in pic). The Wonton Shoyu Ramen was much better. Simple and warming plus not lacking salt probably from the salt in the soy sauce based soup. Still, the egg and small sliver of pork wasn't very enticing.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Ramen was good. I had the miso ramen, extra spicy.
There was no wait to get in on a Wednesday at 5:45pm.
author: grep w.

description:
This place is your standard Japanese noodle house. I wasn't blown away with any of the dishes but it was enough to satisfy my cravings.

We came during the cherry blossom festival, so there was definitely a bit of a wait. You should write your name down as early as possible, they keep a sign in sheet at the front. 

The restaurant is very tiny so you may find yourself a little cramped, I wouldn't recommend it for larger parties. It's perfect if you're dining alone or with just one other person. 

For the food, I ordered the Nabeyaki Udon. I'm a huge fan of shrimp tempura and I was slightly disappointed that there was only one in the bowl, but the one that they do give you is pretty large. And my advice is to eat it quickly unless you want the shrimp to become soggy in the broth! 

The broth itself was decent, again, nothing mind blowing, it wasn't bursting with flavor but it was a nice soy sauced based broth. I didn't find myself sipping it at the end though, I'd say it was more on the bland side so I thought it needed just a little bit more flavor. 

The prices are pretty decent, about 10 dollars per dish. I may come back again if I'm craving noodles, but I would probably skip this place because that is the only type of dish hey serve. The other restaurants in the mall have udon, ramen, and various other kinds of Japanese food, so you're kind of limited here. If you want a combination of sushi AND noodles, there are a lot of other Japanese restaurants that will offer you that.
author: Sara W.

description:
Stopped in for a quick lunch while roaming around JTown. 
Spicy ramen caught my eye.
Ladies were nice. Noodles a little more al-dente than I would have liked. 
Ch shu was dry
Spicy broth was a bit fatty and not as spicy as anticipated. 
Maybe I'm just used to Lava ramen by the ball park or Sawaii ramen closer to my hood.
author: PreciousSwt P.

description:
I wasn't expecting an amazing meal, but I thought this restaurant with a 3.5 star average would at least yield a decent bowl of ramen. Wrong...

My bf and I only had dinner here because it's conveniently located near Kabuki and we were in a rush to catch our movie. We waited about 15 minutes for a table, which is probably only because this place attracts tourists visiting Japantown. 

We both ordered the chashu ramen with shoyu broth and were both disappointed. The noodles and pork were so tough, making them really difficult to chew. Also the pork had no fat on it at all and the broth was basically soy sauce and water. Meh. I definitely would not come back.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Tips all ramen have tasted... The last star would have been given if the waitresses were a little nicer and more on point with refills for water and tea! We were a party of 9 and took up lost the restaurant so you would think that getting drinks would be a little easier. 
But back to the ramen!... I had the spicy ramen it was the perfect amount of spicy! You have many add ons to choose from but I didn't not add a thing. The sprouts that come with it were just the right touch. The noodles were fresh and the broth was not too oily or salty. 
Definitely my new fav ramen spot
author: Angie G.

description: Went hungover for ramen.  I've never had ramen fresh like that, but had heard of it. It was very very good, and the portion is VERY generous. I also had fried baby squid to start, also very very good. There were a lot of different kind on ramen to pick from so I told the waitress to give me whichever she liked the best, and she picked well! She also was very nice and did a great job!
author: Ashlee S.

description:
"Wow, that's a long line," I said, implying that this could either be really good or just mediocre and that we would be buying into the hype.

And as usual, we bought into the hype.

Hook, line, and sinker.

I had the ramen noodles and added the unagi don. Both seemed very average, and the unagi don looked like a kids dish. It was like 1/4 of a unagi, or in nigiri speak...two pieces of nigiri.

I didn't notice anything special about the broth or the noodles, and to me the portions were small.

I kept thinking I was waiting in line to burn calories, and when I got the food I guess I was right.

But the food was okay, and okay means 3 stars.
author: Jack R.

description:
Wow, I don't think I've ever given one star before-- but Suzu earned it. My husband and I came by one afternoon to the restaurant only half full. Our waitress proceeded to give us literally the most rude service we've ever received. I won't go into a long litany detailing every outright rude or sarcastic comment, or every dramatic sigh-- but suffice it to say that my husband and I were so shocked at this woman's behaviour that we genuinely thought it must either be a racial thing (we're POC) or this woman is just trying to get herself fired for some reason. Either way, Suzu, please hire better staff!

As for the food, we only had the vegetarian ramen, which was very bland. However ramen is based very much on using animal broths, so that may not be reflective of their entire menu.
author: Sanya A.

description: Beware! She slams menus when she goes back into the kitchen! Attitude was so horrible!
author: Zoah Z.

description:
I've been here twice now and this place is AWESOME! 
I had the spicy ramen tonight and it was soooooo good. I've also had the chicken veggie ramen in the past. Other dishes tonight - the chashu ramen, the wonton ramen, the gyoza and the tempura = all delicious.  Great prices too.  Service is not really attentive but it's not that kind of restaurant. If you want good ramen, this is a great place to get it.

TIP:  For $2 you can get extra noodles.  Worth it!
author: Karen N.

description:
Definitely coming back to this place !
My friends and I were a group of 8 and we came around 8:30ish at night (give or take a few minutes). we had to wait, but as we were waiting, we got menus and the waitress took our orders so that when we got seated, our food would just come right out!

I got the char su (sp?) miso ramen and let me tell you, the pork was on point! The broth was really good as well. The noodles were sweet, but not overpowering. They also give you a lot, which is saying a lot because of all the ramen places I've been to, this was the only bowl I couldn't finish!

They have good combo deals when you order a noodle dish or something. Definitely going to try them out next time I get the chance!
author: Vanessa M.

description: the seating was pretty tight so we had to wait a bit and they messed up on our order, the ramen itself wasnt the best... i only had one piece of bbq pork while my cousin had four. the miso broth was really salty and the noodles were soggy. Also, the service requires parties 5+ to pay for tip
author: Maily N.

description:
Not the biggest fan of ramen, but I had a sudden craving. We usually go to tanpopo on Buchanan but decided to try something new!

I actually like Suzu! The wait wasn't long, and the food came out pretty quick. I ordered the katsu ramen with shoyu base and added corn. It was satisfying, it got a little salty at the end.. But whatev.

We also ordered the unagi don for an additional $5 not bad, totally worth sharing as an appetizer (that's what we did lol). 

Anyway, I'll probably be back.. If I ever get the sudden urge for ramen!
author: L F.

description:
Ramen was alright. I ordered the ramen with karaage and Gyoza. Both sides were below expectations & tough. 

I also ordered the combination with the chicken curry. Chicken curry is normally served as chicken katsu with curry sauce. This was chicken minced pieces. There was too little meat. 

In short don't order the Gyoza, karaage and chicken curry. 

2 stars for the pricing.
author: Josh P.

description:
The food is decent. But not ramen dojo, orenchi or santouka quality. I had the spicy ramen, which was pretty satisfying for my hangover. 

Prices are okay. I also remember having to wait to be seated since it was a weekend. 

Would I come back? Maybe, but there's no urge. At least I got a cool Instagram pic and some soup for my hangover.
author: Noji N.

description:
2.5 stars.

I was craving for Santouka and was about to go out to SJ, but realized that I had been trying to go to Suzu forever.  This place has the oddest hours and every time I come, it's closed.

There was no wait that Thursday evening.  I had the chasu ramen while the bf had the karaage ramen.  Mine came with four generous slices of pork, seaweed, green onion, and bamboo.

Too bad I couldn't eat the four generous slices of pork!  It was *ridiculously* salty and if I say it's salty, it's REALLY salty because I like to over salt everything.  The broth was also salty and other than the saltiness it was bland and tasteless and extremely light.  The noodles were OK, but a little undercooked and hard.

Bf sorta enjoyed his ramen, but he enjoys everything.

Service was kinda unfriendly.

I was SO thirsty afterwards, thirstier than after eating at a Chinese restaurant that uses MSG.  What a disappointment.
author: Vivian H.

description: The wait for this restaurant is pretty long for only decent food. The ramen itself was okay, but lacking portions such as meat and toppings where the waitress also messed up on our appetizer order but still made us pay. They also automatically add a tip fee if you have 4 or more people which is totally not worth it as service is pretty terrible. Probably would not go back again as Japantown is filled with many other (and better) ramen places.
author: Christine N.

description: I like the food and it deserves 5 stars.  The only thing is that there is a waitress who misunderstands the customers. This had happened twice now
author: H S.

description:
*Sees a packed restaurant*
"Honey, there's a lot of people in there. It must be good."
*Walks in Suzu Noodle House*

*Sees a crowd outside Suzu"
"Yo, that place looks CRACKIN'!"
"Yah, bro we're only in SF once so let's check it out."
*Puts name on waitlist*

.....
.....
.....

One of my friends was craving ramen but he didn't want to drive down to San Mateo so we ended up at Suzu. There's always a crowd outside Suzu so I thought it had to be good. For me, a tale-tell sign of a good Asian restaurant is if you see native patrons. There was zero at Suzu. 

Suzu specializes in ramen, udon and soba with house-made noodles. There are also various dons (rice bowls) and curries on the menu. Can't decide? They have combos were you can mix and match ramen, udon or soba with a don of your choice. 

Ok, ok so I know ordering a don in a noodle house is like ordering fish at a steakhouse but let me explain. I'm allergic to MSG so I try to stay away from soupy/saucy Asian foods. Also, I was eyeing the other table's ramen and the portion of noodles seemed very large which immediately set off in my head that it's probably "quantity" over "quality". If I'm going to get a MSG attack, it better be worth it and this case it didn't look to be. 

CHICKEN KATSU DON - $10.95
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gPUXFQkf4koX8CmWJR7wMg?select=p_01XBxOX6m_4WGs0DBv1w
One breaded chicken cutlet was sliced and placed top of a Mount Everest mountain of rice and drizzled with tonkatsu sauce. The katsu was crisp and tender but very bland. The tonkatsu sauce tasted straight from a bottle as it had that syrupy consistency. It was nothing that I couldn't get at Nijiya Market down the block in the pre-packed food section for half the price.
 
My friend, the human vacuum (but never gains weight) ordered the ramen combo with a katsu don. He normally inhales his food and finishes our leftovers. This time he didn't even finish his own food. My other friend ordered the curry don which she didn't like. I tried a sip of the broth and it was awful. The broth was ALL salt with no depth of flavor or spice. It tasted like it was made from a powder packet. You can actually still taste the raw curry powder in the broth like it wasn't cooked long enough in the broth. 

Service was equally as bad. The rude waitresses passed our table over 10 times without coming to take our order. It wasn't a big deal at first since we were busy chatting. We had to wave our hands in the air to get their attention. It took about 15 minutes to get our food. 

2.5 STARS rounded up to 3 STARS for filling my tummy without an MSG attack. 

Just because a restaurant has a crowd outside does NOT mean it's good. Thanks for the lesson, Suzu. 

OTHER NOTES:
*Small restaurant with 30 seats
*It's always crowded even on non-peak hours
*Expect a 30-45 minute wait during peak hours on weekends 
*CC's Accepted
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I've been here twice; the first time with my son, who attended SFSU and loved coming here. Years later, he's living in Cambodia and I went back to SF/Bay Area to visit my brother & his family. I went to Suzu early, to be able to shop Japantown Mall and other shops in that area. The ramen was as delicious and filling as I remembered and there was no wait for a table around 1pm mid-week. I finished my ramen bowl and couldn't even try the gelato shop afterwards.
author: Karen O.

description:
I've  been here twice so far and have enjoyed my selections. There's little things here and there I would nit pick about, but overall a good place to grab ramen if you're in jtown. 

First of all, on my second visit it had a horrible smell on the corner booth that I had to move to the table by the door to move away from it. The odor smelled a lot like piss, which made no sense since we literally walked in when it opened and was the first few customers to arrive. I don't know if it's the water they use to wipe down the table or its been there, but the odor was so strong I moved over to the table by the door for fresh air. But there was another couple behind us, who stayed at their table so I'm not sure if it was just the table I was at. Either way, horrible representation of the restaurant to be smelling like piss inside the facility.

The bowls here are pretty big, really satisfying. I really love the broth here. It's not too salty and doesn't taste like a bowl of sodium. I love drinking the broth on its own even without the noodles. The first time I got the spicy miso ramen which I think is just extra bean spourts in the bowl and second time I had the one with spicy miso with spicy green onion in it, whichever that was. I'm a little disappointed that they serve a hard boiled egg oppose to a soft boiled one. Overall, the broth and the noodles are good. I'm not too big of a fan of the extra toppings I had chose, but I could bypass that factor. Nothing really special though. They have all these "different" types of ramen, but its really just an extra topping in it that makes it "different". Expected more in the bowl. A few of the selections definitely could be combined with other ones to make one kind of bowl. For that, it loses a star and another one for their bad smell in the restaurant. Service is okay, no complaints.
author: Denise N.

description:
I went to Japantown to meet with my friend and we decided to eat ramen. We choose Suzu because she hasn't been there. I thought there would be a long waiting lists but, it was pass lunch time, so there's no wait. We were greated by (I think) Japanese woman and sit in the corner. The tea came right away after we sat down. 

We little bit confused with all the ramen choices, because all sounds appetizing. I and my friend got suzu ramen since they put karaage and gyoza in it. I ordered agedashi tofu as appetizer and my friend order kakuni don as a combo for her noodle. 

The food was just ok if you compare with other ramen place around.. The ramen was little overcooked, they gave us hard boiled egg, and the broth was just ok. I think I can taste something in the broth that I can't figure that out, it taste like bamboo shoot liquid. I and my friend was talking about spicy food, thats why I asked for sriracha, but they gave me other chili (not sriracha) because they said that I have to pay a dollar extra to get the spicy paste.. Nevermind then. It already tasted better with the chili sour thing.

The waiter was pretty attentive, she asked if we were doing okay and came back couple times to refill the tea.. 

It was $19.50 not including tips for one suzu ramen with agedashi tofu..
author: Cynthia S.

description: I have been to Suzu a few times and the food is generally very good.  The service is also generally pretty lacking.  My last visit was the worst I've seen it and resulted in my wife and I being insulted by one of the waitresses.  We won't be coming back due to the general lack of customer service.  Shame as the food is pretty good.
author: david f.

description:
Okay, I definitely remember this place being a four star place but I can see why it's getting bumped down a star or a half star now. The wait was rather long, and I got rather hungry. Don't know if that makes a difference (usually does) but my experience was average.

I came in with my girlfriend on a visit to SF and I been going to SF for years since I lived in Norcal, and would see this place since it opened but never really went and tried it. I ordered the Curry udon here and it was basically udon in a miso base that was meant for ramen and with a slap of curry on top of it. The only other time I had curry udon was when it was like udon in like a curry sauce not soup. I never seen it like this, I always seen it the way I had it before. Anyways it was a bit saltier, maybe because of the miso and curry combined. My girlfriend just get some miso ramen which I thought was whatever. Nothing was extreme. I have had way better in Japan and down in socal. I want to be impressed not disappointed Japan town.

I give this place a 3 stars because at least the service was decent and the food was average. I want to be wowed if I ever come back.
author: Tuan T.

description:
Great place. The ramen was amazing. The broth was not too salty and the noodles were spot on. 

Ordered the Suzu ramen and curry rice chicken. The gayoza was a little soggy but that wasn't too if of a problem. I ate outside of he place and it's not bad. Inside looks nice and cozy. 

10/10 would eat again
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Didn't seem like a very busy spot. Probably we went on an off-time. 

Veggie tempura was VERY OILY! But the ramen and udon tasted good.
author: Vikram A.

description:
As soon as we sat we were served hot tea. Nice. Typically other restaurants want to take our order first. We enjoyed the kimchi but would prefer if it was a little more crunchy. Not spicey enough. That's why one star dropped. 

Kar age was nice and hot, crunchy and tasty. Did I mention juicy after one bite. Yes we enjoyed this appetizer. 

The pork belly ramen shoyu was served in a large-sized bowl. Didn't care for the fat on the pork. Pork was not tender enough but enjoyed the dish. Portion was plentiful. Soup base was okay. I've had better but am not complaining. It served its purpose. 

Service at 4pm was perfect. No wait and food was served fast.  I recommend and will return.
author: Michelle P.

description:
The food is pretty decent here, but there is limited seating inside the tiny restaurant! Parking can be tough on the street too, but I guess that is just SF in general.

We ordered the butter/corn ramen with the pork belly appetizer. The pork belly was OK, but the ramen noodles were just the right firmness and the broth was quite tasty. But when my friend tried to order their tonkotsu broth, the server let us know that they don't serve that anymore... sad, I was looking forward to trying that too!
author: Nina H.

description:
This place is for tourists who doesn't know any better. Unfortunately I fell for it as well.

First thing I noticed when I enter Japan Town is the door ads for this place. Since I was super hungry and the weather was super windy I thought ramen would be perfect.

The service was so-so. The only reason why I say that is that I was standing in the door way for quite awhile before someone made eye contact with me. Is that an Asian thing? When I did made contact, I told the hostess that it's a table for 3 and she asked if I had put my name down even though at the time, the place was not completely full.

Besides the food portion, I find the food rather bland. We ordered the meat veggie ramen, the spicy ramen with green onions and nabeyaki udon. Only the nabeyaki udon was somewhat decent tasting.
author: Jingwen Y.

description:
It seemed a little strange at first to find gyoza and karage swimming around in my ramen, but it ended up being my favorite part of the Suzu shoyru ramen. (I would recommend putting it off to the side so it doesn't get too soggy!)

The ramen quality (base, noodle texture) by itself doesn't really wow me, but when the Suzu is put all together, it makes for a pretty enjoyable and filling meal!
author: Christiana C.

description:
Tried another ramen place today! This little noodle house is tiny but certainly busy. I came here for lunch and every table was taken. There was a small waiting list and a few people waiting already, however don't worry! They are FAST! The bf and I didn't wait that long (maybe 10 minutes or so) before we were seated. The waitress brought us tea and menus. We ordered and probably less than 10 minutes later, our food arrived. I was impressed at their speed! Same with the taste!

FOOD
-Ramens have a choice of 3 base soup flavors - soy sauce, miso, or sea salt.
-I ordered the Kakuni Ramen (BRAISED PORK BELLY) ramen with a soy sauce base. This was an explosion of deliciousness in your mouth. The braised pork belly was so tender and WELL marinated in flavor. It was sweet which complimented my soy sauce broth. The ramen came with half a boiled egg, 1 leaf of bok choy, and the usual green onions, etc. I think next time I'll add more veggies into my order (an additional $1/$2 or something). 
-Portion size was just right. I wasn't overwhelmingly full after (which I guess is probably a good thing, hah!) 
-Broth wasn't too salty :) 

SETTING
-Small little restaurant, so they are very tight on space
-Japanese Ramen place run by Thai.
-Given the busy setting and limited space, service is really fast! (Our waitress kindly urged us to sign our receipt after handing us back our credit card + bill). I looked up and saw the crowd of people outside and understood.
-Friendly staff. We were greeted upon arrival and departure. Tea was refilled without asking. 

I'm happy to report I've found another ramen restaurant that I approve of. Will be back!
author: Grace J.

description:
I come here for hiyashi soba (cold soba noodles with veggies and some chicken karaage).  It's a great option when you crave noodles but it's too hot for ramen.  The veggies were fresh and the karaage was hot from the fryer.  The portion wasn't too big.  I was bummed the egg was fully cooked instead of soft boiled.  Most ramen places make soft boiled eggs.

I'd recommend this place if you want an alternative to all of the sushi places upstairs but something still Japanese.  Be prepared to wait during meal times, though.  Usually there's a 20-30 minute wait and you have to write your name down on the list.
author: Christine L.

description:
When I go to Japantown, I always notice the big crowds waiting in front of Suzu Noodle House. I decided to try this ramen joint out with my sister because of our ramen obsession. We ordered 2 shoyu ramen bowls with an order of karaage chicken. Unfortunately, this ramen disappointed. Some of the ramen noodles were not cooked fully. The broth was ok, but not extremely flavorful. Also, a few pieces of chicken were overcooked. However, I liked the egg and other veggies within the broth. 

Sadly, Suzu Noodle House did not meet my expectations. It was an average ramen place with the advantage of being located in Japantown. Regardless, it's not worth the 30 minute wait. If you truly want good ramen, you can find better places elsewhere
author: Jessica E.

description: This was the the second highlight of my trip to San Francisco. I ordered the chasu ramen with miso soup.  The noodles were al detente. The place is very cozy and fills up quick.   The soup itself was very rich in flavor. I will definitely make this a stop in my next trip to beautiful San Francisco.
author: HeyYou W.

description: Had the Pork Belly Ramen with a shoyu broth. It was underwhelming. The noodles were relatively thin and uninteresting. The broth was ok but not very complicated. The pork belly serving was very generous, but over-seasoned and cut too large. The only other ingredients were two pieces of bok choy, a few strips of bamboo shoot, half a boiled egg, and a little bit of seaweed. It wasn't terrible, but I'm thinking there is better ramen to be had in Japantown. The service was fine, but I was there after 1:00 on a weekday.
author: Larry L.

description:
Ramen in SF always disappoints. Why are all the amazing ramen places in San Mateo, Oakland, Hayward, San Jose, Santa Clara and not a single 4 star or up one in SF?

LA and NYC have the best ramen in the nation as well, what gives SF? Your sushi and everything else is amazing, can't you do a delish Japanese bowl of pork broth noodle soup for $9-13 and make it great?

Suzu isn't bad, don't get me wrong, it's inside the popular Japantown Japanese mall, it's just not very good. I'm spoiled by the top list:

Ippudo
Dojo
Orenchi
Parlor
Himawari
Kotetsu
Yokohama
etc

The chicken karaage ramen is tasty, is very big in size, but the broth just lacks. Their pork belly is the same, overly fatty pieces, but tasty, and again, lacking in broth flavors.
author: Chuck N.

description: $5 food for $32. Ordered the Edi Ramen, which had 3 shrimp, half an egg, a leaf of Bol Choy, and one bamboo shoot. You'd think for $12, you'd get more toppings. I added a extra chicken curry bowl, which had no chicken in it. Maybe they meant chicken flavored curry? Gf just had the miso soup, and it had the minimal above toppings, plus one piece of pork, that she shared because she felt bad for me. All noodles, average soup. Thumbs down.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I'm a big fan of ramen, but unfortunately was disappointed by the spicy miso ramen I had here. No standouts in terms of toppings (added corn) and the soup seemed greasy. 

The service, on the other hand, was great!
author: Linda X.

description:
They specialize in udon, soba and ramen noodles here.  I came for the ramen.  They have three different broths based with shuyo (soy sauce), shio (sea salt) or miso (soybean paste) made of chicken and pork.  My bf and I both chose the shio broth.  His was pork belly ramen with extra noodles.  It came with a boiled egg, green onions and bamboo shoots.  He took it out to the bottom of the bowl.  I did likewise to my kimchi tofu spicy ramen with a fried shrimp added.  

They have a pretty plentiful selection of ramen here.  However, much of it is pretty simple.  -not loaded with stuff unless you do the extras which can add up quickly when a bowl starts at $10 plus.  Apparently, I chose one that came with nothing other than kimchi, tofu and green onion.  Oh, well.  I still enjoyed it.  

What else here?  The service is pretty non-existant.  She seats you with your tea and water, brings your food and is never to be seen again unless you can get her attention in the vicinity.  One small glass of water and tea for each of us.  That's fine.  It reflected in the tip and really we're not inclined to return despite the hearty ramen.  We don't go out to eat for self-service.  Besides that, this is just a tiny joint in the Japantown mall.  There are a million other choices around here.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Nice place to sit and rest if you are tired from walking  & get a warm bowl of ramen in the midst of all the cool shops in Japantown.  Servings are huge, service is prompt but overall the broths are just ok in flavor.  We tried all three- soy, miso and sea salt based.  The sea salt is the lightest in flavor.  The things we did enjoy were the seaweed salad and kimchee.
author: R A.

description: Horrible food! Some of the worst ramen in the city. Please do not eat here. This place used to be great, but no longer.
author: Eliza F.

description: Shoyu ramen is a basic dish. It was my first time having a dish from this restaurant. Overall it was well prepped and for what it was worth I only had half and still have some left over
author: Josh S.

description: We came here at around 9PM on a Sunday. It was crowded and the place was small so we had to wait 30 mins, which was expected so I didn't mind much there. The food (ramen) was okay-ish, not as great as the other ramen places I tried. The broth was very very salty, my ramen and are my family's ramens. The noodle is the regular egg-noodle, nothing special. The service was alright since it was kinda late and crowded. Tips were added automatically with a large party (I suspect 6 or more people). Overall, NOT a place I would recommend for a good ramen bowl.
author: Eva H.

description: I tried the ramen here last week and it tasted very good! Totally different from the instant ones and I could actually taste the difference! The texture of the ramen good and it was slightly chewy; the strands were so long that I feel like it never ends as I was eating it. My friends also got the takoyaki and it was crispy on the outside and full of fillings in the inside! It was a bit too salty but I would definitely buy it again; I would recommend it! I didn't get to try the salt soup base, but the shoyu soup base was good. The miso soup was okay, but if you're not a fan of miso, you probably shouldn't get the miso soup base here either. My friend who didn't like miso tried it and she still didn't like it.
author: Betty C.

description: horrible service, ok food, although generous portion. i ordered spicy miso ramen it was ok. but I wouldnt eat here again bye bye suzu
author: Karen T.

description:
Food: ordered the gyoza as appetizer, small size of the katsu don and tempura udon. 

Service: restaurant was starting to get busy but we got to sit down before having to wait! we were given water and hot tea soon after and our server took our order and was able to answer a question I had. the potstickers came out first, my katsu don next, and then after a moment my boyfriend got his udon (with the tempura on the side - thank you)!!

Experience: I am definitely coming here every single time I want katsu don or udon because our dishes were very delicious and the service was great. also I believe we spent less than $20 on the both of us, which never happens!!
author: Anastasia A.

description:
I've been dying to have a nice hot bowl of ramen here ever since my friend told me how much he loves this place.  Since my bf & I had an appointment for a massage at nearby Therapeia we decided to dine in at Suzu.  We got there no later than 10 minutes after it's 11:30 opening on Sunday & though it's a small restaurant, it was already packed.  We did however luck out because one of the two tables outside were free.  

I liked their extensive menu, I'm used to not seeing so many choices for Ramen.  And I have to admit that their rice dishes looked good too.  I settled on the Suzu Ramen ($12.95) and he got the Chicken Karaage Ramen ($10.95).  We waited awhile for our food, about 20-25 minutes, usually ramen is pretty quick!  My Suzu Ramen had chicken karaage, two pieces of pork and two fried gyoza.  Plenty of the juicy chicken and the gyoza still remained fairly crispy.  The pork was so tasty, probably the tastiest pork that I've had in my ramen!  They give plenty of al dente noodles.  Both our ramen came with an egg, green onions and bamboo shoots.  The bamboo shoots needed to be cooked longer however.  

After bf finished his bowl he said two words that totally shocked me, I'm full!  He was shocked himself too because he's never full from ramen or pho.  So, Suzu must give bigger portions!  

I can't wait to get another bowl of ramen here!  The high prices and the wait is what keeps it from being a 5, at least for now.
author: Cat C.

description: I enjoyed my experience here!  I had the shoyu ramen with pork belly.  I loved it.  The tempura was good too.  Quick and friendly service.  Would come here again!
author: Bayilani V.

description:
Absolutely terrible customer service: it was just me and my 5 year old daughter stopping by for lunch. We didn't get checked upon once by our server (she replied later saying that she was checking on us "with her eyes"), we were given ONE fork for two - I never got a chance to ask for a second one because server came to us and clearly "checking with eyes" doesn't mean "reading minds". No help with anything. We had to wait longer than anyone else to even get our order in, because we weren't worthy enough, apparently. And then, after I had to ask for a bag to carry out our leftovers (I did not want to spend anymore time there), she sassily responded "okay", as she was walking away, and then added that there is a charge for a bag (which I don't care about, it's fine, it's the way she was treating us and the way she was talking to us). 
Everyone else seemed to be worthy of her time and attention, but us, a mother with a child, no - we only got glanced at a few times. 
I'm so frustrated and I will never ever suggest anyone to go there. 
Oh, and they now don't pick up the phone, because, yes, I would love to speak with a manager as soon as possible. 
Experiences like this one should never take place in customer service.

Update: they finally picked up the phone, but there is no manager on duty. Apparently they don't know her (manager's) schedule, she doesn't show up for at least 7 days straight (those are waitress's words) and clearly doesn't care about what's going on at her restaurant. 
I will be calling back tomorrow at their suggestion.
author: Karina C.

description: Holy Yum. New favorite noodle place in SF. Get there early for lunch before 11am to put your name on the waiting list. I got the Meat Ramen with Chicken and Shoyu. It's amazing!
author: Merlino T.

description: I got the Suzu Ramen with an extra egg. When I got the bowl of ramen, I immediately regretted  getting the extra egg. I may be spoiled, but I expect higher end ramen restaurants to marinate and soil-boil their eggs. The eggs they use are almost completely hard-boiled and not marinated. The chashu was also disappointing. It was bland and tough to chew. On the other hand, the broth was actually decent.  When you pick a ramen flavor, you also specify which type of broth you want (out of shio, miso, and shoyu). I got the shio flavor. What I like about the soup is that it is not very salty and I can taste the chicken stock. My favorite part about the ramen is actually the two pieces of gyoza they put in it. They were large and stuffed with vegetable. The vegetables were seasoned to perfection and wrapped in fried dough.
author: Wayne C.

description:
I will be honest, I have mixed feelings about this place! 

We came in and signed our name on the wait-list, but even as we were walking back to the restaurant and we could hear our name being called, they automatically skipped us and made us sign up AGAIN for another 30 minute wait. I was not happy at all about that!

We were eventually seated outdoors of the restaurant, majority of my friends ordered ramen (Miso and Tonkatsu) with one of my other friends ordering Kaarage. I personally had the Miso-Ramen but spicy. I felt there was an overwhelming amount of oil in that broth, and it actually left a strange after-taste in my mouth. Honestly, I ate the noodles but left the broth, it actually disappointed me a lot. 

There was also a lack of toppings or anything for that, all I felt was in there was one piece of what looked to be bok choy? They didn't even give me any other toppings!

Overall, I can do better than this for the $10 I paid. 

+1 star because my friend really liked her tonkatsu ramen. 

It is located in the plaza/mall (downstairs!), parking would be in the garages or street parking, but it really depends if there are any events going on that day.
author: Mariah L.

description: I heard this ramen place with good and since I was in Japan town I had to try.  There was a bit of a wait, so I was hoping that it would be worth it!  Had the Sesame ramen and also ordered the takoyaki.  The takoyaki was actually pretty meh.  It was kinda mushy and I would probably not order it again.  We sat on the outside tables on the side and service there wasn't very good.  The ramen itself was not too special.  I love ramen but if I was every craving it, I don't think this would be close to the top choices of ramen places I would go to.  I was expecting it to be better based on the long line that was here.
author: Teresa W.

description: Decent noodle soup go-to.  I had their lightly-salted shio kakuni, a bowl I'd say Pinoys would find quite familiar:  kakuni like pork adobo, clear broth so much like tinola, and noodles like in mami but a bit more and a tad better.   I still prefer Hanabi in Burlingame and even the three San Mateo ramen group, but like Hanabi, Suzu's bowl did not break the scale the next day, and I like that.
author: Erick ..

description:
A nice little place on the corner of the mall.  There were five of us and we sat at the entrance with an extra chair added to the end.  The ramens were good, nothing out of the ordinary.  Avg prices around $10-12 for ramen.
+++ 
With an additional $3 you can add on katsu don, kakuri don and for $5 you can add an unagi don, which is great if the ramen does not fill you up
The add ons are top of a small bowl of rice. So we were stuffed.
Extra add ons were about $1
---
We expected some garlic in the add ons but no garlic was on the menu
We were a group of 5 and they charge 18% service charge for 5 or more, kinda steep for lunch
Dissapointed about the egg, as it was a regular half of a boiled egg.  Guess I am spoiled by the half cooked orangy yolk eggs which I've had in other  ramen places.
Also found only one slice of chashu pork, abit stingy, I must say.

Overall a good experience, nothing to rave about. May go back to try other items at a later time.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Even though this place is located in Japantown and there might be other nearby places to get ramen, don't be deterred by the long line outside Suzu! There must be a long line for a reason, right?!

I used to come here quite a bit when I was younger since I hung out in Japantown fairly often. Each type of ramen has incredibly flavorful broth, and I love that they put egg and seaweed in it. The addition of corn never hurts either! My favorite has always been the Chicken Karaage ramen since the karaage they make is great and goes well with the broth. I'm also a big fan of their curry ramen. It's a bit oily, but it has a nice kick to it and the broth has lots of flavor. It's definitely a nice change of pace when you don't feel like getting "normal" ramen such as miso, tonkatsu, etc...

The restaurant is pretty small, which explains why the line can get pretty long at times. There also aren't a whole lot of big tables here either, so don't expect coming here in a large group. Other than that though, I've always loved the ramen here, as it's quickly become my favorite spot for ramen in Japantown. I'd highly recommend checking it out!
author: Aaron W.

description:
Good ramen for a reasonable price. There is a variety of ramen or soba noodles on the menu.  I personally like the miso ramen and get chicken karaage on the side. There are more choices for appetizers too. The croquettes are abgood bet but you only get 2 pieces in one order.

The place is quite small and it's popular so plan your meal accordingly since they don't take reservations. Put your name down on the sign up sheet and roam around Japantown. Go take pictures in the photo booth or belt out 'Welcome to the Jungle' at one of the several karaoke places in the center. Enjoy!
author: Andrew M.

description: Soooo delicious. We lucked out and did not have any wait time. Get the miso spicy ramen! You won't regret it.
author: Msha D.

description: Not sure what all of the bad reviews are about, this place is great to stop in and have a solid bowl of ramen, udon, or soba noodles. Fast service, in and out in 30 minutes, if you really need to be. Good hot sake, green tea. No complaints on my end! Definitely stop here if you're hanging out in Japantown for the afternoon.
author: Stephanie L.

description: There is this old saying about follow the crowd if you want good food.  It works well for me most of the time, but not this time at Suzu Noodle House.  It's never easy to write a bad review, but I must say the food at this place were just plain bad.  The ramen from broth to toppings failed on so many level that I don't even know where to begin.  The worst part was the weird and slimy tasting meat they called beef.  This is the first time I can't finish a bowl of ramen.  I decided to cut my losses, and saved some room to go somewhere else.
author: Roger W.

description:
Very solid ramen and Japanese food in general. 

I had the spicy negi ramen and the mixed tempura. 

It's by no means the best ramen out there, but it is a consistent, high quality Japanese restaurant with a large ramen selection. 

It's the kind of place you would find under a subway station in Tokyo where locals come to eat day in day out. 

For a good, affordable, comfort food type meal, this is the spot.
author: Boaz N.

description:
The wait can be annoying... really annoying. There are lots of fun things to see though while you wait like that cute moche stand nearby or you can stare at the Japanese hair salon to see what type of fashionable trends they are performing... it's always so interesting.
The noodles are great and audente. Although it isn't the curly kind of noodle and doesn't seem very ramen bouncy like feel to it. The toppings are really not impressive. The slice of meat is not a good cut and it is over done to the point that it is tough. The soup base is good though. I had the ship and liked it a lot. It wasn't too oily or too salty. Nice and clean. The shoyu soup is also good; the soy sauce gives the broth a sort of meaty taste to the broth.
Service is prompt and not delivered with a smile. They are all about getting the food to you and getting you out. This is an ok place.
author: Anna C.

description:
The plastic shrink wrap from the ramen package was cooked and partially melted in my soup. My main concern about this was the possibility - or not, I wouldn't know - of plastic compounds leaching into my food. Our server said that she'd never seen that happen. In my five or so times eating here, neither have I. We weren't charged, and she offered that I choose another dish.

Aside from that funky occurrence, my friends and I have had consistently positive experiences here. But you know, from now on I'm going to swish my chopsticks around a bit, covertly probing my food before digging in.
author: Dan B.

description: Suzu Noodle House is one of my favorite spots in Japantown as of now. They have a pretty diverse menu with more traditional ramens as well as udon and sobas. For a little extra money, you can make your noodle bowl a combo with the addition of a donburi of your choice. I had the kimchi nabeyaki soba, which came in a hotpot that kept my food piping hot for the entire time. It was a good balance of kimchi, vegetables, and soba, not leaving me overly full. It felt like a homey dish that I would eat at home, not loaded with sodium or extra flavorings. My boyfriend had the tonkatsu ramen, which came with perfectly chewy noodles. He also had the curry chicken donburi, another homey bowl of comfort food. The wait can get extensive sometimes as people know the best spots to go to in Japantown, but it's definitely worth the wait!
author: Ashley T.

description:
Located in the very back of the Japantown shopping center, this little noodle house offers an array of udon and ramen. Although there aren't a lot of tables, the wait for one isn't terrible due to quick service and fast turnaround.

There aren't size options to choose from, but my bowl of veggie and meat ramen came in a much larger bowl than the bowl of Suzu ramen. They charge for $1 for add-ins like an egg, corn, and even green onions, and $2 for things like extra noodles and shrimp. I felt $1 is a little much for a regular egg. It's not soft boiled and deliciously gooey and runny, either. It's already pre-cut, too. I guess I'm just spoiled by Orenchi in the South Bay. My broth was a little more oily than I'm used to, but the broth of the Suzu ramen was actually quite good.

Overall, I would probably come back again if I'm in need of a quick noodle fix.
author: Vivian L.

description: 20-25 seat noodle house in Japanese shopping complex, not unlike the hawker markets in Singapore. Casual environment. Fantastic $10-14 ramen bowls. Miso broth w/pork belly was excellent.
author: Sam N.

description: Ramen is ok here, I had the kakuni ramen.  I've had better elsewhere, but I was hungry and it did its job. This review would have been four stars, but I felt the service could have been better.
author: Dee W.

description:
Totally average.  I came in around 6pm on a Thursday and was seated immediately.
I had the Karage shoyu ramen with extra spicy paste and added bamboo shoots.  Bamboo was good.  Wish I had asked for more toppings.  The spice was hardly there, maybe 2/10, and I found myself adding more and more of the red pepper that was on the table.  The broth had an interesting flavor that I initially didn't like but gradually grew on me as I started tasting a strong soy sauce flavor.  I ultimately could not finish the broth and ended up with a stomach ache later (my bad for trying).  The noodles were average.
I'll probably come back again when there isn't a line just to try the curry ramen or udon.  I wouldn't wanna spend $15 on the same bowl of ramen again.
author: Audrey D.

description:
Came here expecting a decent ramen. Others recommended the suzu ramen and it was on the borderline of being edible. On top of all that, the waitress was a little rude, so that kinda worsened the experience.
However, I would recommend the pork belly and the fried baby octopus. Overall I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. For a noodle house, the noodle wasn't great.
author: Adriana H.

description:
We can here while Cherry Blossom festival was happening so the wait was super long. The ramen here is average, although the service is not bad. I'd recommend getting the Karaage (Japanese Style fried chicken) ramen since you don't really see that anywhere else. 

My favorite part about Suzu is the amount of stuff they put in your ramen! Many ramen places charge you extra for adding pork, an egg, or green onions for example, but this places gives you all of that without extra charge.

This wouldn't be my first pick at Japantown, but I wouldn't mind coming back for another bowl of hot filling ramen either.
author: Vivian W.

description:
So.....

We've eaten at Suzu many times and thought their ramen was some of the best in the city.  I always had the butter and corn shoyu ramen...so good.

But, last time we were there, about a week ago, we happened to sit at one of the only 4-tops in the main room.  I sat with my left side to the kitchen.  After eating my ramen that evening, I turned and looked into the kitchen and noticed their health score posted on a small side wall.  It said "73."  

I did a little research on the health codes for SF and here's what a 73 means:

*Multiple violations observed
*Typically, several high-risk violations

This translates to: "violations that directly relate to the transmission of food borne illnesses, the adulteration of food products and the contamination of food-contact surfaces."

You can check the information out for yourself at http://www.sfdph.org/dph/eh/food/score/default.asp

I can deal with a 90, but a 73 is extremely bad.  If you eat there, know that they do not practice food safety.  This could lead to unsanitary conditions or worse, you getting sick.  Such a low score also means they have to be reinspected often...well, it's still a 73.

We will not eat there again.

Also, Yelp puts scores right on the restaurant's page and it lists a 73...from October 1st!  If you eat there, you can get very sick.
author: Jake B.

description:
This is one of the restaurants that's guilty for spreading wrong image of ramen. 

They don't really deserve any star in my opinion. 

For some reason people like this place, but it's not at a level of authentic ramen at all.  If you already like places like Orenchi Ramen, Yamadaya, Yokohama Iekei Ramen etc in the Bay, forget this place.  It's not even close.  Broth, noodle, everything.
author: Taka T.

description: One of the best ramens in San Francisco! Just a heads up, most likely there will be a wait. Maybe 10 - 45 minutes wait. It'll be worth the wait trust me.
author: Cal N.

description:
Food taste like water, waiter has the WORST attitude ever had in a restaurant!

$13 for a disgusting bowl of noodle with POOR service!
author: William W.

description: Sadly I think something has changed.  I hadn't been back to Suzu for a while due to the long lines.  I used to love their chewy round noodles.  Instead, I found on a Saturday around 12 or 1pm that there was no wait.  The noodles have changed.  First, they are no longer round chewy noodles.  Now they are somewhat flat/rectangular and quite soft.  Second, it seems like they are reducing the things besides noodles.  There was one bok choi leaf (who puts that in ramen?!?) in addition to the menma bamboo, sprouts and well done hard boiled egg.  The one piece of pork was overly sweet and was a cut of pork I didn't recognize.  It seemed more like a cut of tongue.  Not sure what happened but it's no longer the Suzu I knew...certainly not worth waiting in line anymore.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
I was in the area today visiting the cool Japanese shop in this center. I saw a new shop and decided to get my Ramen on. 

Place is clean, servers are sweet, place was full. I ordered my dish and it was good. Just good. 

You spend 10.95 on a bowl of noodles and vegetables and you expect excitement. I wasn't. There was option but onions for a buck? Each additional item cost 1-3 dollars. Not a good deal.

I was very close to a strange couple and has to listen to the conversation because they were at my table. Holds about 25 inside and 6-8 outside.
author: Mario A.

description:
New hours!
Now open 11:30am-9pm daily! http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8QAMC7Xi6i3YG8KvCj79bA/l

Suzu's reputation as the best ramen in Japantown is well deserved. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/d8KJBHTXPyhfDZZOE_RnxQ/l Although most everyone would agree that the best ramen shops are in the South Bay.

In my opinion reviews older than a year or two are no longer valid, because the staff has changed and the broth has really improved over time. The chef blends filtered chicken and pork broths for a savory taste that will appeal to most western palates. The noodles are decent, and the chasu pork is tender although sliced very thin. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/2EfcozLEisfRUXMADGUviQ/l But like many others this place makes hard boiled eggs, I prefer soft boiled eggs. Unlike other ramen shops that have a basic bowl and charges extra for each topping, here u simply pick from a dozen ramen bowl choices ($8.95-$11.95). There are also 8 ramen combos for $10.95 that include a side of donburi. Other items in the menu are hearty nabeyaki udon hot pots.

On the appetizers side, the gyoza is good. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/JZCqn2a_XipgBpN524X6Sg/l The batch I bought just last week was freshly made, with a nice crisp bottom. Karaage (fried chicken morsels) on the other hand was only okay, nice crispy outside but the meat was a little mushy. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HmtvyQesNI2wlSQQgqamPg/l The combos are a nice way to try 2 items at once, u get a medium size portion of udon, soba or ramen, plus your choice of a side dish portion of any donburi. http://media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/suF1RjEWHln-y9CQFsl1pA/l

Come on weekdays, or get there early to get one of the 30 coveted seats (5 tables for 2, 4 tables for 4, and 2 tables for 2 outside). Sadly there's no space to expand (unless that flower shop on the left closes). On weekends, make sure to write your name on the waiting list as soon as u get there.

NO to go orders. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BkSqAJkHmacQ-36FAlxVGg/l
They don't validate Japantown garage parking.
author: Luis C.

description: I like this place. Favorite ramen in SF as of this moment, not too greasy and very balanced, with strong toppings. Get the suzu ramen miso or soy flavor with spicy on the side. You can also add a small plate of japanese chicken curry for 3 bucks as a combo.
author: Mashav S.

description:
