Come here on a rainy day and crammed in a party of 8 in the small place. I tried their chicken udon and the chicken was really tender! My udon was great, I wold definitely recommend it. Most of the people with me ordered ramen and that look good too, but I think the general consensus is that they've had better. 
   Come with a small party, great on a cold day, and service sims fast!
author: Mia S.

description: Bad service and mediocre food, for a relatively high price.
author: Beerit G.

description: The ramen here is okay.  The garnish topping is sparse, and in my opinion, there is too much MSG.  There is not as much variety on their menu.  Tanpopo, Katana Ya, RamenDojo, and Himaware have much better ramen.  Service here is lacking.  I barely sat down, no menu in hand, and I was asked- "So do you know what you want?" The help do not anticipate, and are inattentive.  My water glass sat empty, as the waitress passed my table three times.  Finally I had to ask for more water.
author: Robin A.

description: I have never had any udon and ramen as salty as this place. Seriously overloaded on salt. The texture of the chicken was like it was boiled for hours. One star only because service was alright.
author: Erik Y.

description:
When reviewing (and subsequently giving low stars) I tend to feel bad; in this situation, it's because Suzu has clean facilities and friendly employees. At the same time, though, they serve god-awful food. I don't like to dole out 1-2 stars, but the ramen here truly doesn't deserve anything more than 1 star. (I'll allot another for the friendly service and overall cleanliness of the place.)

I mean, that's why I came here: for the ramen. I'm in Japantown. I don't want any old ramen. I want good, solid Japanese-style ramen. The kind that gives you a facial when it's placed in front of you. The kind that has a chewy bite to its noodles, with a soft-boiled egg that adds creaminess to the pork-bone broth. The kind that has flavorful and moist chashu (pork slices), with bamboo and green onion added for flavor and texture contrast.

Yeah, the ramen here had none of that. With too-salty a broth, an overcooked (and cold) hard-boiled half-egg, sinewy pieces of pork, and bamboo that overpowered the broth, I nearly cried into my bowl of soup. But I didn't, as that would only make it saltier than I could already handle. (And I like salty!)

It was a $10 lesson, but now I know to search elsewhere for a good bowl of ramen.
author: Adena B.

description: The food isn't that great. I got the curry with croquette while my friend got the ramen. She didn't enjoy the broth and it below average for her taste. As for my curry, it was too salty and my croquette.. Was the worst I ever had. It's extremely gooey... Like watery inside. I've had many croquettes in Japan and here in japantown.. And this is the worst. I won't be coming here again. I gave two stars since the service was good at least. I'm assuming this place is popular cause it's a tourist spot.
author: Jei L.

description:
The food is alright, nothing spectacular. The service isn't bad as well. The one star is just for shady business practices. My auntie, doing that whole Asian lady thing, sneaks up to secretly pay before anyone else can. 
Five minutes after she comes back to the table, the waitress brings the change of $21.xx so the meal was $78.xx we assumed because there was no receipt. (Maybe they skimming on their taxes? Don't know, don't care.) so we leave $15.xx on the table and get ready to leave. My uncle says to hold up cause the math doesn't add up for what we ordered. Asks my auntie if they added gratuity, and she says they never showed her the check, only took her hundred. We ask to see the check, added gratuity of 18% AFTER tax for a party of 4+1. After tax gratuity is shit enough as it is, but trying to sneakily get that 30+% tip is major . The waitresses saw us leave extra too and didn't even try to mention they already charged gratuity. Like Young Dro said, "F.D.B."
author: Alfred W.

description:
small ramen place inside japantown shopping center.  Ramen with big wooden spoon.   Portions are good sized. Vegetarian ramen comes in a flavorful clear broth with cabbage, eggplant, carrots, tofu, and bean sprouts. ($10 ish). Service was decent.
after ramen, go upstairs to sophies for delicious crepe!
author: Linda T.

description:
My roommate recommended Suzu as the best ramen in Japantown, so I decided to come here for a solo lunch on a work-from-home kind of day. Suzu is quite small and I can see that the wait could be very long on the weekend (even on a weekday lunch, the place was almost full). I've always imagined ramen as the perfect, socially acceptable meal to eat by yourself. Suzu's not the ideal eat-alone-at-a-ramen-bar kind of deal - there are only tabletops for multiple-person-parties, so come with a friend!

I got the Kakuni ramen, miso-flavored ($10.95). It came with a generous helping of kakuni (pork belly), green onion, bamboo, and half of a hard-boiled egg. The bowls are giant and mostly filled with broth. Although the broth is flavorful and I have not yet felt a desperate thirst after eating here, it did not stand out to me compared to the other ramen spots I've tried (Orenchi, Ramen Dojo, Santouka, etc). It comes out piping hot but the actual flavor is one dimensional.

The service here is aloof and inattentive, but food comes out very quickly. If you're not too picky about ramen, Suzu is a solid choice and nothing too terrible can come of it.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Came here right after a few hours enjoying myself at the Kabuki Spa. In a juxtaposition of healthy self-care vs. self-indulgence, I followed up relaxing (and somewhat dehydrating) baths with a nice big bowl of salty miso ramen with dumplings. 

And it was divine. The end.
author: Allison S.

description:
Super long lines, actually not THAT awesome. 

There's always super long lines at this place.  And I have no idea why that is.  Its actually not that good.   

As ramen goes this place is pretty standard, nothing really is THAT outstanding.  Not to say that its bad.  It's just.... ok....  

And being in Japantown there's so many different options for ramen, which makes it quite surprising that this isn't better.  

Note: The broth is full of MSG, so ask for a coke to cut through it.
author: Maggie F.

description:
I am a fan of Suzu.  i really liked the al dente texture of the ramen.  The broth is a bit salty, but they can add water in it if you would like.  

We had both the curry ramen and the fried chicken ramen.  The fried chicken was delicious, and the curry was great (though I wished it would have had more vegetables or something)

The total (including tip) will be about 13-15 dollars per person depending on what type of noodles you order on the menu (and excluding appetizers).
author: Alison L.

description:
The food was good as usual. Some odd things about the service. 

I asked for a plate and the waitress finally brought one, then she tried to take the other plate away. Very weird. 

We asked for water and hot tea. The waitress said, ok but you better drink all of it. 

We asked for one extra napkin. It was scary - if we could have not been stunned by the giggles of the waitresses in the kitchen. 

Seems like the waitresses get a kick out of being less than hospitable. 

Reminds me of that Seinfeld episode- the soup nazi. 

Take your sense of humor with you and you will probably enjoy the good food here.
author: Michael P.

description: I love love love this place, mostly get the karaage but have tried others. My bestie and I have a regular date here and no, I'm not Japanese and no, I haven't yet been able to travel to Japan (but a girl can dream!), but delicious ramen is delicious ramen. It's affordable, prompt, and they now serve all day, plus it's a stones throw from Imperial Spa. IWhat more do you need in life? And if the line is too long, there's a bomb stores next door.
author: Valerie C.

description:
I was craving ramen after watching alot of asian movies and documentaries on the history of ramen, so since me and le boyfriend were on our way to sf we decided to stop by our favorite area Japantown!

I had the ramen noodle that had cabbage and all ramen came with chicken pork or beef and I thought it was very delicious! If you are feeling down or sad this is the place to be! The service was good and very attentive to customers! Love this place, I think ill come back for more! 

They say its always good to slurp the ramen as a tradition to get a taste of the air combined with the broth. But it was not so apparent because none of the customers were slurping it lol. I tried.
author: Melissa U.

description: My cousin brought me here when I was craving ramen. It's in the city and parking can be a pain/expensive if you're used to mainly free parking from Southern California like me. The wait can be quite long, especially if you're in a big group. The restaurant is pretty small, but doable. I like that they serve you tea. I always order the karaage ramen and though it gets a little soggy, it's delicious. The soup is always piping hot too! I really enjoy this restaurant and would recommend it if you want some ramen, but don't come here if you're starving. The service can be slow and the wait can kill you. Is it the best ramen? Debatable. But it's pretty damned great. Plus, you can get a crepe upstairs for dessert later and do some shopping while you wait or are digesting
author: Jenn T.

description:
This tiny ramen house in San Francisco J-Town can be packed like sardines. By the looks of it, this place can fit about 25 people maximum but not comfortably. There is also outdoor seating or an indoor porch if you will that can fit another five or so. A waiting list can be found dangling out front for the next rotation of fish. 

As I was seated, I can easily join the conversation with the folks next to me. No matter how hard I tried to tune out on how they eat their rice with Maruchan ramen chicken seasoning at home, it was unavoidable. I have to admit, that was entertaining.

I ordered the chashu ramen and chicken karaage. The verdict, I've experienced better. It seemed like there was no love in their broth and just threw in some toppings.
author: Gene B.

description: Very good ramen in the Japantown mall. Convenient location too.
author: Peter K.

description:
This place is good, but not SoCal-good.

Environment: 3/5
It's dark, small, and not particularly clean.

Food: 3/5
The fried chicken ramen can be skipped. I was a bit bummed out to actually eat it, since it sounded like a great idea in my mind.

The spicy ramen is yummy though! Beware that if you ask for extra spicy, they'll charge you a dollar extra, which annoyed me a bit when I received the bill.

They don't have tonkotsu ramen, which was a little disappointing too. The miso works well for me though!

Service: 3/5
It was alright. Friendly, but not too friendly; quick, but not too quick.

Not the cheapest option, as it is in a tourist-y spot. I haven't had much better ramen in SF though, so if you're craving ramen, give this place a shot!
author: Joseph T.

description:
They don't have tonkatsu soup base, so I tried their shoyu ramen but only find out that the soup base is literally came from the package. The pork is bad too, it taste very fake. 

But they do serve free tea tho.
author: Wei L.

description:
Last time I came with a friend it reeked like toilet..IN the dining room. Like stank toilet. 

Food meh, albeit nice n hot.
Chinese owned
Will not come back ever. 
The end!!
author: Petri Y.

description:
Definitely one of the better places to check out in Japantown. After consulting my trusty Yelp app, I found out that a lot of the restaurants in the mall portion of Japantown had a really low health inspection rating - so I avoided those like the plague! Suzu is simple, quick and affordable. After sitting down and ordering your food comes out very quickly 10 minutes max. They are able to get you in and out very quickly. Which was a major plus in my book. The food was tasty and they didn't charge for tea (unlike some other places I've been to). I would recommend checking out Suzu's for lunch or dinner if you're in the area. 

Tip for travelers. Be sure to put your name on the clipboard outside the restaurant. That is their way of know who is next on the list.
author: R C.

description:
I think I've been very spoiled by good ramen and have developed a taste for a specific flavor type. I'll go ahead and disclaim now that I prefer pork based broth over chicken. 

Okay, first impression is this place is always busy and full. It is tiny, so not sure how much of an accomplishment that is. There are about 10 small tables crammed into a little room. Careful while you slurp, you might splash your neighbor. We came late on a weekday, so didn't have to wait long. I ordered the shoyu ramen and the husband had the shio ramen. 

Egg - hard boiled and no flavor
Noodles - good consistency 
Broth - not a lot of flavor
Toppings - regular bamboo, green onions, nori + bok choy

I'm more accustomed to a very rich and porky broth. Some people consider that amount of porkiness to be too rich/salty. So, maybe I'm just not into thinner broths? My shoyu broth tasted like it came from an instant noodle flavor packet. I tasted a spoonful of the shio broth and it had even less flavor. Also, I hate when they mess up the egg - automatic one star deduction. They seem to do it on purpose here, so again, I guess I'm just not into this style. 

I've had ramen in Tokyo, Austin, Houston and NYC. This place is really not good. Sorry I wasted stomach space here instead of Yamadaya down the street. 

Complementary tea is given when you sit down. They don't give water unless you ask for it. Not sure what kind of tea it was.. it didn't taste like green tea, maybe it was really watered down.
author: Emmi D.

description:
The decline of Suzu Noodle House has been a sad thing to experience. The ramen got worse, the prices got higher, then the ramen got slightly better and the prices got higher and now the ramen is not good at all and the prices are still high.

The last time I went will be the last time I go. The noodles were inedible and the broth had a bitter aftertaste. Horrid. 

Since they no longer resemble the Suzu that they once were, I'd suggest a new name based on the new consistency of the noodles. 

Welcome to Glue-zu Noodle House, for when you feel like eating paste.™
author: Horace A.

description:
Standard ramen place.  Broth was kind of bland.
Line is too long.
Service was good-especially regarding the bf's many food allergies.
Burned my tongue.
author: Susan C.

description: Just stopped by this place based on the yelp reviews. the Tonkatsu don side was amazing for $3, and the shoyu ramen was flavorful but not overwhelming. cozy atmosphere and extremely fast service.
author: Evan K.

description:
After Raman dojo nothing is as good! Yeah I've been tainted. 

I tried the spicy raman, it wasn't spicy at all and I asked for extra chu siu - I'm sorry but it wasn't worth the 2 extra paper thin slices for the price. The noodles were good, dense, chewy with a good bite. 

My friend loved the karage and enjoyed her noodles. 

Overall okay noodles, broth was lacking and I was annoyed that all the normal side weren't included and required more $$.
author: Jade W.

description:
I don't know how this place has 3.5 stars!!
Ramen is just plain awful here!

I came here once, over a year ago and the ramen was extremely salty. Today I decided to give them a second chance since all the other ramen places in japan town were closed at the time. 

I ordered the spicy ramen, which was not spicy at all and barely had any flavor. It only includes bean sprouts and 1/2 an egg.

This was also the first time the egg was hard boiled in my ramen, which was awful!!!The egg should always be soft boiled/ a bit on the runny side. 

Definitely the worst ramen I've ever had. This place is a total rip off. For sure never coming back. 

Pls don't come here if you know what good ramen is.
author: Tina D.

description:
*good ramen
*efficient service
*generous portions
author: Monkey B.

description: I ate miso Raman and my husband ate curry at here. It was really low quality food. I hope that people don't think this is normal Japanese food. I don't recommend this restaurant.
author: N C.

description:
Their curry ramen is really delicious! Extra spicy paste added more flavor in it. Got an option with miso and was not disappointed at all! Very good! Braised pork belly as an appetizer is perfect, I've decide to eat it with the ramen and that was just a perfect idea!
Maybe it's a little bit on a salty side, so coke or water is a good choice to order with your ramen. 
Will definitely come again!
author: Asiyat T.

description: A good but far from great option for Ramen Lovers like myself.  Don't go with expectations derived from ramen shops in Tokyo, Sapporo, or other places you may have visited in Japan.  Do go with an open mind, and an appetite for a generously-sized noodly bowl of tasty warmth, and you will be happy.  We scarfed down a bunch of gyoza too- they were quite yummy. I'll be back.
author: Andy S.

description:
Suzu's ramen is far from meeting even the minimum requirements of a legit ramen. Surprised Japantown allowed them to hang around inside the mall. Ajisan's standard might actually be better the Suzu. 

One sign if a proper ramen is how they cook the egg, It has to be semi runny in the middle. The bowl I ate had an overboiled egg that was not even cut properly. I only had a quarter of an egg in my bowl. 

Noodles were of decent quality. Maybe they outsourced a good brand of noodles. But there was a bunch stuck together in my bowl; thus undercooked. Really bad techniques all round so far.

And the broth, come on guys. It's nothing special and forgettable. 

Before going to this restaurant, look at the pictures of it's noodles online and you'll see what I mean. Look at the egg, the presentation and everything. It's not worth $10. Service is ok I guess. 

Instead, try Waraku. A ramen place nearby. Much much better ramen there.

**Recently tried Yamadaya ramen. REALLY GOOD!
author: Ken T.

description: I really like this place. The spicy Ramen and service was excellent. Nice little Ramen house...sit outside if tables are available.
author: David S.

description:
So it was my first time walking around the mall in Japantown and I LOVE ramen. I was pretty hungry and the ramen house looked packed - a good sign right? Nopes, wrong. 

I got the karaage shoyu ramen and it came with four large karaage (fried chicken) pieces. The pieces were chewy and tough = not appetizing at all! And the noodles were worse than cup-o-noodle noodles. The broth was simultaneously bland and too salty... how is that even possible? On top of that, there were two wimpy bamboo shoots and one limp piece of baby bok choy. Wow, was I super unhappy for paying $10+ for this sad bowl of ramen.

The only thing that saved the meal was the takoyaki. You get five for around $6 and they were large, with big pieces of octopus in them. Yum - almost as good as I had in Japan!

Lastly, service was VERY bad. I mean, I understand if you are busy, but the servers looked very angry and I was scared to ask for my beer that they had forgotten. AND, when I went up there to pay, clearly stating, "Can I pay for my table please," because we had obviously been done with our food for some time but no one stopped by with the check, the angry girl said, "No no, we will call you in we need to wipe tables first go outside." I had to say again, "No, I want to pay," and she glared at me before giving me the check.

Thanks but no thanks. Give you money over to Ramen Dojo in San Mateo, or any other ramen joint because this one is not deserving.
author: Elizabeth V.

description: The place and The pork slices were very good and perfectly cooked.. Shoyu Ramen noodle is one of my favorite The  pork brisket was tender. I always order  these type of flavor because come's with corn and the soup was very tasty.. I so love this specially during the cold weather... this place will be better if its little huge.. so that way We don't need to wait that long...
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Before the restaurant opens at 11:30AM, we already put our names down with 10 minutes to spare. Boy were we glad - by the time we have decided what to get, the tables were all filled. What's so great about this restaurant is the location. If you've been to Japantown before, this is probably one of the restaurants you've stumbled across unknowingly if you've visited Japan Center.

Since it's Cherry Blossom Festival and we plan to sample other treats at the vendors on the street, we decided to forfeit appetizers. I got the braised pork belly ramen with the salt soup base. The soup is flavorful and ramen just the way I like it - not too soft with a good texture. The braised pork tastes good, though a little on the hard side. What really disappointed me was the egg - they only give you a boiled egg, rather than the soft-boiled egg I expect in ramen. Egg aside, Suzu is a convenient restaurant to get quality ramen - if you do not mind the wait.
author: Genny C.

description:
Food: Good
Service : Good
Price: Not bad
Chopsticks: Toothpicks?

Get some real chopsticks! These things can barely stand the weight of my noodles and it's wasteful to use disposable sticks at a restaurant. Bringing my own next time. 

Ok.
author: Emilio S.

description: I didn't love the ramen here. It lacked flavor for me. And i asked for it spicy... The service was wonderful and the staff was all super nice but after leaving Suzu Noodle House I couldn't even remember the taste of the food. It was unmemorable and that's not how ramen should be. Usually I'm craving it for days on end and Suzu was so so to me. I could walk away and never come back and that made me a little sad. I do love my ramen but maybe I haven't found the right place yet.
author: Sarah M.

description:
One of my favorite Ramen places so far. I love the fact that there are so many options, especially since I prefer udon noodles. 

Staff is friendly and pretty quick to get through the waiting list for seating. 

They'll make it how you want it but are happy to make suggestions if what you ordered might not be the best combo. 

Good date place.
author: Bret P.

description: Changed owner. Quality is way worse now. Still acceptable but not what it used to be.
author: Joseph L.

description: After living in Singapore for 12 years, I refuse to eat Asian food anywhere except Suzu Noodle House. They cook all their dishes (especially their udon and ramen) absolutely correctly! No complaints here! You definitely won't regret your lunch or dinner there!
author: Juliet R.

description:
Food: so so
Service: bad

Ok, here is the thing: 
the short hair waitress said to us:"we don't have to tell everything to you!" (Because we don't know they auto-charge tips for 5 ppl as a party! Then that waitress told us that they don't have to tell us everything! Plus they don't give that much services tho!)
Then we said we won't come back because that waitress's attitude, then guess what, that waitress said to us: " then don't come back!!!!"

What!!!!!! We have the right to decide which restaurant we wanna go, but do U have to say that to your customers? We pay $ and we should get the same price services!!!!
author: Zhi Huan L.

description:
Very small and usually full. Reasonable prices. Nice staff, although hurried. The food is traditional udon and noodles and is very meddle done.

We live in the area and had not been before but will make it a regular spot.
author: v n.

description: Great service, food and prices. My ramen was excellent and my son said his curry was the best ever. Food was served quickly and hot.
author: Mark S.

description: I've been here before and remembered it being much better than it was today. I had a shoyu ramen and vegetable tempura. Really, nothing about the ramen was very good. The noodles didn't seem done enough and the pork was kind of tough. The shoyu broth not very flavorful. Service seemed reasonable, though it wasn't that busy at the time.
author: Chris T.

description:
Saltiness.

Someone please tell me the best ramen shop in San Francisco because this is definitely not it.

Having been to the likes of Ramen Dojo (my #1), Maru Ichi, Santokou Ramen, Orenchi Ramen, Shoki Ramen, and Halu Ramen, Suzu pales in comparison. Overpriced, super salty (I got miso ramen and I had to pour nearly half of my water in to make it bearable), and overcooked chashu pork (I ended up giving both pork pieces to my bf after taking one bite). Places like Maru Ichi gives garlic chips for free, but it's an additional 50 cents here as a topping.

I was so disappointed especially because we were looking forward to eating ramen that night. I think the only reason why the restaurant was so bustling and there was quite a waitlist is that there's only like 7 tables inside total.

We walked to Nijiya afterwards and bought some ramen to make at home the next night...it turned out better than this.
author: Esther Y.

description: My friend and I ate here after an amazing soak at Kabuki spa. I lived in Japan for 3 years about 20 years ago and this is really great, authentic japanese ramen. I had miso ramen and she had the spicy/kimchi ramen. We left super full and happy.
author: Kim C.

description: 18% automatic gratuity for mediocre food and subpar service. As a server myself, I thought it was a little ridiculous, especially when we were ignored on several occasions.
author: Biti N.

description:
There's always a line here. My cousin already told me their ramen is not that great. Still, I dragged her along just so I can try it for myself. Should've listened.

Prices are around $7-9 per bowl. Small portions. 

On their menu, they had "HAND-MADE RAMEN" written across. But I was quite skeptical when I saw and tasted it. The ramen was thin and hard. Served in a shape that seemed like it had came out of a package. No good.

I had the Tokyo Ramen, which comes with pork, wakame, bamboo, egg and sprouts. The broth was bland. The egg wasn't marinated. The only part I liked was the pork. And they only gave me 1 piece!

I was still hungry after.
author: Marti L.

description:
Miso Ramen-$9
+added spicy paste, 50cents
+added tofu, $1

Each ramen bowl came with half a boiled egg, 2 pork slices, bamboo shoots, seaweed, & green onions. I found my spicy miso broth to be just ok. It wasn't as flavorful as I hoped it to be; thats why I didn't care to finish the broth. The ramen was great though-- it had superb elasticity and chewiness to it. I will most likely come back to give their other ramen a try.

Next visit,
Karaage Ramen (ramen w/ fried chicken)
Spicy Negi Ramen (ramen with spicy green onions)
Tonkotsu (ramen w/ creamy pork marrow broth)

Note:
One bowl is super filling!!
complimentary hot tea
located on the first floor of Japanese shopping mall
author: Christine H.

description: Their combo menu is a great idea. Especially when you're so hungry a bowl of ramen won't suffice but two bowls would be too much. Unfortunately, I didn't find anything great about their ramen itself. Nothing about their ramen stands out to me. If you're hoping for slow-cooked eggs in your ramen, you'd best try elsewhere.
author: Yad L.

description:
This place is a little small and it does get packed during lunch and dinner hours. But it's definitely worth the wait because the ramen is delicious. 

I love that this place bc you can count on the consistensy of the flavors. 

Best food to eat when it's rainy and cold out.
author: Arlene R.

description: Fried chicken morsels and potstickers in my ramen? Yes, please!  This was just what the Doctor ordered on a cold December night before a movie at Kabuki. I got the shoyu broth and it was good but I'll try miso next time. I also loved that they had veggie options and yummy looking side dishes like croquettes. I'll be back!
author: Melissa M.

description: decent ramen with reasonable price. very delicious broth. the downside is that it's too small, u will have to wait during rush hours. and service is a bit slow...
author: Andy W.

description: Amazing ramen. Hand made noodles and it's delicious. Could drink the broth all day. Definitely one of the main reasons why I'd go back to the city.
author: Alex A.

description: Went here during the cherry blossom festival.  The wait wasn't to bad about 45mins.  I orderd the chasu ramen and it tasted realy good. The egg was hard boiled which I liked, im not a big fan of soft boiled. My boyfriend ordered the miso ramen and he didnt leave any left. Will come again this one of my bf favorite ramen shops.
author: Tiffany I.

description:
Bring back the WANTON RAMEN !!!
Would be 5 stars if they didn't eliminate my favorite bowl:(
author: Claire G.

description: I always come here for ramen. The soup is good but the quality of the noodles have decreased over the years. The texture is a little weird now
author: Agnes W.

description: Mmmmmm ramen! Lots of types of ramen toppings with customization options and a side of a small donburi is a great dinner in my opinion and they make both of them great with a quick and friendly service
author: Levan G.

description:
I was so disappointed by the ramen here! They were stingy on the toppings, the broth was salty and not impressive, but the noodles were the perfect texture. You're better off getting your ramen fix at tampopo across the street or in san Mateo Dojo Ramen....

T^T
author: Emi K.

description: Ramen not boiling hot enough for me. They add in tip if you're a party of 5. Each ramen topping is $1 each
author: Susannah K.

description: Just not very flavourful. Was disappointed, wanted good Japanese and it wasn't to be found here. Also it was really hot in there.
author: Zene B.

description:
The kimchee udon and the curry udon are really flavorful and filling. I would order either again. :)

The restaurant is not good for big groups but the wait was not unbearable. If you go here I suggest going in a part of 2-6. The service was a little slow, but I don't blame them because there were a lot of customers there at the time. I give 4 stars based on the food because I really liked it.
author: Ashley Y.

description:
Where do I begin?!
。Terrible food -- a bowl of noodles for 10.50$, that only had 4 small things in it.
1) noodles 
2) badly chopped green onions 
3) ONE piece of bok choy
4) half a hard boiled egg
Let me just say, I would pay 6$ at the MOST for that. Not worth it, the quality of food has gone down considerably since I was last here a year ago. 
。A smell of urine --if you sit near the back, there will be a very strong hobo-ish smell. Terrible and appetite ruining!
。Grumpy service -- I get that it can be very tiring after a busy day, but some waitress are forgetful. 

Never coming back here.
There was also a 15 min wait. Not bad, but
the smell put me off the most. 
I don't even know how a restaurant can smell so bad!!
author: Kylie G.

description: To be fair, we decided to check out this ramen joint instead of going to the one upstairs (we've gone several  times) since the reviews were better here than there. Let me get to the point: the service was slow. Maybe because we were seated outside? Then, we waited over 25 mins for our food. When the waitress handed my ramen, she slammed it on the table as if I did something wrong. Wth. The chashu (meat) was COLD! And it wasn't tasty at all. It was hard and, well, cold.  So, I placed the meat underneath the noddles so that they warm up a bit. Unfortunately, my friend did not do the same. He ended up having diarrhea that evening. We ate the same exact things the entire day, he just didn't do what I did to his chashu. I certainly do NOT recommend this ramen joint to anyone.
author: Justine Y.

description:
Ambiance: Very cute, simple little place inside of a Japantown mall. There were only two servers for the whole restaurant. They pretty much call you from behind the restaurant and ask "How many?" and then say "take this one" and point to a table. I don't think any one should take this as rudeness since it seems this was the style of the place and the servers actually seemed to be quite helpful, and explained how we should eat the dishes as well. 

Appetizers: The green salad is AMAZING! The dressing is just delicious and I wanted another salad at the end of my meal it was soo good. The croquette was good, and a hearty size. 

Entrée: The soba noodle with vegetables and tempura was solid. It kind of tasted like miso soup with noodles and a side of tempura, but it was a nice flavor. I'd probably try something else next time, although I loved the tempura and would order those separately again. 

The price was really reasonable.
author: Sara A.

description:
Gradually I am becoming more accustomed to what goes into a good ramen bowl, and the spicy ramen here was good.  The broth had kick but wasn't that spicy, and there was a good amount of meat.  Green onion and egg were in there too.  So why overload it with bean sprouts?  There were a bunch in there.  I like a few as garnish just like in some pho noodles, but after the first few bites of ramen, the ramen to sprouts ratio, so to speak, was about 50/50.  For $10 a bowl I would like more of the other stuff and less sprouts.  But overall, it was a little better than Sapporo-ya.

Plus for an additional $3 you get a mini bowl of rice with various chicken or pork dishes, the katsu was crispy without being overcooked.  Good fried garlic tofu and gyozas too (though only four for $6).  When I see the Neat Asian store, I know just where to go next!
author: Sal M.

description:
I used to really like this place and have been 3 or 4 times but have been for the last time.  I'm not sure if my taste changed or the food got terrible but it is not edible in my opinion. 

The curry was so rich a tablespoon would be enough for the whole plate but they lathered on 2 pounds of it. The ramen was bland and oily. 

The service was fine though not too friendly. Don't expect them to ask if you need anything, you will need to wave them down.
author: Ryder M.

description:
Had the BUTTER&CORN Ramen (Paula Deen would be proud) and it was AWWWWESOME! The square pat of butter melts into the broth and really makes a difference in the flavor of the ramen! The sweet niblets of corn sank to the bottom of the bowl but was a nice surprise with every chopstick full of ramen and pork. I also had a mini Chicken Katsu Don bowl on the side ($3.00 with the purchase of ramen, udon, or soba) and that was delicious too.

SUZU itself can hold about 25+ customers with some seating outside along the restaurant. My party of three waited 20 minutes for our seats but the wait wasn't bad. Will definitely be back when I need my BUTTER RAMEN FIX!
author: Tim P.

description:
We were a party of 11 or so. We got seated within about 15min on a Sunday afternoon which was pretty sweet after walking to different ramen places that were either closed or had 45min+ wait times. 

We were a big group of hangry people. In other words we were also a group that was easy to please. Everything tasted pretty good. I got the one with pork belly and spicy miso broth. Wish I could remember the name of it! Get spicy on the side and share it with one other person instead of everyone getting individual spice. They're $1 each and no one finished theirs. The food comes out in the order that it was taken. So I was the last of my whole group and received my bowl after the first few people were already done eating. It wasn't too bad, but I did feel tortured lol. This place was aight. I like my noodles al dente and these were overcooked. They were too soft for me TT__TT
author: T N.

description:
BOOO for no runny, yolky eggs! That's probably my favorite item in the bowl, along with the ramen of course. I ordered additional eggs, but they came out as hard boiled eggs.

Surprisingly, this place was better than i expected. We originally had plans to go somewhere else, but the line was out the door, and we swung by here to give it a try.

I ordered the Suzu Miso Ramen (the ramen was different that what I was used to, but nonetheless, it was delicious)! 

Overall 3 solid stars--Great place to walk around if you have time. A lot of variety stores within the plaza.
author: Jen H.

description:
This ramen/japanese food place is a pretty popular place in the Japantown Mall. Even though it was late at night, there was a wait to get in. 

I decided to get the Karaage Ramen. The chicken was well made, but in very small portions. The miso based broth ramen that my friend had seemed good, but the salt based ramen was only good at dehydrating me. The amount of karaage was also a bit lacking

Overall, I would say the food here is exactly okay. There is better ramen around town, but the place is acceptable in a pinch.
author: Oliver Z.

description:
I'm on the hunt for great Ramen in San Francisco and I have a lot of places to check out, so SUZU NOODLE HOUSE is the first stop on my adventure...

Nice place, friendly staff, only a few tables occupied. We looked at the menu and ordered within two minutes. I ordered the Spicy Ramen ($9.95) with the addition of Miso Paste (free) and Green Onions ($1.00) which arrived in under ten minutes. Big bowl, big portion!

I loved the spiciness, the freshness of the vegetables, the portion size and the noodles. I disliked the fattiness of the pork, the tasteless 1/2 egg and the lack of richness in the watery miso. Overall the flavor combination was good, worthy of three stars but it did not blow me away.

A quick and tasty lunch in the midst of Japantown, I would go back but I look forward to my next stop in my Ramen Adventure.
author: G C.

description: Solid, good portion and price for Japantown. Clean, but disliked the low hanging lights.
author: Peter L.

description: Suzu always delivers a satisfying bowl of ramen. I like to get the karaage ramen with shio broth. And I get the karaage and gyoza on the side so they don't get soggy. Service is fast, but it can feel a bit rushed because they want to turn over tables quickly. Wait time is usually about 15-30 minutes depending on the size of your group. Make sure you put your name down on the list.
author: Kelly H.

description: I ordered a butter corn miso ramen. It's almost the worst ramen I have ever ate in bay area.
author: Di W.

description: The menu for this restaurant is not current for example there are no desserts and I don't think their sushi either it's a noodle house. The nice thing is they is no MSG and the broth is vegetarian. it is very small so be prepared to wait if you come anywhere between noon - 3pm on a weekend. good Ramen!
author: Cieulien T.

description:
Suzu is located within the mall and always seem to have a lengthy wait. So put your name down on the list, ask the host how long the wait will approximately be, go upstairs to the bookstore and peruse through some Japanese fashion magazines and go back down in time to be seated. At least this is what I do. :)

Service is quick and to the point. No dilly-dallying around. Just a quick "what can I get you", take order, refill water, "here's your check" and leave. Ramen noodles weren't horrible and the flavors was ok. It's perfect for our SF gloomy or foggy laden days. This isn't my favorite ramen spot but I would say it's one of the tolerable ones.
author: Esther A.

description: THE place to go in SF for ramen noodles. I ordered a vegetarian dish (not vegan) and it was flavorful and very filling. You get a lot for your money. It's not a place for a long conversation. Tables are crammed next to each other. It's a eat-in, out the door, kind of place.
author: N H.

description: Used to be better. The seafood tempura ramen was not super flavorful. I much prefer the miso. Also: the second the place closed (we weren't even half done with our meal), the server insisted we pay our check.
author: matthew d.

description:
So if you are expecting authentic Japanese ramen, please look further and away from this place. Shio broth has this uncanny similarity to Chinese broth and it lacks depth and flavour. All I could taste was MSG. I could not drink enough water to quench the thirst. 

Speaking of thirst, if you are thinking of ordering house wine, ask yourself if you like Charles Shaw aka two buck Chuck because that was what I saw in the fridge. So be aware. Servers were unfriendly.

Needless to say I felt cheated and I would rather spend my $10 at other ramen places.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
Tokio Ramen: a pork-based soup (as all ramen normally are) with a few pieces of fatty pork slices, half of a hard-boiled egg cooked in sauce, seaweed, several slices of pickled root, and kamaboko (fishcake).  Tasted like it was made with water from the Dead Sea.  In other words, it was true to its origin in being Japanese by being way too salty.  On my trip to Japan in 2008, Momma Lim and I had stopped by a local street ramen store that appeared to be pretty popular by the amount of locals that were eating in it.  The ramen was so salty that we had to pour iced green tea (served complimentary) into our soup to eat the ramen.  They did say that colon cancer is 2nd (or was it 1st) cause of death in the country.  Lung cancer actually may top that being that Japanese people love their cigarettes.  But I digress... the Tokio ramen at Suzu was equivalent to that soup base in Tokyo.  Would it have been different if it was a different ramen like miso ramen? Perhaps, but salty ramen is still salty ramen! And salt is not good as an overdose!

Tempura Udon: was not exceptional either.  I've had others that were equivalent if not better than what I tasted that night.  For one, there seemed to be a lack of sustenance in the dish.  After you put in your tempura shrimp which was served separately (and for good reason otherwise they would've become super soggy), there was only a few pieces of actual seaweed and kamaboko pieces.  The majority of the dish was udon noodle and soup!

Eel and Avocado roll: fresh avocado slices with unagi (bbq eel) wrapped in nori and rice.  Nothing extraordinary.  Even portion wise I think Tokyo Shokudo here in Atlanta serves much bigger rolls in general.  Could be the cost of living difference?

Not terrible, but I'm sure there are better ramen places here in SF!
author: Vera L.

description: My recommendation: Karrage, Nabeyaki Udon, Miso Nabeyaki Udon. Wonton Ramen/Udon with Shio soup base.
author: Lisha K.

description:
No wait on a Saturday night? I am in! 
However, the ramen wasn't necessarily the BEST, which was a bummer. 

We started off with the Chicken Kaarage and the Takoyaki for appetizer. Both dishes were decent but not spectacular. The takoyaki had way too much sauce than needed, making the exterior more mushy than it should be. The chicken kaarage was good, but to me, it just tasted like Taiwan popcorn chicken. In my opinion, chicken kaarage should be pretty different in taste than popcorn chicken, even considering the fact that they are both seasoned fried chicken. 

As for the ramen, I decided to try the Shio Ramen, which had excellent broth, but the noodles surely needed some serious work. I understand that the noodles were not hand made, but maybe with a different brand of store-bought-noodles, this noodle would have jumped from 3-stars to a 4 or maybe even 5. In a bowl of ramen, the noodles are as important as the broth, and although I was a huge fan of the light and clean taste of the Shio, the noodles' lack of uniqueness just didn't quite do it for me. 

I haven't tried the other ramen shops in Japan Town, so I really dont have much to compare to other than the ramen restaurants in LA. It is a little unfair and biased, but ramen is ramen. If LA can make it spectacular, I expect it to be the same in Norcal!
author: Luby H.

description:
What's so Popular about this place that have to Wait in line ?

I would think to have GREAT Ramen in JapanTown, but sadly to say this place was not what I expected.  Waited about 30 minutes for 3 people on a Sunday Night (before I catch my flight back to NY).  Read everyone's review and decided to give it a try.

As soon as they called our names we got a seat. 3 Waitresses during hours.  Waitress number one is friendly and brought us tea right away and then walked away.  Minutes later Waitress number two comes and takes down the order.

Shared a  Gyoza, and I ordered myself a Miso Ramen (around $ 9.00) and added estra CHAR SIU (Pork) for $ 1.00 for 3 slices (wow, but continue reading).

Gyoza was pretty tasty, but small - You can finish it in one bite.

Ramen came, Pretty big portion, comes with an egg and my extra meat.  But I did not realize the Char Siu was super LEAN and Dry.  Tough to Chew and didn't taste anything that just the rough texture of the pork. Soup was not thick at all, but tasty.  Noodles were  so so, a bit hard to chew on.  Finished it within 10 minutes.

Then Waitress number 3 came and took my bowl and cleaned the table, but the funny part about this is that my Friend across from me was still eating, and drinking his soup that She took his napkin and chopstick away.  I mean that's pretty mean when you see someone still SIPPING the soup and chewing.  And the put the bill down the table and walked away.

I know this place is popular, but not a way to kick your customer's out like that.  Even the Waiters in New york have the COURTESY TO ask if you were done before they take it from you.
author: Helena H.

description:
I actually really enjoyed this noodle house! Came here with my family and we all ordered an assortment of ramen . 

What I recommend: cheese ramen, or pork belly ramen. Cheese ramen is great for the kids, the creamy (parmesan) soup broth and the corn was delish, my cousin slurped it up so happily. 
I ordered the pork belly ramen and it came with this carmelized ginger which was surprisingly tasty! (I hate ginger pieces...) Plentiful pork belly and GREAT BROTH!! I loved the noodles too, cooked perfectly. 

Stay away from their nabeyaki(?) my mom had ordered the hiyashi soba and she ate off more from my bowl!

ramens range from $9-$11.95 each. it's decent price for its location. plus, a bowl of pho probably only cost a dollar less.
author: Sandra L.

description: I got the Char Suz ramen in miso broth with a side of pepper sauce and all I say is AMAZiNG soooooo good!
author: Wanh D.

description: Had high hope but left unimpressed... Gyoza was swimming in grease with stuffing exposed from broken skin. You could probably have better Ramen in other nearby places. Even better, you can buy refrigerated package from Nijiya market and easily prepare a good bowl of ramen in your own kitchen.
author: Lauren P.

description: Great Udon tempura here! Perfectly cooked tempura was not too oily, and the veggies were in no way mushy, something I often get with veggie tempura. The Udon noodles were also perfectly cooked with excellent flavor. The Udon broth had just the right touch of green onion, seaweed, etc. Service was excellent as well. I definitely would return here and hope to try the ramen next time.
author: Glenn A.

description:
I don't like the ramen here.  What I come here for is their curry... they have best curry in the city.  Forget Muracci's, Dojima Ann and Japacurry (and maybe Ajisen Ramen, which also has a decent curry that I eat often); those are good but it's what you eat when you can't make it to Suzu. This is where to get your curry on.

It's a small place so there can be a wait.  They do what they can with service but it seems they are always busy.  I don't have any complaints about that as long as I brace myself for it beforehand (or try to get there earlier).
author: Erika C.

description: The ramen's no longer what it used to be. Bland, bleh, ordinary.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Pretty decent ramen, so I'm not sure what people are talking about in terms of flavorless and bad broth. I had the miso ramen with chicken curry rice bowl kicker. Miso is definitely an intense broth here and your sodium intake will be generous. 

Good amount of noodles and I liked the chashu here. Porky and just fatty enough. Chicken curry went down well, and I love the little red pickles that go with the brown sauce. Tried a spoonful of the shio broth, which is much more clean-tasting and less heavy than the miso assault.

Always a wait, though never a long one. Both times I've been here around prime dinner time, you jot down your name and wait around fifteen minutes before you're seated at a little table or a booth "outside" (inside kintetsu mall still). Go check out Kinokuniya while you're waiting, especially since the comic area is downstairs now.
author: Kevin L.

description:
THE BEST RAMEN IN JAPANTOWN. PER.I.OD.

the establishment is small. like "we only have 10 tables, and you have to wait every time you come here by putting your name on a clipboard because we're that popular" small.

other than waiting awkwardly outside in the hallway every time we come here, the food is ahhhhh-mazzzzz-inggggg. i usually get the combo deal, where you get to choose betweenramen, udon, or soba, and with their beautifully laid-out menu maps, you get to choose an additional "don" item. all under $15.

their ramen is amazing, and their udon broth is the best i've ever had here in san francisco. i've yet to try their soba noodles.

my suggestion for this business is to take their popularity and grow it by adding a second location or removating this one to a bigger space. the only other ramen joint that is worthwhile to go to in the city is katana-ya, but because suzu is right across the street from where we live, it's naturally my favorite ramen spot.

we'll be back!
author: Mike N.

description: Not bad, nothing special though. In fact, I cannot think of anything that stood out (good/bad). So, if you want a standard bowl of ramen I'd suggest Suzu, otherwise there's plenty more to try in Japantown.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Came here with parents over the weekend. The place was already pretty filled at 5:30pm (we thought we would be super early to catch dinner). Luckily very short wait for us. Service is sufficient, but definitely not friendly. We ordered:

- Agedashi tofu: standard.

- Chicken kaarage: softer type of batter. Wasn't super flavorful (we all peppered ours immediately). I'm personally not a fan of that.

- Seaweed salad: standard, but yum.

- Pork Belly ramen in shoyu broth: I actually liked this a lot. Very flavorful, lots of pork belly, and al dente noodles.

Overall I would come back for ramen but skip the appetizers.
author: Linda L.

description:
The portions are huge, and the quality is pretty solid on the chicken ramen.  We had the Udon noodles and they made it extra SPICY just the way we like it.

The place was packed, and staff was friendly. 

Minus 1-star for long wait... told us it would be 5 mins and ended up taking over 20 mins.

I've now tried 3 of the noodle houses in Japan town and this ranks in the top 2.
author: Chris M.

description: Pretty much what you'd expect from a Japantown noodle shop: cheap prices, decent portions, average cooking. I got the butter corn ramen. The noodles weren't al dente, but they weren't overcooked either. The broth was greasy and salty from the butter and soy sauce respectively--not necessarily a good thing. And true to its name, the only vegetable that was served was a few kernels of corn. I expected mediocrity and I got it. So I guess I can't complain about unmet expectations. Still, not the worst dinner option if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Josephine L.

description: I was a bit skeptical about trying out ramen places because I feel that it's something that I can just get at the asian market and make myself in 5 minutes and for less than $1. After trying this place I may just stick to my Neoguri and Shin Ramyun. I had the Wonton Ramen and although it had a lot of toppings and was very delicious looking, it lacked flavor. It was very plain and disappointing.
author: Alisa J.

description:
1) Terrible place run by chaotic Chinese people (not authentic Japanese!) 
2) Terrible service - took us 10 mins to order and another 20 mins to get our drinks
3) No body seems to know what they are doing.  There's only one guy in the back cooking!!! geez no wonder the food only comes out one dish at a time! 
4) The guy next to us didn't get his gyoza with his meals and was being asked by his waitress if he wants it to go (???) Really? an appetizer to go??
5) People kept getting up and leaving their tables because the service was so slow. 
6) The only reason they are so busy is because of the traffic from J-town. 
7) Did I say not authentic?? It's not.

Oh by the way, don't eat in Japantown.  Food is not good and authentic.  Go to Richmond area for somewhat authentic Japanese food ...or go to south bay.   I must admit, I really don't like SF Japanese food....it's never quite as authentic or as fresh as the Japanese food in LA.   Comment from a Japanese person...
thanks
author: Thumper B.

description: I like their ramen, perfect place to go before a movie at Kabuki!
author: Samuele M.

description: awesome noodle spot. i like how perfectly spicy the ramen i got. service was also great. only reason why not 5 stars is that the place is small and it took a while for a party of 3 to get seated
author: Rye M.

description:
Loved the ramen here! was dying of hunger while visiting Japantown and asked an employee of a shop for a recommendation on where to eat. He pointed me in the direction of Suzu & it definitely satisfied my hunger! The seating was a bit cramped but this place is small in general. May not be good if you are with a big group of people. 

FOOD: they have a good variety, mostly everything on the menu sounded interesting and delicious. I ordered the ramen with japanese curry sauce. never thought of that combination before but it was delicious! 

Definitely coming back here again when i happen to be in Japantown. Slightly pricey in my opinion but the serving size made it worth it. 4 stars!
author: Sara T.

description:
I came here with my bestfriend, after shopping in Japantown becuz we were hungry
so first thing we had to wait for 10 minutes for our seat and write down our names on this clipboard thingg . and then we got our seats. it was our first time here. so we didn't know wat to order so we asked the waitress to recommend wich one is good. In the end we ordered Chashu Ramen! I had high hopes for the ramen since my sister said it was a good ramen place haha. but then wen the ramen came. the soup was super salty and the ramen wasn't soft it was sort of hard.. Overall, I honestly think the price wasn't worth it either because the ramen was 11$ and the soup was too salty and I don't really like the noodle texture. sorry /: the amount was alright doe in the big bowl.
author: N S.

description:
I really love the curry udon and able to add unagi with rice.
both are my favorite.
it's nice to get a table outside instead of inside the restaurant.

my friend didn't like the spicy raman he ordered though.

chicken kargage is decent.
author: Rina C.

description:
Not bad. They have some interesting flavours like the Suzu which is ramen topped with gyoza and chicken kara-age and the usual goodies, or mabo (mapo) tofu items, hiyashi chuka (cold noodles chinese style) and quite a few donburis.

I opted for the Mabo Ramen (who thought of putting my favourite Chinese dish on ramen!! It's a brilliant idea). The noodles came out a bit undercooked and I could taste the flour. However, let sit in the broth and it becomes pretty yummy. The broth is pretty standard. I guess it didn't wow me. The Mabo topping was a bit disappointing too -- while the spicy Japanese-style flavours are there, I barely found any meat, and the flavour got way too diluted with the broth. More sauce, more meat would've made this a better bowl of ramen.

Also, the Mabo bowl lacked any other condiments. Another disappointment there (some menma/bamboo shoots wouldn't hurt). Maybe their Mabo donburis would be better?

I stole a piece of chicken kara-age from the mister, and that tasted great. Although, fried chicken is fried chicken, and is hard to mess up too much.

We went during dinner rush but didn't have to wait too long for a table. The turnover is fast for tables of 2. I'd say, if there are less than 10 names on the list, you can safely put your name down. During that 30-min wait you can probably go to the nearby Kinokuniya or Maido to kill time.
author: Alice C.

description:
Never a dull moment when I come here.

I LOOOVE their Spicy ramen with karage (sp??) on the side. I once had them put the fried chicken in the soup. Bad move. The chicken eventually softened and then I wasn't happy with my decision.

I don't like having to wait and I find myself giving people dirty looks when they stay past paying their bill to talk. Dangit, I want IN.

Spicy means spicy. I once swallowed inadvertently and I was coughing up spice for a couple minutes. I thought I was dying. But twas a good spice, I tell ya.

Service is alright. There have been times when I've had to ask for something at least twice. Once, they misunderstood. A few times, they just forgot. The service is always friendly thought. Can't knock 'em for that.
author: Sharon B.

description:
Suzu Suzu Suzu....

What happened? 

You used to be so good to me. You used to love me with your luscious and flavorful ribbons of ramen kisses, lather me with your silky and loving broth. But those days are over! Now you are just lame and timid. Cold hearted and fat. Not to mention, you don't dress up like you used to (the suzu ramen special). 

But really though guys, for those who have eaten at Suzu from way back, you know exactly what I'm talking about. I used to adore this place, by far the best place to eat in Japantown SF. Their broths were a bit salty but was so on point back then. I can easily gulp the whole bowl down. Now all I get are mediocre tasting broth served to me luke warm and little accompaniments (which i didn't mind back then because their broth and ramen was so perfectly delicious).

I went to Suzu last Saturday for my friend's birthday and waited a bit to get seated, no surprise there. I never minded the wait, as Suzu was worth it to me. I quickly realized my usual Suzu special was not there anymore, super sad face. So i settled for the pork belly ramen. Which you guessed it, came with half an egg...a few pieces of pork belly,...and ramen. And then you think to yourself...hmm not that bad...i can live with this, until you tasted the pork belly! What is this? Weird tasting sweet marinade covering this over cook piece of porkbelly. Even my imaginary friend could've cooked a juicier piece of pork belly. I was utterly disappointed. 

For everyone who have been going to Suzu for a long time, please go there again and let me know that i'm not tripping. That the great tasting ramen/udon changed. The service was great like usual, so I can't knock them there. Blah where do i go for ramen now...
author: Tung T.

description: Mediocre at best for the ramen.  I had the chashu which was excellent meat but broth was bland and noodles didn't taste fresh as other Japanese places I have tried in CA.  The service was blunt and to the point as most asian restaurants, short on talk and more on expeeiting.
author: robert s.

description: I am giving them a 2star only because the waitress was very helpful but the owner or head manager was not. Since we had recently been to Japan we had very fresh and amazing Japanese food, Since this was suppose to be an authentic Japanese restaurant we expected what we had in Japan or at least close to it.....so we did ask our waitress who btw was from Japan, about the noodles, she was kind to let us know that these were american style and let us know the noodles would not be the same as the fresh noodles in Japan.  Well a friend we were with actually loves their soup, but I must be honest my two daughters and myself hated the soup!!  After speaking with the owner ( btw she was offended when I asked about the strange taste... what I didn't say is it was actually disgusting!!) she said it was probably the bamboo shoots, she said next time........ ask them not to put the bamboo shoots in..... She gave us no compensation for several large bowl of noodles we could not eat as I took two taste just to give it a chance!!!  So it was a very large bowl left that I NEVER ATE.... The fried Mandu was not tasty to me as well but the Mandu that is not fried I will give a 3 star. Our friends let me trade Mandu with them so at least I did get a few pieces of the Madu that was not fried....Will I go back it's a flat out No!!!
author: Danielle R.

description:
I've definitely been missing out--first time trying Suzu after going to the movies.  We waited about half an hour, but turnover seemed pretty good.  

Ordered the kukuni (pork belly) ramen and added on the unagi-don side to make it a combo.  While the unagi-don could have used a tad less of the sauce, it was delicious none-the-less.  Two big slices of eel! 

As for the ramen, the shio (sea salt) broth was excellent and they gave a generous amount of noodles.  In addition to the pork belly they gave other assorted goodies (make sure not to add on green onions of a boiled egg for $1, because they already give you some!).  Definitely was thirsty after, so can't say no msg was used, but will say that I enjoyed it and plan to go back!
author: Christopher W.

description:
Came here with high expectations because there's always a ton of people waiting when I pass by. 

I'd never wait that long for a table, so I was just in the area and looking for a place to eat and saw that they didn't have a long line.

Ramen was good. Had good flavor, maybe a bit salty. 
I got this stone pot dish, was a lot of food and really hard to eat because it just stays hot

Tiny place, service is okay
author: Erica L.

description: Only so-so, which is disappointing considering it's in Japantown, so you'd expect the best to be here. While the noodles were firm and chewy the way I like it, the shoyu broth was nothing special. I had the pork belly ramen, and there are 3-4 generous pieces, but a little too much fat on them. I ended up taking the fat off the last piece and just eating the meat. I love pork belly, but this was too much. We also got gyoza and agedashi tofu for appetizers; the gyoza were good, though they came out last, about 10 minutes after we'd gotten our ramen, and the tofu skin was too gelatinous. My dad raved about the tonkotsu broth, but my heart still belongs to Orenchi in Santa Clara.
author: Kathy L.

description: Pretty unbearable - and some of the vegetables showed up in our salad are simply disgusting. They are not fresh and completely soggy, almost rotten. I find it offensive that with all that mediocre service and horrendous dish, a forced 18 percent tip is applied to our bill, without any space for us to change it. Don't understand the hype for this place and definitely will never show up again.
author: Wayne C.

description:
This ramen place has one of the best quality noodles!!

I'm a big fan of those chewy noodles, so this is definitely the place to go for me, noodles-wise. There is almost always a wait if you don't go early, so beware of that!

-I usually order the Cha Shu ramen (salt soup base) which is around $12 if I remembered correctly. The soup is okay, but if I drink too much, I end up gulping down water like crazy since it makes you extremely thirsty afterwards ): The egg is always over cooked so I never even bother to eat the yolk since I find it kinda nasty. The cha shu comes with some fat, which I like, but honestly, it's a bit on the salty side.

Overall, I would come for literally the noodles. But then again, for the price, they don't give you that much and the other aspects of the entire bowl of noodle isn't that great.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Miso butter corn ramen is ($9.95) is my go to ramen dish. The portion is slightly large for me but it's probably a decent/average size portion for someone else. Comfort food!! Instant food coma!!!

There are combinations for an additional fee are also nice if you are hungry.

During my most resent visit, I had asked for warm/hot warm instead of tea. The waitress said they didn't have it and would have to microwave some - ok fine. She never came back to our table not did I receive my war/hot water. Customer service is not the best with certain servers.

The waitresses aren't the friendliest and your tea cup isn't refilled with tea over the course of your meal.
author: Kristina S.

description: Two weeks ago I order Zuzu ramen I told my waitress  fried chicken row and the server the Chinese girl told me his kitchen fault  nothing she can do and I forgot I was thinking I have a good Ramen today and she was working soon as I said my table she was coming straight to my face sorry about the last time your chicken well done she screaming my face I told her forget it I'm going to have a Ramen today should take my order she took my order my Ramen have no meat no icewater check is waiting for 15 minutes and really really bad service the place is really good really good Ramen I don't know how those kind of waitress working today is 09/24/15
author: Pj M.

description:
Cool little spot in Japantown.  I needed a ramen fix and it was perfect.  The broth was excellent and that's what counts.  

It's small, perfect for one or two.  It's on the Post side entrance near the cinema.
author: Vincent M.

description:
Huge disappointment.I have heard so many good things about this place  so I decided to 

 I ordered the soba noodles with chicken soup. The soup was so so, but the chicken was mainly grizzle 

when I explained to the waitress she said this is how they cut the chicken and"what do you want me to do?"

Well, for starters don't charge me for something that is inedible

Never coming back here !!
author: eric s.

description: Small little gem inside japantown. This place serves good quality curry rice and ramen. Sometimes it gets a little pack and you may have to wait also it gets a little warm inside. Nevertheless, the food is amazing!
author: Anan K.

description: I'm a returning customer for a reason. I've tried practically everything on the menu and I would recommend the salt ramen broth. My favorite is the pork belly ramen and the corn ramen. Not a very good selection for vegetarians as the veggie ramen wasn't very tasty.
author: Kelly D.

description:
The portions has gotten smaller since my 'ample'  review of 2009.  The quality of the dish was still good, though.

Not sure if I'll be back.
author: Debbie T.

description: Comparing it to Tanpopo, this place has really good ramen. Surprisingly, we didn't have to wait too long for a seat -- perfect for two.  I had myself the miso ramen, and it was pretty good. No complaints, but nothing TOO amazing.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Popular for the noodle bowls at every table.  Each dish is loaded with a lot of the meat and prepared/fried (katsu) very well. 

Braised pork belly ramen = miso flavorful broth, generous pork portions, overload of cut onions, slight thirst after the meal as the broth flavor tends to be a bit strong.

Pork Katsu curry rice = lovely dish presentation, curry and rice mostly separated in the bowl so it is not drenched in the sauce, comes with separated bowls of miso and salad, perfect frying of the katsu keeping the pork moist inside with nice crunch.

Extra - with a ramen order, you can add $3 / $5 for a small bowl of katsu (several combo choices) over rice.

Great and fast service.
author: Ju D.

description:
Very small place but quick turn around and service makes up for it. We ordered chashu pork ramen combo with katsu don and curry with chicken bowl and they were pretty good. Curry had deep flavors and good consistency and the ramen broth (I got one with miso base) was simple and flavorful. However, ramen broth got little too salty for my taste at the end so I couldnt really finish the bowl. Katsu don wasnt anything exceptional nor bad but I've definitely had better. 

Overall, pretry decent ramen at reasonable price so I rated them 4 stars. Keep it up suzu noodle house!
author: Toni S.

description:
Not good for a late dinner. This is the reason I gave them a middle of the road rating. The sign on the door says they close at 9:30pm. Don't think because it's 9:05 that you will get in. 
Word to management: a simple closed, too late to be seated sign would be less offensive than being turned away when the hours indicates your open to serve.

I got in on Tuesday night. Service was slow. My Raman was delivered with an apology for arriving late. 

Maybe Suzu is past it's prime.
author: Dan R.

description:
I have been to this restaurant two times now, and the first time was actually about three years ago with my family. When I first ate at this restaurant it was a Monday, mid-day, in the summertime. This place was the only business in the whole mall that actually had more than two tables filled so we decided to try it out. Two of us ordered the kimchi-ramen, and someone else ordered the tuna don with a bowl of ramen. The fish was very high-quality and the ramen noodles were the best, much better than most ramen noodles I've had elsewhere. I enjoyed the meal so much I vowed to come back and eat here again. I constantly thought about returning for years. I did not get the opportunity to do so until now because every other time I have visited Japantown, this place is packed and the wait time is about forty-five minutes (for good reason,) and when you are famished from walking around in the foggy S.F. summers in a big coat, anything quick is good. 
My father and I were in the city together and decided to have dinner at a restaurant in Japantown around seven on a Saturday night--probably the busiest time of the week for this mall. Every restaurant was filled with lines extending into the halls, but we both decided we needed to have the amazing noodles at Suzu again, no matter the wait. My father ordered the udon and tempura vegetables + shrimp combo, and I ordered the miso broth kimchi nabeyaki with tempura vegetables. I had no idea what nabeyaki was, but I recognized kimchi and udon so I ordered it anyway. It's basically a big hot pot full of chewy, delicious udon noodles topped with tons of vegetables and tofu, and maybe even a hard boiled egg! The kimchi was just right, and the noodles were cooked perfectly. I couldn't finish it all (too much food,) but I enjoyed it thoroughly. Especially the egg! I don't like to eat raw eggs at restaurants so the fact that it was hard boiled put me at ease. The tempura vegetables were equally enjoyable (tempura eggplant is my favorite, it was cooked so well.) I will say the barely tea was too weak, but at least it's a healthy and cleanly option as opposed to a soda or alcohol. If you don't think you can last the long wait time, grab a little snack and put your name on the list, it's totally worth it. I don't understand why the wait time is such a bad thing, it's not the restaurant's fault. It's surprisingly quiet for a place with glass walls (the wood frames insulate it well.) It's a cozy, intimate place with good soups and noodles. The portions aren't small either, or perhaps my stomach is just little. The prices are excellent as well,  under $40 for two people!
author: Aneesa I.

description:
Tiny ramen shop with fast service and decently priced, but a little underwhelming. Order the simple dishes as those tend to be pretty good.

We ordered the shio curry ramen, shio katsu ramen, hiyashi chuka ramen, and takoyaki. Both the curry and katsu ramen came rather quickly with the takoyaki shortly after.  Followed by the hiyashi chuka a while after that.

The takoyaki had tons of itty bitty bonito flakes dusted on them (perhaps to make up for shaving sizes instead of large flakes) but the ratio of tako to dough was actually quite perfect. The curry ramen was a bit more watery than expected. The shio katsu ramen had a pretty decent broth, and the hiyashi chuka "dressing" had a strong peanut flavor, which didn't really help the dish. It also resembled more of a noodle salad with large  lettuce leaves and various veggies on the side.
author: Katherine L.

description:
"Whatever happened to Suzu?"  An out-of-town guest asked me. 

This was my favorite ramen place in the City for almost a decade.  It was my default place for a heartwarming, low-key meal at least a few times a month.  However, the remodeling/ownership change completely killed it.  After a few consistently terrible meals, I stopped going.  While I've moved on to Ramen Underground and Katanaya, it saddened me when my out-of-town friend asked me, after he went there by himself again.  

"I don't know, but it's certainly not the Suzu I know."
author: Shirley F.

description: Got the ramen last time and it's really normal, the lady's attitude isn't really good.
author: Sam F.

description: Lunch combos are super good value. Not to mention delicious.
author: Joseph M.

description:
we had a quick lunch here last week and as always there is a line...well the place is quite small for noodle lovers.we were at the 4th line on the list...it took some time for us to get seated and gave us a chance to walk around the stores around the noodle house since its inside the japantown center.
i ordered chicken karage udon with small side of tempura over rice.
the soup was really good it has that very good flavor.the noodles were cooked perfectly.overall it was a OK visit.not really much in the menu.and its all simply noodles or salad.
author: Enah N.

description: Suzu's Noodle game is OUTRAGEOUS (in a good way). Their ramen is to die for, I love me some Chicken Karage with butter corn mmm. I was a bit weirded out that you might be sat next to someone you don't know but my girlfriend and I met some interesting people because of this. It can get really crowded in the afternoon and in the evening,  but it is worth it.
author: Kevin I.

description: Very mediocre ramen. Broth is not that good. Not the kind of broth that is boiled for hours and rich and flavorful. Noodles were soft and over cooked. Service not friendly. No smile, no greeting, not what I expected from a Japanese restaurant.
author: H L.

description: I could live in their Karaage ramen, with the miso broth and extra veggies. I'm from the Sacramento area, and whenever I make a trip to Sf, I have to stop by here. Nothing really compares.
author: Riana R.

description:
Came here with a couple of other people on a Sunday evening for ramen. It was one of those cold days in SF (and ONLY SF), and I was craving for something soupy and warm. Ramen sounded like a good choice.

I had the Chasu ramen, because I wanted more meat. My friends both got the Shoyu ramen, cause they could do with less meat.  I also ordered some extra seaweed and my friend gave me her bamboo, so I'm not a total carnivore! 

The noodles were really good. Firm, and not soft or overly chewy.  The bamboo was a little odd...maybe I'm used to the more fiber-type that Chinese people eat, but this one was limp and chewy. Still decent, but not what I expected. The meat was ok. It was a little tough, and there was noticeable fat on it. But I guess the two balances??

The price was OK for the ramen. Not cheap, but not too expensive.

The wait here was a little excessive. We left to get dessert before the meal and still had to wait another 30 min. Note to people who are going to eat here: Mark your name down and come back in an hour. Don't come here if you're already hungry.

We sat outside, because we didn't really want to wait longer for an inside table. There's only 2 tables outside, and I was a little disturbed to be sitting less than 1 foot away from a total stranger. Given, there's a wall between us, but still. Hello stranger...what kinda ramen did YOU get?? But the window allowed us to wave down our waitress. Sitting outside means your service will be slower. Don't come here with a group larger than 4. Even a 4 person group will take a while. We converted a 2 person table to 3. 

Its a 3.5, but for the long wait for not the most AMAZING ramen (its good, not amazing) and slow service...I say 3 stars.
author: Lily W.

description:
Had the shoyu kakuni ramen. Thought it was okay but not enough flavour.
Boyfriend had the shio spicy ramen. That was a little bit better.
author: Crystal W.

description: My favorite ramen place in SF. Crunchy kata age ramen is what I usually get. It's a small restaurant but the line goes fast if you are a party of two or less.
author: Reiko S.

description: Very happy with the ramen here.  A clean no-nonsense place in the Japanese mall kiddie-corner to the Fillmore on Geary.  Pork Belly ramen was ace, succulent broth and you can't go wrong with the tempura.  This was the first place I've tried for ramen in SF and I will go back.  Not a religious experience but 4 stars for hot fast and delicious.  There is a wait list at the door and judging by the popularity of the place I'd imagine it gets pretty long at night and on weekends.  We went at 3 in the afternoon on a Wednesday and walked right in.
author: Dangle B.

description:
My sister and I were still hungry after trying On the Bridge. We decided to eat down there. It's a small place. There is like 10 people working there. 

The ramen was not good. I had the spicy ramen and my sis had the friend chicken one. It was so oily. Fat on fat. I'm already so no more. 

One guy who was not really a waiter nicely asked how we were doing. I replied good but can I get a glass of water. He either forgot or just didn't care to bring me my water. I was pissed because we drank all of the tea. But, they were fast to us us the check. 

I will never go back. 

We should have walked to Turtle Tower.

If I wanted greezy ramen. I'd make instant noodle and add chicken mcnuggets.
author: Chris L.

description:
Delicious broth. As a standard miso broth it's richer than most in the bay. I ordered the pork belly and it was delicious. There was a generous portion of meaty, fatty, well seasoned pork. The bowl came filled with green onions, bamboo shoots, baby bok choy and I also added corn.  
Over all the pork belly with miso bowl was very good. The biggest negatives were that they dashed the top of the bowl (and my spoon) with some sort of salty (msg?) seasoning. The broth didn't need it. The other and biggest offender Was that the eggs are hard boiled which is just criminal. I think places that do this more out of cutting corners than a recipe choice. It's lazy and takes away from any otherwise good bowl.
author: Mark R.

description:
4 stars for food, 4 stars for service.  The restaurant itself isn't huge, so there are two tables for two outside, along the glass walls of the restaurant.  We were seated at one of them.  

We both ordered the "tokyo ramen" -- half an egg, juicy pork slices, green onions, egg noodles, seaweed, ... didn't taste like much.  Just tasted like, "OMG WE'RE EATING RAMEN".

*****Side note: street parking is free after 6pm!!! Don't keep trying to put in quarters (they take nickels, dimes, AND pennies) when the time does not increase... because the meters are magically programmed to only record 30 minutes when it is at the 5:30pm mark.  Additional note: the meters ALSO take Visa.  Who would've known.
author: Christina G.
