description: The food was very good but the service was horrible. We were yelled at by our waitress and treated like we were stupid. The ramen definitely isn't good enough to justify the service.
author: Diego S.

description:
Suzu has always been one of my gf's favorite ramen places in the Bay and it's grown on me too.  The thing about Suzu that distinguishes it from other ramen shops is that their noodles are the freshest.  I mean Katana-Ya has theirs made fresh daily too, but I think Suzu actually makes them in house...it's that fresh.  Also, their broth is clear and clean.  Yes, I like miso broth or salt broth, but for something different, Suzu really delivers.

Here's a bit of news:

They used to be closed Monday or Tuesday, but I recently found out that they're open 7-days a week.  They also no longer break between lunch and dinner, which means you can go at 4pm and get ramen while beating the crowds!  Their menu has also changed.  Katana-Ya had their "Katana-Ya Ramen" which had pork, fried gyoza, and karaage.  Now, Suzu also has a version called "Suzu Ramen"...surprise.  My gf and I surmised that the economy is responsible for Suzu diversifying their menu and upping the ante on their hours.  Either way, the customer wins :)
author: Dylan T.

description:
The ramen here is...well, it's not anything great.  It tastes good, but it's not that hearty ramen with a great egg or thick slice of pork...it's just a lot of mediocrity thrown together to make something that's kinda tasty.

The wait is usually pretty long, but the food comes out fairly fast. Also, they don't do take out, even though they have to go containers.  

The presentation was nice, but the flavor was lacking.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Taken from the transcripts of the Commission on Culinary Debates:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O-7gpgXNWYI (...Lloyd Bentsen was great!)

Suzu: "...and I have as much experience making ramen as Tanpopo did when they opened."
Ed U:  "Mr. Suzu, I have eaten at Tanpopo, I know Tanpopo, Tanpopo has good ramen. Mr. Suzu sir, you are no Tanpopo."
(Cheers and wild applause ensues.)
Judy Woodruff: "Please, please, you are only taking time away from your own ramen house."

...but the election was lost at that moment, and Tanpopo defeats Suzu in a landslide. So does Santa Ramen down in San Mateo for that matter. What a shame since I pass by this little noodle house any time I go to the Kabuki and need one of Sophie's Crepes to tie me over until I really have dinner. OK OK, I can be a pig...

Well, Jamie W. and I went here after seeing "Dan in Real Life" at the AMC Van Ness (loved it...read my review on Amazon, will ya?). There was a wait of ten minutes or so, which I interpreted to be a good sign that this place was the choice of noodle connoisseurs. As we were seated in front of the clean-up sink, we perused the menu and decided on two ramen bowls, both $8.50. Jamie went for the Kaarage Ramen, which was their standard ramen bowl with a little side bowl of Japanese fried chicken. It became confusing to us whether he was supposed to put it on top of the broth or just eat it separately between slurps. We needed more explicit directions.

I went for the house specialty, the Mabo Ramen, which was a bit more straightforward since it contained the standard broth with tofu cubes and allegedly ground pork bits. I say allegedly because I couldn't make out the bits of pork in the broth. I was also a bit bummed that no attempt was made to separate the ramen noodles from its packaged state. I had to separate them manually by spearing them apart with my chopsticks. On the plus side, mine had a spicy kick that helped considerably.

We both thought the ramen was rather overpriced given the paucity of ingredients, and the broth was somewhat saltier than I like. Service was on the perfunctory side, but in their defense, they had several tables to serve at the same time. Oh well, it's back to Tanpopo for me...or even more audaciously, getting a frozen package of saimin noodles from the Aloha Warehouse and making it at home.

Suzu: "That was really uncalled for, Ed U." 
Ed U: "You are the one that was making the comparison, Mr. Suzu -- and I'm the one who eats at Tanpopo. And frankly, I think you are so far apart in the objectives you choose for your country that I did not think the comparison was well-taken."
Suzu: "Say what?"

RAMEN - 3 stars...meh
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...nice ceramic bowls, nice noodle house vibe, very Shibuya Station-like
SERVICE - 3 stars...fast but kinda by-the-numbers if you ask me
TOTAL - 3 stars...just barely...marginally disappointed, so I should try other dishes if the mood strikes me again
author: Ed U.

description: Good noodles, no nonsense place. Food comes out fast. Fried chicken noodle soup and the udon noodles (non ramen) can be made without pork- hard to find!  I had the chicken udon (they also have beef) with miso and was delicious and pork free.
author: M M.

description: One of my favorite spots for soup. Spicy tofu kimchi udon is my faaaaavorite. Sometimes it's not spicy enough but the flavor is always spot on. This is the only item I ever order here and I definitely get cravings for it! I always try to eat here if they're open whenever I'm in Japantown! Udon then boba = best lunch/dinner ever!
author: Nas M.

description:
I've been here a couple times... both with my friends who are literally a FAN! The restaurant is TINY, the wait is HORRENDOUS! The food was so so and they SKIMP on the portion, lots of broth, not enough meat! The price is quiet high for noodle soup with very little meat!

My fave.. the spicy ramen... but with all honesty, to me, not worth the drive, the parking fees, the wait and the price...and there are better ramen places in my area..sorry Suzu..
author: Yun C.

description:
Had such a nice time here with some friends who drove up from Los Angeles! Thank you so much for the warm welcome, SF. The service was friendly and prompt, and we were seated immediately. It's super cozy and simple inside; nothing fancy.

I got the spicy ramen-- no special requests-- and it was delicious. I was satisfied by the serving size (drink your broth, people!), but if you're worried about the noodles not being enough, definitely hit up their combos, which are a great deal. 

Having also tried the Tokyo Ramen and Udon as well as the Suzu Ramen... I would definitely recommend the latter! (In retrospect, it seems 
obvious to order the namesake of the place...) It was by far the most savory, and the potstickers were fantastic.

Extraneous notes:
*Order a soda means getting a can... which means no refills. I always wish I knew this kind of thing going into a restaurant, so here you go!
*You know those ridiculous sparkly photobooth pictures that asian girls always take? There's a store upstairs in the same shopping mall that has like... 20 of those machines, seemingly imported straight from Japan. BEST $7 ever spent!
author: Brenda Y.

description: Really great Japanese food. I am not the best judge of authenticity but my date lived in Japan for 2 years and said it was the real deal. Know that it's an extremely small restaurant and not very suitable for groups. We only had 2 of us and waited probably 25 minutes around 4 on a Wednesday.
author: Jordyn C.

description: Let me start with this. We wait for about 30 Min.  Which is ok for a well demanded restaurant. the noodles were great, real authentic soup. The only thing I found out is that for a packed rest, not enough people to attend. Even though, they always managed to have the orders on time and  they were attentive. I like and I would go again. Beside Noodles they other options.
author: Manuel C.

description: Went here for lunch with my boyfriend and ordered the garlic steak bento box. So worth it. It was only $10 and came with SO much food! Definitely couldn't finish it all but the steak was so good I had to finish it regardless of already being full. Great food and a lot of it for a cheap price? Can't beat that!
author: Melissa R.

description: I always come here for lunch when I am in town. I love the cold Soba Noodles with veggies and tempura. Not as filling as the soup and absolutely delicious. The staff are kind and very efficient. Not only does it taste great. I always feel like I have done something very healthful.
author: Mike K.

description:
Quick!  What's my favorite food category?

If you guessed soups, then you would be right.  If you didn't guess soups, you should have read my profile, and while you were there, added me as a friend because I'm trying to get elite status.

Ok, moving on.

I love soups, specifically noodle soups.  Most noodle soups happen to be Asian, another favorite food category of mine.  So when I'm in a city such as San Francisco, while such a large Asian population, its pretty much a given that I'm gonna seek out some noodle soup.  Today's noodle was ramen.

I got the Tokyo ramen, which consisted of ramen (duh), a boiled egg half, some pork, some wakame, and scallions in a chicken-pork broth.  It was excellent.  As someone who has never lived in a place with a large Japanese community, I haven't really been exposed to ramen in any other form than instant.  That being said, I really like instant ramen so I never really stopped to consider that there might be something better.  Well there is.

The pork was tender, the noodles were perfect and the scallions were abundant.  The broth was the perfect mix of salty, oily, and meaty.  The portion, big.  Definitely a pretty good Fullness Factor on this soup.

Additionally, the meal was accompanied by green tea.

Tony Bennet had a song called "I Left My Heart in San Francisco."  Well, I can say that I'm not going to leave my heart here, mostly due to the clusterfuck of a parking situation, but I will leave my stomach here.

Domo arigato

5/5
author: Danny D.

description:
A ramen place with a vegetarian option--not something I come across often! I stopped by here with friends for dinner on a weeknight, having discovered that the place we were planning to go to had nothing on the menu I could eat (except maybe plain rice, sigh).

Having the mild egg allergy I do and noting that their menu mentions that the ramen there are egg noodles, I got the veggie udon. The broth and veggies were nothing to write home about (and in fact, I think I make a better udon soup at home in that regard), but the consistency of their udon is what would bring me back here again. Soft, but with that sort of al dente chew to it that can be called "QQ" (in the good/Asian sense). The omnivores thought their ramen was okay, and gave the place a "B+" in terms of the food.

Another thing about this place is that while the noodles come out good and hot, the service is kind of cold. Of the waitresses that stopped by to take our orders, bring our food, or refill our cups, I think exactly one smiled once. It wasn't bad service, but yeah, they aren't all that friendly-seeming and the dishes don't all come out at once, which can be awkward if you care about that sort of thing (I don't).
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I really really really wanted to love this place, but I don't.  Husband and I passed by and there was a long line and the restaurant was packed.  That should have been an indication that the place is good.  Oh boy were we wrong.  We didn't stop by on the first day because it was too long.

We came back at 11:30 when they opened the next day.  We were the very first people there.  Got seated first, then they let all the other people behind us in.  

Does it make sense to anyone that you get seated first, but your table is the last table for them to take your order?  Well that's what happened to us. I was extremely annoyed.  Everyone who came after us, literally got their orders taken before ours even though we were first.. including the ten top that was after us.  

To top it off... my husband ordered miso ramen and I ordered chasu ramen.  It was okay.  It taste like anything I could make a at home myself.  IT wasn't worth it.

Nothing in comparison to Ippudo, toto ramen or jin ramen in NYC.  What a disappointment.  I hope they work on their service and perfect their dish.
author: Debbie M.

description:
service here is incredibly slow!! we waited 15 minutes before we could order. and they almost skipped our names on the list even though we had been waiting for a good 30 minutes. 

i opted for the spicy ramen, it had some chasu slices, bamboo and some various other things in it. it was a little bit spicy but don't let the red chili oil scare you! its not that spicy! noodles were a nice and chewy consistency. broth a little bit salty but spicy. chasu the pieces were tender but they only put 2 pieces in it.  my friends thought their ramen was ok, but it wasn't the best they ever had. but still decent
author: Stella J.

description:
I think I've been spoiled by the yummy ramen in S. CA bc this was definitely not delicious ramen.  While they get a thumbs up for making their own noodles, the soup was nothing special and I barely drank any of it.  I ordered the combo, which came with a small bowl of tonkatsu on rice (very average and did I say small?) and a bowl of ramen.  We waited a long time for our table, too, as the place has like 8 tables inside and two outside.  When I came back the next day (read why below), there was a huge crowd of ppl waiting for lunch.  I don't get it!  Is it the location or the fact that there are just no really great ramen places in SF?

So the reason I came back was bc I had forgotten my camera the night before.  I kept calling the number I got from texting Google, which kept giving me someone's answering machine (the number Google gives is incorrect!), so I stopped by, and they were thankfully open.  They had my camera in the back - thank you for not jacking it!!
author: Caroline K.

description:
Went here for the first time on a Monday afternoon around 4PM for a triple date. Not a lot of people during this time. I've seen waits for this place on my previous visits to Japantown though.

BF and I ordered the combination specials. Cha Shu ramen and Karaage ramen, both with Unagi Don. The ramen and soup base was good. The Karaage was super! But the Unagi was the best. I will my ramen came with a soft boiled egg though like most ramen places.

Service was alright. Environment was clean. I will consider this place again if I ever want something to eat here in J-town.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Ramen and mapo don combination. Only 13, good serving size, more than enough for two ladies^^ lol
author: Kim L.

description:
So a couple of girlfriends and I decide to eat here before an Audium concert(?) Saturday night. Our mistake to go out to eat ANYWHERE on Valentine's Day weekend. The hostess told us that it would be a 10-15 minute wait which ended up being 45 minutes.

When we were finally seated, we ordered immediately (given the ample amount of time to view the menu). I ordered the miso ramen and one of my friends got the beef and vegetable while the other got a crispy chicken one (it starts with a k, I think).

It came out fairly quickly; we didn't have to wait too long. My ramen was just miso soup you get from a sushi restaurant with 2 pieces of pork and a ball of ramen noodles in it. Needless to say for $10, I was not impressed. It wasn't disgusting, but it wasn't amazing. My friends' ramens were okay, too, but definitely not worth the 45 minute wait. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing, but I would rather go to Halu if I had to wait that long and at least get some yakitori while I wait for my food.
author: Becky K.

description:
Suzu was packed on a Sunday night around 6pm. The wait was probably about an hour by the time we left. Many people say they move you through quick, but I disagree. We were ready to pay for over 10 minutes before they even came and checked on us. It was another 5 minutes before we were able to get the check. 

The Miso Ramen was pretty good. I like my egg less done (soft boiled, not hard boiled) then they serve it here. The broth was good, the pork a little fatty for me. Thinner pork would have been better I think.

The portions are large, and I wasn't able to finish my bowl of ramen. Price was about $13/pp with tip and tax. The ramen comes with hot tea.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Delicious delicious delicious!!!!!!!!!!!

I ordered the soba set, with a small donburi. You get your choice of ramen (Tokyo style), udon or soba (both traditional) and a small entree bowl of your choice (katsu, tonkatsu, curry, etc etc). My boyfriend ordered the karrage ramen. Everything was tasty!!!!!!!

I love how some people just aren't cut out for the wait. It's like.....the place looks delish, why not just wait the 15 minutes?? I will say that I dislike the stragglers, the ones that linger after they've already finished. Slurp down your soup and GTFO. That's how I feel about noodle houses, especially crowded ones......

I will come back here if in JapanTown and a hot bowl of ramen or soba calls my name. Of course, that is, if the call of another restaurant hasn't already snatched my attention.....
author: Jackie F.

description:
Finally this place isn't crowded. We usually go to Sapporo-ya upstairs but always wanted to try this place out.  

So we get there, get seated and I immediately like the combination choices. You can order ramen and a small side dish. 

I decide to order the Chasu (sp?) ramen with the croquette don. But come to find out that it only comes with one croquette ($3) so I order the croquette appetizer ($5.50) instead. 

Anyways, the waitress gives us water and tea from a tray that is almost full of water...so our cups were drenched. whatevs..I don't care, I just want my food! 

So my croquettes come...it comes with a side salad too. It was ok. I think it was a crab croquette and it was a little creamier than I would have liked but still pretty good. 

Anyways, when our ramen comes, it's a smaller portion than what you would get upstairs but I'm kinda full from the croquettes. But after tasting it, yuck! The broth is no where near as good, the pork is soooooo salty. I think they just marinate it in soy sauce or something. The egg is too well done, etc. The soup has a ton of msg in there or something bc I was so thirsty afterward. This place is not run by Japanese people from Japan so it's not as authentic as I would have liked. I don't think they know what it takes to make good ramen...so I'm kinda disappointed. Good thing we didn't go on one of those days where we would have had to wait for a long time...it would have been truly disappointing.
author: Leena C.

description:
Wow, surprised to see my yelp friends give such high praise. I had an okay experience here. My friends and I planned a get-together dinner before hitting up the city night life (we all aren't dwelling in SF). So my friend suggested this place and I haven't had ramen in a LONNNNGGG time.

I had the Curry Ramen and added the rice and chicken Katzu. It was alright. Flavor was there but the menu mentioned it having some sort of meat...well...it was a TINY piece of meat. For the high price? Really? Perhaps I am used to filling Chinese noodles or Pho or other asian noodles with a good addition of meat. Sorry, I'm a meat eater and if I am paying $15-$20 bucks...I better be getting some sort of filling meal.

Again, service was fine but this is going to be TMI. Later that night on our night out, my stomach wasn't sitting right (HARSH tummy pain). I told my old roommate and he said he was fine. Next morning I had to drop the atomic bomb...simply put. My friend didn't have the pain but texted me saying he had the same thing the following morning along with our other friend.

So we are positive that SUZU gave us the bad poopies. 1 Star because eek! Methinks NOT that I will not be back to this particular ramen place. :-/ Nice service but I couldn't enjoy my night because of the tummy cramp. We didn't drink either that night and I personally cramped 20 minutes after eating at SUZU. Bummer...
author: Roger C.

description: We took my mother here yesterday. She has been wanting to try it for quite some time.  I had the Suzu Ramen (shoyu broth). This broth is delicious. The karaage has good flavor but was very fatty. Good gyoza also. It's overall pretty good ramen. We also tried the croquettes. They were not great. The outer coating is nice and crisp but the mash potato inside is runny....more like the texture of paste. It was as if they mixed the potato with a bunch of mayo or something but it was just too runny. It makes it seem as if you're eating something that is undercooked. My step dad tried the chicken with curry and said it was ok. One great thing is they have a lot of great toppings....boiled egg, cha shu pork, green onions, etc.
author: Kel C.

description:
We came here at 6pm on a Sunday, only a 10 minute wait or so, but after we were seated, there was a long line.  I hear this place has some buzz and there is normally a wait.

I had the special combo, which included chicken karrage ramen and a small bowl of curry chicken don.  I definitely liked the crispy/breaded flavor of the karrage, but since it was sitting in the ramen it got soggy quick.  The rest of the ramen was just okay, nothing stood out there.

The curry chicken was good, there was some kind of sweet pickled lotus root in there, nice touch to the dish.

I really enjoyed their barely hot tea, kind of tasted like black sesame seed tea, yum.

all of that was for $14.95, not bad considering I had ramen and a rice bowl for my fat arse.

also our waitress was attentive, friendly and cute.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Disclaimer: This review is for the vegetarian ramen.

2.5 stars. It's apparently difficult to make a vegetarian ramen since traditional Japanese recipes rely on a meaty/fishy broth. Most places fail at trying to make one. A lot don't even have one on their menu.

I give credit to Suzu for having a veggie ramen, but nonetheless it left me unsatisfied. Everyone at the table commented on how the broth simply looked like clear water with some salt. Given the taste, that's what it might have been. At least there were plenty of veggies in it so it felt healthy and hearty. For this, I would have given Suzu 3 stars, but my bowl had a hair on the edge of it. Such things make me lose my appetite.

Alas, I will continue my quest for the ultimate vegetarian ramen elsewhere.
author: Aditi J.

description:
Wow, this place is definitely a NOODLE house.  My Tokyo ramen was ALL noodle with just 1 sliver of meat, and the broth was way too salty.  

The only thing worse than the food was the service!!  The waitress asked us what we wanted to drink, we asked for waters.  When our food came...still no waters.  Since we were getting thirsty from the salty broth, we tried to get the waitress' attention, but she was too busy chit chatting with her other waitress friends to notice us.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Usually, I'm very skeptical of ramen places in Japantown and dim sum places in Chinatown due to the obvious tourist trap locations. However, Suzu was an amazing & fantastic surprise! 

I have eaten ramen several times at both Katana-ya (Tenderloin) and Orochan (Los Angeles) and Suzu is my favorite hands-down. The broth is flavorful and spicy, the noodle consistency is perfect, and the ingredients were plentiful and delicious. 

I had the Ma Po Tofu ramen with extra spicy paste, which had pieces of ground pork and of course tofu. It was absolutely amazing. Still dreaming of it now... :)

The only downside I can see, is that it is a bit pricy. Although, that is completely expected given that it's Japantown and San Francisco. 

Ignore the fake 1-star reviews and try Suzu. You will not be disappointed.
author: kevin l.

description: Over-rated place with overcooked egg on the ramen, hard beef on the udon, super stingy on napkin, $1 for tap water. And at the end they charge service charge 18% for 3 adults 2 small children. Bah never again.
author: san h.

description:
Okay. I'll just say it.

I just don't think there is any ramen in the city that compares to the Peninsula. THERE. I said it.

That being said, of course, you would think that I would be judging ramen in San Francisco on a bit of a curve. You know, give them a fighting chance. Overall, I just think Suzu was "meh." 

I ordered the miso ramen with corn and pork. The noodles were so-so, the corn they forgot and just added in as an afterthought (a small pet peeve of mine to begin with) and it was cold, so the whole thing was lukewarm. The broth wasn't really flavorful. 

If you have other options, go to Sophie's Crepes and indulge in a crepe instead. Or go across the street to Tofu Doobu for a simmering pot of soft tofu.

And if you're REALLY hoping to scratch that itch for ramen but can't make the trek down the 101, I say go to Katanaya. 

Skip the lines and skip this place.
author: Shay F.

description: Decent ramen, but nothing extraordinary.not too rich, I got the spicy one. Noddles on the thicker side. Not a fan of their eggs- just hardboiled. I asked for half noodles and didn't get it.
author: Natalia M.

description: I loooove the ramen at this joint! I just wish I wouldnt have to wait 30-45 minutes to get a table any time of the day, any day of the week and thats because they are usually understaffed and it shows on the service too . But their ramen is soooooo delicious that I cannot give them less than 4 stars!
author: Mariel M.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday since all of the other ramen places were closed in the area until dinner time. There were a couple parties already seated so my friend and I decided to give it a try. My mistake.

The service was kind of slow from the beginning. I ordered the chasu ramen (because it said it came with 3 slices of it!) and so did my friend. Our ramens came out probably 10 minutes later. I took a sip of the soup, stirred my noodles a bit, pulled a bit up with my chopsticks, and saw a hair tangled between the noodles.

I told the waitress and she stared at it closely before bringing it back to the kitchen. Another waitress came back and apologized, asking if I'd like them to remake it. At that point, I didn't even want it but my friend and I were super hungry so I said sure. While I waited for my food, I drank all of my tea. No refills during our visit whatsoever.

10 minutes later my ramen came out. My friend was trying to eat slowly but he was so hungry he couldn't wait for mine to be remade so he was almost done by the time mine came out. About 2 minutes after my ramen came out, the waitress had the nerve to drop the check for our table while I was clearly still eating. The broth was so plain and boring, it tasted like watered down soy sauce. The only plus about it was that the chashu wasn't super fatty like normal places.

Bottom line, terrible service. I don't know why some of my Yelp friends liked this place. I'm appalled.
author: Valerie T.

description:
Suzu Noodle house is a solid but not excellent ramen joint. The noodles are cooked well but seem to be packaged rather than made fresh. The eggs are hard boiled which was disappointing and I wish they offered a tonkotsu based broth. 

On the other hand this is one of the better ramens I've had in San Francisco and it's definitely good for a mid week meal. The miso broth is tasty and the meat quality was very high. Standard offerings like gyoza, karaage, butter, corn and eggs can be added to your dish. I recommend the spicy sesame ramen. 

Don't be put off by the line outside, service is fast and the line disappears quickly.
author: Amaya B.

description:
Four of us had lunch here today and were delighted with the meal.
I wasn't very hungry so I just had potstickers.  But they were perfectly prepared.
The others had noodle dishes and liked them very much.
The service was good and the restaurant was comfortable.
I would like to return for dinner.
author: Philip C.

description:
Very tasty ramen and udon noodles, with many combinations.   We tried the ramen with vegetables, ramen with pork slices, all very good. The udon with tempura was with a fish based broth, also very good. Put take the tempura out quickly or it will get soft:-)

My wife was bot in the mood for noodles so she had their plain tempura. The tempura by itself was very good, with the vegetables or shrimp perfectly cooked inside. Sometimes tempura has mushy batter, but not here, it's very well done, crispy dark golden crispy, not oily. 

Staff are very nice, kid friendly. 
You might have to wait a little at busy times but there are plenty stores around to look into :-)
author: JJ B.

description:
Came here a couple days ago, and unfortunately I wasn't too impressed with Suzu's :/ It was 11 o'clock on a Monday (Labor Day) and it was completely filled with people, so I knew it was a pretty popular ramen place. I figured okay, it's packed, it's Japantown, the ramen must be legit? After a 15 minute wait, we were seated and I decided to order the Shio ramen which has sea salt and some pork slices.

The order came pretty quickly, but at first glance I was already disappointed and craving my own instant noodle ramen I make at home. They seemed to really skimp on the noodles and definitely the meat. The egg was really dry as well and the broth was oily and tasted bland. I tried my friend's Chashu ramen which was a little better, but only because it had a couple more slices of meat! 

For the price that I paid, I don't think Suzu's is worth the money or the wait. If you've ever tried Orenchi ramen, that's what I would consider excellent ramen :)
author: Cindy S.

description:
Suzu has quickly become my new bi-monthly ritual:

Step 1: park car in front of Kabuki Springs on Geary
Step 2: go to Kabuki springs and relax in the communal baths for minimum 1 hour.
Step 3: drop off bag in car and walk 100 ft to Kinukuniya Center.
Step 4: get table at Suzu and order soba, udon, or ramen with your choice of dish over rice.
Step 5: enjoy and repeat in two weeks.

I like that you can order half size sets of noodle plus rice dishes.  Most times I want both and now I can have it!  I like the soup in the hot soba, though it doesn't come with anything in it.  Hot ramen has a piece of pork and some veggies.  The mabo kaarage don is yum yum.  The set is about $12 (rice bowl + noodle soup).

Only reason I took off 1 star is because the servers are kinda moody and seem like they hate life.  Oh, and they don't do togo orders.
author: Alice L.

description:
I was ready to eat when i got to suzu as the noodle shop smelled so good!  The aroma from the broth was very appealing.

We started with the agadeshi tofu appetizer and that was just alright. The tofu was not fried well enough and the battered exterior was falling apart. The sauce was also a bit bland; so you can forget that.

My friend and I both ordered the Suzu ramen with spicy broth and it was delicious. The spicy broth at Suzu is one of the best I've had; it's actually spicy. And it was just the right amount of spicyness - enough to taste it but not I-must-gulp-iced-water-spicy. 

The Suzu ramen was actually too big for me to finish. It contains potstickers, chicken karages, BBQ pork (that was too fatty), hard boiled egg and bamboo shoots & seaweeds. I'd definitely be back to try their other dishes.
author: Terry C.

description:
What a bummer! This place used to be great.

Its clear that Suzu Noodle House has had some changes. I don't know if its a new owner, management or chef but what ever it is...it's NOT working. 

Suzu used to be my family's "go to" place for ramen when in Japantown. What we were served was mediocre at best. The bright fresh vibrant ingredients have been replaced with bland, boring, blah. 

Ever since I read David Cheng's inaugural issue of Lucky Peach magazine devoted entirely to the art of ramen I've been searching for the perfect bowl. Suzu was never the perfect bowl but a least it was tasty. So bummed! 

If anyone has a good recommendation for ramen in Japantown (or any where) please let me know.
author: C J.

description: Solid, well cooked Soba and Udon, generous, fresh vegetables, decent service, quick food on a Saturday night. The Japantown mall setting doesn't do much for the eyes.
author: Surya G.

description:
Got here on a saturday night and the place was packed. The wait was an hour long but totally worth it. The chasu ramen with extra chasu had so much meat in it that everyone was shocked that they gave me that much. The chasu was soft and tender and the broth was rich and flavorful. The noodles are cooked perfectly and the combination of everything together = awesomeness. 

Appetizers to go with, I'd recommend the chicken karaage. Crispy on the outside but juicy and tender on the inside, very good.

Seating is limited, as all good ramen shops are and I'd say that this is probably the best ramen place in Japan Town hands down. Can't wait to go back.
author: Ander C.

description:
I actually have gone here twice and apparently forgot the first time because when I went to look this up on Yelp, I discovered I hadn't written a review for it! For shame, bad Yelper, for shame!

It wasn't because the place wasn't good... we came here during the J-Pop festival a few weekends ago since nothing in the food trucks looked that interesting (and YAY RAMEN). The soup is delicious with lots of stuff in it, and we left quite satiated.

That being said, I ordered the vegetarian ramen that has tofu in it. I forgot about the tofu until I found one small 1/2" cube at the bottom of my soup, when I was nearly done it. Not that I really care about boiled tofu in ramen (I find it rather eh to be honest) but if you're going to list tofu as one of the ingredients, it should actually have tofu in it, not one measly little piece of it. 

The other complaint is that the service was good when we got there, but when it came time to pay, none of the servers would stop by to take our money. Say wha? Why would you not want to gather up the money and get us out of there? We were waiting on change, since my friend wanted to leave a tip, but after sitting there for five minutes without a server taking our cash and check (even when we tried to get their attention), we plunked down just enough to cover the check (with maybe a $1 tip) and got out of there. Sorry Suzu, we wanted to leave you a tip, but you snooze, you lose.

Overall, food is good, service is mediocre.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
I like the ramen, however...

This place seems to rarely be open. Or whenever I happen to be around and hankering for a bowl of ramen - it seems to be too busy or closed. 

Tends to have inefficient service. Everything seems to take awhile.
author: Gee H.

description:
Mediocre food and service. 

Came at 8pm - ran out of pork belly ramen and chasu ramen, could have told me that before I started to order. 

Ramen noodles undercooked and many were stuck together - soup base was just okay. Minimal toppings ... 2 bamboo shoots, 1 bok choy, and some green onions. 

Why is there no good ramen in Japan town??!
author: Daniel K.

description:
One of the better ramen places I've eaten at in the city so far. Although I prefer the thinner noodles, the broth is really what makes ramen for me. I ordered the shio (salt) broth & it was just right- not too salty with just the right amount of taste. The pork was on the salty side but perfect with the broth. 

My fiance ordered the cha siu ramen which was tasty as well, with many slices of pork included. 

For a 2 top, we waited around 20 minutes to get seated, and another 15 minutes after we ordered to get our food. Although the restaurant is small & slow, the ramen was worth it & I would go back again to try something different, maybe one of the combos with ramen, rice, & maguro for only about a dollar more.
author: Alysha K.

description: Don't waste your time coming here. I've been sitting here for 20 minutes no water and get any attention. Waitress walked away when I told her I had a question about the menu. Awful service.
author: ann marie t.

description:
Whenever its cold, I'm always in the mood for some type of noodle soup.  I was in the J-town neighborhood, so I decided to fill my belly with some ramen.  Suzu's a bit small, so we had to wait about 10 minutes to get seated.  

We got the Chicken Karaage to start with and then the Tonkatsu Don and Tempura Don Ramen combos.  The Chicken Karaage came out first, and the ramen combos quickly followed.  The chicken had good flavor, but it eventually lost some of its crispiness after it sat for a bit.  The ramen was good with flavorful broth.  The broth was nice and hot and warmed me right up.  My tonkatsu was crispy and the portion was just enough.  

The combo was definitely a good deal.  I left feeling very full and didn't finish everything either.  

If you come here before they close, you might not get seated.  I came a second time before closing, and we were turned away even though there were plenty of seats in the restaurant.
author: Patra I.

description:
After reading all the rave reviews of I decided to give this place a shot. Is it just me or is ramen all the hype nowadays? 

The decor is very modern with simple dark wood and open space. There is also "outdoor" seating. I was brought back to Katana-ya from looking at the menu. The menu looks exactly like Katana-ya's menu! Well not exactly but there is a big resemblance. 

The bowls are very deep. Even though it doesn't look like a lot of food there is enough. The noodles were decent kind of like Katana-ya. I thought overall it was alright. You get one piece of pork if you didn't order the cha su ramen. 

Price is good. I wouldn't mind coming back here only if I was in the area.
author: Sarah C.

description: This has become our neighborhood go-to ramen spot. It's consistently good! The curry ramen (ask for it spicy) is amazing, definitely my favorite on the menu. Prices are fair and service isn't great but not bad either.
author: Elena K.

description:
SUPER OVERRATED. There's always a wait. Normally my boyfriend and I eat ramen upstairs at Sapporo-ya. We always see a line outside Suzu so we decided to wait one day to see what all the fuss is about. You're not missing out on anything.

Noodles are too hard. Do not enjoy al dente for ramen. 
Shio ramen - Wayyy too salty.

Despite not having the best ramen experience, I wanted to take the half of a bowl left home because I hate to waste food. They told me that they were out of to go container lids so I couldn't take it. I told them I didn't want to let half of my meal go to waste. After a lot of discussion they finally put a saran wrap cover and rubber banded it to the top. Come on people! Go next door and ask to borrow a to go container or something! 

Next time I want ramen, I'd rather go to Sapporo-ya upstairs where there is no wait and the noodles are great.
author: Gina R.

description:
Snooze Snooze Noodle House

I would like this place a whole lot more if they had gave me more than a one dinky piece of pork (almost the size of my egg).

Broth was good and not salty (like other ramen places).  The noodle was good.  And so, it's sad to only give the place only 3 stars.  $8.95 for a simple ramen w/barely any toppings.

Me: Hey do you think this place is cheap on the topping or did I get jipped?

Friend: I don't know...maybe you got jipped? But you know, I don't have much meat in mine either.

So what gives?  Would I come back here again? I wish I can say yes, but I don't think so.  At least not until, someone writes a review about having a full strip of pork in their bowl
author: Theary K.

description:
The combos are the best deal. On my last trip here I had the chicken katsu donburi and the ramen. I've also ordered the chicken karaage combo and it's equally delicious.

The plus: the food is delicious and the service is friendly. The minus: the wait for a seat is sometimes long bordering on insanely long.
author: Dani D.

description:
Perhaps the better ramen place in the center, but overall, it could be overhyped. Like any other busy, overhyped restaurant, service can be flaky. Some quiet nights they can be better, but busy day, oh man. they'll give you that look of "quickly pay and get outta here". 

On cherry blossom Saturday, I was here with 3 other friends and they literally asked us to get up the table as soon as they cleared our checks. I work in the restaurant upstairs and I swear to the food god we never EVER could do that to customers, no matter how busy we are. 

Oh, and don't order their miso ramen unless you're in for a high-blood sodium driven pressure in your vessel. Go home with the shio.
author: Rika P.

description:
Boyfriend ordered corn ramen and I ordered chasu ramen. Chasu Ramen stank of rotten bamboo shoots but corn ramen was good. Sent back chasu and they told me its supposed to be like that! Avoid unless you love food poisoning.

San Francisco is a hotbed of good food and with the price of food going up people need to step up their service and quality to match the insane prices. My reviews are getting increasingly aggressive because I see this as a 'eaters' market, where restaurants need to pay attention to the eaters because they're charging so much money.
author: Stephen H.

description:
I've had better. Had a bowl of not-so-memorable ramen here.

Why are good noodles hard to find in sf?! My hunt continues...
author: Nadiyah S.

description: Ramen was good. After we finished and, in less than 8 minutes after paying, the waitress asked us to leave while we were still having a conversation because people were waiting to be seated.
author: N J.

description:
Love this place!  There's sometimes a wait for seating because it's a small place, but once you order, the food comes out pretty quickly.  The mixed sashimi appetizer is a "must order".  I wasn't expecting super high quality sashimi, but it was melt in your mouth good!  For $7.95 we got 4 slices of salmon and 3 slices of tuna.  The chicken karaage was really good too - great portion.  

As for the ramen, I got the Spicy Ramen the first time.  I like less cooked noodles and theirs was perfect.  It wasn't overcooked or too undercooked.  The broth was really flavorful, but you can see a decent amount of oil.  The second time, I got the chicken karaage ramen and the noodles were perfect again.  The bowl portions are pretty generous too.  

I haven't tried the other types of dishes yet, but definitely will in the future.  So if you gotta wait for a seat, suck it up and do it because your taste buds will thank you.  =)
author: Jenn K.

description: The food is ok and staff are very nice, it's only the cleanliness that did not dazzle me!
author: Amir A.

description:
While trying to convince my friends to go to another ramen place I liked elsewhere on the way back home, we ended up being too hungry to make the trip so we ended up staying and eating at Japantown instead. Having some prior pleasant experiences eating here before, I figured I offer the suggestion amongst my friends and we ended up grabbing food here.

Being quite a small place, there was a decent wait time as we waited to get seated. After we got a table we were pretty set on what we wanted and I ended up getting the unagi avocado roll dinner combo with cold udon (since I felt a craving for cold udon for some reason).

The roll came out and it was a decent small appetizer portion of 4 small pieces. Nothing too special about it. The udon came out to be cooked very nicely though, and the flavor was just wonderful. Sadly I was still left pretty hungry after I finished though. Good food, but I wish I had just a bit more.
author: Trung N.

description: Best noodles in J town if not in the world. And I don't say that lightly. I've eaten noodles all over the world (except for North Korea and noodle deficient societies). The miso ramen is my go too. Topped with an egg and if you so desire pork belly (lots of other options including fried chicken). The noodles are super fresh and you have to contend with a massive bowl. Oh joy! Of all the problems to have this one is tops. If you're coming for lunch give yourself a 15 minute wait time as there is usually a line. There's a wait list by the door so sign your name (in blood of needed) the moment you get there. I haven't seen any fist fights over line jumpers but I must say that it would be perfectly reasonable to protect your place in line. What's a little misdemeanor battery when trying to get through the door of this place.
author: Jahan T.

description:
-another Kara age & kwik slurp before hitting the matinee at Sundnance Kabuki.

One Kara age
One Suzu Ramen
One Double Cha shu Ramen

Instant tea
Instant cold water.

Kwik & efficient.

[Kakuni Ramen has been discontinued, even tho it's still listed on the menu.  BOO]

Let's go again tomorrow!
author: Clifford L.

description:
A small ramen shop inside the Japantown complex. You will have to wait during peak meal hours because there are so few tables.

I have had the miso ramen and the spicy ramen. They make their noodles just right.
The broths here taste good but the bowl of ramen as a whole doesn't satisfy me like other ramen shops do. I am not sure whether its the small amount of food or the lackluster quality of the secondary ingredients, or both.

The service is decent and the food comes out fast, but the food needs to improve for me to come back.
author: Alfred L.

description:
I had Kakuni (stewed pork) Ramen. Slightly above average, as average as an average Ramen in Tokyo would be. Is it worth lining up for? No. Is it worth walking in and eating it? Yes.

Good: broth was nice. Although I tend to like Tonkotsu, their shoyu broth had nice flavor (although I suspect they may be using a dash of MSG). Menma: good. Even if it came from a can. Kakuni, generous portion, nice texture and flavor.

Not so good: noodles were al dente, but not in a pleasant Ramen noodle kind (chewy and curly).

Bad: half a hard boiled egg. Egg needs to be soft boiled. Two strands of spinach. WTF? No Naruto?
author: Yasuo S.

description: I'm so sorry that I'm giving a 1 star for them. The worst ramen I have ever had in town. If you are a ramen lover, please don't try this one. You will be very disappointed. Service was bad too. I still had half a bowl, but the two waitresses came over 3 times and asked... 'Are u finished?' 'Are u done?' OMG. Forget it, I won't come back!
author: Stan L.

description:
Reasonable prices, flavorful ramens, combo meals! Sold!

I trek a bit further from the pad to get to Suzu over Tanpopo for some ramen. Their ramen is yummy, satisfying, but I have to admit that I'm not a ramen snob. I like how they have combos where you can get something like a side of ma po tofu over rice, or curry, or salmon-don with your ramen or udon or soba (even though it's way too much food when you do get that!). The only thing is they often have a wait, but many people go walk around the little mall while they wait...which means they skip down the list pretty quick. The nice thing is that they don't always cross your name off the list if you're not there when they call your name, since so many people do that. Overall, solid place for a meal.
author: Christine L.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Tokyo Ramen = I like how the noodles were neatly folded, making it easier to pick up and place neatly in my soup spoon ^__^ I also like how the soup spoon was ergonomically designed with a hook at the end to curve around your finger, and the divit to hook onto the bowl when resting the spoon on the side. Smart! Anyway back to the soup.. the toppings left a little to be desired, only two pieces of pork :( Some bamboo shoots, some green onions... Soup was simple, good, a lil plain.. Not bad, but there's better places for ramen :)

SERVICE:
Not bad

ATMOSPHERE:
I like it, kinda basic contemporary clean. Inside the Japanese mall.
author: Angela L.

description:
I was craving a good bowl of Ramen and happened upon Suzu Noodle House after reading some favorable reviews. It didn't disappoint.  It's probably the best ramen spot I've found in the city thus far.

I ordered the Suzu Ramen which included bbq pork, japanese fried chicken, fried gyoza, hard boiled egg, wakame, bamboo shoots and scallions in an incredibly flavorable pork broth.  The ramen is housemade and had a great texture and bite to it.

I would never think to put fried chicken in a ramen soup, but it definitely worked. Great flavor!  The potsticker I think it could have done without. It was a bit superfluous.  The broth had great depth of flavor and it was the perfect bowl of soup for a hangover or on a cold day.  At $14 it isn't cheap, but for a good meal, I often don't care what the price is as long as I leave satisfied.  I would definitely recommend this spot!
author: Matt E.

description: The veggie tempura had a nice assortment but tasted just average with a bit too much grease. My vegetarian miso ramen was pretty, but so bland. I added spice and soy sauce to make it decent, at least. Perhaps something other than the miso flavor would be a better choice, but I'm not sure I could be persuaded to go back and try.
author: Rachel M.

description:
We should've read the reviews first rather than following our noses.  

We spent the whole day sightseeing so my husband, cousin (who was visiting from another country), and I decided to walk around Japantown when we were hit by this glorious smell.  We were starving but decided to sign in and wait as the place was packed and there were many people waiting.  This is where this place started to lose stars. We sat right next to the sign up sheet and I noticed my name was next. The waitress totally passed us up and started calling out names for party of 2's because there was a small table available.  I thought to myself, shouldn't she have asked us first if we wanted that table.  After calling out several names, I sort of say something under my breath and I guess she heard me, she eventually asked but we, of course wanted a bigger table... - one star

Now we're seated at our table and we all opt for seafood dishes as it was holy week.  My cousin and I decided to get the J ramen (I think that's the name), it's spicy with, well, it should have shrimp and salmon.  So we're waiting for someone to take our order.  I notice two parties come in after us and they have their orders taken before we do.  I flag one of the waiters who was bussing off a table and he ignores me and continues setting up a freaking table... - one star

Eventually we place our orders and one of our appetizers comes, the octopus dumplings.  It's pretty good. The waiter offers us small plates and acknowledges that we have another appetizer coming. So now, I'm like, "OK, he's going to get a couple brownie points for that one".  Our main dishes arrives. My husband has the shrimp curry and my cousin and I have ramen.  I'm mixing all the goodness in my bowl and notice there's NO salmon.  My cousin doesn't have any either.  The salmon was replaced by 2 small clams and mushy tofu.  Geez, the waiter could have told us... - one star (actually this should be - two stars)

Eventually we realize that we didn't get the agedashi tofu so we ask.  In a minute, it comes out.  The tofu is sticking together which means it's been sitting out for sometime now... -one star

At this point, we all just want to go home.  I'm partly embarrassed because here I am showing my cousin around the city, it was her first time here, we're having a great time and earlier that day she says she loves it here but then we decide to eat at this place, everything just goes downhill from there. We decide not to leave a tip because they didn't deserve it.  As we were walking towards the bathroom which is around the corner, the waiter comes up running and asks, "was there a problem?"  I don't hesitate and tell him.  All he says, "OK, I just wanted to know."  Not even an apology.  HORRIBLE SERVICE!!!
author: Rose E.

description:
I believe this is the best place to eat compared to the other restaurants in the mall. Great deal on the Lunch Combo (10.95) for mini rice dish  (like with Tempura, Salmon Sashimi, Ugani, and there's more choices) PLUS your choice of noodle hot/cold ramen, udon, or soba with 1 slice of pork, green onions, dried seaweed, and bamboo shoot in a tasty pork broth. Great portion size. 

I tried the Salmon Sashimi over rice & ramen lunch combo. The salmon sashimi was soo good, it melted in my mouth. :)`  The ramen was delicious, a little al dente/chewy just the way I like my ramen. The broth was a little too greasy though. 

Overall experience: B
author: Karen P.

description:
Whenever I go, the place is always packed. I usually bring a party of around 5-8 people and for a small place like Suzu, it's always hard to get seats. The wait is worth it though. I usually try a different type of ramen when I go there so I can't say I have a favorite or usual. Their ramen broth is amazing! My friends and I can't get enough of it. Normally, I don't drink much broth when it comes to eating noodles but Suzu makes me finish more than half of the broth. 
The price for the portions are what I like to call "normal SF Japantown prices". If you don't normally eat in Japantown you would consider this as "expensive" for the portions. 
Service is a bit slow, but I can't blame them when normally I have a big party. However, if you go a little bit after the lunch rush the service speeds up.
author: Carina L.

description: This used to be one of our favorite spot.  Today, the one piece of green in the noodle soup was not fresh, it looked it's been in the fridge for weeks. There were maybe 2 pieces of bamboo shoots, half of an egg and 2 piece of meat in the miso Ramen, that's it. Definitely not what I remembered before.  One of the waitresses was clearly annoyed when I didn't hear her question and asked her to repeat. Not going back for a while. Plenty other Ramen places to try in sf.
author: Helen T.

description: Wife and I had two different types of noodles and they were both really nicely done. Tea was wonderful, ambiance was nice. The first place I've been that actually reminded me of being in Tokyo. It's not a five star but its the best I've found so far.
author: Daniel E.

description: Noodles were al dente which was good but the broth was too oily probably from the fried chicken. Presentation wise, a nice looking bowl of ramen. I love ramen but this sadly didn't meet expectations.
author: Sandy P.

description: This is honestly the worst eating experience I've encountered. They messed up my order. I asked for no onions and no beans sprouts. Granted, I don't like to bothersome so I attempted to pick off everything I didn't want. It was too much too pick off so I asked for it to, to be redone. I had paid extra for chicken and an extra egg. When my "fixed" food came back. It did not have my extra egg and came back with 1/3 of the chicken my first ramen had. If it would have been my mistake, I wouldn't have complained. When I brought the missing egg to the waitresses attention she said she would take it off the bill. Then she came back with some bullshit excuse and flat out lied to me. I really tried to be nice and give this place a win by not even mentioning the fact that they had given me less chicken, noodles and broth the second time around. Ultimately I came to the conclusion that they just don't give a shit if the food is good or if they've provided good service. I ended up paying for an extra egg, which I did not receive and a few tiny pieces of chicken. I wouldn't have cared if the food was good. The noodles had no flavor and neither did the broth. it was fucking gross. 15 bucks down the drain. I took maybe 3/4 bites. Basically they messed up my order and instead of fixing THEIR mistake, they chose to remake my new ramen and save money by skimping me out on everything I had paid extra for. DO NOT EAT HERE!!!!
author: Jessica M.

description:
I'm a huge fan of ramen and this place didn't quite do it for me. It wasn't terrible but it definitely wasn't what I consider to be good ramen. 

I ordered the Miso Ramen. The texture of the noodles was perfect and the noodles seemed fresh. However, the broth wasn't very tasty.  I'm sorry, but if the broth isn't up to par, then the ramen isn't up to par. This wasn't good miso broth. Also, I was missing the nori in my bowl of ramen. I'm not sure why they don't put nori on it but I did notice and did miss it. 

This place has acceptable food and okay (but not great) service. I would be willing to try this place again sometimes . But I really hope they improve the broth.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: This is my second favorite ramen place. Went here with some old high school buddies after watching a film at the SFIAAFF in Japantown. The place was packed and it was difficult to move our chair around for fear of bumping into other customers. Food was good though and I finished my whole bowl of ramen. I would definitely come back.
author: Cindy S.

description:
downgrading... soup base still the same... and yes, they still have spicy negi... but i think the kitchen staff and everyone else there has changed... 

the noodle is definitely not the same... they use to have on the windown posting that it's home made noodles... i dont see that anymore... so i'm guessing that maybe it's under new kitchen staff cuz the noodles are NOT GOOD!!!!!!!!!!  it's pasty and over cooked... gross... 

damn it... i guess i'm left with Ken Ken ramen only...
author: Kelly H.

description: Amazing!!! I just came here two days ago, and I want to come back again! I loved their cilantro ramen with added spicy sauce. It was so comforting because it was both spicy and warm and it had cilantro! The wait to get a table wasn't too bad. Me and my friend only waited for 10min. The place inside was very cozy too with mostly small tables. I would recommend this place to anyone that likes home made ramen noodles. I just paid for parking in the parking garage though. I wasn't able to find street parking.
author: Diana C.

description:
I don't know why everyone is racing about this place. I was extremely excited to try this place and after waiting for 30 minutes, I was greatly disappointed. 

I ordered a ramen combination with Mabo Tofu. The Ramen broth was bland, noodles were stiff and has the consistency of spaghetti. The presentation was nice because they fold the noodles in the bowl before they add the broth. The pleasantries end there.

The Mabo Tofu bowl was also bland. I've never had a bowl of Mabo Tofu so bland. This bowl makes the packaged sauces by House look like five star cuisine.
author: Michael C.

description: Ramen was great. Ordered suzu special and gf ordered vegetable ramen. It turned out great. My suzu tasted funny at first until I mixed it all up. The flavor I was looking for came out. Her dish was great. The broth was good and the price was very fair. We tried the pork belly and takoyaki both were delicous. So many options around here but pick this one.
author: Yves D.

description:
4 1/2 stars. I went two times in a weeks time. I think everyone who eats here always starts out in frustration because it is so hard to get a table here. The wait is always soooo long. There is only one cook, so the food comes out at a slow, but even pace in the order it's supposed to come out in.

I love their lunch specials because you get an extra side dish with your ramen for the same price it would be for just the ramen at dinner time. I get the Salmon Don Noodle Combo. You have a choice of noodle (ramen, soba, udon). I always get ramen. 

The salmon is fresh and when you combine that with the warm rice and a hint of wasabi, YUMMY! The ramen is filling. For people who really like salt, this dish is a little bland, so they have spices on your table you can add. I like it the way it is. 

TIP: Get there right when it opened at 11:30, then you'll get a table. or go close to 2:45pm and the line usually isn't so bad because they close after lunch at 3pm and people get frustrated and go somewhere else.
author: Leanne K.

description:
My friend made a very valid observation of the customers leaving Suzu Noodle house as we arrived. " Look at everyone wiping the sweat from their brow, this is gonna be so good".  Primarily we chose to eat lunch here because of how many people were either packed into the little space or waiting patiently outside.  The  smell floating from the kitchen was enough to sell me and the accolades on the store front provided further mouth watering  anticipation. I'm no ramen expert but I am indeed an enthusiast and the execution of my Tokyo Ramen was satisfying  enough to make me plan my next visit.

To be fair -
I'm comparing it to my deep lust for Orochon , A bowl of ramen  the two of us  experienced last summer in LA that has not been easily forgotten or contended. 

Noodle Density was perfect.
Broth could use a little spice but God knows my stomach wouldn't agree.The thinly sliced pork in my bowl was saltier than my partners  bowl but still deliecious. 

I didn't like that the kitchen  was exposed and I  saw a girl eating a granola bar. The staff seemed exhausted or like they could use a couple shots of sake.   $13.00 buys you a bowl of ramen and don.
author: Hannah A.

description: Something happened to Suzu. I think it's new ownership; it's certainly new management. Many of the servers are gone, and I've seen a couple elsewhere in Japantown. The changes can also be seen in the prices (higher) and quality (lower). There are few places for quality ramen in SF; this used to be one of them.
author: Jerry D.

description:
Weird.  I came back here last night and the menu has totally changed.  Though they offer more non-ramen options, it seems that the quality-- and to a lesser degree the portions-- have changed for the worst.  At least the prices haven't gone up appreciably.

I should've known something was up when I came here at prime dinner hours and didn't have to wait.  I have a feeling that a lot of their previous regulars noticed the drop in quality.  I wonder if the ownership has changed.  As it stands now, I'd rather go to Tampopo or Katana-Ya downtown.
author: Dave N.

description: Overall is above average. Ramen was pretty good, I liked the variety in what they included. Very small but that's to be expected in a ramen shop. Would come back if I was ever around Japantown again.
author: Bruce L.

description:
This is a review of the one time I came here and ordered a combo special (in the $12-13ish range), which includes a noodle (ramen, udon, or soba) and some kind of donburi (rice dish). 
Since I had just come back from NYC and had high expectations (especially after Ippudo), I didn't want to ruin this place and order ramen, so I ordered the soba noodles instead.  I also got a salmon don. 

Since I couldn't resist, I did end up trying my friend's bowl of ramen as well.  The noodles in both the ramen and the soba were both firm and chewy in texture, which I love.  I actually have no complaints about the soba whatsoever.  The ramen was just ok.  The broth was simple, but nothing special.

The salmon don was very lackluster.  The fish didn't taste fresh.  This could have been due to the fact that the rice that it sat on was a bit too warm.  The rice was also lacking proper seasoning with rice vinegar and sugar.  

This place always seems to have a wait, which I don't understand, but hype does drive more hype.  I definitely won't be waiting half an hour to eat here again.  Heck, I probably wouldn't even if there was no wait.  There's plenty of other restaurants in Japantown to try.
author: Jeanne L.

description: One of the worst ramen I've ever had. Instant ramen soup probably better tasting. Noodles were strange texture. Ordered a gyusuji don, which was basically sugared meat on rice. Best thing I had was the edamame. Strange how there's a long line to this place.
author: Nancy S.

description: A great overall place to catch a satisfying lunch. Not worth 1-2 hr wait though. The noodles are fresh and the broth decent. Some interesting donburi selections like Mabo Don (spicy minced pork tofu over rice). The karaage curry (fried chicken curry over rice) is a very generous portion enough for small appetite to take home or big appetite to feel happy all day long. Ramen with karaage is also good, dip deep fried chicken into the ramen broth gives it a brand new dimension. Don't expect overly friendly staff here but they are respectful and polite at heart - if it is your turn they will let one person occupy a big table - I really like them for that. Pot stickers the gyoza recently deviated from Japanese style to more Chinese style with heavy oil and thicker skin. I personally didn't care for it but the portion is definitely bigger and still with good taste - a hungry guy may really appreciate it
author: Dilys S.

description: My roommate and I have been craving ramen for the longest time and were so shocked that none of the places in Japantown had good reviews! But we saw that this place was pretty busy, so we took that as a testament that it would be pretty good. I got the spicy miso ramen, which is normally my favorite, but wasn't completely blown away. While I though the broth was quite tasty, I wasn't a fan of the ramen texture. They weren't quite chewy enough and they also seemed too starchy, like the kitchen hadn't rinsed them off after boiling. It made for sort of a weird mushy yet oddly firm texture that I wasn't a big fan of.
author: Samantha C.

description: Probably one of the best ramens I ever had. I'm not a big ramen fan but when I tasted Suzu's Noodle house I was in love. The broth was perfect, there was plenty of noodles and portionable veggies to meats. I recommend the Kaarage ramen, its my favorite. Everyone must try
author: Teresa N.

description:
Nice little restaurant in Japantown.  Service was really quick but the food wasn't very memorable. 

Dinner:

-Goyza - thick skin and not much filling.  It was ok.

-Miso Ramen with Pork - It was ok. Soup was a little bland and the portion was a bit small. 

Really can't say much about this place...
author: Ying F.

description: This place is not on the top of my list to go for ramen. I had the spicy miso ramen with pork belly. I just didn't like the soup base. It was really plain. I was really excited for it too because my friend said it will be good and we waited for about half hour for a table. :(
author: Annie H.

description:
A group of my friends and I were craving for ramen especially after a night of polk st bars! 

The place is small but super cute.  Very clean and it got crowded really fast especially for being 11:00 am on a Saturday night.  We opted for seaweed salad, fried chicken and dumplings for appetizers and the chicken to me was the best.  

For ramen, I chose the spicey pork ramen.  It was decent but I wish it was even spicier.  I saw others getting the donburi and it looked super good.  I have to try that next time.
author: Anna B.

description:
This place usually has a line which means it's worth waiting for.

I came here on July 4th and I was freezing because I was only wearing shorts and a T-shirt. What would be better to chow down on than some good soup (udon/ramen)?

We waiting about 20 minutes to get a table. The place is small and it feels like they can have more tables--but whatever. We finally got to sit down in the warm room and anticipated delicious noodles and soup.

I ordered the Chashu Ramen. I feel that the taste of the pork was overpowering. Retrospectively, I would have ordered the Miso Ramen or the Tokyo Ramen--I feel that they would have been more balanced and tasteful. My eating partner ordered the Vegetable Udon. I didn't really like it too much because the vegatables were overpowering just like the pork in my ramen. I would recommend just getting regular udon to appreciate the soup and delicious, chewy noodles.

This is one of those places you always pass up if frequent Japantown but never think about eating here. Supposedly this is one of the best places to get ramen/udon. I would disagree though given that I've had ramen all over California and even in Japan. Albeit, this place is about a little over average (3.5).

Lastly, service was great!
author: Marlon T.

description: This place always has a wait, but if you go early in the day you can usually have little (10 min) to no wait. I always get the spicy ramen with the miso broth and its amazing! Although there have been several times that its completely lacked in salt. If adding a lot of extra salt doesn't bother you, get the spicy ramen! It is very spicy but for someone that considers themselves to like spicy things, its very tolerable. My fiance always gets the udon pot and it is almost always so hot that he cannot start eating until Im already halfway thru. This place is hands down the best ramen you can get n japantown . The also have a few udon, appetizers, etc..
author: L V.

description: The good things are that I like the toothsome noodles and the staff is nice. But the broth (I've had shoyu and miso and both disappoint) doesn't hold a candle in flavor and complexity to my beloved Santouka, the lone slice of chasu is lean and tough instead of falling apart tender, and the egg is overdone. I've always come midafternoon when the place is empty, but I don't know why anyone would wait in line for this soup. Go instead to the Kissako stand in the lobby for the delicious onigiri.
author: Cecilia L.

description:
John G. Daly City, CA send Message for my review of Suzu Noodle House 
"My Japanese co-worker said that the owner of Katana-ya (Chinese) bought Suzu and that is why the quality is no longer the same."

Yes, the owner of Katanaya took over the Suzu.

By the way, the owner of Katana-ya isn't really Chinese, he was born in Japan.
There are many Chinese born in Japan, so as many Koreans born in Japan. Some of them have been blend in the society. Well, some singers, movie stars,  Ball-players, Sumo-wrestlers, Pro-wrestlers, Yakuza, Politicians, Professors and Owner of Pachinko-parlers and food corporations are, especially after the WW-2. OK, I'll give you example.

Rikidozan, Sumo-wrestler, and later Pro-wrestler
Oh Sadaharu, Ball-player
Harimoto Isao, Ball-player
Yamamoto Fujiko, movie star
Misora Hibari, singer
Saijo Hideki, singer
Wada Akiko, singer
Yazawa Eikichi, singer
Matsuzaka Keiko, movie star
Iwaki Kouichi,  movie star
Matsuda Yusaku,  movie star
Yasuda Narumi, movie star
Matsuda Hitoshi, comedian
Oyama Masutatsu, Kyokushin Karate
Nakamura Hideo, Kendokai Karate
Ozawa Ichiro, Politician
Nakata Hiroshi, Politician, Mayer of Yokohama
Nagano Tetsuo, Professor at Tokyo University
Kan Naoto, Politician
Yonekura Hiromasa, chairman of Sumitomo Chemical, also the chairman of the Japan Business Federation
Shigemitsu Takeo, Shin Kyuk-ho, a Korean-born Japanese businessman. He founded and led the Lotte group.
Kazuo Inamori, a philanthropist, Japanese entrepreneur, and the founder of Kyocera Corporation and KDDI Corporation. He is the chairman of Japan Airlines.
Yamaguchi-Gumi, Yakuza, about 30% are Koreans.
Kiyoda Jiro, , chairman Inagawa-Kai
Son Masayoshi, Softbank CEO

Many more. 

The island of Japan can not activate with all of them. It has been the way for many years, and, in my opinion, they are all true Japanese. And Thank God that they are totally against Gov of China. I think because they are not the member of Illuminati, like Beyonce.

About Suzu?
As Katanaya is going down hill, bad manner of waitress and service, Suzu is not good place for me anymore. The Broth is getting lame had strangely funky flavor that I don't know wtf is going on in the kitchen.
author: Nobu K.

description: This place is all right but not great. I ordered the Chassu ramen (pork) and the portion was pretty big. The noodles weren't as soft and chewy compared to other ramen places I've been to and the flavor didn't really stand out. It is upwards $10 for a bowl. I didn't have any problems with service though, the waitresses were nice and checked up on us to refill our waters / tea.
author: Allison L.

description:
Okay...so I been here many many times. I always get spicy ramen because I'm Korean and I eat everything spicy. I have tried chicken karaage, curry rice, mabo don, spicy ramen, tokyo ramen, shoyu ramen, spicy negi ramen. Spicy negi sucked it wasn't what I expected. Just hella marinated green onions everywhere. SALTY SALTY SALTY! All the other things were just alright. I think mabo don is the most okay one. 

Last time I went with a friend of mine, I got spicy ramen as usual and she didn't know what to get...so I said try suzu tanmen. SUZU TANMEN. It must be their specialty because it has Suzu in it. But it obviously tasted like shit...not even shit...it didn't taste like anything and my friend got mad at me. She was hella pissed so I said I will pay, you can order something else. but she was like NO Fxxx u.....We don't talk anymore. JK. We went to On the Bridge afterwards. Fatasses ftw.
author: Sunny K.

description:
Twenty minutes prior to the listed closing time @ 9pm on a busy Friday night. 
 "We are closed."  
"It says you are open until 9pm?"
"Well, then we are not taking any more people"

Random 2 patrons waiting from the list... "We changed our minds we are going to eat elsewhere"

"Oh looks like 2 free spots just opened up, can we take those?"
"No, we are closed, sorry."
"No, you are not... sorry, pshffffff!"

If their ramen wasn't so tasty I should dock them minus one star, but I see  how it is, bitchy little waiter had to GTFO and get his Friday night on. whatever, this is how you slowly loose good regular patrons.  Auh-huh well**gasps**.
author: B H.

description: Decent ramen place that hit the spot. I ordered the char siu ramen and my friend got the ramen with wontons, and I was disappointed to see that hers came with char siu in addition to the wontons - had I known this, I would've ordered the wontons so I could get two-in-one! Ah well. Maybe next time.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Suzu Noodle House is a a somewhat small restaurant in Japan Town. It fits probably around 30 people inside. Usually there's a line around lunch and dinner time, but like other ramen restaurants, they have a wait list outside. This place has a set ramen type of menu, which is a bit different from ramen restaurants so things like choice of broth isn't selectable. They have a few different set ramens on their menu. It seems like most of these ramen are shoyu, but they have a miso broth one.

Usually spicy for Japanese food isn't really spicy when compared to other Asian cultures, but their "spicy ramen" was quite spicy. It's definitely worth getting the spicy ramen if you're a fan of spicy food. The ramen noodles are chewy and great, which was the best thing out of the whole ramen. Everything else tastes alright and mediocre. The soup tastes a bit bland without flavor. There were two small pieces of cha siu and it wasn't amazing or great. The boiled egg they put in is a hard boiled. Lastly, there's the common bamboo shoots and seaweed inside the soup.
author: Steven B.

description:
3.5 stars. Been here about four or five times, always Shoyu based broth.

Broth: tasty, but not outstanding. It's not so tasty that I will gulp down the whole bowl, but tasty enough that if I'm just sitting there talking to a friend, I'll finish the portion.

Noodles: moderate texture, not too hard.

Fixings: moderate, not super memorable. I like their fried chicken.

Combos: slightly expensive, but their sushi bowl combos are great. Mapo natsu (eggplant) feels like something that can be made at home (but with a lot less grease)

Decent place to grab a meal when you are in Japantown, although I would say Mifune generally offers better deals in terms of food. 

Expect a slight wait. I've never not had to sign their check-in list before, but at the same time the wait has never been ridiculous for me (under 30 minutes).
author: Chris S.

description: Been here a few times once with friends then brought family. I love the fried chicken ramen! There was so much to each and the ramen was great and the broth addicting. It's a new favorite! From vegetarian to good and spicy they have something for everyone! It is a small place that can get packed quick. Any wait is worth it!
author: David L.

description: My friend suggested to go here since she said it was good a few months ago. The line was long so we thought it would be good. OMG, super salty and expensive ramen. Never coming back..
author: Vivian L.

description:
I love Suzu Noodle House. It's my favorite place to get ramen in SF. I am very particular about my ramen, and it just so happens that Suzu somewhat meets my standards. I grew up eating authentic ramen from chefs from Japan, but unfortunately they retired. This is the closest thing to what I call "authentic ramen" from what I have had. Although, it's a bit expensive due to the little amount of meat, and the half of an hard boiled egg you get in your noodles. I order the Tokyo Ramen every time, and the noodles are just so satisfying as well as the delicious broth.
However, this Noodle House is a small place. You do have to wait a while if you go at peak hours.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
A cute ramen-ya located downstairs of SF Japantown. The broth isn't anything memorable but the noodles are pretty good. It's curly and chewy, just the way I like it! 

I had the pea sprout ramen since I've been craving veggies. It was good. But I broke my rule of always ordering the "house ramen". I'll need to come back again and try the other ones. We also got the karage which was pretty good. The batter was kinda flakey. 

By the way - this place is usually packed and has a huge line since the store is super small. I would come early on a weekday (before 6pm) to eat instead of the weekends.

I will come back again and try their signature ramen and update my yelp review!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Okay but not spectacular. I came here last night after having drinks at a bar around the corner. I was craving something hot due to the chilly and foggy weather (ie. summer in SF). I had been here a few times before and knew the ramen was standard, so it was an easy decision.

We didn't have to wait long considering it was a Saturday night (even though the place is pretty tiny). It's located right inside the Japantown mall so I imagine it gets a lot of traffic. My friend and I don't eat pork so we asked if there was a chicken broth available instead. The waitress told us only with the udon. This actually makes no sense to me - if they have chicken broth for the Udon, why can't they use it for ramen? Anyway, we both just gave in and settled for the pork broth. You have to choose a broth flavor as well - soy sauce, miso, or salt. My friend who got the soy said it was a bit bland, but my friend with the miso really liked it. I got the soy as well but I ordered the spicy ramen, so in the end all I could taste was spice! I'll be honest, it was a tad too spicy for me - the noodles were good but there was so much spice I had trouble sipping the broth. It was also an unnaturally bright red color and I ended up doing a napkin bib to avoid staining my shirt! The space can get really stuffy and hot inside, add in the hot tea and hot soup and I was sweating by the end of the meal.

Overall I think this place can be good, but there are a lot of choices and you have to know what to order.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
The portions are rather large and the waiting staff was fairly attentive to our needs.
