I had the Suzu Ramen and I would say the karage and the dumplings didn't really add anything to do the dish in terms of flavor.  The ramen noodles were decent (medium chewiness and nice texture).  The broth was just average and doesn't really stand out compared to all the ramen places I have been.  The cost is quite expensive as well for ramen and I would probably choose somewhere else to get the same food for cheaper.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
I'll give it 2 stars for the price being economical but not good for flavor and ingredients in your dish. For one the lack of flavor in their broth. Second, for every topping you should have in a good ramen...you have to pay for it to be added. 

I've tasted better...if you want really good broth and fresh noodles, go to Ramen Club @ Burlingame...good food and worth the price and drive!!!
author: Foodie F.

description:
As ramen places go for the Bay Area, I'm only "Eh" on this place.  But compared to other ramen places in Japantown, I have to say Suzu is pretty darn good.  I've tried SapporoYa and some of the ramen at the other "traditional" Japanese restaurants in the shopping center, and this is definitely the best of the bunch.  The wait on a Saturday afternoon at 1pm was about 25 minutes.

The prices are really good for ramen in SF.  Our tea came out immediately after we ordered our food.  Service was fairly attentive, considering we were sitting outside the restaurant on the side by the windows.  I got the Karaage Ramen ($8.95ish?) with the karaage on the side ($.50 extra, WTF?! Is it b/c of the extra dish to wash?) and my sister got the Tempura lunch set (a really good deal at $10.95, lots of food!).  We were both pleasantly surprised at the size of the bowls.  Her vegetable and shrimp tempura came out first, piping hot.  It was a full tempura bowl with sauce drizzled on the pieces on top of rice.  Then my dish of maybe 6 good sized karaage pieces came out (no lemon).  Then our two separate bowls of ramen arrived.  We basically got the same thing, same size, but in different looking bowls.  Mine was flat and wide, while hers was taller and deeper.  Both bowls came with copious amounts of negi, seaweed, bamboo, and half a boiled egg.  Hers also came with a few slices of pork.  

Unfortunately, I was not blown away by the broth, which I think should have been pork based, but mostly just tasted like salt water.  It didn't have any richness or depth to the flavor.  I dumped on the powdered pepper/salt/garlic/onion stuff, but it didn't really help.  I may try the Tokyo Ramen next time, as the picture shows it comes with a deeper looking broth.  I would return here if I were in the mood for ramen while in SF, but there are definitely better places along the Penninsula and in the South Bay.  Santouka is definitely my new fave!
author: Leslie H.

description: Small noodle house inside Japantown. Loved the Nabyaki Udon. Huge portion served very hot (excellent post movie, rainy SF day choice.)
author: Beth J.

description:
I would definitely come back here!  I ordered the tempura udon -- the tempura batter was just right, not too thick or thin; the udon noodles were cooked just tender enough (and the menu says they're handmade - impressive & yummy!); and the udon broth was tasty.  Love it!  

Luckily before our movie at the Kabuki we were able to get a table right away, were served efficiently and made our way to our show just in time!  It's a small place so you have to catch it at just the right time -- put your name down on the waitlist asap on arrival.

Dinner+tax+tip = $13
author: Maile N.

description: Fine for fast, cheap noodles. Not outstanding, but ok. Server brought me check halfway through meal without asking if I wanted anything else.
author: Leah H.

description:
Disappointment. 

I guess every time I came here I've always had the spicy ramen which was delicious, but just because it's spicy,  and full of MSG. YUM!

I ordered the cold noodles with tempura this time, and it was mediocre at best.The noodles were quite hard, like it wasn't cooked long enough. Unfortunately it was cold noodles so I couldn't have let sit for a bit in the soup or anything. 

My friend had the miso noodle, nothing spectacular. I guess if I come back here again, I'll stick to the spicy ramen. 


There always seem to be a wait, when we got there, they told us 20 minutes and to put down our names, we came back 15 minutes later and our names were apparently called and scratched off already, but when we ask them, they put for the next table, so points for service.
author: Jessica T.

description: This has become one of my new favorite places. I came here before a movie at the Kabuki. The list was a little long but went fast. Pro tip: don't walk away because they will give away your table. I love the soba noodles, and udon noodles. Super large amount of food for about 12-13 bucks. Definitely a Japantown spot worth going to. YAY
author: Julia D.

description: Now that Iroha has closed (BOO!), I've been on a mission to find another ramen house to satisfy my monthly miso ramen fix. Suzu is definitely that place. The boyfriend and I ventured here last week for dinner after a movie at Sundance and my karaage miso ramen was delicious. He had the chasu miso ramen and the pork was tender and lean. I am looking forward to coming back and SLURP my heart away!
author: Kevin C.

description:
This is my new absolute #1 Ramen house (it's the only one I've been to in SF though). So I heard the wait is quite long, and I saw there is limited seating and a sign up sheet, so my boyfriend and I, this past Saturday around 1PM, decided to walk around the Japantown mall first instead to see if there were other options. 

We returned around 2PM (they stop serving lunch at 3PM), and put our names on the list, within 5 minutes we were seated. 

The ramen menu is large, with 10+ different types. I can't remember exactly what I ordered, but it was delicious. My boyfriend ordered the Chau Sau (sp?) ramen with extra spicy broth - it was the tastiest thing ever! (VERY SPICY!). They charged $1.50 extra for the extra spicy broth - no biggie, it was worth it. The noodles are perfectly al dente, not too soft and so yummy. I'm usually the type to order noodle soup and just drink the soup - I really dislike noodles, with this, I couldn't stop eating the noodles! **Hot Tea is served free of charge. We also ordered Pot Stickers, a bit pricy ($6) for 4 pot stickers, but they were yummy. 

My only downfall was that they didn't take Discover Card - only Visa/MC but not suprising for an Asian quick sit down restaurant, I should be happy they took credit card at all!

I'm not sure about the parking situation - we walked from our Hotel over on Van Ness.
author: Vivian P.

description:
Hum, where to start? First off, the wait is ridiculous to get a table, especially if you have a party larger than two people. After 45 minutes of waiting, we were seated. Then place is small and crowded majority of the time. The service wasn't too bad, our waitress was somewhat prompt and accomodating. My complaint would be the food.

I'm not really into ramen, never was and never will be. I've had Suzu's Tokyo ramen before a while back and that was a big disappointment. So this time, I opted for the kare katsu don. You really can't go wrong with this dish because it's your basic flavorful curry with don katsu and rice in a bowl. Apparently, since Suzu is known for its ramen, other food items on their menu aren't as great, even though their ramen tastes gross and bland. The curry sauce tasted like crap and the pork cutlet was so hard to chew. The only thing I enjoyed about my dish was the red daikon, which is pretty sad. 

The only good thing about this place is large portions, other than that I wouldn't come here again. For the taste, quality, time, and price....definitely not worth it!
author: Hannah L.

description: Great ramen, I asked for the pork belly Ramen it is outstanding.  Service is great and fast. Also got the gyosa it was heavenly. My taste buds are happy
author: Alejandro S.

description:
Ive been here several times, Good for a quick bite to eat if there isnt much of a line, good luck on the weekend as it gets busy, the place is small.
I thought the noodles were ok, i enjoyed the pork, but the broth in my butter corn ramen was kinda salty, and my dining partner agreed as well.

also ordered the croquette appetizer, i enjoyed that as well, crispy crust and creamy potato filling. 

service was quick food came out fast, for the price u cant really complain cause i was full.
author: Yelper S.

description: Fantastic noodles. My girlfriend and I eat here at least once a month. The Japanese curry udon is incredible.
author: Kirk J.

description: We were surprised by the extremely salty soup, very small portion of noodle, low grade egg, and the watered down so called tea. It is unbelievable! And they added mandatory 20% service charge to the bill. The service was just mediocre, the English of the waitress was very bad and hard to understand. The tax charge was placed in the beverage section, we were confused. It is totally not worth the wait and the money. I will never go there again.
author: Turtle F.

description: A BUG IN MY FOOD!!!!!!I created an account to write this review, I had previously visited this restaurant in September for the first time, and today after class I was craving ramen. Ordered a butter corn ramen, ate it half way until I discover a BUG!!!! Green black with wings maybe a fly but flies don't look like that!!!!!!!! Utterly disgusted called the waitress over and checked what it was! Took it back and the rest of staff looked at me with nasty looks! The kind waitress came back and offered another one! Kind but why the hell would I want a bother one . She offered just 10% off my bill such would do nothing. I was really aggravated even though I like calm I felt sick and just wanted to get out of there in the ended I still stupidly paid ! If they lowered it to $5 the. What ever but still was almost what the order was!! Never coming back here even again!!!! Feeling sick !!!!! It taste good bus God know why!!! People be cautious!! I was looking at my food the whole time! But still that atrocity showed up in my food!!!!!!
author: Jazmin P.

description: Best traditional Ramen I have had in years.  Soup base is clear but with rich flavor.  Noodles texture is perfect - not over cooked or under.  I wish there is same quality in Los Angeles/Irvine area.  The wait is long but worth it.
author: David D.

description:
Came to this place at 6.45 pm and waited till 7.30 pm.......HMM they certainly have a weird waiting list system. They allow people who doesnt show up who made the reservation ahead of those who showed up and waited the entire time. Somehow thats just weird. 

Me and my sis got the Agedashi Tofu, Takuwan, the Butter Corn Ramen and Spicy Negi Ramen. Originally we wanted to eat the takoyaki but the waitress seems to mistook or odered for the Takuwan( Its kinda silly considering Takoyaki is way different than Takuwan) Perhaps they misunderstood the first syllable of the word? HMMMM.........So i guess service wise, it wasnt that good. But the food saved this place. I liked my butter corn ramen, the Agedashi Tofu was crispy and hot, and the Takuwan which we didnt even consider was pretty good! 

Suzu noodle is pretty small, so I reckon they might want to expand the place to get more profit, but overall since the food was decent, id give this place 3 stars!
author: Cavin T.

description: The pork is underbraised, the broth lacks any depth of taste, and the noodles taste artificial. It probably gets the people coming because it's open at times where other better places are closed. I Don' t understand how here or Sam Tung gets any positive reviews. I believe most Yelp contributors do not get noodles.
author: John K.

description:
The GF was working late last Thursday evening, so I was on my own for dinner. It was drizzling out, so I thought it would be a good evening for noodle soup. 

Most of the noodle houses in Japantown have left me, well ... 'whelmed.' None of them have really impressed me enough to return for a second visit. So, imagine my surprise when I dug into my hefty portions of Suzu Ramen and Ten Don. Making good ramen takes the right touch. I could taste the freshness of the house-made ramen. The broth was tasty, and not over-seasoned (e.g., too salty). Having enjoyed the ramen dish, I moved on to the Ten Don. Tempura requires incredible technique to get it right. Even the smallest mistake could lead to a soggy crust, or limp veggies. This was not the case at Suzu. The crust on every piece of tempura was perfectly crisp. 

I really enjoyed my meal at Suzu. And, guess what? I will be returning for another visit very soon. It's going to rain tomorrow, right?
author: Jaime R.

description: Great ramen noodles. Broth is chicken and pork mix.  Decent toppings.
author: James W.

description: Suzu, earned another star from me. Had the spicy ramen w/ extra cha shu. Broth packed a punch and was very tasty. Quite popular so lots of folks waiting, if you are into Manga wander down to the end of this area of the mall to loiter. Service was efficient this time. Itsa popular joint and rightly so.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
This place was good. I had a good but hurried experience. Overall, it was quite pleasant. No complaints. 

Even though they close at 9PM, I saw the wait list said CLOSED. We came at 8:40PM. I was really hungry, but we talked to the waitress and she was nice about it. I understand when you want to close up early so you don't allow anymore. However, she said that if we wanted to wait until a table opened up before 9PM, she'll let us. 

We got seated. I ordered the Tokyo Ramen. It was really good! On the salty side, but the noodles were SO good! They were perfect texture and everything! 

Decor is cute too! A good ramen place by far. But then again, it's ramen. You can't go too wrong on ramen?!
author: Josie W.

description: This restuarant has been my favarite ramen here in San Francisco. I give 5 stars for the food but 1 star for the service. I came here with my friend and sit outside the restuarant. I had an order of Spicy ramen and my friend had a butter corn ramen. My friend has got an order as usal but me not. I have waited over 15 mins to get my order. I asked them what happen why dont i get my order same time with my friend and why do i have to wait so long ( restuarant is not busy at all, 3 waitress and 4 tables) . And the answer is "Its depend on the kitchen". You gotta tell me girl.
author: Chayawee Y.

description: Good noodles but the broth was bland.
author: Michael E.

description: My roommates and I went here last night for our first venture into Japantown. We were seated immediately and served quickly despite having a party of four, which seems rather unusual. I ordered the Karaage (fried chicken) ramen and dumplings. I've had better at some trendy, expensive places in New York, but Suzu was definitely above average and really flavorful. Although the menu was a bit confusing at first--and I was amused to find typos like "porkberry" instead of "porkbelly"--the experience seemed genuine overall. Try it if you're in the area!
author: Jacob S.

description: The food here isn't amazing, but could probably satisfy your craving for ramen or soba. The curry ramen wasn't too good. The cold soba was nice. The karage ramen was good as well. The service here is poor and slow though. I would not come again.
author: Tiffany B.

description: I've been coming to this place for years but have been out of state for the past two or so. On a recent visit back home my father and uncle were in town and we decided to get some ramen soup, so naturally I highly recommended my old favorite ramen house. Immediately upon entering I could tell something had changed. Subtle differences at first like the tables were not straightened and more table tops were still dirty than usual even though it was not that busy at the time. Even the tables that were set didn't look as though they had been cleaned properly. Then I noticed the service was not as warm and charming. Then the food arrived and it completely lacked the robust mouth watering flavors I had grown accustomed to over the years. Soooo disappointed. What's the deal?!?!?
author: Sky R.

description:
Going out to eat with my sister inevitably ends with either one or both of us overly stuffed bellies and mass amounts of left overs.
Our latest battleground, Suzu Noodle House.

Here's the review after feasting on noodles, appetizers, and tempura:

I'm still fairly new to the wonderful world of noodles (specifically ramen, udon, and soba variety anyways) but I am beginning to figure out what I do and don't like.
I hate to say it but the noodles here was mediocre - under seasoned broth, okay tasting ramen, and super salty chasu.

It's a cool looking restaurant.  The location is ideal if you want to grab a quick bite before a movie (quick being dependent on the waiting list, of course).  And the plethora of positive reviews from yelp would have you believe you were in for a treat.

Unfortunately, Suzu reminded me more of Majikku Ramen - more look than substance.

Overall, I liked the tempura and might even go back for more.  It was crispy without being soaked in oil.
The thing is Suzu is suppose to be known for their noodles, right?
author: Dan B.

description: Stopped by for dinner on a Monday afternoon. There was a consistent line and waiting list so we had high hopes for some good ramen and Japanese food - we're in Japantown, after all. Friend had the miso ramen while I had the pork katsu curry. Portion sizes were decent but both dishes were pretty salty and we were gulping down water for hours afterwards. Possibly my fault for getting katsu curry at a noodle house but I had a huge craving for rice (which still remained unsatisfied).
author: Cathy C.

description: Suzu was a wonderful surprise.  I came with a friend after seeing a movie at the Kabuki theater, and I immediately fell in love with the traditional noodle house setting.  My friend had the pork ramen, and I had the curry.  I love Japanese curry and I also love ramen, and the combination was, as expected, strange.  I think they cooked some curry sauce and dumped it on top of a bowl of ramen broth and noodles.  It sort of melted into the broth, but not entirely.  There were also random scraps of meat (braised chicken or pork?) mixed in with the curry.  While this description doesn't sound very appetizing, it was exactly what I wanted - half ramen, half curry.   It had the wonderful thick, gravy-like flavor of Japanese curry, and the saltiness of the ramen broth.  The bowls were very large, but not overly full of noodles so I didn't feel sick even though I had eaten every last one.
author: Rachel A.

description: It was just ok... When we asked for extra spicy, the broth was just covered in a later of chili oil...other than that, the broth was flavorful enough. I wouldn't go out of my way to recommend this place to a friend, but it's convenient to have within walking distance.
author: Cindy C.

description: What happened to this place?  Used to be one of our favorite go-to's for ramen.  We immediately knew something was different when the ramen arrived and there is a lot more noodles but it was completely overcooked.  There is also bok choy now in the ramen!?!  The soup is lacking any complexity in flavor.  Very disappointing.  Did they sell?  Change management?  Change chefs?  Not the same Suzu we've loved in the past.
author: Diana W.

description: My usual is the spicy ramen with extra noodles and extra pork, side of kimuchi, and an order of all salmon sashimi. Their service is pretty good; my tea cup or water cup is almost never empty. I kinda wish the spicy ramen was more spicy tho.. Oh well, it's still always yummy.
author: Garland W.

description:
I have been looking forward to starting off my trip to SF with a stop at Suzu!  Met up with a couple of friends, and with my suitcase in tow, we came here for dinner.  This place is small and sits at the entrance to a small mall in Japantown.  There are only 8 tables inside and two outside in the hallway, so the wait is unavoidably long.  Fortunately, we only had a half hour wait.

The three of us had the Spicy Mabo Ramen.  Theirs is the best I've had so far.  The broth is very flavorful, the noodles are a bit thicker than other places and al dente.  It's all nice and spicy too, so make sure you have some water or tea to help you out.

We also ordered a side of agedashi.  Like the ramen, it's beautifully presented.  The order comes with four small squares of lightly fried tofu.  The texture is perfectly silky.  It comes topped with green onion, minced daikon radish and ginger, and sits in a light broth.

While the posted hours indicate that Suzu closes at 9:30 pm, we saw that they turned away a customer a little after 9 pm?!  They are not open on Tuesdays.
author: Carol L.

description:
Ramen is an art in Japanese culture, some places in Japan spend 60 hours (not sure if it's true....) brewing the broth! I don't expect to EVER find this in the US, buuuuut it is a crime to only add salt to any soup/broth! 

I think there are better places for ramen especially since this one has a long wait. The noodles are okay and service is fast once you get a table, but I can't eat salty broth.
author: Jen L.

description:
This place was busy busy! We had a short wait after writing our names on the clipboard by the door. It was a longer wait to get our order in to the poor overwhelmed server. 

The miso nabeyaki udon was very flavorful but there was a bit too much tempura floating in it. My husband ordered katsudon and was disappointed it didn't have the eggs and green onions like he was used to. Still, it was good. Mom ordered the pork ramen with soba noodles instead and said it was tasty but not earth-shattering.

All in all, tasty food but not the absolute best. I think I've been spoiled by my local ramen house!
author: Lau B.

description:
I've been to this restaurant about three times and am finally convinced that this place is over-hyped.

The third and last time I visited, I came with a friend. Even though we sat a the table right at the kitchen door (where the waitresses are always entering and exiting out of) it took awhile for someone to take our order. I ordered regular shoyu ramen, and my friend ordered miso ramen.

It was a bit awkward that my bowl had so much soup, while hers was half-filled. We each received only one slice of chashu (pork) and that's pretty sad considering their prices aren't cheap.

Before even finishing half of our ramen, our waitress abruptly gave us our bill. Granted, the check was faced-down, but we literally JUST got our food! It was a subtle gesture of telling us to hurry up and leave, despite having to wait a nice amount of time before even getting a table (there's usually a waitlist). Rude.

In a separate sitting I ordered ramen with chicken katsu. I asked if I can have the katsu served in a seperate dish rather than in the soup (or it'd get soggy). They charge for that. Unless you let me keep the extra plate, I don't see why I would have to pay extra?

Mediocre overpriced ramen with semi-crappy service. I will not be wasting my time waiting to eat here again.
author: Mei H.

description: Mmmmmm.... I had the spicy ramen with onions and shared the takoyaki (octopus rounds) with all of my friends. It is a bit pricy at Suzu noodle house and you sometimes have to wait 30 mins to get in, but you can always go to the bookstore or stationery store upstairs while you wait!  Nice waitstaff.
author: Patricia M.

description:
Of course everyone has their own opinion on ramen and restaurants but i for sure thought the ramen here was very good.  I had the Miso Ramen with a side of Katsudon which costs $13. sounds reasonable.

I've had a fair share of ramen around the bay area and id say this is one of the better places.  If only the wait wasn't so long i'd probably eat here way more often.

Service seemed fine although this isn't relevant to me, but they kept turning away customers at 8:30-9pm  even though their sign posted says CLOSES AT 9PM.  But whatever, who wants to go to a restaurant last minute anyways.

Also i farted in the restaurant but no one noticed.
author: Kenny C.

description: After having Ramen in Japan several times to compare to this ramen place, the ramen is not good. Very little flavor, greasy and just not good overall.
author: Scott C.

description:
Came here as it was close to the hotel we were staying at looking for some noodles. 

Upon entering the mall, you place your name on the a list, no hostess really and the place is small. We went around 12:00pm on a Weds and was not that crowded. We were sat down within 5 minutes. Agree with others that this is not a place for groups bigger then 6, as seating is very limited. 

The staff is very friendly, but lack on service as my wife really just wanted some water and it took her 4 times to ask with 2 different waitresses. They were prompt however to ensure that my green tea cup was always full.

The ramen noodles were good, the pork was a little to salty. I would say that it was average. 

I would say if your in a hurry and need ramen noodles that this should be a good stop. However if you have time or a big group of people to hang out with that you should carry on your search.
author: Eric G.

description:
Good service, small place, okay food.

I'd recommend the suzu ramen since it has the same broth as the chiashu and karaage ramen, but comes with both meats in it. The noodles are great, they have a nice bouncy texture when you chew them. 

The broth however isn't the best. It's not cloudy... and it lacks any sort of depth. I think they also use too much pickled bamboo shoots as well. The egg is hard boiled and not soft boiled, which is unfortunate. The chiashu is very lean and a little on the dry side.

As for appetizers, the potato croquette is nice due to it's nice crispy outside and creamy center, the vegetable tempura is a good choice as well since it has a variety of items, however the agedashi tofu wasn't too great.

Over all this place is convenient if you're going to the other shops in the konikuniya shopping mall or the movies, but probably not worth making a trip just to try it alone.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Friend was visiting while on a lay over so we had little time to spare to explore the city and food. By the time we got to Suzu Noodle House, she only had 1 hour before she had to be back at the airport. Luckily for us, there was no wait. They gave us a table right away, we ordered and explained our situation and they got our food out relatively fast. Great, fast service!

They are even more awesome because they offer a vegetarian option, which is not common at ramen places. While it was not a traditional bowl of ramen, the vegetable noodles I tried had a more mild tasting, thinner broth compared to the normal pork base soup, but it was still delicious. It looked pretty plain and bland but it wasn't. While it was not complex and strong in flavor, its simpleness was very satisfying.
author: Angela T.

description: I'm sorry Suzu. I used to like you, but then you had to go and make my ramen salty as heck to the point where I literally had to pour in a good half a cup of water to dilute the miso base to a point of being able to eat it. Not pleased, but I am not hating against the staff because they try. It's the kitchen. Sayonara~ Suzu. I doubt we will meet again.
author: Diana L.

description:
I decided to try Suzu after passing by one weekend, enticed with the hopes of finding a new ramen place to frequent. I will echo what others have said, that this place is pretty comparable to Katana-ya, although without as much variety. They have a combo menu just like Katana-ya does, which I decided to order from. Broth was rich, noodles felt authentic. All in all it was just okay.

The only thing I didn't like was sitting at the table in the corner closest to the kitchen. The wait staff was very attentive. So much so they kinda all huddled by that doorway  just a couple of feet away from where I was sitting. Maybe it was all in my head, but it felt like I was trapped in an encirclement of vultures, waiting to swoop down and clean my table.
author: Ray W.

description:
I used to come here on a weekly basis about a yr ago. 
I'm not sure if the management's change or ingredients changed but the ramen definitely does not taste the same. The texture itself is more soft and taste/feels more like pasta.
author: Jae C.

description: Takoyaki appetizer was so good! I got the fried chicken ramen and loved it, they give you a lot of food for a good price. The service was good and really fast considering how busy it was that night!
author: Shelby W.

description:
awesome ramen! i've been there a couple times now, and this past time i've tried the buckwheat noodles instead. It was still just as tasty as if i had the regular ramen, but instead, it was the gluten free option! 

the portions are a good size, and left feeling stuffed! i think it's worth the amount that they charge, especially since it's in J-town.
author: Bettina L.

description:
Since Suzu updated themselves with a mdern-esque design and an expanded menu, I thought I would update my review for them as well!

Overall, the quality of the food is still the same from what I remember and from my first experience.  Since my last visit, their basic menu is mostly the same, but with additional types of ramen to choose from and more items for their ramen combo meals.  I'm not sure if it's one of the newer additions or if it had always been there, but I noticed that they have a house ramen now (Suzu Ramen) that's very similar to KatanaYa's house ramen - fried potsticker, chicken karaage, roast pork, seaweed, and bamboo (just missing the corn I believe).  Obviously intrigued, I ordered it just to compare, and it was pretty good!  It's not quite as good  as KatanaYa's (they give a choice of spiciness and broth), but it's a solid alternative considering the wait at Suzu is generally shorter for a table, parking is (relatively) easier and cheaper, and at least you're waiting indoors for a table rather than on the street in the cold.

Service varies based on who your server is, but it can range from adequate to good.  One server we had wasn't very friendly but did a good job at taking care of our table, while another was really friendly.  I think before I might have been a little more tentative with my four star (I thought I gave them a three until I checked), but they've definitely solidfied their spot in my book.
author: Mike L.

description: I ordered the spicy ramen so this is a review of that. The taste is good, probably considered quite spicy to some. However there's exactly one piece of chashu in it. It's mostly just ramen and bean sprouts. I think there was two pieces of bamboo shoots. I finished it feeling hungry, unlike tons of other ramen place who offer at least decent portions. Theirs is subpar. I regret coming in.
author: Eric C.

description: It was OK, I. Have had worst. It was a little salty for my taste, but I ordered the butter corn ramen and they literally gave me 1 piece of pork, and it was pretty small. Is it just me that thinks that's wrong. If in dishing out $10 I think I should get at least 2 or 3 pieces of pork. Otherwise it was pretty got for the price it was.
author: Edwin C.

description:
Hits the spot for serious ramen cravings.  

I  felt it was unfair to give Suzu 5 stars since its the only noodle shop that I've tried in J-Town.  However, it was the perfect pre-show meal before seeing Roky Erickson at the Fillmore.

(+) The Spicy Ramen was just plain great.  I loved the porky, salty, fatty broth.

(+) I love that they had only one beer: Asahi Super Dry on tap.  An ideal companion for Spicy Ramen.  

(+) I pilfered bites of Gyoza, Tempura, and Pork Katsu from other's plates.  They were all very tasty.

(+) The prices were pretty cheap, but probably not more so than other Ramen houses.

(-) If you come at busy time, you will have to wait.  Hour long waits are not uncommon.

THE BOTTOM LINE:

(+) Long wait, but fast service and delicious Ramen.
author: Matthew S.

description:
It was my first time back in a couple of years, and I'm very excited about the new energy at this small ramen house. 

The noodles were good, better than I remember. My mother got the spicy tofu ramen, which is a bowl of kimchi and tofu cubes in a very nice pork and chicken broth. I think it might even be fair competition for the old standby Katana-ya!

I ordered the tenzaru soba. The tempura is a flour batter and very light, not greasy at all. The soba is well-executed and had a freshly-made quality to it. 

It's a lot better, and we got seated right away at around 12:30pm, which was a first.
author: May T.

description: It's about time I give a 5 star rating!  And well deserving as I have been there at least 15 times and still think of this place when I think of --ramen--!  The noodles are as fresh as they come.  My favorite are the Mabo and Suyu Ramen.  The broths are light yet tasty and silky. Another fave is the Agadashi tofu.  I highly recommend this place to ramen lovers.
author: Diane V.

description:
I agree with Amy H. below: What is the deal with bringing out the bill so early? It's like saying, "Now that you have ordered and must pay us, I no longer need to be polite, so pay up and get out of here so we can pretend to be polite to the next sucker until they begin eating."

Suzu doesn't do a good job of hiding the fact that it's only concern is the bottom line. Yes, we know they are in business to make money but we don't want to be reminded of that while we're eating. Another example of this is how differently you will get treated if you are alone vs. out with a group. Whenever I came here with someone else I would get decent service, but twice I came here alone after work and I felt like they resented me for taking up a table for just one person, even if I was taking the worst table (the small one in the back on the outside). One time I paid with cash and my change came back in the form of a plate full of coins. Was I supposed to be happy receiving dozens of pennies and nickels (obviously I left it all as part of the tip)?

One of the times I ate at Suzu I was lucky enough to get a waitress that was was ultra polite, friendly, and attentive. She was working the first time I ever went to Suzu, but the waitstaff hasn't been good during any of my subsequent trips to Suzu and the food, while good, isn't anything to write home about.
author: Colin D.

description: Forget about service at this place. Besides the waitress doesn't listen when taking order, she never checks back on the table. She suggested miso soup as a substitution to an item that I didn't care, as the result I only got miso soup and she ignored the main order! First time I had to leave restaurant hungry.
author: Nutty V.

description: Big portions but not very flavorful. Each "topping" is a single item. One vegetable stalk, one half an egg, one bamboo shoot, etc. And a minor but frustrating bit, the waitress charged $2 to swap chicken for pork in the ramen after saying I could trade something. All in all, overpriced food in an area with much better options.
author: Michaela S.

description:
Definitely recommend you take advantage of their combo special where you get to start off with a choice of a basic noodle-y dish (udon, ramen, or soba) accompanied by a small but packed rice bowl of your choice (ranging from donburi to chicken katsu, tuna, or curry). The portions are very decent for what you pay (around 11-13 dollars) and it's more than ample enough to fill you up.

Unfortunately it only adequately fills you up as opposed to satisfyingly or even sufficiently filling you up. Their food, from what I've tried, is generic-good at best. Their ramen is fairly sub-par, though not horrible on a freezing cold SF night (aka every night) when you want a hot bowl of noodle soup. I've just had way, way better elsewhere. The broth is salty and uninspired, though, and the pork slices are salty and overcooked/too lean, while the noodles are just kind of . . . there.

I'm doing a really good job of selling this place, I know, but it's always fairly packed and the hot tea refills are consistent, so it's not too bad. Not amazing, but if you have to have a quick meal somewhere in Japantown, it's alright. What's the Yelp commentary correlated with a 3-star rating? Oh, right: A-OK.
author: Betty W.

description: The wife musta dragged me here like three times since my first try.  She LUVS the ramen.  It is a pretty decent place to eat for the price, but I can only eat so much so she orders the extra unagi don for me.  Service is quick and friendly, space a tad tight, but still worth the trip.
author: Joel M.

description: Since they changed hand the ramen is no longer good.  I really miss their spicy ramen.  Suzu no longer rivals Yatanaya.  No comparison...
author: TopCat W.

description:
3-3.5

Suzu is a tiny little place inside the Japantown mall.  I came here for a lunch date with my boyfriend, and the wait was surprisingly short.  For me, it was a tossup between the mabo ramen and the miso ramen, but in the end, I went with the latter.  Our orders came out pretty quickly, which was good, and it came with a huge soup spoon, which I also liked.

The miso ramen comes with seaweed, bamboo shoots, a boiled egg, and pork.  The meat was flavorful and tender, the boiled egg was yummy, and I liked the hardness of the noodles.  Even though these components were good, the overall dish didn't impress me all that much.  It was decent, but nothing that blew me away.

Perhaps next time the dish I order will be better ... I know there will be a next time because my boyfriend really likes this place and is upset I didn't like it as much as he did.
author: Can C.

description: Good ramen, descent price, expect a crowd. Small space, convenient location in the japantown mall. Servers were friendly. Most important health score above 90!
author: J C.

description: Been here several times and tried a variety of dishes including several different ramen and udon, katsu curry, karaage, takoyaki, gyoza and more. Authentic and extremely flavorful; the soups are rich and complex. Unagi don was especially memorable. Not so memorable are both the atmosphere and the service, but neither are bad enough to diminish the overall experience. Well worth a visit!
author: Josh H.

description:
I love going here whenever I'm in Japantown. It's an excellent noodle house with fresh noodles always! 
Last time  I was there I tried the miso ramen and it was perfect, the right blend of miso with a boiled egg, veggies, and seaweed. 
Overall this place is worth the wait since there is always a line on the weekends.
author: Alisha R.

description:
I usually get the mabo tofu nusu don (eggplant, tofu, pork on rice).  A tad salty but satisfying.  I've had the ramen too but since I'm not a huge ramen person, I thought it was just alright.

TIny place that usually has a wait.  They have a signup sheet as they don't take reservations.  

What's great is that after you've had the salty, you can go upstairs and get sophie's crepes for the sweet.
author: C A.

description:
If you are looking for delicious mouth watering udon...Suzu is not the place for you! 

Just left the establishment and my meal isn't sitting well.  I might (will) throw it back up once I return home.  Word of advice - do not get the beef nabeyaki udon. The meat is in these large gooey cubes, super tough and frankly disgusting. It has no business being in a soup broth.  It tasted spoiled as well. I complained about it and the waitress admitted that it wasn't well received.  I asked why they served it then and she said some people eat it all up.  Id like to know who and treat them to a decent meal! She said I should try something else next time and I told her flat out there will not be one.  She finally gets the point and asked if I wanted a discount on my meal (did she really need to ask?!) I said if you like and then when I get my final bill...no discount whatsoever! I still gave some tip because I can't help myself not because she deserved it.  Needless to say the service matched my feelings for the meal....a big F!

I have to admit SF does not offer a lot of great options/selections when it comes to udon and I've looked far and wide.  If you are on a diet and looking to throw back up your meal, Suzu might be the place for you.
author: Joanna C.

description:
Anytime I'm in Japan Town I always make an attempt to eat at Suzu's. The wait is usually long but if you're lucky and get here semi- early you'll end up waiting 30min or less maybe...
I always order the karrage ramen, the noodles are firm and perfect just how I like and the chicken is also a nice compliment. Overall a very good bowl of ramen for the location.
Decent selection on the menu and reasonable prices. 
Would recommend if you're in the area or else try Tanpopo across the street.
author: Miss H K.

description: I went here with my parents. We came at 7:30 on a Tuesday night so we didn't have to wait. I ordered the butter corn ramen. It's basically ramen with a slice of pork, bok choy, corn and a small slice of butter (yum!) on top. I ordered the shio broth and it was a little lighter in flavor than I would have liked (maybe I should have ordered miso broth like my parents), but was still pretty good. The egg was a boiled egg slightly over-done. I generally prefer soft-boiled eggs with some yellow yolk oozing out so I was a little disappointed. Overall the experience was good. Not super outstanding or anything, but not bad for ~$10 per bowl.
author: Blaire F.

description: 3 1/2 stars for this place!  They don't give you much ramen, but it is a good bowl of ramen.  I think it's a good choice if you're inside the building and you want something warm to eat.  Or go up the street for Waraku and you will get fresh garlic that you crush at your own table if you'd like to add this in your soup.  And their egg is oh so good.
author: M. T.

description:
I ate here in the past. Maybe a year ago and it was decent. This time around I noticed 1-there was no line (the last time I came there was a line and about a 20 minute wait) 2-after we put our name on the list (you do this yourselves) no one actually came to check the list. Even when they had about 3-4 open tables. Another customer came up about 5 minutes after we did, didn't put their name on the list, and sat at a table and motioned to the waitress that they were sitting. The waitress nodded. So much for using the list!
We sat down and ordered the Gyoza appetizer and the Takoyaki appetizer. For the mains we ordered one Tempura Soba, one Shio Ramen with sesame seeds and chili oil, and one 
Spicy Kimchi Ramen. 
The appetizers came after our bowls of ramen. The Gyoza was ok.. nothing great, typical frozen gyoza variety. The Takoyaki had a lot of breading but did not have much flavor. The Shio Ramen with Sesame and Chili oil was just bland. Nothing but a tinge of spiciness. Funky bland Char shiu, 2 of the smallest pieces of bamboo shoots, and one really sad looking piece of Bok Choy. Just NOT good and so far away from the great Ramen I have had in the past. Same goes for all the ramen we had. The Soba was the best of the lot but I use that word very loosely. My brother used a lot of pepper flakes to add more flavor. 
This place use to be decent so I don't know what happened but I wont be coming back unless all the other ramen places close down. Also we had to flag down the waitress in order to get our check..even though they were not busy. I can live with so so customer service but I can't tolerate food that is prepared so blandly.
author: Rik K.

description:
Still one of the tastier ramen house in J-town, but slipping in my ratings book due to poor service/communication and portions that seem to get smaller and smaller. The broth was very salty today too. That plus the wait plus the cost versus what you get and I don't know if I will be back anytime soon. 

So our table got three combos (ramen/soba/udon + a donburi). I specifically asked (since I didn't remember) which ramen the combo comes with; I asked if I can pick any of the ramen flavors. The waitress said I can pick any one of the ones on top;  just not the ones around $12. 

So I ordered one Tokyo ramen and two cha-shu ramen. When the first one came out, I looked at it and I thought it was cha-shu so I gave it too my nephew, than the next two came out and they all look identical. I asked the waitress which one was the Tokyo ramen and she didn't know. Then she said 'oh wait', two of those are tokyo and the other is cha-shu. And I looked carefully and the cha-shu one has two extra pieces of cha-shu. So I asked what's the difference? And where is my egg? I was told that the combo size ramen doesn't come with egg! Which ticks me off (even though this happened last time I ate here but I guess I had a better experience so I didn't remember that part) because nowhere on the menu does it say that. So we tell the waitress we what we really ordered and she was nice enough to bring us several extra pieces of cha-shu. Little did I know that the there is an extra $2 surcharge for this. So the combo costs $13 for a small bowl of ramen and a smaller bowl of donburi plus a $2 surcharge. That's $15 per person. For ramen. Yikes!

We also ordered two plates of gyoza which definitely wasn't as good as last time. First they came out as soon as I ordered them - which I feared made them not freshly made. My fears were confirmed when they were not crunchy on the bottom at all and they were lukewarm at best. If everyone at my table (especially my son) wasn't so hungry, I might have sent them back.

So I'm out $67 (three combos+2 gyozas) and I'm still hungry afterwards. That to me is the epitome of a bad eating experience.
author: Dom L.

description:
The ramen noodles are great and the broth is pretty tasty, but the broth leaves a kind of residue in my mouth that sticks to my teeth and always makes me wish I brought a toothbrush and some toothpaste with me. 

If you decide to dine here be prepared to wait.  It's very small with limited seating and is very popular as well.
author: Erich D.

description:
I tried the sea salt ramen (?) here one day for lunch with a couple of friends. I thought it was really good, but the only ramen I've ever tried otherwise was instant, so maybe that's why, ahhaha. 
-Really liked the thickness of the ramen, and the meat!! 
-Broth was too salty for me to completely consume, but it was good! 

Service was meh ... but we didn't really require that much attention after we got our food anyways. The place is also really tiny, so ... you can expect a wait during lunch hour. However, we were seated in no time when we went around 3PM... 

Overall, a great place to have lunch if you're in the area.
author: Ashley N.

description: i did not like what i've  ordered. I had better Raman at other spots!!
author: Tiger L.

description:
I was quite disappointed in my overall experience. I got the spicy ramen and was underwhelmed. I suspect they use msg in their soup, the noodles were over cooked and their broth was very light/not flavorful. If you like thicker broth, Katana Ya is a much better choice.

Also, there is a 3 card maximum per group. The service is sub par and not worth the automatic 18% gratuity for groups of 5+.

There is nothing bringing me back here. Wasn't terrible but won't be coming back.
author: Olivia B.

description: I was told this is the best Ramen in Japan town, I ordered the most expensive one, while the fact is the taste is OK but not a "wow" Ramen at all. Soba is not recommended, it is not better than the one I cooked at home
author: Iris L.

description:
This is my favorite Miso Ramen that I've had in America. The broth has lots of flavor without being overly salty. 

I think it is better than Katana-ya or anything else I've had in the Bay Area. 

I will definitely be back.
author: maria g.

description: Get here early! If you can beat the rush you don't have to wait on the list. Ramen comes in large portions I can barely finish. Service is quick but it gets very busy during dinner rush. Very filling and satisfying.
author: Charlene K.

description:
Tried Chasu ramen. Pretty good, but not enough. The soup was VERY good tho.


Here are my cons;

Only a half slice of egg - and it was 'cold.' Huge downpoint. If they serve 'one whole' medium cooked egg in there, that alone will get one more star. Cmon, it aint that expensive. You guys can do it.. and dont ever give customers cold egg again.

Bamboo shoots are little smelly. I and most customers can afford it, but I know this could be a problem to some people.

Chasu is not good. Taking out the fats from chasu? Well.. If only it tasted good without 'em. I can't dig into details becuase I don't know sht about makin ramen chasu, but I can certainly tell the flavor wasn't there enough. Since its America, many customers might demand less oily chasu, but 'Chasu Ramen' is for chasu lovers who love chasu with deep flavor. Suzu's normal chasu does not have that much. 

I know I was in store around closing time, but taking out my bowl, asking me 'finished?' at the same time? Don't do that. Yeah I was finished but I could have one or two more sips of your awesome soup. 

Suzu ASKs for tip. I wasn't in a mood for give tip to 'em becuase of the cold egg slice, although employee asked me to give some tips. I'm not an asshole, and I work in restaurant too so I just tipped her, but meh.. not happy about it.

Overall, okay but unmemoryable. Try it if you feel like some ramen around the location.
author: Brandon K.

description:
This place used to be good.  But, not anymore.  Maybe b/c they are always busy and crowded hence they don't have to put in any effort.

The flavors just weren't there.  The pork belly wasn't so good.  Noodles were only ok.  Soup flavor was ok.  Suffice to say, I left my bowl of noodles along with 2 pieces of pork belly uneaten (it came with 3 pieces).

My friends and I also have no issues moving tables b/c they wanted to combine two tables that were next to each other for a bigger party, but please be appreciative that we are doing you a favor.  Acknowldgement such as a "Thanks" would have been nice!

I will not be coming back!
author: Dorothy L.

description: giant bowl of spicy kimchi ramen for $10, 5 stars u get. got the mixed tempura today too, and although its not as cost efficient, it was delicious! highly recommend this place, and dont forget to stop at Daiso and/or Ichiban for a Japanese dollar store fix after.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
I still love this place and was looking longingly at the various and delicious looking bowls of noodles other customers were slurping whilst I supped on Hiyashi Chuka (Japan's Summer dish:  cold chinese noodles).

Do Not order Suzu's Hiyashi Chuka.  I worship this dish and have most probably slurped it at over 100 cafes and dives in Japan.

Suzu's Hiyashi Chuka bares no resemblance to any Hiyashi Chuka I've ever eaten or probably will ever eat.

Suzu, learn how to make this absolutely wonderful Summer offering or take it off your menu, please.
author: Jay D.

description:
Had the Suzu noodle soup combo. The broth and noodles were good. I also ordered the Gyoza (pot stickers) appetizers, and it alone cost $5.95, when you only get an odd number of 5 pieces that are hella small and is like $1.25 per piece or something like that. Just definitely not worth it.

I was not happy about the prices of the food here because I feel that it's overpriced for what you are getting, which is why I took a star away. And another star I will take away was for the service because my waitress never checked up on us or offered/brought out any waters. And plus they do not take American Express.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
When it comes to ramen, I have high expectations.  There is a crucial balance between the right flavored broth, noodle texture, and amenities.  This place just didn't hit the mark.  It wasn't anything bad per se but just very unimpressive.  Especially for a place in the heart of SF's Japantown, you'd think this place is THE place, it's not.   

The broth is ok, though bland unless you get miso.  But miso is flavorful in itself so they can't really take the credit.  My friend ordered the spicy ramen and you'd think it's some special formula but all it is is a bowl of kim chi dumped in with noodles.  wack.
author: Krystal C.

description:
Overall satisfying and tasty!  Good broth, good noodles, loved the giant heap of cilantro in my cilantro ramen and the side order of kim-chee is PERFECT for sneaking into your ramen.

My only gripe: ONE PIECE OF PORK. C'mon, really? Fellow ramen eaters...wouldn't you say two pieces of pork are standard? Minus one star.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Pretty good ramen place....but I give it a 3 compared to the real stuff in Japan.

Noodle portions are quite large and the meats (pork and tendons) were nice and tender.  Broth was slightly salty and simple.
author: Wendy H.

description: The spicy ramen was full of heat..almost too much. I wish there was more soup. There was a good amount of toppings. The noodles were al dente and cooked perfectly. The mabo rice was underwhelming and so was the gyoza. The ramen is more expensive compared to all the other ramen shopps in the mall.
author: Eve C.

description:
Coincidentally after * watched Ramen Girl (Brittany Murphy), we've frequented two ramen shops in one weekend.

We headed over to Japan Town for its festival and decided to eat inside the plaza.  We've walked by Suzu quite a few times and it's always crowded so we wanted to give it a try.

The restaurant is tiny. It probably holds 30 ppl. The ramen master and the waitresses are authentically Japanese. If you don't like ramen, you shouldn't come here as the menu is 90% noodles.  We ordered the Tokyo Ramen and the Chuka Hiyashi (cold ramen noodle). Both of the noodles were tasty but not too die for and I didn't find the broth to be particular delicious.

However, there was always a steady stream of patrons coming into the restaurant. They also take a 2 hour break in the afternoon from 3-5 so make sure you get there or before or after that time, Kitchen CLOSED-no exception. This group of guys was seriously bummed when they found out they just missed the boat.

I'm curious now to try the ramen at Katana Ya for a taste comparison.
author: Betty C.

description:
I did not have a very good experience here. 

I arrived with one other person and we ordered together. She ordered sushi, and I ordered Ramen. She received her dish and finished it before they even brought out my order. It must have been about a 25 minute difference in our wait. This is probably not common, however it is a very obvious oversight by the staff.  

We were starving so we shared our dishes.  Both of which left something to be desired. I forget the name of the Sushi, but it had Tobiko and Avocado garnish. The presentation was inviting, however the ingredients seemed to lack flavor. It simply wasn't interesting, and I think this could be because the ingredients were not fresh. The Ramen was with the Shoyu broth and it lacked character as well. It was standard. I was hoping for fantastic, seeing as it took forever to prepare.
author: Brandon C.

description:
One of the better ramen houses I've been to - sans the ones in Japan of course. Every time I visit the restaurant it's packed with patrons all desiring a hot, delicious bowl of ramen. 

The last time I came here, I didn't realize we needed to put our names down on a wait list so the people after us actually wrote their names down first. However, one of the waitresses was perceptive enough to remember that we were ahead of the other party and let us sit down first. Snaps to that! Service went down-hill from there, however, because they forgot my request for water and everytime someone came by to drop off our order they would just immediately turn around and leave without asking to see if we needed anything else. 

Onto the food - I ordered the Miso Ramen while my boyfriend ordered the Ramen and Chicken Curry Combo. Everything was really delicious and there was a perfect amount of ramen in each bowl. The ramen had a good, chewy texture and the broth was extremely flavorful - although one could say the Miso ramen was a tad salty but that's the flavor of miso! I enjoyed the hardboiled egg, seaweed, bamboo shoots and pork that was included on the bowl. The chicken curry was also delicious - sweet and savory like most Japanese curries are. I, however, did not like that they brought out the bowl of curry long before our ramen arrived. A bit odd in my mind. 

Overall, an excellent ramen noodle house! I cannot wait to come back and get my ramen-fix!
author: Stephanie L.

description: I went with my brother and he got the combo of spicy negi ramen and unagi don where I got just the pork belly miso ramen. He wasn't very impressed with the spicy negi ramen, but loved the unagi don (raving about the perfect portion of eel to rice ratio). I liked the miso flavor in my ramen and the pork belly was spot on, but the noodles were only okay. I also ordered spice on the side which is good for me because I can only handle so much spice!
author: Karen C.

description: I stopped in at this place on one of the busiest weekends I've ever seen in Japantown. I had no idea it was the Tofu Festival.  I was undeterred by the craziness and signed my name on the clipboard and patiently waited for a table.  I was secretly hoping for a table on the outside of the restaurant because there was a little bit more space and privacy behind the row of plants.  You have to wait around the area because they call your name a couple of times and if you're not around you get crossed off the list.  I got my wish and sat outside.  I slurped my vegetable ramen and people watched.  The ramen noodles were soft yet chewy, the perfect balance. The service was quick and friendly.  Best to come here hungry because the ramen bowl is huge!  Not bad for a restaurant inside the mall at Japantown.
author: April L.

description:
*Slurp*

It's hard being a hot mess (believe me!), but even worse if you are neat and tidy and decide to eat here.  

Totally worth showing off your messy side for this hole in the wall treat.

The noodley goodness of ramen, and odon swarm around restaurant while you try and decide what to get.

I personally like odon (love the fat chewiness of the noodles) and usually get them fried...but they don't fry them here, which I'm glad now because there were so much better swimming in broth of green onions, kelp, and miso. I ordered a side of salmon don because I love sushi! It's a bowl of rice, raw salmon, wasabi, and seaweed shreds. So, literally sushi stripped!

Soooo good, and so inexpensive. Worth the short wait at the door on the waiting list.

Go here, and get filled for less.
author: Jessica R.

description:
My office hates me. They hate that when I ask them what the best place to get ramen is, they start craving it. My bad. Seriously. 

I've been a ramen virgin until this place. I've never had REAL ramen before. Just Top ramen. If that's even close. I had all these preconceived ideas about real ramen. I assumed you eat just the noodles, not with broth. I'm crazy okay?

This place had decent reviews so I tried it out for lunch. It took me 15 minutes to put my order in. They didn't understand what the heck I was saying. Next time I'll go there and order by number like the Americans do. 

Chewy and fresh ramen. Soup was rather plain, but wasn't overpowering or oily. I loved the idea of the mushrooms in it. Will eat here again for lunch. I'm too turned off by the idea of waiting for a table here. The place is SUPER tiny. 

$8 for a combo lunch which includes ramen and a rice plate. Good deal for starving fat people like me.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Was in town with my wife, and after checking Yelp, we decided to give it a try.

And seriously, I doubt Yelpers' review on this one.

It taste so bad and bland, not even close to what we have in the South Bay (Orenchi).

We've ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and the broth tasted like it was made from instant noodle pouches, and the Spicy Ramen, didn't taste good at all.

The thick pork also taste so bad, felt like was marinated in soy sauce, way too salty.

We both have tried many Ramen both in the States and in Asia.

And the karaage taste bland, no flavour at all.

Truly, if you're in town for Ramen, think twice heading to this one, cuz, I'm sure other venue might be way much better than this Noodle House...
author: George T.

description:
All my friends and roommates rave about this place.  I always wanted to try and like this place, but could never stand the crowds and the line.  

Today was different. Not only was there an unmetered parking spot right across the street, but there was no wait for us at all.

We got in and were served almost immediately.  They have the same non-drowning soup spoons like the ones from Shinsengumi--so well engineered!  My sisters and I ordered the Tokyo Ramen and the Spicy Ramens.  The broth was alright and the noodles were okay too.  I wouldn't call it the best ramen place ever.  I actually haven't found any in the Bay Area yet.

I guess it's only Santouka for me.  

Oh!  The startling point that drove my sister to make me write this post/warning:  
*They only serve ONE piece of meat in each bowl.  Just. The. One.*
author: Linda T.

description:
While at the Kinokuniya Stationery Store, I asked the cashier if he liked Ramen.
He looked at me a little suspiciously, as though I had just asked a Latino  if he eats beans, or a Southerner if he scarfs down some chitlins.  But truth be told, for many years we'd eaten at Sapporo-Ya when in the Japan Center, and it had gone a bit downhill sometime in the last 30 years.  We were looking for a local recommendation.

Despite his reservations, he managed to mumble that Suzu was a lot better than Sapporo-Ya, so we ran downstairs to give it a try.  G-man had Cha-shu Ramen, and I had one of the combos featuring a nice little unagi-donburi and a slightly smaller bowl of ramen.  The unagi was some of the best I've had, remarkably tender and juicy.  The ramen noodles were nice and chewy, perfect amount.  Clean if somewhat uninspiring broth.  Very reasonable prices.  Service a little sullen. 
A little more than 3 stars, a little less than 4.
So...Luigi, got any good pizza recommendations?
author: Kimberly V.

description:
This used to be my favorite ramen joint. :(

My most recent visit to Suzu was utterly disappointing. My Tokyo ramen had exactly two pieces of chasu (sliced pork) and three slivers of bamboo shoots. The ramen was undercooked and the broth lacked the genuine tonkatsu flavor. My friend's bowl of ramen was just as pathetic as mine. 

The customer service sucked as much as the ramen. My friend had to ask THREE times for a tea refill. The bill, however, dropped on our table the moment we finished our last mouthful of half-assed ramen. It was as if the waitress wanted to get rid of us as quickly as possible! The way I see it, abruptly giving your customers the check without allowing them a little time to process the last of their food is just plain RUDE. 

Sure, the ramen is cheap, but I still don't think it's worth my money. I don't think I'll be coming here again.
author: Lillian D.

description: I went here this week, had the katsu curry. It was very yummy, lots of rice and curry sauce. They gave me extra pickles too. I think this place has great curry!
author: Nick D.

description:
Meh I wasn't impressed. I had the Tokyo Ramen, unaware that it only comes with ONE sliver of pork. Sad. We also wanted to try the soba noodles and was also a bit disappointed. 

The only high point was the chicken karaage - I would go back just for this appetizer alone. Delicious beginning to end...perfectly fried and comes with a small salad and yummy mayo-ish dressing. GET THIS!! If I could rate this dish alone, it would be 5 stars hands down.

Otherwise, nothing to write home about - still on the hunt for ramen as good as LA's Daikokuya...
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
My first introduction to ramen was at Suzu.  Now after having tried several other ramen noodle houses, I have to say Suzu is still my favorite.  I love the noodles here, they're handmade and cooked until they're perfectly chewy.  The broth is also very flavorful.  Chicken Karaage ramen is my regular order.  Their Karaage is the best--- seasoned well and crispy, even in the broth.  I hear they charge extra when you get the Karaage on the side though--- what's up with that?

Suzu is always pretty busy at peak lunch and dinner hours, so expect a wait.  It's a cute little spot with a handful of tables inside and a couple outside.
author: Anne A.

description:
Why does this place have longer lines than Sapporo-ya upstairs? Sapporo-ya is so much better! I can't believe I let myself be fooled by people who probably only lined up for this place because it was the first ramen shop they saw. 

Don't get me wrong, this place is pretty decent. But if you just walk up a flight of stairs, you'll get much tastier ramen and gyoza.
The gyoza here is what really fell flat. It was just undercooked so it was still wet/soggy-- upstairs, the gyozas you get are much bigger and are done just right with a slight crisp finish.  

The tempura-don here was tasty. Everything was fried just right. I'll give them that. But their rice was cooked with too much water or something, and it was mushy.

The ramen was mediocre. The noodles were undercooked and still in a "block" form as though they had simply placed a pack of noodles into the bowl, which bothered one of my companions. (Other places, they cook the noodles separately, drain, and then place into the bowl of soup).
author: Saori E.

description:
I havent' been to Suzu in awhile.  I went with my husband and a friend.  I remember the last time we were there, the ramen was just okay.  This time we went for dinner on Wednesday, the experience was pretty good.  

We got the agedashi toshu, croquette, Karaage ramen with spicy, spicy ramen and Suzu ramen combo with curry.  Everything was good. Everyone left happy and full.

I have to go back another time to make sure it is consistenly good. hehe. Will definitely be back.
author: Carol K.

description: I had the Shoyu Ramen, shrimp tempura, and gyoza. It was ok I would not recommend it. I would rather go somewhere else.
author: Kristine D.

description: Love the spicy ramen.  Pretty darn hot and will clear your sinuses and get you sweating. The food is really good but the waits can be long.
author: Gregg D.

description:
Oh how I miss ramen.  In Colorado, we don't have many options for even decent ramen.  We came to Japantown specifically for ramen, almost went to the place on the second level but saw there was no line for a table at Suzu.  

We ordered a bowl of udon and ramen (off of the lunch specials menu).  The udon broth was slightly sweet, the noodles were cooked perfectly, chewy, hot, delicious.  The ramen was in a saltier broth and it was perfect as well.  We split the two bowls between the three of us and I could've easily polished off two on my own (I say that now, but the portion size was great, not too huge, not too small).

Service was fast, food was great, staff was helpful.  I'd definitely come back and will recommend Suzu to people traveling to SF!
author: Rachael B.

description:
I was hyped to finally wait in a short line to dine here.  Friday night at 8pm, 10 min wait - yay!  
I thought I'd get a combo to try more...but I have a feeling it wasn't the best idea.  I opted for the udon & tekka don.  The udon was awesome - al dente, overall great.  The tekka don was a waste - I would NOT recommend.  The boy's ramen was good & kaarage mapo tofu don was solid - spicy, flavorful.  Next time, we decided to opt for a single noodle dish instead of trying a combo.  

(Note to self: re-yelp on 2nd visit and hope for 4-5 stars)  
From my experience, this is one of the best noodle houses in SF that I've been to.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Between the horror stories of the service and the wait, we were more than lucky, especially considering we had a party of 7. They definitely present a vibe of "eat, pay, and leave," but our procedure is typically to eat, pay, and leave, so it works for me. Also as to portion size, it's perfectly fine for the cost, and the last thing Americans need to do is eat more. 

In descending order of our choices this evening:
Nabeyaki udon - Definitely the highlight, great broth.
Unagidon with soba - Also a well-balanced broth, prefer the soba noodles to the udon.
Karaage chicken curry - Very tasty as noted in many reviews.
Miso ramen - Solid, a bit salty.

I don't know enough about local noodle houses to put this place in context, but if I worked around here I'd stop in for lunch regularly, if not passionately.
author: John M.

description:
First time I had udon, it was delicious. Second time I chose ramen and there was this eggy taste I wasn't too fond of. Plus their soup tasted exactly the same as the kind they used for the udon noodles (maybe even less flavour) which had me upset. 

There's usually a long line, but it's not due necessarily to it's popularity. More like the small space and slow service. Depends on who you get, you can have a good or bad experience - unfortunately that speaks for Suzu as a whole.... 

no consistency... 

One thing I couldn't stop eating though: Karaage chicken. So yum! Other places have just batter, but this is real, juicy chicken.
author: Christal Y.

description:
3.5 stars to be exact

I like the curry karaage over rice
I like the chewy ramen noodle, minus the soup
I like the clean simple space and service
 
0.5 - nice alternative to Tanpopo with a smaller healthy portion
author: Katie K.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to Suzu this weekend when we got the hankering for some ramen.  We didn't have a very long wait, despite what I had read, and the service was prompt and efficient.

My girlfriend had the Tokyo ramen, which seemed like the basic.  The noodles and ingredients were good, but she found the broth to be somewhat lacking in flavor and density.  It did seem pretty light to me as well.

I had the spicy ramen, which was quite flavorful and hot.  

The noodles seemed quite fresh and had a nice bite to them.  The pork was meaty but not as tender as I would have liked. Overall the portions were generous and a good value.
author: rik p.

description:
I'm not a fan of this place at all.  I'll be frank that this review is based off of one visit and the shio ramen.

The wait here wasn't that bad for a Saturday late lunch.  The service here is shotty at best.  I had to flag someone down for tea, water, and to pay.  I felt completely ignored and that it was just "here's your food, here's your bill."  

The shio ramen was sad.  The broth was not flavorful.  The noodles are bland.  I had to drown my broth in spice to make it even remotely more flavorful.  I do not plan to come back at all, but I will give this place 2-stars.  It wasn't so awful I stopped eating, but it certainly has that potential.
author: Brent A.

description: I always end up in an awesome dreamland when I eat here. My favorite dish is croquette curry and seriously, the curry is perfectly spiced, the croquette is crispy on the outside and milky potatoes on the inside. You will have leftovers for later that get even better after sitting in the broth. So good.
author: Melissa A.

description:
I have tried all the Ramen places in Japan Center and this is my favorite. Yes, it is by the front door and yes you seem to have to wait longer for a table. I ordered the Karaage Ramen which comes with chicken. I thought it was very good. The noodles were a little undercooked, as they should be, in my opinion. I thought the broth could have been hotter. I would have liked more seaweed and less chicken, it was actually more chicken then I could eat. The chicken was also a bit too salty for my taste. The table we sat at is actually along the side of the restaurant, out in the mall area. This is fine, except that I had to flag them down to refill our tea and we had to wait a really, really, really long time for them to come and run the credit card for the bill.
But for me, Ramen is mostly about the noodles and I think Suzu's are really good.
author: Kathleen Y.

description:
Literally, a bowl of noodles. 

I think the word "chasu" normally connotes "chasu" in the plural. I've never heard of "chasus" or "chasi." Why? Because no one ever serves you a SINGULAR STAND-ALONE PIECE OF CHAS"U"! And it was not even a substantial piece, but a rather thin and dry one--like a coin! For this reason, if you ever go and want chasu, do not order anything but the "Chasu Ramen," which will equip with you with 4 pieces (and watery broth). My boyfriend ordered one of their combo sets, and the tonkatsu he had alongside his ramen was fit for a doll...in a dollhouse. 

1 measly star to match Suzu's amazing stinginess!
author: Nicole L.

description:
The best NabiYaki in SF and NYC.

Please stop eating here so I can get seated faster.
I just can stand waiting for you guys to finish eating and chatting.
Just Kidding . Everyone should try this place once.

It used to be even better a few years ago.
author: Anthony M.

description: Cool little spot that I can't say nothing bad about, I brought a party of 8 with me and they accommodated us really well with a wait that wasn't too long. The service here is excellent as we sat down they served us tea right away and gave us water. I really liked their tea here by the way. On this night, I ate the miso ramen and it was above average, both the broth and noodles were done really well. Unfortunately, when it comes to eating ramen, I really need it to stand out and be more then just packaged soup I can make at home. This is still a good spot to go if you need a quick fix of ramen, but not if your looking for an amazing bowl of soup.
author: Limuel G.

description:
I love this place for their perfectly priced ramen and a side entree.  When I come here, the wait is a bit long as it's usually packed with people, but it's definitely worth the wait.  Located right in Japantown, you can browse the other stores before they call your name. 

I usually get their great deal on ramen, udon, or yaki-soba and a side of rice and assorted dishes.  Their ramen is good, flavor-full, and will fill you up.  Plus their side dishes can include unagi, teriyaki chicken, tempura, or chicken katsu and rice.. all for around $11 or $13!! 

It's a bit small, but intimate enough for a party of 2 or 4.
author: Reb R.

description:
Came by this place after a windy windy walk along the Fillmore. What better way to warm than a nice bowl of ramen? Ironically, I didn't even get the ramen?!?! I ended up getting the Mabo Nasu Don (tofu + ground pork + eggplant + rice). It was great!! Chomp chomp... and the portions were nicely sized (considering this was $11 which should probably be more like a $6 dish!) The eggplant came out crunchy which I liked and the pickled ginger that they put on top of the rice was a great add to the plate!

We did come by pretty late, but didn't have to wait long at all for a table. And the food came out quite fast! Good and fast service -- just how I like it!

Only 4 stars for now.. I'm reserving the last star until I finally try the ramen!
author: Lina W.

description:
Yum yum ramen!! I love the concept of combination deal for lunch, but truthfully that's massive carb attack and next time I'd stick with just one item. 

Tad pricy, but quality is awesome and can't deny. 

Sign up board at front is hard to miss, and kinda annoying concept, but that's how it is.
author: Tom I.

description:
I love getting my Ramen on here! It's obvious that Suzu has the best Ramen in the city because there are always people lining up before it's even open. I usually have  to wait 20 minutes to get a table, but considering the amount of tables and the amount of people, Suzu turn tables relatively fast.
Their noodles are always fresh and the broth taste so clean! I've switched from Pho soup noodles to Ramen for my Sunday morning ritual because of Suzu's.
author: Tina C.

description:
I'd give this a place a 3.5.

Came 30 minutes before closing and the restaurant was filled with people. We sat out on the "patio" instead of waiting for a table inside.

I ordered the chicken karage and miso nabeyaki udon at the recommendation of the waitress. The miso nabeyaki udon was very good and rich with flavor. Maybe a little too thick because I couldn't drink too much of the soup. Could use some more vegetables in my opinion. 

The karaage didn't come out until we were halfway through our meal and I even had to go inside the restaurant to catch a server's attention to ask where our karage was. She came back after 5 minutes and said that the kitchen was backed up with orders and it would come out shortly. However, I am pretty sure the first waitress just forgot to order it and lied about the kitchen thing because the appetizers from tables who sat down after us arrived in a timely manner. I'm also a server and I forget to put in orders too, servers are human after all, but there was no need to lie about it.

Overall, the food is good. But I am disappointed in service. The server who took our order never checked on us and the staff only started paying more attention to us after the karage incident. I don't recommend sitting out in the patio if you want more attention.
author: Momo C.

description:
Suzu Noodle House was such a wonderful surprise! We went here for dinner prior to movie night at Kabuki Theaters and absolutely loved it. It's a great deal if you're looking for a Saturday dinner for two under $35. 

We came here around 8:30PM and only waited about 10-15 minutes, which was a lot better than the last time, when we ended eating elsewhere. Our server was great, and got our order while we waited, so what when we sat down, the food was ready to enjoy. The hot tea is complimentary as well, so drink up!

On to the more important thing: food quality. We both ordered the rice/ramen combination, plus a side order of the karaage chicken. It was more than enough food for two, and we ended up having to take our appetizer home. We ordered a chicken katsu-don + ramen, and a curry-don + ramen. The small rice bowl can be very filling, so don't eat everything. The ramen was really good as well - the broth was clean, hot and not too salty. I would have preferred to order chasu ramen and get a meatier-flavored broth, but considering the price, I ended up with a great deal. Our service was really wonderful as well. 

This place is a great place to stop by!
author: Amy N.

description: Sooooo good! If you love Ramon noodles, this is the place. I believe they make their noodles in-house? Had the veggie Ramon this visit, was truly delicious! Yum yum! Perfect place to get warm during cold SF evenings.
author: Ronney R.
