description: my favorite place in japan town mall to eat. usually a wait to sit but food comes fast and is always good and a great deal with the combo for a huge ramen and a small app or side add on. service is sufficient but i would not say friendly - but thats ok get the job done.
author: B S.

description:
I should have turned around and walked out when the waitress loudly said "OH MY GOD" in a disgusted voice after I arrived at 8:40pm.  I figured that I still had 20 minutes until Suzu closed, and how long could it take to make a bowl of ramen?  So, I sat down, and checked out the menu.

I tried to order Tan Tan Ramen, however, it wasn't on the menu - but they had a similar looking dish, which sounded good, Mabo Ramen (spicy tofu with ground pork ramen).  The waitress and I couldn't understand one another, and her return from my table to the kitchen numerous times, and the conversation she was having with the chef (in English) made it clear she had no idea what I'd ordered.  Finally, a nice guy came out of the kitchen and clarified my order and shortly a large bowl of Mabo Ramen arrived.

I don't think I could have been more disappointed with the food.  First, it wasn't spicy.  I realize I'm white, but I actually wanted something with some heat - no luck.  Second, the noodles were disgusting.  They were clumped together like they'd been laying around all night in the bottom of the pot.  The broth didn't taste good and the Mabo didn't have visible pork located anywhere in it.  AND it cost $12.  Without exaggeration, I could have gone to Nijiya Market, bought the ingredients for Tan Tan, and come out with more cash leftover.  The boiled egg I ordered (for $1) was actually the best part, which earned it the one star depicted above.

The waitstaff closed the doors at 15 minutes before 9pm, and handed out the bills, explaining they were closing the register, we were welcome to finish eating (thanks!) but we needed to pay now.  After paying, and then leaving a tip, I snuck out when I thought no one was looking.  The food was barely edible.

Save your $12 and find somewhere else to eat. Yuck!
author: Kim S.

description:
Eventually reached this place after barking down the wrong direction of Geary street. Really nice location, but the service is a bit breathless. 

I am not a huge ramen fan, and ordered a dull vegetable ramen soup for one reason or another. But the soup was good, almost refreshingly pure. Would try again.
author: Bangali K.

description: I got the Spicy Ramen, the soup was tasty not overly spicy, just right, enough to make you sniffle and sweat a little. The noodles were just ok. The pork was good.
author: Karen T.

description: very good soup and pork belly!  clean. service is good and responsive.  we had good food and time here!
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Their Mapo Ramen hit my spot.  Spicy and flavorful.  
I was thinking it might come out more saucy than soupy, because mapo tofu is pretty saucy, but it was just a bit of tofu and pork with sauce on top, then you mix it up with the ramen and soup underneath.  What happens though, the tofu floats up at the surface of the soup but the pork sinks down, so you have to fish for the pork through the ramen.  
The broth...ehh.. was good when I was slurping it, but I was so thirsty an hour later.  I had to drink two bottles of water to combat the thirst.  
In the end, I'm still going to shop around for a really good ramen place.
author: Debbie N.

description:
Wow! this place was busy sunday night.  I was in a party of 4 and we had to wait 45 minutes to get a table.  We got seated right in front of the door so there were cold blasts of air...anyway, more on the food.

I got the plain hot udon and the salmon mini donburi. the rest of my group got the miso ramen with either a unagi mini donburi or tuna mini donburi.  The food came out pretty fast, and they served tea.  I enjoyed my udon, and the broth was good.  The salmon donburi was decent.
My companions said the ramen noodles were a bit thicker than they usually have, and their broth was really salty.  But they also admitted that it was miso, and if they ate the noodles and broth with the green onions, it cut down the saltiness a lot, which helped make it more enjoyable.

I would have given 4 stars, but we had to keep flagging down servers to get refills on tea and to take our order...but they were nice about splitting the check. I'll be back to try other items on the menu.
author: A F.

description:
I went there yesterday. We were visiting Japantown and wanted to have some noodles. There were lots of people waiting, so it made us curious how good this place is. We had six people. 

They told us to wait and let at least 3-4 teams go ahead of us since we are a big group. After about an hour wait (I know this since I had to go out and put more quarters for my parking), we were seated separately first, and they combined two tables together later. 
We ordered Tokyo Ramen and Spicy Ramen...etc. The noodles were OK. Nothing special. 

The thing that made me mad was that they were trying to charge me 18% 
of tip after 1 hour of wait since we are big a group.
When I asked the waitress about 18%, she didn't know about it, and the other girl came and explained they charge 18% for group of 6 or more people. I started asking questions, and the girl got upset and refunded the money. haha... They were going to charge me if I don't say anything, but since I questioned them, they took the charge off?????

 First, we had to  let other teams go first since we were big group. (I did not know 6 people are big group.) 

Secondly, they never cambe back and asked if we need anything while we were anything. 

And last, only one waitress knew about the policy about charging 18% of tip for 6 or more pople.

I hope they put their policy on the menu and be consistent
author: Michelle K.

description:
I'd been back just four days from Japan, and I already needed a fix. Soba noodles were on my mind, and the thought wasn't going away. I tried thinking about other things, maybe a burrito, a parfait, I don't know, something else. But I was hungry. A ravenous hunger that only running a (rainy) half marathon can give you. Since I couldn't take a quick flight to Tokyo, the 22 up to Japantown seemed like a good alternative to get what I craved.

Dare I say Suzu's veggie soba, a steaming mound of buckwheat noodles, veggies and tofu was better than what I had on my trip. There is a reason there is a bit of wait. It's because this is some of the best Japanese food in the city.

After devouring every last bite I made my way back home, fix fulfilled, everything Japan still lingering nicely in my mind. Nice that this one didn't require a 16 hour flight. Just a 16 minute bus ride. One that will likely be taken again next time the urge for soba hits.
author: Jason B.

description:
My impression for this place was...the kitchen is bigger than the restaurant itself. Just a thought.

Good ramen.
Bad service, but whatever. Ramen just makes me think 'quick lunch!' So it didn't bother me. As long as my ramen came out fast, I'm good.

I had the Karaage ramen with SPICY broth. Spicy is capitalized because it's better!
author: Marlis T.

description:
I have a special place in my heart for Suzu Noodle House as it is the first stateside Japanese restaurant that I ventured to eat at after having returned from a vacation in the Motherland of Japanese food...aka...Japan.  There may be better Japanese restaurants out there, but for the above mentioned reason, this has turned into the go to joint for me and the BF whenever we find ourselves in Japantown.

I typically order the chicken or pork katsu with a side of cold soba--a simple, hearty meal that always hits the spot. 

That being said, we've had our orders messed up on two different occasions, so service is spotty.  Also, I'm not a fan of their new practice of serving the starter salad on top of the warm bowl of rice that accompanies the katsu.  Warm salad leaves?  Ugh.
author: Momo R.

description: Just not very good ramen. It's difficult to pinpoint what's more mediocre: the tough to eat Char 'Shoe', the curry ramen that comes served with a floating mass of thick peanut butter like curry paste, the overcooked soggy noodles or the Gyoza with the consistency of samosas. I'm sure the complexity of this dilemma will bug me for about 5 minutes. At least the water was good.
author: Shawn M.

description:
I'm sorry, but Suzu beats Ka-tanaya. I really think so. I really enjoy their ramen and the cha shu is one of the best I've had in the city. Yes, the line can be pretty ridiculous but the food really makes up for it. 

Their menu offers so many varieties of ramen, soba, udon and don- not to mention combination lunches and dinner for only $10.95!  Their broth is so flavorful and their noodles is cooked just right- it has a bite to it. NOT SOGGY like other noodle houses. This is one of the few places where I don't stick to just one item on the menu. I know for the most of us, we're so comfortable with ordering what we had the first time that we naturally to back to what is "safe". I've actually tried the salmon don, Tokyo ramen, pea shoot ramen, karaage Ramen, and the chashu ramen. Not disappointed with any of them!

Suzu, you are my go-to spot when I'm in dying need for ramen.
author: Jenny K.

description:
The place is tiny. Service is ok.

Fried chickens are amazing. The ramen is great, but the quality is very inconsistent. We got really wonderful chasu and ramen one time, but a month or two later we came back, and the broth tasted just like salt water, the meat was chewy and the flavor was just not there... The 3rd time we were there, it was better, but still not up there. Plus side: my mom now likes ramen. My husband likes the place too, but it's not for me.
author: S C.

description:
One word, delicious. It was my first time at Suzu Noodle House and it won't be my last. Writing this review is making me crave for it right at this moment. 

I had the Cha Shu Ramen and it was delicious. The noodles were plentiful as well as the meat, the bowl didn't come with much broth but hands down, it was one of the best ramen broths i've tasted. I usually don't like the bamboo but the ones here was salted just right and complemented the noodles perfectly.  I would definitely recommend this place, you might want to go early to beat the rush, there's a sign up list outside the door and your name is called fairly quickly.
author: Teresa N.

description:
Waited 30 minutes for a table. Got seated at a dirty, unbussed table.  Waited 10 minutes for service. At 9:30 on the dot, our waitress came over to inform us that they close at 9:30 and the kitchen had already thrown out all the food so they wouldn't be able to serve us. 

Their ramen is tasty, but it's not worth this sort of crap.
author: ali r.

description:
I would say this is comparable to Katana-ya ramen

In comparison:
1. noodles, side orders, pork, are better 
2. the pork/chicken broth does not have that long slow-simmer taste to it though

Order the ramen + side special - I recommend the chicken curry + ramen, the kara-age is money too

Also the ramen + side dish combo is priced with the Tokyo ramen as given but you can pay more and get the specialty ramens and still do the combo. I priced up ($1-$2) to get the Chashu ramen which is the same as the Tokyo-ramen but with more slices of pork.

enjoy!
author: Noah P.

description: I really like their broth and that they give choy (greens) with its order. Lost a star because the meat is always too salty for me, but I do love the handmade noodles. Coming here at lunch is better than in the evening because it is crowded then. I ordered the Chasu ramen and enjoyed it. Recommend them for their broth and handmade noodles! :)
author: Amanda C.

description:
I am so sad I as I have to write this review.  I remember when I was a kid, I used to go to Japan town with my family to look at the shops, eat taiyaki and eat noodles here.  There would always be a line massive line to get in here, and I would sit at the table with my dad and enjoy a hearty bowl of ramen, with noodles that they prided as being hand made and the broth flavorful broth and the steaming wafting into my face and some freshly cooked, crispy skinned gyoza.

Recently, I have returned with my father and wanted to relieve a little bit of my childhood.  Initially things were looking promising, there was a little bit of a lunch line and it looked quite busy.  We ate our meal and sadly we left a little disappointed, the bowl of ramen was smaller then I remember and maybe I'm much bigger from back then, but the bigger issue I had was the noodles, they were overcooked, thus eliminating any of the benefits of enjoying hand made noodles.  The gyoza I had was still pretty good, it still had a nice hot filling and a crispy char on the skin.  

Now I'm not sure if maybe my taste buds have matured, or maybe I have been spoiled as newer ramen places have emerged over the years, but considering the price per hour that you are paying to use the associated parking lot, it's hard to justify coming here as there are plenty of alternatives elsewhere that I can go to that are a bit closer, cheaper prices, and no parking fees.  It's such a shame because I had so many fond memories in coming here.
author: Chris T.

description:
Recently I've been on a "which noodle soup do I like best?" kick. For a long time it was pho, no question. I think living in SF has changed that. There's just not the quality of pho in SF as there is in SJ. Udon is another at the top of my list especially if i can get my tempura on the side. It took me a while to warm up to ramen but I'm starting to come around. It might even end up at the top of my list!
Suzu has become my go to ramen joint in Japan town. There's always a bit of a wait but to me it's worth it. They have the best Karaage that I've had anywhere, very crispy, well seasoned and fresh. The ramen noodles are dense and chewy, the broth is rich and flavorful. Last time I got the spicy ramen which is soooo goood and soooo spicy!
You know how there's a point when spicy food goes from deliciously spicy to masochistic? well the spicy ramen is just before that point. 

Let me illustrate:


-------------------------------------------- - Masochistic spicy
           ----------------------------- - Suzu spicy ramen


Does that help?

So far I like the ramen at suzu better than the ramen at Santa Ramen, which may be blasphemy, I know, but what can I say? I likes what I likes.
author: Melanie V.

description: I had the miso ramen but was not too impressed with broth.  There wasn't much depth of flavor.  My wife had the Udon and it was nothing special either.
author: Edward L.

description:
I remember writing my first review for Iroha up the street. I read some of the reviews for that place and thought to myself, "What are all these people bitching about? It's just a bowl of ramen."

My, how things have changed. While I've never been to Japan for some real authentic ramen, I've been to a few places in Vancouver, New York, Honolulu, and Southern California that have really opened up my eyes to what good ramen can taste like. RIch broth. Tender cuts of fatty chashu. Al dente hand cut noodles. And all of it has to come together perfectly, the temperature, the toppings, the savoriness, all in one harmonized note.

Suzu provided a similar experience before, but I'm guessing the ownership may have changed. Now they have combo menus much like the new menus at Katana-Ya. Personally, I think it's a crock. You don't need a combo meal with your ramen to make a good meal. You just need good ramen.

And to that end, to say that Suzu delivers the best ramen a) in J-Town--would be accurate, b) in the City--would be debatable (we could really use some good Ramen around here), and c) in the Bay Area--keep looking, there is certainly better ramen out there. I'd recommend Santa Ramen or Ramen Dojo in San Mateo.

That said, at least there is a viable option for what's left of J-Town when it comes to ramen.
author: Tony L.

description:
Tokyo Ramen = WAY TOO SALTY!  As in, I could only finish half of the bowl!  I gave the rest to my boyfriend to finish, but he took a few bites and was overwhelmed as well.

There were also three waitresses, almost doing the job of one efficient waitress.  Two would stand around and chat with each other, while the other would be refilling teas.  And then they would switch out, with another serving dishes while the other two chat.

Also, my ramen came out within minutes of our ordering, but my boyfriend's meal didn't come out until at least 5 minutes later...and then his appetizer came out five minutes after that.

As we were leaving, I wanted to laugh at the crowd waiting for a table and tell them they would be disappointed...
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Saw the great reviews on Yelp and was craving ramen on a chilly August (thank-you San Fransisco for your 50-degree "summer" weather!!!) late morning. Decided to call to see if they were opened, so I explicitly asked the guy who picked up, "What are your hours?" He responded back with, "Come. We are open." I should have learned from growing up with Asian parents where English is a second language, that the guy had no clue what the hell I was asking him. We show up at the door at 10:30. The sign said it opened at 11:30. Well, that was a huge FML moment. We ended up going a few blocks down to Gussies'...which was also an equally disappointing moment in my eating career. 

I guess now I'll never know what those 3.5 stars on Yelp meant...
author: Blenda L.

description:
Daisuki...daisuki...daisuki SUZU!!!!...this place morphed me into a 
chibi-sized anime character, that was how joyful I felt about this tiny Japanese noodle shop. I knew it was good when I found Japanese folks waiting outside for a seat. The anticipation only made the food taste sweeter. The barley tea elated me...the cheerful servers made me smile...the bowl of steaming soba noodles...the crackly soft potato croquettes...this place was like my first summer love...sigh.
author: cindy w.

description: Got the Cha su ramen. It was not that great. THe broth has little flavor. Pretty much clear soup with a little flavor. Not what I'm expecting from ramen broth. The noodles were good. The chasu was a bit dry. There really wasn't anything special about this place.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Had the Tokyo Ramen bowl on Saturday night. Prices are decent, considering a San Francisco Japantown restaurant.
Broth is a little on the salty side, some MSG, but not too much as i did not get a pounding headache and cotton mouthed from other MSG laden places.
Big lines of people. Service was good. Portion is okay,  but the light on the char siu and other ramen ingredients. ( mostly noodle with 2 thin sllices of pork and an egg with garnishes)
author: huey o.

description: So good that I was really about to eat here twice in a day, or I was just delirious from hunger and having to hang around Japantown. Great chewy texture to the noodles and affordable prices. The dry ramen is a particular standout. In retrospect, they do skimp on toppings and you can't customize your bowl to the extent of other ramen places. I work in the area when it's not too crowded though, so table for one please.
author: James P.

description: Came back recently. Did they change owners?? Menu is different, decor changed, portion size smaller, broth not as tasty, etc. We have to find a new ramen house to go to now. Sad.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
I strolled in while wandering the neighborhood and noticed there was a line, so I put my name on the list and sat in the mall. The line moved rapidly, I think there were 6 parties ahead of me, but I didn't wait more than 10-15 minutes.

I had the miso ramen with pork belly and it was very tasty. The service was adequate, I don't expect super star service at noodle places in general. I would come back again.
author: Katherine F.

description:
I was in and out of Japantown today, hoping to have a really good ramen before heading back to my hotel after a gorgeous day in the sun. My feet were killing from all the up and down action of the hills that make up San Francisco so when it was time to eat, I was in no mood to be disappointed.

At the advice of two guys loafing around outside the Kinokuniya Building, I decided to forgo one of the other ramen places nearby for Suzu. With limited opportunities to eat certain things, I really wish I had gone elsewhere. All I had was the miso ramen, as I wanted to have something else a little later. 

I'm sad to say that my ramen wasn't so great. The noodles were way too rubbery and chewy. There should definitely be some spring to them but I felt like I had a mouthful of rubber bands. The broth was OK, but the creaminess of the miso broth should always be accompanied by bean sprouts, which it was not. The boiled egg was not runny, which I did not mind and the pork was also too chewy. There wasn't enough fat in the meat so that was a let-down.

Service was on par wirh the food. I noticed a mixed crowd of Japanese and nons, but don't be fooled, it was nothing special. Surely there's better nearby.
author: CalamityJane T.

description:
Dined here twice and I would rate their ramen a 3. The broth is good, but is lacking stuff. Could use more ingredients inside. Maybe have the option of adding additional ingredients?

The combo option is nice when you do not want to get too full. I do not think it's a good bang for your money because the extra dish is very tiny.

Is it worth a long wait? NO. If you're craving for ramen in Japantown and there is no line. Sure, eat here.
author: Chatree T.

description: I'm not sure why this restaurant is always so packed. The ramen is decent but nothing worth waiting more than 5 minutes for. It's definitely not Ramen Dojo or Orenchi Ramen good. The appetizers were adequate. We got the Agadeshi Tofu, Gyoza and Karaage. Nothing stood out. I highly doubt I'll be back since I live and work so close to my two favorite ramen joints.
author: Chi N.

description: This is a Japanese ramen restaurant located at Webster/Post in the Japantown Kinokuniya Building. To be honest, I've tried several of the ramen choices and combinations here, but I don't think any of them are particularly good. The gold standard that I measure all my ramen experiences to is Santouka Ramen and this place doesn't even come close. The noodles don't have that al dente firmness or chewiness and the meat isn't juicy enough, tender enough, or fatty enough for me. As you can tell, I am extremely picky about my ramen and pretty unforgiving about any perceived flaws. Also, it's pretty obvious, especially for ramen, whether or not quality ingredients were used and you can instantly taste the difference e.g. the soup base richness. I would discourage getting the tonkotsu (pork bone broth) ramen since the portion size is relatively small and not worth it. I really had high hopes for a consistent Japantown ramen joint and even after my initial disappointment, I returned several more times to give this place another chance. Sadly, none of the experiences was redeeming in any way shape or form. All in all, I probably won't be back anytime soon.
author: Andy C.

description:
This is place is a little hidden gem!  We ordered the spicy ramen and the Miso Pork Ramen.  It was delicious!  Their homemade ramen makes all the difference!  

This place is affordable, quick, and delicious!!!!! 

Unfortunately it is pretty small so there can be a wait but it is well worth it!
author: Jessica J.

description:
Thoroughly underwhelmed.  I don't get what the hype is over a restaurant with a grotesque wait over what's effectively Japanese fast food.  This isn't haute cuisine, people.

Stopped by there tonight since there were a couple of tables already open.  I had the chashu ramen, my wife had the tokyo ramen (shoyu ramen).  My noodles came out firmer than al dente, and the soup was not hot enough to cook them further.  I have a hard time believing that these guys make their own noodles with how firm and glutenous these were.  There were 6 slices of chashu in my ramen, and the portions and were good so they get at least two stars for that.  However, the pork was overly fatty and overly salty.  The bamboo shoots were bland.  

Total check for two bowls of ramen & a soda, about $22.50.  12 minutes from order to food on our table.  It's decent, but not worth waiting on the hostess's sign-up list.
author: Chris A.

description: Ramin was good ... not as good as the ones I've had here in LA or Rowland Heights but it was good. Not ground break or da bomb is what I heard from in town friends.
author: Justin C.

description: Top 3 Ramen house in SF that we've found - only reason not 4-5 stars is there is always a long wait, they rarely answer the phone to place pickup orders but the noodles and apps are fantastic. Reasonable prices too.
author: Elliot S.

description: Excellent ramen in the heart of Japantown. I haven't found a better place in the city. Great service was an added bonus.
author: Napoleon T.

description:
I would lean more towards a 2.5...

Like the other reviewers mentioned, the dishes here are heavy on broth & noodles, and short on the stuffing. I've been twice in the last week or so; the first time I got the beef & vegetable ramen, and the second the chicken & veggie.

Both dishes were pretty sparse on the veggie. I think the chicken dish had approximately 3 zucchini slices and 1 broccoli floret. I don't even remember any in the beef. As for the amount of meat, the chicken had barely a full chicken thigh in it, and the beef about 6 strips. Pretty low for the hefty 12$+ price tag.

The noodles and broth were both very good -- I liked the udon more than the ramen -- but for the price I expected a way more satisfying meal.
author: Annie F.

description:
I've probably been here 3 times total, and it amazes me how many ramen spots have popped up in the city yet many of them are not that good.  It's like the sushi chains.  Out of 10, theres 1 good one and maybe 2 decent one and the rest garbage with the price reflective of that.  However, Suzu stands as one of those 2 decent ones as it has a good price but I think for ramen, it is on the dense side and needs to be softer and more flavorful.  The broth is ok, but I do enjoy my ramen being a little bit more milky perhaps with the miso or something.

I also had tempura with rice added to the ramen since i KNEW for a fact it'd be small and not fill my fat ass up, but it was ok.  It's not necessary but they compliment a dinky ramen bowl so well!
author: Vincent K.

description:
Only tried this place once and had a fair impression. The noodles are apparently housemade which were pretty nice, cooked firm. The broth was on the thin side and the toppings were decent. 

The place is tiny and service seemed a bit oblivious. I'd come back to try it again though. Ramen close by is convenient, but don't think I would drive out of my way.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I am a ramen lover. Though this place does not comapre to a lot of places that I've already been to, I still think it's good.

Their combos are a pretty good deal, well at least I think so because I like variety. The bowl is very nicely presented and the noodles are served in such a neat and organized way.  Bad thing is...that it's a little bit on the bland side. But overall, I like this place because this place gives me a very authentic feel to it!!

I need to give it another try!

Pics: http://winendinesarahstyle.blogspot.com/2009/12/suzu-noodle-house.html
author: Sarah F.

description:
I heard the wait here can be long, but 40+ minutes for lunch...that's just brutal. Is it the slow service or are we all just slow eaters these days?

Anyhow, ramen is about the broth and just importantly the noodles, and the noodles here were so-so at best. When it comes to noodles it all boils down (no pun intended) to texture and flavor, and the Suzo ramen noodles failed on both fronts...and were generally just lacking.

As for the broth, it's "ok" (I got the Suza ramen with the stock / base broth). It just wasn't as aromatic and lacked the hearty, meaty, porkiness, that I was hoping for. I did try the miso broth as well which was definitely an upgrade, but shouldn't a good broth be able to stand on it's own?

However I will say that most, not all, of the various add-ons to the Suzo ramen are pretty stinking good in particular the chicken karaage which was seriously tasty (juicy, tender, crispy - perfect) as were the fried gyoza. The bbq pork was "meh" just a bit dry for my liking and lacking that flavorful punch I was looking for.
author: David H.

description:
Had a craving for ramen so we came to Suzu Noodle House in Japantown.  Tiny place with a waiting list.  We waited about 30 minutes to get seated.

Ordered Spicy Ramen, Tokyo Ramen, and Chicken Karaage.  The ramen was average.  The Karaage was greasy.  Nothing special.  Had better elsewhere.

Their hot tea was good.

"Craved ramen...left craving good ramen.  Asi Asi"
author: Junho S.

description:
This place is simple. Nothing fancy, don't expect the best of ambiance, but DO expect delicious ramen.

I ordered the Suzu Ramen bowl and made sure to tell them to make it just a little spicy (a friend's recommendation). The Suzu Ramen comes with LOTS and LOTS of noodles, delicious broth (remember to ask for mildy spicy for the good stuff), seaweed, green onion, pieces of pork, fried dumplings, fried chicken, and a boiled egg. For $12.90 I had leftovers (plenty enough for tomorrow's lunch)!

Not too salty, not too spicy, and the fried dumplings were TO DIE FOR. I'm a huge ramen fan, and I think I've just found my go-to ramen spot. Great for comfort, a hangover, or to satisfy your ramen craving. YUM!
author: Ashley D.

description:
This is my second ramen meal for this week. 

I was not satisfied with my last meal somewhere else. So this was a place that I always had a good experience. I needed to satisfy my ramen craving. I ordered my usual..spicy ramen. It comes with a piece of pork, some green onions, bamboo shoots, and lots and lots of spice!! The broth was super spicy hot....just the way I like it especially on a cold night like tonight. The ramen noodles were perfect and did not get soggy 10 minutes into the meal. Perfect! My friend ordered the unagi and udon combo. He said it was delish. I believe him since he loves noodles too and can be picky. 
Service was decent. We had to ask for tea several times. That was a bit annoying.
The waitress recommended the cold udon and shrimp and veggie tempura. It sounded good and I will try it next time. I'm sure it will be good when the weather gets warmer.
author: Molly T.

description: Really good ramen.  I have tried the various broths: sea salt, shio, miso, and shoyu.  All are very good.  I like the way the noodles are served "al dente".  The only negative is that the place is too popular for its space.  I always have to wait for a seat, but I guess that makes more economic sense for them.  I still need to try the cooked dishes, but the ramen is great.
author: SF P.

description:
Mmmmm, miso ramen.

You can get a combo dish of miso ramen and ahi tuna sashimi for $11. 

I'm not normally the biggest ramen fan, but this was the tastiest, most flavorful noodle dish I've had. I HIGHLY recommend it, especially with the side of ahi tuna (it's served over rice)...very filling and a great deal.

Seems like they have strange hours - they closed at 3pm (on a Saturday) but let us sit because we had been waiting for a while. They also close pretty early (9pm I think) but it's in that Japanese mall so kind of makes sense, I guess.
author: Hannah L.

description:
Expect a wait for this place.  I've been to SF every year and every time there's a line.  We were determined to get in this time..SOOOO worth the wait.  We both had their ramen bowls...YUMMY.  I of course ordered the Kaage chicken ramen....love this newfound food.  The husband ordered the tokyo ramen...be warn you only get 1 piece of pork...he was disapppointed.
I would've given a 5 star but I think they use MSG...we were very thirsty afterwards...no wonder it tastes so good.
author: Van L.

description:
It's hard to decide between 3 or 4 stars as I like this place to a large extent. 

But: the service is somewhat cursory, rushed. The type of service you get from a small operation that has become popular and knows so screw you because we know you are going to come eat here, anyway. It's not at the soup nazi level, however. Just not engaged. 

Like most ramen places (and Japanese cuisine in general) it's somewhat pricey for what you get. But still worth it, I suppose. 

In the end what keeps me from going here is that the combo of msg and sodium in the soup makes me heady and groggy afterwards. And messes up my tongue abit. It ends up being kinda like I have to decide, Okay today I'm gonna go get the Ramen high. Most of you are probably inured to such things and wouldn't even notice it. In that case, you're golden; it'll taste pretty good and you can go buy a manga while you wait for a table.
author: A D.

description:
This place kinda bites. A buddy of mine whose food opinions I trust told me this was the best place in town for ramen, and honestly a guy would be generous to say that it was sub-par.

I guess they must be doing something right to get the lines that they do, though I can't imagine what that might be. The service is pretty slow, and for a place with about 10 tables, one would think that they'd have a decent time handling it.

And while they expect their waitresses to speak some English, they sure can't read it. If you want to get seated without hassle, learn some katakana for writing your name on the seating list.

The food wasn't great. I ordered some gyoza and it was alright, though it's hard to screw up gyoza. My 'Tokyo' ramen was middling at best, however. The broth was kinda weak and the noodles were more like spaghetti noodles than ramen noodles.

Truthfully I'm not even sure what they mean by calling it 'Tokyo' ramen: I've savored tons of ramen in Tokyo and none of the places I've been serves ramen like they do at Suzu.

I suppose it's servicable, in the end, but honestly I'd be happier with a brick of Maruchan and not having to stand 30 minutes in line for it.
author: Cristopher B.

description:
Tried their spicy ramen.
They have the same menu as Katana-ya (did anyone notice that??) but the flavor of their broth is lacking and way saltier. Less flavorful, but the perfect ramen texture redeemed them. Sorry, I think I'll stick with katana-ya.
author: Ellie C.

description: The ramen noodles were good and the broth did not taste like it was infused with MSG. The seaweed salad and tempura was the usual. The tea does not stay hot or warm in the cups they use, a pot should be offered. If I ever want ramen and want something like typical Japanese noodles, I would come here again. The waitresses are kind also, good service overall.
author: Manu M.

description:
I really loved this place back a couple years ago when it first opened.  For months, it seemed like no one (but me) dared try this tiny little Ramen house.  It was seriously like a ghost town every time I showed up.   And that worked out perfectly to my advantage.  It was so great being able to just walk in on any night of the week, sit down, and be instantly served some fantastic Miso Ramen.

Those days are unfortunately long gone.  For the brave souls that eventually stepped away from overhyped spots like Mifune and gave this place a shot...They were surely rewarded with some really great Ramen & Donburi.  And thanks to those who chose to Yelp about their positive experience...this place has subsequently blown up.  Much to my dismay, there is now a line on almost any given night.  I'm happy that this place will likely stay in business for a long time to come...but I selfishly miss the days when I could slurp my Ramen in peaceful solitude and get lost to the sound of crickets in the background.
author: Justin L.

description: I ended up at Suzu after reading the numerous reviews about ans what say they have some pretty tasty ramen.  The place is small like most noodle houses I've been to but unlike the other places I've been to the service is really quick.  I was seated and within 7 minutes tmy order was out on my table.  I ordered the tokoyo ramen which was renamed shoyu ramen.  It is a chicken and pork based broth with soy sauce so has a soy sauce taste to it.  The ramen was cooked to  perfect al dente and the pork was nicely seasoned and tender.  The highlight was the broth itself.  It's all about the broth and they did very well that I basically ate the broth to the bottom.  Pricing is nice compared to Georgia since of course there's not many ramen places around.  I will be back if I'm in the area.
author: Nekiba M.

description:
I came here during the Nihonmachi Street Fair. We waited about 30-40 minutes during peak lunch time (12-1pm).

I knew there was a lot of hype about this restaurant so I wanted to give it a try. Anyway I was pretty disappointed as I didn't really see anything special about the place. I ordered the nabayaki udon and it was *shrug* eh.... the soup wasn't very flavorful... tasted more on the watery side than brothy side.

Maybe my mistake was ordering udon... was the hype all about the ramen? I guess I will have to try again to find out.
author: Crystal S.

description: Easy to travel to, inside a building that houses many other Japanese stores, Suzu Noodle House did not disappoint. Our appetites were okay, so we all just went with a bowl of ramen. Solid broth, served quickly, easy peasy, no fuss.
author: Shang S.

description: Great ramen place if you can beat the line. Their flavor is a bit on the light side which most people probably don't prefer, but it's just the way I like it. The wooden ladles they give you add some interesting flavors to the taste, but it makes me worry a bit about how sanitary it is.
author: Calvin W.

description:
So where do I even begin? This place is so overrated! I can't understand why there is always a line to eat here?! As a ramen lover, I say "hell no" to Suzu. 

I went here the other week and ordered the lunch combination special with an appetizer of shrimp dumplings. The ramen broth was nothing to write home about, the toppings meager, the noodles too fat and bloated. The little curry bowl on the side was tasty, but come on, no meat, no tonkatsu, no nothing on top?! Just rice filler.

The real nail in the coffin was that the shrimp dumplings were of the frozen variety one can buy at Nijiya for $2.99 for a pack of 24! Seriously. Just because they microwave it in the back and serve it in an authentic-looking dim sum basket does not make it worth $6!!! 

In sum, I'd rather drive to San Jose to eat at Santouka Ramen at the Mitsuwa food court than shell out money for this place.
author: Jenny K.

description: Only came here because my daughter wanted to try it out. I wasn't even that hungry. So l ordered only an appetizer. Wife ordered the Croquette curry. Tasted so delicious I ended up taking her order.
author: Eehno E.

description: I like Suzu. Some say it's not too authentic and bemoan the lack of Japanese staff. I say Suzu ranks in the top tier of SF ramen shops. And it's the best in J-town for sure. Maybe that's not saying much for our local ramen, but I've been coming here for years and to me, it just keeps getting better-- they even seem to have increased their portion sizes. I like their noodles, I dig their broth. Their karaage is pretty good too. On the other hand, their egg leaves much to be desired, as do the eggs in most SF ramen joints.
author: Brett W.

description: Funny little joint in the mail. Get the outside inside table. I've been coming here for years and always been a fav. Good cheap eats (even though they just raised the prices). It's always busy where 15 minute wait is the norm. Eat and move on type of place. I've only been there once since they changed the menu. It was still good but maybe not as good. Maybe a new owner? On a raining day before a movie, it's the spot.
author: Jeff D.

description: Miso ramen was very good.  The noodles were very tasty and portion was just enough to be filling for me.
author: T. K.

description:
My favorite ramen spot. The noodles are fresh and have the perfect texture. I've tried most of the different flavors broths, but my favorite is always miso. The bottom of the bowl is always a little sad. 

Even udon, which normally bores me, is perfectly done here. 

You will probably have to wait if you don't come early enough, and they are closed on some random weekday. Check the hours before you go. 

Save room for dessert, Sophies Crepes are right upstairs!
author: Diana H.

description:
Came here right before dinner rush hours and was seated promptly. Order the Karaage Ramen which came with standard toppings:
- green onions
- bamboo
- seaweed
there was about 4-5 pcs of chicken karaage...I personally didnt like it...it was kinda fatty and oily. 

If you're at Japan town and don't want sushi, definitely check this place out, its a hit or miss.
author: tracy l.

description: The tonkotsu ramen is good - I can happily eat this again and without complaining that it isn't like ramen in Japan.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Wanted to try Suzu many times, but on weekends and evenings it is packed. Turns out if we go at 5:30 for an early dinner, it's super easy to snag a table (and street parking!).  A friend who lived in Tokyo for a few years recommended Tampopo, and while that was an okay experience, I find the Ramen at Suzu much more tasty and interesting and more generous portions.  

Really, it's hard to go wrong with any of the Ramen. I particularly enjoy the Ramen with cilantro.  My son likes that one and the chicken katsu.

Suzu is cute, and has a trendy look compared to the other Ramen houses in Japantown, but is still our hands-down favorite.
author: Jen L.

description:
For the price, the portions are a wee-bit small. The broth was good, their curry is scrumdiddlyumptious and the ramen noodles were decent. Agedashi Tofu appetizer was small, but tasty. We also ordered a side of Curry $5 (VERY SMALL) and a side order of Chicken Kaarage (Also VERY SMALL).

THEY DO NOT DO TO-GO ORDERS 

Weird? Very. Service was not great and the ramen was good, but didn't live up to its' hype.
author: 3beeskitchen ..

description:
Went for lunch and there was a wait, good sign. the lunch specials were a good deal and i like variety. My bf wanted chicken katsu with ramen combo, but wanted a side of curry for the chicken katsu and rice. totally willing to pay the extra whatever, they said they can't do it at all... he would have ordered the chicken curry but it wasn't fried... and they wouldn't or didn't know how to make that side of 'sauce' work... weird. everywhere japanese has chicken katsu. we didn't get why. 
anyway the ramen noodles were yellow, had pretty good flavor, but were a bit al dente for me. the pork broth was yummy and meaty and i also tried the miso which was creamy. 
they really have good lunch specials in j-town. can't beat it.
author: Sydel S.

description:
We spent a weekend playing tourist in Japantown and we dined in Suzu twice. The first time we went I had the Beef and Vegetables ramen. This was pretty bland and I was really disappointed. My partner really liked her spicy ramen. If not for her I would not have gone back! Round two I ordered the Shio ramen. This was sooo much better than the first one I ordered. The broth was more flavorful and earned them the 3rd star on my rating scale.
Service was fast and courteous and they were pretty accomodating when I had to change my order. I am very thankful for that ! 
I wish there were more good ramen places in Japantown (of all places). Suzu is good enough for me to go back if I am ever back in this neck of the woods.
author: Chummy S.

description:
this is, so far, my favorite ramen place in SF. the wait can get pretty long, but it is well worth it.
the broth is flavorful and warming, and the noodles are chewy and delicious. personally, i like it better than katana-ya.
definitely good for a warming, tasty dinner if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Cami J.

description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE Suzu! I was introduced to this place a few years ago and instantly fell in love with the ramen here. It's unlike any other ramen place I have tried. The noodles are so much denser than most ramen noodles and very fresh (NOT like top ramen which seems to be what other ramen places imitate....I do like top ramen, but I can pay 25 cents for it at the store!) I get the Tokyo Ramen, and I haven't ventured on to another dish because I love this one so much. The broth is delicious, and the bamboo, pork slices, boiled egg, and pieces of seaweed really compliment the noodles and broth wonderfully. I even brought my friend here and she absolutely loved it too, we will both drive up to SF (from Fremont!) just to have dinner at Suzu, and we always leave completely satisfied. If you are looking to have the best ramen in the bay area, try Suzu, you will not be disappointed!
author: Sarah D.

description:
Cold SF temps makes for a perfect ramen night. Trying to stave off the chill from my bones, I was excited to find a table waiting at the typically line out the door Suzu. 

I had my heart set on ramen, going with Tokyo Ramen ($8.95). My large bowl contained thick chewy ramen, a slice of cha shu (agree that there should be more of it), bamboo shoots, wakame (seaweekd), half of a hard boiled egg, and some negi (green onions) for flavor. The highlight for me was the broth, a sweet savory blend of chicken and pork broth. Great flavor! Really enjoyed spooning all of the tasty warm liquids.

For just $3 or $4 more, you can get a dinner combo that includes a big bowl of ramen (or soba or udon noodles but no meat), and a side bowl of rice with something on it. Like the Tonkatsu. It's a great deal and exceptionally filling.

I like the authentic nature of this small ramen shop. Easy comfort food that fast and filling. Just be willing to wait or come at off hours.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Though I was born in San Francisco, my parents rarely took me to venture out into Japantown when I was younger.  When my childhood friend wanted to hang out, he suggested we hit up Japantown and grab some lunch.  I jumped at the chance.  We parked in his designated school parking spot and walked in the rain to get ramen, which I have been craving like crazy ever since it stopped being accessible when I moved to NH.  We walked into this mall-type area, and I was shocked by how many people were there to eat ramen on a random weekday and how tiny the shop was.  There was a list of people in line.  We added my name to the list and wandered off to look at tiny trinkets and anime stuff.  We returned in half an hour to discover that they had just called our name!  Oh, nooo!

Luckily, the waitress was extremely nice and gave us the next table that was free, less than 5 minutes later.  I asked my friend what he normally got and I ordered accordingly.  I got the spicy ramen combination with a bowl of rice and raw salmon.  The spicy ramen came out soon after and I was GLAD.  By that time, I was starving.  The piping hot soup came and got my glasses foggy.  I put down my glasses and put my entire head into the bowl and started slurping the delicious and perfectly spicy soup and ramen.  Oh-so-yummy....  

The ramen portion was sufficient, but I still had to eat the salmon bowl.  The salmon was fresh and the rice was perfectly cooked.  Just writing about this place is making me crave it and want to return soon.  Santa Ramen ain't got nothin' on Suzu!
author: Nina P.

description:
I don't come here often. Not because it's not good, but because it's such a long wait to get in. When I'm in the mood for soupy noodles, I want warm comfort food now, not 30 min from now. 

But when I happen to saunter by and don't mind waiting, I add my name on the waiting list and order the vegetable soba. Out of all the great savory, spicy, chashu, ground pork options you may wonder why? I know a place is good when even the "blandest" sounding soup base is tasty. And actually I enjoy the vegetable soba the best for all the veggies and tofu. Soup is HOT too. That is key!
author: tessie n.

description:
I went with the Mrs. for a Saturday dinner after exploring Japantown.  This place is small, cramped and wait times can be quite long.  We were the 4th party on the list and waited over half an hour. . .not worth the wait.

The ramen is handmade which is a plus, but it did not meet my expectations.  It was probably the worst handmade I've had.  Not to say it was bad, but it was not much better than instant noodles.  The soup base was not as rich and tasty as I've come to expect from eating Ramen at restaurants.  In addition, we ordered the dumpling appetizers which were homemade as well and if they didn't cost $6 for five tiny ones, I'd recommend them.  Service was rather slow as they had only two waitresses attending to all of the tables, cleaning, and seating guests.

I can not recommend this place.  There are so many better places to eat in Japantown so don't waste your time here unless you like wasting time and eating mediocre, overpriced ramen.
author: June P.

description: This happened two years ago but I still remember and decided to write another review.   The ramen had a moving maggot on the vegetable. We complained to the waitress. Showed her the moving maggot. the waitress had a normal look on her face they took it back removed the vegetable and brought it back. They even charged us full price for that. We have never been back since then.
author: Leon L.

description: Phew! We got in just before the line formed: Suzu seems to be a very popular joint in the heart of San Franciso's Japantown.  There aren't many tables, but it's not overly cramped, and there are a few in the mall space just outside the restaurant.  The noodles were good; the broth lacked a little flavor (we had one Tokyo Ramen, one Miso Ramen). Toppings on both were rather paltry.  Service was friendly and prompt.  Suzu is a good option for something warm and filling, but I have no doubt there are other tasty options very nearby.
author: Tamara M.

description:
One of my favorite places for lunch in the City. For a mere $8.99 you can procure a gigantuan bowl of ramen or udon (excellent broth!) accompanied by curry over rice or whatever over rice dish it is you fancy. Oher choices include tuna sashimi, unagi and tonkatsu.

This combination deal has many choices, and makes me happy every time.

I only wish they'd serve the tempura sauce on the side to prevent sogginess.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Yumilicious.  I love noodles...especially ramen and udon!  I haven't had the udon here, but the ramen was delicious.  I had the kaarage ramen, and the kaarage fried chicken (lightly fried chicken...in kind of a sweet batter) is super tasty.  The noodles are made fresh daily, and you can taste the difference.

This is no Top Ramen!  The wait isn't too long, but there are only a few tables (6-8 tables).
author: Wendy L.

description:
WARNING: Make sure you smell your gyoza dipping sauce for bleach flavoring!

Ok w/ that disclaimer made. I would still come back for their ramen because it's flavorful with generous portions. I ordered the mabo tofu ramen. Not very spicy so I had to add chili powder. Broth was flavorful as my fellow yelper Lisa N said. (We actually visited this place together, hi Lisa!) Prices are fair and service was ok. But that gyoza incident scarred me a bit.. so next time I hope they make up for it, some way, some how.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I am a bit of a ramen buff, and when I go to a new place, I usually get the standard Chashu Ramen. I have to say, I was pretty disappointed. The Chashu (roasted pork belly) was tough, and thinly cut. The broth was a bit on the thin side. The half of a boiled egg was white, showing it wasn't boiled in the soup base. Bland.

Ramen itself was good, and cooked to the proper firmness, and the price was good. That being said, I had serious stomach issues last night and my main suspect is the Chashu. Won't be going here again.
author: Scott B.

description:
FINALLY on my FOURTH attempt to try this place, I was able to try this place. 

-1st time: opps! Came on a Tuesday. They're closed on Tuesday. 
-2nd time: Had our name on the list, but was turned away because it was going to be 3pm after waiting over 30 minutes.
-3rd time: Their list was "closed" already. 
-4th time: Came 30 minutes after they opened and had to wait about 30 minutes to be seated. But alas! I was finally seated!! VICTORY!

I got the cha shu ramen. Edgar G. got the salmon don with ramen thing. Waited about 15 minutes for our food to arrive. We asked for more wasabi and was given a dime amount. *hmm... ok?* Then we dig into our bowls of ramen. I noticed I barely had any green onions, which was good because I usually scoop it out anyway. I probably had about 6 thinly sliced pieces of cha shu *hmmm...* and not one but TWO bamboo shoots! TWO! Not a couple... just TWO! wow! Edgar G. also asked for cha shu in his ramen though I'm not sure how much they gave him. 

Our bill comes and just for ramen and the extra cha shu our total came out to about $25. $2 for the extra cha shu. I don't know what all the hype is about this place and why people wait so long just to eat here, but this place is sooooooooooo skimpy with EVERYTHING and their ramen isn't even all that cheap! Well, it took me FOUR tries to figure this out. Sorry Suzu, I don't think I'll be returning any time soon.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
I heard much from my wife about this place especially for their ramen, but I got the donburi instead. Particularly, the Mabo Chicken Karaage don. I was quite disappointing because it had more rice than everything else, not enough tofu and it was not impressive as a dish. I felt like I was eating at a Chinese restaurant. The only thing that saved it was the Chicken Karaage in it. 

However, in all out fairness, I can only say this about this particular bowl. I'm pretty sure that the ramen is much more appealing and perhaps some of the other donburis. 

I will try this again in the future and hope that I take a better experience out of it with a different dish.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
The four stars are for the ramen only.  The overall experience had some issues.

First, we showed up near closing time and put our name on the clipboard list after the entry called "closed".  (Now I know what they meant--that they were projecting that anybody below the "closed" entry would not be guaranteed being served.)  We got in anyway.  

While we waited for our ramen, I noticed that the (young) servers were a bit inefficient in their movements. They served someone a wrong bowl, but did not realize it until after the customer picked up a spoon and started to swirl the soup in preparation to take a mouthful.  The server quickly grabbed the bowl and returned it to the kitchen prep.  I watched as the prep staffer changed spoons and rearranged the ramen back into the original presentation--noodles straight and neatly packed into a bundle in the middle of the bowl of broth.  This bowl was then brought back out to the correct table.  The customer snickered, suspecting what really happened in the kitchen, but was probably too hungry from waiting to complain.

The chefs labored too long preparing a bowl of ramen.  This of course precipitates into harried servers and impatient customers at the tables and wait line.  Perhaps the chefs are trying to achieve "zen" in every bowl of ramen.  (hey, it rhymes!)  Whatever... if they sped up their delivery, more people could experience their delicious ramen and they would make more money!

Notwithstanding their operational issues, my char siu ramen was perfectly prepared.  There were six slices of pork and the broth was seasoned just right.  The ramen noodles were straight rather than curly, but done al dente as I like it.

I believe ramen is getting popular, since at least five J-town mall restaurants were offering it in the $9-10 range.  I will have to do a comparison test one of these days.  For those who want to cook ramen at at home, go to Nijiya Market across the street, and look for the refrigerated ramen packets by Sun Noodles shipped from Los Angeles.
author: Mo D.

description: The noodles are super tender and perfectly cooked. I got the cold udon, which was great. The rest of my family got ramen that tasted fantastic. It's a cute little spot and perfect before you walk around Japantown.
author: Morgan T.

description: Suzu Noodle House started out with promise. I found the chicken curry rice + miso ramen dinner combo to be very reasonably priced. A few bites in, I was pleased. The noodles were excellent, perfectly al dente. But as I dug more into my meal, I was overwhelmed with saltiness. And that's saying alot as I have a very salty palate and I like things salty.
author: Monelle A.

description:
I really enjoy a yummy dish of noodles, however I was very disappointed with Suzu Noodle House.  The noodle dish was bland at best.  The broth was boring.  The chicken in the soup was rubbery; the vegetables were decent. The waitress was polite.  The venue is clean.  

Overall, there are many, many better places for noodles in SF.
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
So sad...  We loved this place the first few years it was open.  Cheap, not to fancy ramen place.   Good food nice staff.  

I wish that was the case last night.  I think there are new owners!!!  Blew it guys!  Menu change, price change, new staff.  Sorry $25.00 for us both to eat bowls of so so Ramen with no drinks???  

Two words: Blew it.  

Classic... buy a busy place and raise the price right away to cash in on the clients!  Wrong...  i'm gone!
author: Christopher F.

description: My 2nd favorite ramen place. If you're ever in Japantown, this is a must. Wait can be rough tho so get a little snack first - there's a little stall of Japanese mochis beside it. I highly recommend their Karaage ramen - oh so yummy!
author: Cholita L.

description:
I'm in love!  Again!

One of my best friends introduced me to this place last Friday.  I ordered the Miso Nabe Yaki Udonand salmon/tuna sashimi to start.  The others ordered the Karaage Ramen.  My order was one of the best udon dishes I've ever had.  The udon noodles were the perfect texture, soup was super tasty, it was yum!  Portion was huge too and I could have avoided ordering the sashimi to start if I knew how large the soup would be.  The salmon sashimi was really good...it even had a buttery flavor.

I'd definitely return as there were several items on the menu that I wanted to try.  It took me like 10 minutes to decide on ordering the miso nabe yake udon.  Heh!
author: Michelle N.

description: I waited a couple of weeks to write this review. In the meantime, I had the opportunity to eat ramen at several other restaurants in the City and in the East Bay. All of them were better than the shoyu ramen I had at Suzu. Ok, let me back up...I have been to Suzu dozens of times and enjoyed the food each time. However, on Monday, June 2, I had the worst ramen ever. The broth in the past was a 9 out of 10 has dropped to 0, yes, zero! It was brown, hot water, absolutely no flavor. I don't send food back but I had to. I was convinced the cook forgot to put some ingredients into the broth. The same "brown" water came back. I spoke to the waitress, the cook and everyone was just shaking their heads. The cook said he would talk to the manager upon his return. Whaaaat? They did not offer to remove the ramen from my bill. I literally could not eat it. So, I paid and left. I don't think I'll be returning anytime soon unless I hear they have a new cook. I have been eating at Suzu since they opened and have waited in line for a seat numerous times. The ramen, especially the broth used to be one of the best I've tasted...not anymore!!
author: Yoshiko K.

description:
I went here with my decidedly non-token Japanese friend as we were on a ramen bent and had already tried a couple of the highly-recommended SF places. Almost surprisingly, we found the restaurant was actually inside in the Japantown mall, which scared us due to the tourist-targeting potential. But we forged ahead anyways.

Overall, Suzu has a really comprehensive menu of Japanese favorite (tempuras, tonkatsus, curries, soba, and such) but this is a noodle house, so the ramen took center stage. Wanting to be honest judges, we order the straightforward and basic Tokyo Ramen bowl. And...we receive a straightforward and basic ramen bowl. There was absolutely nothing special going on here. The noodles were the best part, a little thick, a little raw, a little dense...they were the highlight. But everything else (and there wasn't much else floating in there) was disappointing. The broth was...insubstantial soup, the pork was ultra-thin and beef-jerky salty, and nothing else really happened in there.

It was a decent dinner for $7.95 based on the noodle quality alone, and who knows, maybe the tonkatsu is bomb. But overall, I'm not in a hurry to return.
author: Tolga E.

description:
Had a craving for soup and came to check this place out late on Saturday night.  It closed at 10pm.  I waited about 20 minutes for a table for two and there were only two groups in front of me.  

The food was very tasty, flavorful and fresh.  We got veggie tempura for appetizer and I got vegetable ramen and my friend ordered some kind of meat ramen.  Green tea was complimentary but had to ask for water.  

The service was slow because there were only two waitresses serving the busing joint. 

Overall good food and good experience.
author: daisy t.

description:
This is THE BEST ramen in San Francisco. 

I did enjoy Tanpopo, it was decent. Tasty. But there's nothing like Suzu. The attention to detail and presentation is really something else! The broth is perfect, the noodles are perfect, the ingredients are fresh and cooked to perfection.

This is the jam right here! Don't pass up the opportunity to go here.

Only cons: 1) too small = long wait usually.  2) closed Tuesdays.

Screw it... I'm going there now. Seriously.
author: Alland B.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Sunday with the husband and a friend. The wait wasn't too bad and we were seated outside since they were packed inside. 

Husband got the tokyo ramen which he said was meh. The egg is too cooked, the broth is not as rich, and if you wanted meat don't get this one. He only got one piece of pork. 

My friend got the tonkatsu and ramen combo. He was not impressed.

I got the cha shu ramen which was basically the tokyo ramen but I got more meat but for a $1 more. Also not impressed. The broth was a big giant MEH...but apparently it's chicken and pork flavor but just tasted like poorly flavored water. Egg was also waaaay over done. Uber sad face because the egg is usually one of my favorite things I look forward to with ramen and it wasn't the least bit enjoyable. The best is when the yolk is still runny. 

The only thing I enjoyed about this meal was the ramen. It was pretty good but having it in this bland soup kinda takes away your appreciation for the ramen itself. It would be awesome if I could just buy the ramen noodle and take it home to make my own soup. 

We saw other people getting the soba noodles which looked good but looks can be deceiving. 

I probably won't be back here anytime soon. The search for the best ramen in san Francisco continues.
author: Lang T.

description:
Had the soba noodle soup and the ground pork with rice set (which they basically called ma po tofu.)  The ma po tofu was a welcome change from the usual Japanese restaurant menu, although real Chinese-style ma po tofu would have put this restaurant's version to shame.

When the soba arrived, I could tell from first bite that the noodles were very square -- the boxy consistency evoked "institutional."  The broth was way thinner than I expected from any establishment calling itself a "Noodle House".

The soba was preferred/referred by the waitress over the ramen, by the way.  

Service was okay; restaurant filled up at prime dinner time.
author: Christine T.

description:
We waited a good 30 minutes before getting seated. This place is TINY! There are less than 10 tables in this hole in the wall. The waitresses were super nice and the service was great. 5 Stars for that.

I was FAMISHED and so ready to eat, and of course, ordered more than I should have. They have some great lunch combos for $10.95 and up, which include a small rice bowl and a bowl of  ramen/udon/soba. I ordered the tonkatsu and ramen, which was probably a mistake. The tonkatsu was a bit too crispy for my taste. The ramen was super generic and I got ONE piece of pork and probably 3 bamboo shoots. The noodles were al dente (read: good), but nothing special. 

I do wish I had gotten the salmon or tuna combo instead. Overall, 3.5 stars (Yelp should really allow for half stars!).
author: Jen C.

description: We were craving some good hearty ramen and thought we wouldn't be disappointed, especially if we were in Japantown, right? Eh... not so much. We thought Suzu Noodle House would be a good choice given it's name. It's a noodle house, so the ramen has to be great, right? Eh, it was a-ok to me.. nothing amazing, but not terribly bad either. I recommend the Kakuni (braised pork belly) ramen with shoyu flavored broth. The pork is beautifully flavored. The broth, on the other hand, can be a bit salty for my taste. So be sure to drink lots of water. My partner ordered the chashu (sliced pork) ramen with shoyu broth as well. His pork didn't taste like the chashu that I'm used to, which falls into piece when you bite into. It's a bit tough and lacks flavor. He ended up not finishing his chashu and the ramen, which is very unlike him. Lastly, we decided to share a karage appetizer and was also disappointed with that. It tasted more like popcorn chicken from a boba shop and not the authentic, traditional Japanese karage that we wanted. Anyway, Suzu is alright overall, but this wouldn't be my first choice to satisfy ramen cravings.
author: Cassy H.

description: Very unaccomadating. Asked for veggie broth with udon, and they couldn't do it
author: emma w.

description:
Super salty. Can't taste anything except salt. We want to try this place because we always see a long line outside this restaurant. We are so regret after that.
We ordered a miso and soy sauce ramen, the bamboo shoot, pork, soup, ramen were all salty. The pork is overcook and is like chewing gum. Not anything like a real japanese ramen, and unbelievably this kind food is sitting in japantown mall. Basically, if I give zero or negative star, I will. I will not recommend my friend to try their food. Really bad experience
author: Amy Y.

description:
Delicious.

Noodles: They use fresh noodles in their dishes, and cook them perfectly somewhere between al dente and just chewy. For dishes that are primarily noodle-based, they got the noodle down and also the proportions are just right.

Broth: Tasty. Nothing mind-blowing but flavorful enough to accompany the noodles and condiments well.

Menu: 4 stars instead of 5 because I am a vegetarian and they only have one, boring-sounding ramen with a vegetable- instead of meat-based broth. Ended up flexing my vegetarianism, hehe, and got the spicy vegetable/tofu/kimchee ramen, a pork-based broth, which was super spicy yet very, very pleasant.

Prices: Good pricing on ramen and ramen + donburi combos. $7.50 for vegetable tempura is a rip-off.

Service: Very nice and friendly wait-staff who are a little less than professional but approachable and above all else, honest. Our server felt comfortable saying, "I don't know," when we asked what set their restaurant apart from others; it was refreshing to not feel like someone was sucking up to us. Then she guessed it was the broth? Cute :)
author: Jen N.

description: Hi.  I have been in my ramen kick for quite a while now and Suzu most definitely is one of my favorites.  Their pot stickers and ramen are exceptional.  My other favorite is Otoro.  Actually, my top three ramen places are as follows 1) Otoro, 2) Suzu, 3) Katanaya.  Ramen is like medicine and Suzu is certainly very delicious and heals any and all types of physical and emotional sickness (within reason, of course).  Yum...
author: Peppa ..

description:
This is a really small restautant, but the food is always delicious. My date had the karaage ramen and I had the Suzu ramen, both were great but the consensus was that the house dish was better.

The service is quick and pleasant as well.
author: Benjamin M.

description:
Best chicken katsu donburi (with egg and onions and green onions over rice) I've ever had!  You gotta eat it while its still crispy, cuz when it sits the chicken gets a little soggy.  The sauce and the egg are incredible.  I've had this dish hundreds of times and this one is THE BEST.  

Also had the ramen (combo w/donburi), and it was amazing too!  The soup broth was out of control - not too fatty, not too oily - a little on the thinner side, probably no MSG, and so delicious.  I couldnt stop drinking it.  And the noodles are fresh and yummy. 

The gyoza we had tasted a little cold tho, like it wasnt cooked long enough.  Still edible.  Would have given 5 stars if the gyoza was hot and good.  Other than that, highly recommended!
author: Sage S.

description:
My friend and I wanted to try this place out. We had walked by this place plenty of times when its busy.

We were eyeing the four seater table, but its understandable we only have two people. However two single customer came in after us and they were given the big tables?

We ordered our ramen my friend wanted sea salt base soup, but the waiter gave him chicken base making his own variation. BIG DISAPPOINTMENT.


I ordered Edamane, but he forgot my order.
Soup: Moderate
Meat: Stingy! They only give you one small piece!
Service: Horrible! (The waiter had the nerve to ask how everything was going)

They weren't even busy!

I won't be going back
author: Somi S.

description:
A zen dish a carnivore slurps on a rainy day.

Decided to try pea sprout ramen based on nobu k's tantalizing writeup. This came in an almost greenish broth flavorful and light with excellent chashu, seaweed, bamboo shoots a half egg and fresh pea sprouts. The noodle strands (tidily arranged in the bowl as if somebody ran a comb over them) offered smooth texture and excellent elasticity which some may prefer over other variations. Tempura side was well-fried (reminiscent of some cheaper tempura houses in Tokyo) but a hint of oil was present.
author: M Y.

description:
I've been going to Suzu since they first opened several years ago. I think the best part is the noodles -- they're made in house and fresh every day. The problem is that I either remember the noodles to be better than they actually were, or I've developed an unrealistic standard for how noodles should feel.

In any case, Suzu is still a great place to get Tokyo-style ramen, and it's wonderful addition to the area.

Give it a try the next time you're around, but try to get there early so you don't have to wait in line!
author: mimi k.

description:
I came here for a late breakfast on my 40th birthday, after partying all night in the Castro. Everyone at the table had a hangover.  The soup healed us. And then we went to Kabuki for the rest of the recuperation.

Such a nice, cozy place with the yummiest noodles.
author: RIbbon M.

description:
Suzu's udon, unagi-don, and unagi-cucumber roll totally kick butt. Chewy udon noodles, delicious broth, soft hot eel...delish!

Eh, but i do NOT like the ramen. Had it about 2 or 3 times and was consistently underwhelmed. Not a fan of the limp noodles nor of the mediocre broth. 

But dude. The udon is super nommy. i nom-inate it.
author: Jade L.

description: This is definitely the most solid ramen I've had in SF. The place is modern and cute, the menu is full of interesting choices, and ramen was just plain good.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I've been wanting to check this place out for a long time, so after a long day at the spa I decided to grab some ramen here.

I ordered the pea shoot ramen. When it came, there was so much oil on the surface that with the light reflecting on it, it looked like there was a hair on my egg! I didn't realize it was oil until I tried to get the 'hair' out.

Everything tasted pretty good, expect my slice of meat had this really gross fatty chunk that I had to spit out. 

Also, I was not crazy about the service. It was 4:30p and the place was pretty empty, but they brought my check while I was still eating and dropped it like they couldn't wait to get rid of me.

The food actually tasted OK, and I'm not ramen expert...but I had a hunch it wasn't supposed to be so greasy. I have read that this place is better than the other places in Japantown, which is really sad. So, I guess I'll be back if it's some sort of ramen emergency, but not under any other circumstances.
author: Rachel A.

description: Well, after much research about how it should be served, I guess this all comes down to personal preference, but Suzu serve their noodles al dente and we just didn't like that!!  For early dinner tonight (no line yet), I ordered Karaage with Miso ramen.  My partner ordered Tonkatsu ramen.  For us, there was more than enough food per order.  The broth were both tasty enough.  The only thing we wished for was less chewy noodles.  But that's just us...
author: Yvette F.

description: I loved Suzu when I moved out of SF a year and a half go. I went back today and the menu and food are totally different. Wouldn't the new owner try to keep up the same food?! It was so disappointing. I don't even know what to write.
author: Purva G.

description:
So sad, since our first experience here.  its a popular place, and we were the first there at 4:50, it opens at 5.  We were still eating our crepes from upstairs.  I think i had the Summer special here last time, and it was so good, we ordered another one.  

They didnt have it this time, I was going to order the Tokyo ramen as backup but she said that the soba was the same. NO ITS NOT!!LKJTLKJESLKJTkjakj.  i didnt even finish it, because soba is so bland. I have got to remember things i like and dislike, even though they are recommended.
author: kim w.

description:
Average ramen. Average Nabeyaki. There's lots better in this city.
The reason for my two star rating is because we were presented with our check and asked to pay halfway through our meal because the restaurant was closing. Nevermind this is bad service to begin with, but the server just set the check down, said they would closing and not very politely asked us to pay. 75% of the tables in the restaurant were still eating and had checks dropped right as 9:00pm arrived.
Servers...I understand you probably have some place you'd rather be. Mr. Manager, I assume that you have to count cash, reconcile credit card receipts...but this is not acceptable in a sit down restaurant. This is the service business and incredibly bad service to do this.
If the food had been amazingly awesome, I might think about going back, but after this...nope.
author: Chris I.

description: I have been coming to Suzu Noodle House twice a year for the past three years. Each time I come, the quality of the ramen noodles continue to get worse and worse. It was my favorite ramen place three years ago so I continue to come hoping that each time it would redeem itself. But each time, I am disappointed by its karaage chicken, which has significant fat attached, as well as its ramen noodles. This past Saturday, it was more of the same mediocrity yet the lines are still as long as ever. Go figure. It may be a shadow of its former self from three years ago, but it still is a decent place for consistently okay ramen. Of the ramen bowls at Suzu, my favorite is the Ma Po Tofu Ramen.
author: Rich M.

description: Their core competency is ramen, and I wouldn't deviate too far off the path at this place, I mean why should you? If you want sushi or other types of Japanese fare, please, save your reviews for another place that specializes in that. People seem to complain about the line, but hey, lines are there for a reason: this place is good. Opt for a school night, especially in the beginning of the week, and the only lines you'll see will be your chopsticks eagerly awaiting to be used. The several times I've been, I seem to always get the Tokyo Ramen. Although not as good as the top ramen houses in Tokyo, this place is authentic enough, the noodles are supple and not overcooked, the broth is tasty and not too salty, and I always leave happy. Most recently I complimented with a delicate tofu side dish. My main complaint is that they give only one slice of pork chashu in the Tokyo Ramen, where nearby Tampopo gives about four to five pieces. However, the ramen and chashu are a bit more elegant here, so I can deal the quality and lack of quantity. I haven't conjured up the guts yet to slurp freely here, but perhaps one day I'll order a beer and give them the true compliment, slurps and a burp! Enjoy! Itadakimasu!
author: Brian J.

description: Owner changed and so did the menu. I craved the spicy Suzu ramen and it's no more. I even got my white boy husband to enjoy ramen because of Suzu. Now the food is "meh". Please make the previous owner come back, I'll beg if necessary.
author: Monica W.

description:
Needed a quick bite before going to my favorite theatre (Kabuki). 
Just a few feet away...in the mall, is an intimate, warm,welcoming noodle shop. Previous reviews very accurate! I had the cilantro ramen soup. Warm, delicious soup with perfect noodles! As much as I love cilantro, it was a little overpowering...next time I'll order it plain.  Hubby had the chicken kariage with Japanese curry! Yum! Perfect for a normal (chilly) san fran evening:) can't wait to try more! Only negative, the maguro (tuna) sashimi not sashimi grade in our opinion:(
Btw. Service excellent! Very friendly and welcoming:)
author: Halina Y.

description: Stopped by Japantown over the weekend and noticed a line forming outside of Suzu even before it opened.  This made us curious so after about a 30 min wait or so, I ordered the Chicken Curry Noodle Combo.  I have to say I wasn't overly impressed.  Everything was pretty much standard so I don't know what the whole long line thing was about.  Went to Sophie's Crepes afterward to make it all better :)
author: Emi N.

description:
I was feeling slightly under the weather this past Thursday and had intended to pop into the Kabuki Springs for some recuperative spa / sauna action, but I needed to get some grub first.  Ramen or soba sounded like the perfect fix, so I pulled some quick Yelp research and decided to scope out Suzu Noodle House.

Good call.  I am now officially Krazy for Karaage Ramen!!  Large bowl, looks and smells great, lots of ramen, lots of karaage (breaded, boneless chicken chunks), and half a hard boiled egg and some other additives.  Taste?  Fantastic.

Cleared my congestion and filled my tummy so well, I ended up taking a pass on Kabuki and roamed around Japantown in a ramen bliss instead.

I am absolutely going back soon to try more on the menu!!!
author: Chris C.

description:
