it is with a heavy heart that i give suzu these two stars.

suzu used to be my favorite place for all things curry.  yes, i know everyone comes here for the ramen, but for me the secret was in the curry.  thick and flavorful, with chunky bits of pork, the curry don was a song to my heart.

alas, they have changed the recipe, and what was once an authentic bowl of curry comfort is now a gelatinous corn starch mess.

please bring back the old eggplant mabo don recipe.  i beg you.
author: Josie M.

description:
As a ramen lover, I wanted to try this place.  After a long wait outside and with warnings that we may not be served since they close at 3:00 p.m. we persisted and got seated at 2:45 p.m. 

 We knew what to order and did not waste any time in putting our order.  Our ramen bowls arrived 15 minutes after we ordered and got  our tab within a few minutes.  The servers were nice, but also insisted that payment must be made ASAP as they were closing at 3:00 p.m. 

I did not enjoy the full flavor of  the broth as we were totally rushed ~ I did consume my bowl of ramen in less than 10 minutes!   The toppings were scant with only one paper thin slice of pork. 

They are doing a great business with a long waiting line, but for me, I  won't be returning back.  Never been to a place where they were so anxious to boot out customers ~ they should be so happy to have such a thriving business in this economy.

Won't be back, and they could care less.
author: Tabisky C.

description:
Wow. can't believe I didn't write this place up!
cheap Udon with curry.
yum!

if you want to spend more $$, go to Maki upstairs. but this is good when maki is full or you don't want to spend that much...
author: Sophia Y.

description:
ALWAYS ALWAYS A LINE........Went there around 8:45pm last Sat and there was still a line (please note they closed at 9:30pm)!  My friend and I waited 20 minutes for a table....Unbelievable! 

Finally, we were seated, gotten our menu, and the waitress gave us water.  The waitresses are nice but very SLOW.  It even took them another 10 minutes to place our order.......The lunch/dinner combinations are pretty good deal.  The price is around $11.95-$13.95 and you can get a small bowl of rice / sashimi or sushi rolls plus a bowl of regular ramen/udon/soba!  The portions were small but still able to fill you up.  I highly recommend their udon noodles, very chewy and tasty. 

Overall I'm definitely happy with this place and will be going back for sure (of course avoid the peak hours)!
author: Liza T.

description: Got gyoza and karaage ramen. Both were good and the wait to be seated or for food wasn't very long. We got pushed out a bit quickly, but that's understandable because people were waiting. I'd recommend it.
author: Aneesh S.

description: Get the spicy miso ramen with ground pork! Very delicious and soft egg noodles will seal the night sharing with two people! I also ordered takoyaki, 5balls of flour surrounded with small octopus bit and glazed with sweet okonomiyaki and spicy mayo sauce and bonito fish flakes Good place for ramen, very small and cozy.
author: Ting W.

description:
This place was simple.  I went here with a friend and the wait wasn't that long.  I thought it was popular because every time I walked by, it seemed like there was always a lot of people waiting in line.  

I could already tell that this was a ramen place but it had other things.  The kitchen looked small and I'm always wary of having sushi in a place that doesn't have a sushi bar.  So i decided to focus on ramen, and I got the tokyo ramen while my friend got ramen with an avocado salmon roll. 

It took a little bit longer than i had thought to get the food, but thats okay.  It was a small kitchen after all so I didn't have too many complaints.

The broth here is thinner than I'm used to with most hearty japanese ramen, and it wasn't too salty, which sometimes annoys me.  The ramen was firm, and tasted great but I could have used a little bit more noodles.  It was a simple dish done right and I finished the soup to the bottom of the bowl, which is a great sign.

My friends ramen was great too and he seemed to enjoy his avocado salmon roll, but he can yelp about that himself.

The prices were alright but I was not happy that they didn't validate my parking.  Didn't make sense because its a restaurant in japantown so you'd think they wouldn't have a problem doing that.  Not a really great ending to the meal.
author: Evan T.

description:
I'll admit that I'm not an expert on Japanese noodles...however, I do know what I like. And not only was I a fan of the soba last night but I'm also a fan of it right now as I'm eating my leftovers for lunch. The soba noodles are definitely thinner than other ones I've had in the past but that doesn't bother me. They are quite tasty, as is the fish broth. There were little pieces of tempura thrown in there that had a nice crunch last night (definitely not the case with the leftovers but that's pretty obvious, right???). I got the combo of the soba with the maguro on rice - which also totally hit the spot. We also started off with the tofu - a nice, fresh start to the meal. 

Throw in that the service was totally sweet and that, albeit small, the atmosphere was very nice, too. 

Am already looking forward to going back!
author: Jen N.

description:
This is my Lv 85 quest to find the best ramen in the Bay.  Will update as I continue - hope there's a good item at the end..

10-pt scale rating + descriptors on broth, noodles, bonuses.  I also note wait times and such.  I used to review commercial products, so hopefully this will be standardized.  I will get the most popular item there if I can, otherwise whatever I like.

10/10 is Daikokuya (LA).  Ratings lower than a 5/10 - I won't return.

Reviewed so far:
Suzu Noodle House (SF) - 8.5/10
Ramen Dojo (San Mateo) - 8/10
Maru Ichi (Mountain View) - 6.5/10
Ryowa (Mountain View) - 3.5/10
Himawari (san Mateo) - 3/10

To try:
Tanpopo
Izakaya Sozai
Santa Ramen
Ramen Parlor
Orenchi Ramen

SUZU NOODLE HOUSE (SF) - 8.5/10, Chashu shio Ramen.
Overall: My favorite ramen in the BA so far.  Traditional ramen shop size, feel, and ramen style.  They also have udon and other stuff I may try later.  I'm told the mapuo ramen is good.  I will be back, many, many times.  I prefer this place over the Dojo so far because I like the traditional ramen more than the crazy Dojo-style... it's not as oily, and I think the noodles are better here.
Broth: Really deep flavor, a tad oily, but really flavorful.  Seriously, close to Daikokuya level.
Noodles: Best noodles I've had so far, possibly ever in the US.  
Other: bamboo shoots, green onions, konbu in generous portions.  Chashu is tasty and not fatty.  I would've liked options to add more stuff, but this was quite good.
Bonus: free green tea
Tips: Expect a 30 minute wait, small ramen shop.  But its indoors in a Japanese mall of sorts.  Don't sit on the patio side unless you like slower service.

Ramen Dojo (San Mateo) - 8/10, Garlic pork ramen, mild spicy.
Overall: Garlic pork ramen, oh my goodness this is good.  This place has a VERY unique style, unique for kuro ramen even.  They specialize in spicy ramen... personally speaking, mild is enough for me, and I have high spice tolerance.  Medium was my limit and was pushing it (about 4/5 at a korean place).  Generous portions, customization, delicious broth, HOT soup... this is worth the wait.  I've been there twice, and probably will go more.
Broth: REALLY TASTY with a long-lasting flavor.  It's a bit oily, but so good!!  It's kuro ramen, so it's blackish, but don't be put off by that.  IT IS SO GOOD.  And they gives you a LOT.  
Noodles: Really great texture, generous portions.  
Other: Comes with bean sprouts, lettuce, chives (great addition btw), quail egg, mushrooms, whole fried garlic.  Chashu among the best I've had in ramen.  There is little fat compared to other places, great texture, great taste.  I highly recommend getting extra chashu for $1.50 (cheap compared to the other additions - which are questionable in price).
Bonus: Great customization options, appetizers are pretty good.
Tips: Be prepared to wait BEFORE they open.  They have exactly 24 seats.  Line up and be one of the first 24 people.  If you're 25th, leave or wait another 30-40 minutes.  I recommend getting there 30 minutes early on a weekday dinner (maybe 20) or 45 minutes early for weekends.  Being #18 is the same as #1 in seating.  They will come out with a clipboard and ask for party size before opening - better have your whole party there.  Also, if you're there late, they can run out of garlic pork broth...

Maru Ichi (Mountain View) - 6.5/10.  Kuro ramen with bamboo shoots.
Overall: Quite filling with a great portion size.  No real wait if you can find parking.  
Broth:  Not as tasty as the Dojo but not as oily either.  Pretty flavorful but not the best, but good size and price.  And no wait.
Noodles: The noodles are a bit thinner than other places.  Texture-wise, they were spot on - chewy, great texture, and definitely good ramen noodles.  
Other: Bean sprouts, scallions.  Options to add more.
Bonus: Kimchi to snack on while you wait - good quality too.  Free tea.  I like that you can see the dude making the noodles in the window - pretty killer machine he's using.  
Tips: Not much of a wait, this place is huge inside.  Great for quick ramen in MTV area.  I'd go back.

Ryowa (Mountain View) 3.5/10 - Tonkatsu ramen with gyoza and rice.
Overall: Filling portions, not terrible.  Cool decor with Japanese TV shows and ramen bar feel.  $0.50 gets you 3 gyoza and rice.  
Broth: Watery, not that great.  I wouldn't get this again.
Noodles: Noodles were great texture, thin
Other: Gyoza were really quite good, but I don't go to a ramen place for gyoza.  
Bonus: Free kimchi to snack on
Tips: Short to no wait, def get the combo for $0.50 more.  But Maru Ichi is way better.

Himawri (San Mateo) - 3/10.  Miso ramen.
Overall: Honestly not impressed.  It's not terrible, but for west coast this was not passing.  My bowl had lots of stuff, but eh..
Broth: not flavorful, watered down
Noodles: Noodles ok, I can make better
Other: lots of stuff, forget what
Bonus: empty place, no lines
Tips: It was cheap and fast..
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
Suzu Noodle House.

Noodle is great. Nothing much to say about the noodles. I really like the noodles for this place.

Meat: Very little meat.... They need a little more pork in the soup....

Price: It alright....

Services: What service!!!! They just give you the food and that is about it. 

Once in a full moon they will refill your waters. 

Place: Small... Perfect for business! Bad for customer visits! Be prepared to wait for seats.


Four stars for the noodles!

One star off for being a very small place and less meat in my noodle soup. And the service is a hit and miss..

_______________________________________________________________

So Suzu have changed some of their portion in their menu, and i believed they actually read some of these review and helped improve their food portions. Its alot better now, and i am giving them 5 stars for their effort.
author: Ernest S.

description: Not too much going on. I chose it because it was busy. Hot tea is included. For $9.50 I got miso ramen with tasty broth and one piece of pork, 3 thin pieces of bamboo, half a hard-boiled egg that was still a bit cool, green onions, and noodles. Didn't really seem like much for the money. Waitress indifferent and didn't check in with me after delivering food. I wouldn't bother.
author: S B.

description: Fantastic little ramen joint right in the middle of an indoor mall.  The wait was long (self sign up list next to the door) but the food was delicious.  I had ramen with roasted pork belly and we also had the fried tofu appetizer.  All were great.  Also at our table were potato croquets, super tasty as well as the traditional ramen (w/ extra port of course).  Only recommendation...don't drive (parking is tough) and get there early.
author: Scott L.

description:
Oh yes, yes yes.  Found a good noodle place with flavorful noddle soups.  Hmm they may be too oily and considered American, not sure... but I know that most Soba and Udon dishes taste like water.  The ones here are delicious and come with another side (like raw salmon, or another meat of choice...) Super great deals.

The staff though are very cold.  Like, very cold.  I think they might be robots.  But they get the job done.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Fried chicken ramen was good but I wish it was spicy.   I tried another bowl that was spicy and YES it was spicy!!!  Big enough to share really.  $10-13 a bowl.

Pretty small place.  Normally a line of about 10-30 min wait.  Go upstairs after to get a crepe!
author: Joe M.

description: "Meh. I've experienced better" is exactly how i feel about this place.  i was really excited to try this place since it looks legit, but i was pretty bummed out by the taste (or lack thereof) of the ramen.  And for 9+ bucks, it simply isn't a good deal. I still have yet to find that go to spot for my noodles. Tanpopo is an honorable mention though.....
author: Alex G.

description: Came here last Saturday... They were out of pork belly and I ordered the bbq pork instead.  The miso was salty, the pork was dry n tough.  Service was ok...nothing special
author: Bich P.

description: i'm told suzu changed ownership recently--or at least that was the explanation given to me for the poor quality and execution of the food. the noodles were thick and overcooked (mushy), and the broth overly salty. overall, the ramen felt a bit chinese...even without considering the bok choy they included in each bowl. probably won't be back.
author: stefanie h.

description:
Thanks to Neil K. I can avoid the endless food options in Japantown and head straight to Suzu for a hearty warm bowl of ramen. There's something about those nifty curly noodles that always hits the spot! Broth is rich but not salty. Noodles are cooked to perfection. What more could you ask for? On my most recent trip, I took a shot at the udon and was not disappointed. If it weren't for the freaking hot 'special iron pot', I would have slurped down the bowl in a matter of minutes!

A quick tale: They have a couple 2-tops outside the restaurant. One time we sat at a table inside, right next to one of those tables, with only a thick clear glass pane separating us. As soon as we sat down, we knew right away that the couple next to us was having the 'break up' talk. The boy avoided eye contact. The girl fought back the tears. They both slowly sipped their tea to avoid talking. Can you say "Awkward!" at the dinner table?
author: Susan L.

description: The ramen was weak here.  Not super impressive.  But we ordered fried tofu and the daikon salad.  Both appetizers were great.  Very delish!
author: Sandy P.

description:
The noodles are pretty good.

The broth is a little bit too salty.

The service was absolutely terrible- worst waitress I've had in years.  Sullen, grouchy and just miserable.  Wouldn't rush back...

I have a simple theory- maybe I'm weird...  If I act surly and crappy to my clients, why should I expect them to hire me again?  I can't stand spending money to eat food in an environment of angst.  Perhaps it's further exacerbated by the fact that in most Japanese restaurants the emphasis is on superlative service and this was a polar opposite.

Anyhow- meh...
author: Stirling E.

description:
If there is one thing that we really look for in our favorite ramen houses, and any restaurant, really, it's consistency. Without it, experiences would be dictated by the luck of the draw, and that provides little confidence to diners. I bring up this issue because it seems to be particularly troublesome in recent times for Suzu, unless you count the unfailingly long wait list. So why do I keep coming back? Because on a good day, they are really on top of their game, and I've been willing to take a risk for such a reward.

In the past 4 years that I have been frequenting Suzu, I have tried nearly every ramen on the menu: the tasty Karaage Ramen, the Mapu Tofu Ramen, and the Spicy Negi Ramen, to name a few.  Today, I am reviewing two bowls of ramen from my recent visit to Suzu: one of their staples, the Tokyo Ramen, and one of their new offerings, the Beef and Vegetable Ramen.

One thing I noticed right away during this recent visit was the new menu cover. It highlights a new approach Suzu appears to be now taking (perhaps due to pressures from other bay area ramen houses): handmade noodles daily. I was excited to see how Suzu's handmade noodles faired next to Maru Ichi who also makes their noodles in-house. (check my posting on my blog)

The presentation of the Tokyo Ramen told me that today looked like a "good day" for Suzu as the noodles were neatly folded under the other ingredients as opposed to loosely strewn about in the bowl on days when the main chef appears to be taking vacation. Topping the noodles are the chasu, egg, nori, and bamboo shoots. The broth looked light, mostly clear with enough oils floating on top to keep me interested. The Beef and Vegetable Ramen, on the other hand, did not give the most impressive first impression. The light color of the soup seemed to be mostly chicken broth, making me wonder if the broth would have any depth to it at all.  The vegetables included zucchini, cabbage, carrots, and mushroom.  For $1.50 extra, I had customized this ramen with some spicy negi on top to give it a little kick just in case the ramen started getting boring.

On to the taste test! Despite its nice presentation, a sip of the Tokyo Ramen's broth was enough to realize that the main chef was still missing from the kitchen. It was lukewarm (cardinal ramen sin!), a bit too overpowered by the chicken broth component, and did not have enough depth to keep me interested the whole way through.  The chashu was tender and tasty, but there was only one piece. Compared to other bay area ramen shops, the chasu was also not a standout. The noodles, the only factor that gave real plus points to this bowl, were al dente and had a nice sheen to it.

Surprisingly, the Beef and Vegetable Ramen broth, though not much to look at, had a good flavor and was complex enough for me to enjoy during its entire consumption. Moreover, the broth came out much hotter than the Tokyo Ramen, and I could not taste the overpowering chicken flavor in this one.  The vegetables added a nice element to the ramen because it made me feel like I was eating a healthier ramen, and there were plenty strips of thinly sliced beef in the ramen to make me feel like I got my money's worth.  The handmade noodles were the same texture and appearance as the Tokyo Ramen.

We know everyone can't look their absolute best every single day. The same goes for a ramen restaurant. While I wouldn't recommend this as one of the best in the bay area, it remains a good pick for San Francisco simply because there are not that many options available on days when the Peninsula or the South Bay seems too far. One can only hope to catch Suzu on a good day because, if they do, I certainly believe they are guaranteed an above average ramen.  For others that aren't willing to roll the dice every time, perhaps it's time to leave Suzu for those ramen lovers willing to take the risk.  Plus, it will shorten the wait list next time I go.
author: Ramen S.

description:
I'm giving extra points for the tasty unagi donburi mini bowl that came with my ramen special. I really love well made unagi and the portion was just right since I'm eating my green onion, bamboo shoot with a slice of pork ramen noodle bowl too. The noodles were super chewy, and I'm not used that type of texture. I like my noodles more cooked and a bit soft to eat, but it was still fresh and yummy. The broth was good but not extraordinary. All in all, still okay after not eating here for a long time.

Service was brisk and we got seated only after waiting for 10 minutes.
author: Pauline L.

description:
This place is AWESOME! The flavor was incredible and the prices were super reasonable! I'm surprised at some of the mediocre reviews. Because these folks are workin' those noodles!

Initially,  I was a bit annoyed that my friend insisted on waiting 30 mins for a table for 3, since the restaurant kiddy corner to them was a ghost town, but I guess a wait means they've got something right.  Once I savored the gorgeous soba heaven I knew it was worth the wait. 

I opted for the soba noodle soup, tempura prawns and rice... and at $7.95 how can that be wrong. While the portions are not huge, I love that they have simple fresh goodness without supersized calories. My friends got the same noodle combination with the unagai (delish) and the ahi tuna. All was OMG good!

While the wait is long, I was thrilled with the end result. These people rock the soba noodles in a very very nice way... yes!
author: Manuela F.

description:
My co-worker recommended this place as one of his favorites. I love ramen and this place does not have great ramen. I wouldn't even pay $5 for a bowl here.

My first experience was great! I thought the Chasu was made perfect and the ramen was delicious. 

I decided to return a while later and my second time here was not that great. The soup base was too salty. The Chasu was salty and chewy. The service that day was very slow and the waitress wasn't the best.

I thought I'd give this place one more chance; so I went a 3rd time. This time I ordered a ramen with mabo tofu over rice. This ramen was the same where the Chasu wasn't good and the soup base was just too salty. The mabo tofu over rice tasted like something straight out of the microwave. The service was very slow even though it was not busy. The waitress was not friendly.
author: Anyta L.

description:
Obviously popular spot. Line can be long, seats get filled up about 10 minutes after they open at 5 on a Thursday.

The tempura udon in an iron pot I got was surprisingly good. I'm not a huge fan of Udon because people don't know how to cook it. I hate mushy udon, flavorless udon, or bad broth. The udon here is perfectly cooked, slightly chewy, lots of flavor from the fish broth, and the broth is clear but flavorful. It comes with a blah shrimp tempura and mushy carrot tempura. I was very pleased with the noodle and broth nonetheless.

The ramen my friend had looked yummy, 6-7 slices of cha siu, nice textured handmade noodles, deliciously looking broth. 

Fried chicken appetizer is quite nice too, it's crispy outside, juicy thigh meat inside. Did I mention I hate fried food? This one tastes ok to me so it might be pretty good for everyone else.

Good alternative of Tanpopo, or Katana-ya. Though the best ramen place in the bay area still awaits to be discovered...
author: Yuchi C.

description: Tasty ramen.  Try the Chashu -  flavorful broth, extra pieces of pork, hard boiled egg, and scattered scallions.  As other reviews have mentioned, the broth is salty so definately ask for some ice water.
author: Kim K.

description:
This is the only restaurant I eat in Japantown as I would be so heartbroken if I went somewhere else knowing that homemade noodles and gyoza awaited me.  However, the last time I was there I got sides because it was sweltering outside and hot soup was the last thing I wanted.  The sashimi was surprisngly fresh and much better than many sushi spots that I go to.  I also ordered the gyozas and they were amazing too!  This place is the best and everything is super fresh.

ps: The spicy ramen is THE best hangover remedy ever!
author: maggie m.

description:
Totally overhyped. After hearing/reading such great things about this place, I was really disappointed.

The noodles are the same chewy spaghetti-esque consistency of that of Orochon in Little Tokyo but the broth is nothing to sing about. Not great, nothing to write home for, just okay. I had to dump shoyu and pepper into my soup (which is rarely a necessity for me). The only highlights were the wonderfully seared gyoza and the gingery karaage.

Good thing they have a good variety of things to choose from. I certainly wouldn't bother getting the ramen again.
author: Torie Y.

description:
Serviceable, but completely unmemorable ramen.  Fixings were minimal - some bamboo shoots (which were admittedly quite tasty, having been marinate), a plain hard-boiled egg, some greens, and a couple of meager pieces of chasu.  Noodles were cooked al-dente and had a nice chew.  The miso broth was a bit too salty, and lacking the meaty depth of the better South Bay ramen houses.

They do takeout, which is rare for a ramen place.  Always seems to have a line long too.  Still, for my money, the best ramen in San Francisco remains the tonkotsu at Izakaya Sozai.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Wow, is all I can say.  This place has horrible service and to boot, I found a BREAD TIE IN MY RAMEN!!!!!!!!  Yes, they were apologetic, but aren't they supposed to be?  They didn't charge me for my ramen, which was 3/4 eaten, but woopty-do!  They should have comp'ed our entire table's meal.  In general, I do not complain about finding a hair in my food, b/c let's be honest, shit happens and you can't always track every single hair, but a bread tie????  That is shear lack of attention to detail when preparing a dish and completely unacceptable.  If I could have given this place a no star, I would have.  I live in Japantown and can say that Tanpopo's ramen is way better, even before this incident.  Anyways, be careful, you might find foreign, non-Japanese, items in your food!
author: Neil K.

description: Not good. The michelin reccommendation should be rescinded. We ordered ramen noodles, and the broth was extremely salty. Usually I like noodles in my spoon of broth, but I had to abandon the spoon and suck down chewey noodles by themselves. Another grave mistake is that the pork belly was tough and dry. Pork belly is only supposed to come one way: melt in your mouth. This was all wrong here.
author: Thlel Yan D.

description: We had a great time here tonight. Both bowls we ordered were delicious. We decided to try the shoyu broth, which the waitress described as more traditional, and were not disappointed. This is a cute place with friendly service. If you're in the mood for ramen this is a great spot to try!
author: Caitlin J.

description:
I'm no expert on ramen or noodle houses, but I'd love to find any noodle house that tickles my salty desires, and Suzu did just that. 

The place is a bit small, and its clear by the wait, this place is known for good food. So be prepared to wait when you come, especially if you are in a group of more than 4. 

Both my girlfriend and I had the tempuradon combo...which was a bowl of ramen, udon, or soba with a side bowl of white rice with tempura on top.  We both had the ramen choice with our tempura. The first thing I noticed about the food was that the tempura was really good.  I could not think of another place where I've had such fresh tempura in the city.  The ramen was equal in its "homemade" taste. I will definitely be returning to try more of the menu. 

...and as long as its cold, this place will be high on my seasonal places to eat to get warm.
author: Jimmy L.

description: After reading so many reviews on Yelp I decided to try it out.  The waiting list was long but they moved people pretty fast.  I didn't think the ramen was anything special.  We ordered the curry ramen which was oily and salty, the fried chicken was flavorful but not spicy enough and the miso ramen was just okay.  Everything was just too salty.  I like Santa Ramen in San Mateo so much better.
author: Cindy L.

description: First ramen place I tried in SF and it was a total disappointment. I got the vegetarian ramen with miso and it was bland, even after dumping soy sauce and chili powder into it. My sister got the cold soba noodles and it was equally disappointing. Bland and overcooked noodles. Maybe we ordered wrong in getting vegetarian dishes but I won't be going back here to find out!
author: M N.

description: I used to love this place.  Since it changed ownership a couple of years ago, the food is just not the same.  The broth of the ramen is not tasty , not enough miso.  All the things that made their ramen tasty are omitted and has to ordered as extra for $1 each like onions, sprouts, and miso.
author: L T.

description:
The ramen here is actually pretty good, we learned upon are second inspection. The fact that the wait staff remains fixated on closing the restaurant as soon as the clock strikes 9:30 remains an annoyance, but it's their restaurant so whatever.  As long as you dine earlier in the day this won't be an issue, but if you come close to closing be prepared to eat and run,because they literally aim to close AT 9:30. 

all things considered (especially the wait and so-so service) I still have to strongly recommend Tontopo Ramen across the street as my favorite ramen place in Japan town.
author: Alex D.

description: My gf heard this was a good place for ramen, and we were skeptical. Should have listened to our intuition. Any place that has a lot of different kinds of noodles is a specialist in none. The shio broth is boring, with no depth, and the varieties sound interesting but the ones we got were disappointing. The only place with worthwhile ramen is still - #1 not in Japantown, and #2 Izakaya. Nobody Japanese goes to Japantown for Japanese food.
author: Kenji L.

description:
We arrived promptly at 11:15 a.m.; however, they don't open until 11:30- they let us in anyway! We were the first table sat and had this small noodle house to ourselves when, right at 11:30 the crowds came and the place was jam packed within five minutes! I couldn't believe it; there was even a line outside! 
I had the Chicken Ramen which was excellent- the whole table (of five) ordered Ramen and it was super fresh and the broth was excellent. 
The prices are good and its worth a try; just be prepared to finish your whole dish as they don't let you take it home...
author: Janell D.

description:
What we ordered:
Tokyo ramen = tasteless 
Miso ramen = too salty
Fried chicken = so so
Don't forget to smell the ramen noodles before you eat it.. Simply horrid!
author: Bobby C.

description:
If the weather outside if frightful, and you want a fire that's delightful, come to Suzu for some warm, ramen goodness. 

The entire place is maybe 20 square feet with a few "bonus" tables directly outside the restaurant. Although they serve lots of ramen, I was in the mood for some protein so I got the chicken katsu and soba noodles. Both were delicious. When I first saw the chicken katsu come out, it wasn't as much as my hungry stomach anticipated... but after polishing off the soba noodles, I was glad for their (and my) restraint. 

I found the meal to be perfectly adequate... which is what they called me in college. Handsome, and perfectly adequate.
author: Jared S.

description:
I only heard about Suzu through a friend whose friend apparently swears by it.  She offered to drive me from work all the way to Japantown so I thought why the heck not?  Anything to get away from work and the further the better!  Anyways, when we got there the only annoying thing is that you have to find metered parking on the street that has a maximum of 1 hour and then you get to the restaurant and there's a wait!  There's usually a pad of paper and a pen left on a chair outside for you to fill out as soon as you get there.  

Service is slow and the line is long but trust me, the food is worth it.  Now I know that everyone says not to go to Japantown for Japanese food since it is only for tourists and not very authentic but I think this place beats the trend.  The waitresses and most of the clientele seemed to be Japanese.  When we finally got seated 30 minutes later, we each ordered a ramen and decided to share a sashimi platter.  The sashimi was 4 pieces of tuna and 4 pieces of salmon and although small, were super fresh and fantastic!  I got the spicy ramen and it was definitely spicier than most Japanese versions of spicy soup which I loved so it was perfect.  Ended up only costing like $15 per person so well worth it.  I liked it so much that I made the hubby take me back here for dinner!  Sadly, I got the exact same thing because I was already craving it again.

Update:  last week when I was at a movie at the kabuki theatre, I called the restaurant afterwards to see if they were still open.  Nobody picked up so I assumed they were closed and we spent another 15 minutes deciding where to go.  We happened to walk by on our way to the other restaurant and peered in to see people eating there so we ran in.  The waitress told us that we were too late since it was 9:27 and they close at 9:30.  Jeez I was annoyed!  Pick up the phone and we would have been there on time!  Anyways, one thing to note was even on a Thursday night when they were about to close, they were pretty full.   I would definitely not go in a large group though since it would take forever to get a table for more than 4 people.
author: Susan L.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place out since one of my friends recommended the spicy ramen.

Since the bf LOVES ramen, he never turns down the option to eat out for ramen...NEVER. Poor guy, I don't like it too much, so he's a little deprived. 

So, we decided to check this place out. As expected, there was a line on the list. We didn't mind, since we could walk around the mall and stuff. We went back to check about 20 mins later and saw that we were next!

After we were seated, we were pretty much set to order since we've been eyeing the menu from the window. I got the Mapo Tofu Ramen combo, bf got the unagi roll ramen combo. I opted for the spicy soup and added a boiled egg for an extra $1 each. Bf kept his traditional. We also ordered the edamame, which came with salt added on the top. That, I wasn't too big a of a fan for. The unagi rolls came and they were very fresh and tasty. My mapo tofu came in a little bowl with rice. I was a little shocked since I was hoping the tofu and stuff came in my ramen...yeah I don't know why I thought that. But, o wells, it was still good, I'm just not a fan of white rice. 

The ramen finally arrived and I had to taste the soup first. It was very good, not too salty and enough spice to kick you in the mouth! I, of course needed MORE SPICE, so I added that spicy ramen flake stuff they have on the side of your tables. I added ALOT. It made my ramen more exciting to eat! The noodles had a perfect texture. It was chewy and not super soft, I like them with a little bit of "raw-ness". Overall, I thought it was better than some places I've tried in SF, but Katanaya still wins my vote for the Best so far. 

The bf enjoyed his bowl of ramen, but said Katanaya, Hotei and Izakaya Sozai were still a little bit better in his opinion. 

If you're a ramen lover, and still haven't tried this spot, you definitely need to!!

I would've given them 4 stars, but our waitress came to take our order without writing ANYTHING down....and if she hadn't forgotten like 3 out of 5 things we said, I wouldn't have knocked out 1 star. Next time if you assume you can remember everything your customer orders, but realizes, 'wow their order is a little complicated'...go and get yourself a notepad!!
author: Christina T.

description:
I came here on a Sunday night, completely drained from a sun-filled day at the Gay Pride Parade.  Needless to say, I was tired, thirsty and hungry.

There was a slight wait but we were seated pretty quickly (Thank GAWWW).  I ordered the Spicy Ramen and waited in anticipation.  

10 minutes went by and everyone, I mean EVERYONE got their Ramen except for me.  Here I was, sunburned, exhausted, impatient and starved to the brink of being crazy, thinking WHERE THE F IS MY FOOD?!  I then proceeded to ask the waitress, where's my food?  She assured me it was coming soon so I sat and I waited.

After what felt like forever, my bowl of spicy Ramen finally came.  You ever felt so hungry that you weren't hungry anymore?  Yeahhh, that's what happened to me.

 Gyoza's good though because THAT came on time =/
author: Lisa W.

description:
I just upped the rating to Four Stars....   Yup.  The ramen is divine, really good.  I love the spicy ramen, well, I have no problems with the menu, the broth in the soup was complex and deep.  For ramen maniacs like myself, this is probably the best ramen-ya in SF.

So why the upgrade from two stars?  The staff.  I have been there about two dozen times, so i am hooked, however, the serviceused to be the worst i have ever seen.  (here comes the rant....) Below is what I wrote before... but now it's much better... I have been there twice a week for the last three weeks and it's so much better.... 

  Actually.... A list of what I have witnessed before from the staff...

1. Smiles or even making a customer feel welcome is rare.  
2. The staff will hide in the kitchen until the last possible moment, and only run food out when it's getting cold. (i have had lukewarm soup and gyoza...)
3. With at least 5 names on the list, clearing the tables and moving customers in and out doesn't seem to be a priority, I have watched tables sit with bowls for over 11:00 minutes. (had nothing better to do than time them while waiting 28 minutes for a table)
4. Did I mention unfriendly service? Is the staff really that unhappy to work there?  I own a business that depends on service, and the staff at Suzu would not last a week with my staff.
5. If  you think service is slow inside the main dining room, just wait and enjoy the special joy that is being completely ignored sitting in the outside tables.  

Okay, so that's it. But lastly, a note to the owner: 

 I see that you care as much for your  customers as much as you care for your ramen.  You have a gift.  But please make it more fun for your people to work there, or help them find some sort of happiness while they work there.  Smiles, saying hello, not getting lost of the kitchen and clearing tables will pay off for your loyal fans.  However, please note; my loyalty to your wonderful food is finding limits with your miserable service.
author: Avan M.

description:
I have passed by this place tons of times. It's on the first floor of the japantown mall, so you always see it on your way in and out of the mall. There always seem to be people waiting so I assumed it must be good! Well I tried suzu finally when friends from out of town were in town for a work conference. The ramen is pretty tasty but certainly not the best i've had. I ordered the ramen with fried chicken & gyoza, $13 later I was certainly satisfied but not super impressed with the flavors. Don't order the garden salad! it's terrible, iceberg lettuce with a mayonasy dressing. 

Service is so-so. They're good at seating you but once you get in your seat, the attention is spotty.
author: Ka C.

description:
This place was once great. Used to be one of the best bowl of noodles in town. They have undergone many changes in the past year, all of which are terrible.  

The decor is now awful with harsh fluorescent lighting. The serving sizes are smaller and more expensive. 

The food is barely suitable for a dog to eat. 

Not sure what happened to this place, but I hope it closes down soon, so that a real noodle house can take its place. 

Food: The broth was lacking in flavor, and the serving size was very small for $12. In addition, the egg that was in the soup was ice cold, suggesting that they have a bunch of precooked boiled eggs in a fridge that they just toss in the soup at the last minute. At least heat it up guys. Really?

Again this place used to be great. 

Service: While eating, we were asked to pay the bill 5 minutes before they were actually closed. I had a few bites of my soup left, and told them to give us a second. They very very rudely demanded that we pay NOW, because they needed to close. There were also three other tables occupied at the time. So, it's not like we were the only people in there keeping them from going home. I have never once had a server demand me to pay while eating before closing time in the manner that they did. I threw my chopsticks in the bowl and left the exact dollar amount, plus a 19 cent tip just to spite them. 


NEVER EVER go to this place. You will be sorry. A year and half ago, I would have recommended this place to every person I know. Now, I hope they crash and burn. No customer deserves to be treated that way.
author: Rob M.

description:
It was about 10 minutes to five on a Sunday afternoon.  Suzu doesn't open for another 10 minutes and people were lining up to get in.  You have to put your name on the list because they don't take reservations.  The place was full by the time they sat everyone sit at 5:05 P.M. and there were others waiting to get in.  They used to let you take food to go but they don't anymore.  (Something about them wanting you to spend time with them.)  

My 3.5 year old daughter loves noodles so we split the Tempura Don Ramen which has a side of tempura on top of white rice and ramen soup with meat.  She ate the only shrimp tempura and a veggie tempura.   (I'm not sure what it was but it was orange.)  I ate the other 3 tempura - zucchini, green pepper and sweet potato.   I had to ask for a fork because my daughter still trying to figure out chopsticks.  She devoured the ramen and drank most of the soup.  (I suspect that she liked using the big soup spoons.)  My back-up plan was to offer her the rice if didn't like the ramen or tempura.  My only complaint is that the tempura came with the sauce on it. I prefer my tempura plain or at the very least with the sauce on the side.  

I can't recall what I ordered the 1st time that I went to Suzu.  I recall that the portions were pretty big.  Great place for quick, yummy and inexpensive food if you are going to watch something at the Kabuki.
author: Kaye M.

description: Food 3, service 2.5.  Ramen noodles cooked well, broth and toppings mediocre.  Nabeyake udon was underwhelming, small, over priced for what you get.  I have yet to find a Ramen place on par with NYC or LA here in SF, kind of sad.
author: Robert K.

description:
This place is okay.  I like the thickness and crispness of the noodle...but the broth does not have enough flavor.  Think they only have shoyu flavor...but didn't really check. It's not bland...but just lacks the rich flavor and depth that i prefer in ramen broth.  

The combo's are nice but since it's a noodle house... we went for the ramen.   Just average...nothing special like Ramen Dojo or Ramen Halu in San Jose... or even Izakaya Sozai in SF, which has an awesome
author: Vien C.

description:
my favorite Ramen place in the city... 

yep there I said it.. 

better than Katana-Ya (i went there...) 

I'm never disappointed in what I order and I love the mix and match menu so I can try a different starter every time with my ramen... Love the poke bowl and ramen with fried chicken..
author: Ken B.

description: Write your name on a pad of paper right outside the door and wait for a table. The udon was terrific, mine with chicken broth rice cake, hard boiled egg, pea pod, seaweed, cabbage, tofu, green onion. I added red pepper flakes a shoyu. The guy had udon with fish broth (delicious) and all the vegetables I had and the addition of shrimp tempura. My only complaint was that the soup was so freaking hot, that it took a good half hour before I could eat it. Maybe the trick is to phone order ahead of time......
author: Bleep S.

description:
Had a late lunch with my friend last Friday after seeing it mentioned in the current CSAA magazine Via.  I ordered the combo lunch special, eel and ramen.  The ramen was good - better than expected and tasty.  Nothing really special but good decent noodles.  Cooked just right and with a simple broth.  The eel was also good but made more interesting after my friend was telling about a video she saw on eels back in college.  She ordered the curry with chicken over rice which was pretty good too.  

Overall, the food was good enough to come back for.  But not craving it!!  It is a small place downstairs in the JTown mall.  Doesn't look like it can handle a large group.  Place is popular with people constantly coming in.  Service was fine and efficient.
author: Ray Y.

description:
I happened to be in Japantown around lunch time and saw that this place had a lot of stars on Yelp so I decided to check it out.  After waiting for about 5 minutes, my wife and I were seated and we both couldn't decided what to order as everything on the menu looked good.  It was then that I noticed the line that was starting to build up outside (after reading some of the other reviews, I'm guessing we arrived fairly early) so we just ordered so that we wouldn't take too long.

I ordered the shrimp tempura w/ vegetables along with a spicy ramen and my wife ordered the chicken karaage curry along w/ an order of gyoza.  All of the dishes were delicious although my wife couldn't really handle the ramen.  The noodles were cooked the way l like and the batter for the tempura was just the right amount and wasn't too heavy.  

This place makes me wish I didn't live in Hawaii.......For about 40 minutes anyway..... :-)
author: Stanford T.

description: Just not happy with my return this time.  The soup was not spicy enough and tasted a bit more salty than usual flavor. I did not feel comforted this time with what was supposed to be comfort food!  I guess the chef might of had an off day.  I'll give it another try and update if it goes back up a notch.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
My sister-in-law and I dined here today for lunch around 12:30 p.m.   We LOVED our entrees.  Noodles are such a comfort food.  We each had the combination entrees.  The ramen I ate was so fresh and didn't get soggy in the broth.  Everything was cooked to perfection.  The "don" part of my meal was awesome and had some kick to it.  My sil had spicy ramen which she loved and she enjoyed her eel don.  The female servers were very nice and helpful.  
I actually needed a knife to cut up my noodles as I'm recovering from periodontal surgery; they didn't have any knives which I can kind of understand but don't most restaurants have 'em?  I just made do and it was fine.
author: Kekumukula N.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night and it was pretty packed, my friend and I waited for about 5 minutes to be seated which isn't bad at all. I didn't know that there was seating outside until after I left so I am not sure if those are reserved for busier times or if they were simply filled when we got there. Regardless, the wait wasn't long at that time of night (around 8'ish).

We both got the Miso Ramen but his with Karaage (fried chicken). The noodles were bouncy/chewy which isn't as bad as it sounds, it is more likely that it is intended to be that way. The cha siu in mine was seasoned unevenly so parts of it was oversalted and other parts were okay. It came with bamboo shoots which were pretty good but I feel like they were overcooked. There were some leafy greens with a bit of bitter taste (reminds me something of Chinese spinach) and half of an hard-boiled egg. The soup itself was salty, big surprise, it's miso. However, I don't feel like it was as salty as some people made it out to be because if it wasn't salty, nothing else would have any taste.

Over all, I enjoyed it. Service was nice and the food came pretty quickly. I definitely see myself coming back. The only reason why I am refraining from giving a 5 star is because I did not feel like that the food was exceptional in any way (yes, I'm a hard critic). Yes, there are times when I crave ramen (as does everyone) but that doesn't necessarily mean that this place is the first place that comes to mind when I am/will. But for a place that does ramen, it fulfills that role very well.
author: Richard C.

description:
In pursuit of finding a new go-to ramen in the area (nixed a former go-to after the quality of service declined), I've been here several times now.  

The good -- The quality of ramen and other noodle dishes I've had, whether it be the nabeyaki or the sobas.  The noodles are just the right chewy and the broth not too oily or salty.  It makes my tastebuds dance and leaves it asking for more.
The bad -- The service could use improvement.  As many other reviewers have said in details, they don't manage their wait crowd well.  You have to be w/in ear-shot when they call your name or will give your place away.  This "policy" needs to be written out or shared in some manner so the eagerly waiting crowd is aware of this (as I requested of the staff/manager).  Furthermore, the staff may skip names so we have to be attentive while we wait around for 30 +/- mins.

Take note from a lesson learned -- they have limited hours and are closed between lunch and dinner.

Repeat factor?  Yes.  The ramen is good, no question.  But the other reasons mentioned above take away its luster as a definite winner of being a go-to ramen place in my book.
author: Carol K.

description:
Went here on a cold windy night. My boyfriend's sister introduced us to this place. I saw a small corner store and thought it felt very quaint. 

I ordered the Tenpura Don Ramen Combo. The food was delicious. Tenpura was served over rice and had sauce on top of it unlike normal tempura with dipping sauce. The rice was very sticky and hot. The Ramen  I ordered was delicious. Broth was hot, noodles were fresh, and there was just enough meat for the entire meal. I enjoyed every filling bite!

I'd go back again =)
author: J-nine I.

description:
Terrible noodle house. Their soup is super salty. It burns in my mouth, I guess it is MSG.


I won't go back again.
author: Han B.

description:
Came here for  a quick bite to eat, and was quite impressed.  I used to be a regular to the normal stomping spots in J-town.   I can't believe that I always overlooked it.  

Great service, good noodles and great broth.  Their ramen is a little on the thicker side.  But still melts in our mouth, like good ramen should, take notes TOP Ramen....

I could see how the wait could be a turn off.  The place is pretty tiny.  But, I lounged in around 1:30-2 and had no problem finding a seat and getting my order placed.  The wait staff was supper nice...

If I get a chance, I would definitely stop by again.
author: steve c.

description:
I dont really eat ramen and have only had it a handful of times so i dont have the best base for comparison but with that said, it was a tasty meal. 

OVERVIEW:
The noodles were Al dente (I likes), the broth was oh so savory (within the realm of yummy, it was a tiny bit on the salty side - still yum though) and prices were super reasonable @ ~$7/dish. By now this place is a well known secret so the wait can be a bit long. It's tasty but I personally wouldn't wait longer than 15 mins. 

Beware: the "goodies" (featured items - ie. chasu, etc) in your choice ramen dish are disappointingly skimpy. 




WHAT WENT DOWN:

Suzu ramen:
Broth/Noodles - see Overview
BBQ pork - flavorful and cooked just right
Fried chicken - exploding with flavor (ie. Salty good!)
Bamboo - salty and preserved. Canned. 
Deep fried pot stickers - meh. Is ok. 

Katsu don - pork flavorful and fresh. Perfectly fried - light and savory. Sauce not overwhelming applied (read: not soggy) and surprisingly tasty. Way overcooked eggs. Overall, best Katsu don in the J-town mall thus far.  


For those who care, this place does offer a combo option of a ramen bowl and another item. What you will not get is 2 full meals. What you can expect is a normal size ramen accompanied by a dinky "taster" side of the chosen combo dish.

Apparently they no longer do take-out? What's up with that?!
author: Kenneth L.

description:
I was on my way home one day when all of a sudden my pregnant belly said, STOP!  Feed me ramen!  I made the hubby pull over and search for a place in Japantown to eat ramen.  Suzu just happened to be the first place we saw right at the entrance to the mall.  After staring at the large ramen bowls through the windows that people were eating, we decided to try it.  I guess the bowl was just big but the portion inside is probably average.

Honestly, I don't even remember what I ate.  I just scarfed it down.  I know I had a combo one time with unagi and changed my pork broth to a miso and got charged an extra $2 for that darn miso.  Whatever was inside the broth must've been good because I ate it so fast.  The next time I went, I came back for the miso broth and passed on the sushi.
  
I'm debating if this place deserves 3 or 4 stars.  I bumped it up to 4 because I just beat the crowd the few times I came here.  Best to come early since there are very few tables to sit at.
author: Stacey C.

description:
My lovely movie partner and I stopped by this place to grab a bowl or two of yummy Japanese noodles. Suzu Noodle House delivered and we were presently surprised that it was affordable. Just as we got there a line for tables assembled. 

The down side of the experience was that we sat out in the mall area not inside the establishment. There was a very unpleasant smell (I think the hair dresser was the culprit). I know it was not Suzu fault but it did take a bit away from the experience. 

I will be visiting this place frequently but insisting that I sit inside from now on!
author: Ryan B.

description:
Went to this place for lunch yesterday.  I was craving some Japanese food, so fiance and I decided to walk around Japantown and look for some Ramen shops.  I have walked past this place several times, but never wanted to wait because it is small and always busy.  We decided to put my name down and wait.  Since we were next, the wait was minimal.

I ordered the Salmon Don Noodle Combo and my fiance ordered the Karage Ramen.  The taste of the broth was fairly flavorful.  The noodles were a bit undercooked to my standards but had decent texture.  My Combo came with a Salmon over rice which was the best part of my meal.  The fish was fresh and nothing goes better with raw salmon than wasabi and soy sauce.  YUM!  

Service was prompt, the servers were friendly and attentive as expected from Japanese establishment.

If you ever are in the area and there is no wait, make sure you check this place out.  If there is a long wait, you may want to put your name down and check out Sophie's Crepes upstairs.
author: Albert H.

description: Finally tried Suzu to see what the fuss is all about... I'm giving it the benefit of 4 stars even thought it should be 3.5 but hey why get so technical!?! The noodles are a bit hard my taste. The miso base was quite delicious. The kaarage was different than most places; it was lightly battered and had an airy crunch, consensus around the table was we liked it! Overall not bad... I used to not come here due to the wait but last night (Wed night) was ok... about 15 minutes. Do try it, it's good. Warning: closes at 9pm or earlier!
author: Stephen Y.

description: Ramen is excellent. Pot Stickers are tasty and substantial.
author: Average Guy R.

description:
considering how many times i've been to Japantown (well... honestly, not that THAT much), I'm surprised I've overlooked this place so much. 

To put it simply, this place has a good balance of all the good qualities of my choice ramen spots in SF: the noodles have a chewiness like Katana-ya, and the broth is just as tasty as Tanpopo's broth. 

I highly recommend the Suzu Ramen as it has chashu, karaage, and dumplings. Beware of lines (but this can be curtailed by the location being inside the Japantown plaza).
author: Sean L.

description:
This is our current go-to place for noodles. We had a *fabulous* ramen dish with kimchee (I think) on top. It was perfect when we had it a few weeks ago. We couldn't find it on the menu the other time. 

This place seems good for kids, sine I see a bunch there every time I go (which has been 3 times now). It is great for 2 people, but any more than that takes a while. "2's company, 3's a crowd" is so perfect for this place.
author: Benjamin T.

description: I liked it, the ramen noodles were yummy, firm yet not too firm.  I had it with the tonkatsu, which was very tasty with just a hint of ginger.  But the bf thought it was too expensive--$40 for two bowls of noodles, a beer, and the agedashi tofu appetizer.  I'd go back again.
author: C L.

description:
My 200th review (after being MIA for like a year.) is my favorite ramen place in Japantown.  Having coming back from a recent trip to Tokyo and having my best bowl of ramen ever in my life in Ropponggi Hills area,  its safe to say that I know what good ramen taste like.   Suzu comes really close to the ramen I had in Tokyo,  nice aldente ramen noodle, just the right amount of broth flavor to each bowl and just right amount of meat and veggies to fill you up.  I eaten almost everything on the menu and to date my favorite has been the mabo ramen,  just the right amount of heat and great spicy broth.  The other thing I don't ever pass up here is their agedashi (fried tofu).  They are probably the best agedashi I had here in SF.    

Service can be spotty at times but for the most part it is nice enough but I mainly come here for the ramen and willing to deal with spotty service.  Too bad so many people have found out about this place and now the waits are worse now.  Bah!   Oh wells.  

So people can you guys  just stay away from here so I can get to my bowl of ramen quicker....pretty please?
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm not a ramen fanatic, to me I'm like, "What's the difference between this and the msg-laden crap I make at home for $0.39?"

I have eaten at several Ramen joints.. Genki....Tanpopo.. and others that I forget the name of... that unmemorable...  Still never understood the ramen craze..

But one sunny day at the Cherry Blossom, my besties wanted Suzu.. I was like GreEaAt another ramen joint I could add to the list of "food-I-dont-care-for".

It was a bit crazy.. well it was a busy Saturday, with Cherry Blossom.. it was like crazy..  After waiting 20 minutes, we got a table! Not shaby, since the group ahead of us..was waiting for like 40 minutes! *they had a group of 4, we had a group of 3*  So don't go more then groups of 3 or be totally the last table seated!

We ordered:

-Potato Croquettes: Yum! tho you really can't go wrong with deep friend mash potatoes with pork bits...

-Agedashi Tofu: I HEART tofu.. so I'm biased.. but my tofu-hating bestie had one, and she liked it!

-Tokyo Ramen, and the Ramen/Salmon Sashimi Combo: These were what my besties ordered... They loved their dishes! And the Sashimi/ramen combo was a good deal!

-Spicy Ramen: I always order spicy when it comes to things I could care less for... thinking the spice will make up for lack in taste.. WELL maybe i shouldn't have......    It was actually really spicy (which the waitress did warn me about).. BUT it was daymn good!!!  I felt the spiciness overpowered my taste buds from tasting how much yummier the ramen could have been!  Which is a rare of me ever to say, cus I the girl that thinks everything tastes better spicier.  Noodles had that homemade yummy chewiness.  

Portions are quite filling if not too large for an average girl.  Prices are decent (noting that its in the jtown buildings), and service wasn't bad.  Unlike other yelpers, I did get my food in a timely manner, and actually my whole table got their food at the same time.  Maybe I just caught the kitchen on a good day?

Overall Suzu has made me appreciate ramen joints (this one anyway)... and made me look down on those $0.39 ramens I get from Sunset Super.
author: Deanna T.

description: I think it was an off night, the noodles were ok, the service as usual rushed, but there were flies everywhere...please clean the kitchen, you should not have flies everywhere.  Ack! just thinking about it!!! Must take out my "Simply Japanese: Modern Cooking for the Healthy Home " cookbook and make my own noodles, but I liked you Suzu!!!
author: linda c.

description:
Decent noodles that will warm you up on a chilly day. There can be a bit of a wait to sit but and if you are not nearby when your party is called they move on down the list and make another party very happy.

Pros: inexpensive, large portions, decent service, tasty

Cons: wait time, ambiance
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
we had the miso and the cha su ramen. 
small little place, and you have to sign your name on the clipboard and then stand outside & wait for a table to open up. service was quick once seated, and i thought price/portion ratio was reasonable.
but the broth was SO SALTY, we both thought so. There wasn't anything impressive enough to make me want to go back.
author: bonnie y.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. Small hole in the wall feel in a mall. There seemed to be a wait to get in. All good signs of good ramen. After about 20 minutes of waiting, we finally got to sit and order. 

I had the salmon don, chashu ramen lunch combo. The salmon was excellent and I can't say enough about Japanese rice. I just love the sticky texture and the subtle sweetness. 

The ramen noodles were fairly decent and chewy. The pork was pretty average. Unfortunately, the broth usually helps determine the overall quality of the dish in my book and I found that they were a bit too salty for my taste. 

Service was very good. The waitresses were super friendly and prompt in pouring us tea when our cups were empty.

I might be inclined to try this place again but I probably will be trying another dish instead.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
When I think of SF japantown ramen I think of suzu.

The wait is long but I still think it's worth it. It's a small place with good food. More like a hangout place with your close friends than an intimate date spot. 

If you don't know what to order, I'll recommend the Chicken Karaage Ramen. You can't go wrong with fried chicken! Noodles are delicious and the broth is great.  If you're really hungry, there's an option to combo it with more sides, ie tuna sashimi with rice.

Note that on weekend lunches they've cutoffs on signing up on the waiting list. So come before 2pm-ish or earlier if you want a chance at eating here.
author: Jun Kang C.

description:
Ok I ate here again on Mon.  The miso ramen was so much better than the last review I gave it.  Super flavorful and had ample chashu and toppings.
The broth was very rich and delicious :)  I wonder if they changed owners again?? The agedashi tofu was really good with a yummy broth and ginger shavings.  I will be coming back again, yay!!!
author: Akemi O.

description:
i like tanpopo ramen more.  the ramen broth here is too salty, and the ramen texture is just not as great.  i had chicken karage and there were a decent amount of chicken pieces
it gets crowded here really quick, so its best to come early.
author: Karen L.

description:
This place wasn't bad. I came here with a friend after roaming around the hood looking for a place to eat, there was a line so we figured it was good. 

We had the tempura which we expected to be a lot bigger. I tried the kim-chee udon and enjoyed it.  I would come here again but it's not my new favorite place or anything like that. Nothing really stood out.
author: Jacquie S.

description:
Apparently I need to check out Tanpopo for Ramen since the naysayers seem to like that place much more then Suzu, though I found Suzu awesome in so many ways.

Dinner combo of Sake Don & Ramen for a mere $10 was a pretty sweet deal in my opinion.

'dia and I tried to have lunch here but they had closed their waitlist as soon as we got there.  Apparently they shut between 3:00PM and 5:30PM between lunch & dinner seatings.

We found sustenance at mediocre Maifun (ugh) and loitered japantown for several hours before returning to Suzu for dinner.  

I was beat down tired.  I had a messenger bag full of random stuffs that I managed to lug from the Mission to Jtown.  We had hit the grocery store where I had stocked up on azuki beanpaste for MochiBall Making Extravaganza 2009 as well as Soy Milk (as it always seems to be so much cheaper in Japantown).  I felt like a hobo.  A pack mule.  A Hobo Pack Mule Extraordinaire.  Apparently I have amazing back muscles.

Fueled on mediocre Udon and a handful of cookies, by the time we sat down at Suzu, I'm sure dirt in a bowl would have sufficed and I would have yelped a 5-star review.

The mini bowl of Sake Don was the right size to compliment the larger bowl of Ramen so it didn't feel like too much food.

Service was courteous and was consistent with refilling water and tea even long after we paid our bill and lingered in conversation.
author: Jen I.

description:
While roaming around Japantown for the first time we came across Suzu Noodle House.  The mall and the restaurants were oddly quiet and traffic free on a Thurs evening at 6pm (I'm from NYC so maybe I'm just used to busy restaurants and shopping areas) but Suzu was almost packed so we gave it a try.  I ordered the special combination which for me was Tokyo ramen and a gyudon or beef bowl.  The ramen was excellent, great subtle flavor and just the right amount of salt but missing a few additional ingredients I would have liked.  The gyudon was tasty.  The rice was coked perfectly and the beef was decent quality with good flavor.  I would have liked the beef thinly sliced but I suppose that is personal preference as how each restaurant or family makes this comfort food dish.
The service was average being that it seemed the waitresses were rushed and our waitress didnt even crack a smile.
author: Will F.

description:
I really wanted to give 4, 1/2  stars but I couldn't. The food was almost as good as it gets. I really enjoyed my meal,  ramen with chicken katsu don, it was really tasted. The place has about ten tables, so its kind of small. Lucky, we got there right before the rush, because lots of people were waiting for a table; however,  they do a good job of turning them . For the price, you get a lot of food. It is a good deal. 

My favorite part of this place is the waiting staff. Its kind of dorky, but I wanted to leave a boy my number and they were super cool and cute about it. The waiter even  went to check him and told me, he was a good looking.  

I had a great time and enjoyed my meal, the staff and atmosphere. Plus you get to walk through Japan town. Loved it and highly recommend.
author: Andrea T.

description: Pretty damn good ramen IMO. Best I've had in a long time. Have had ramen in over dozen places CA/NY/NJ/Tokyo and this has just become one of my fav.
author: Cheung L.

description:
the ramen is decent, a little bit on the salty side though, i also wish they have one of those soft boiled eggs in there instead of the fully cooked hard boiled eggs in the ramen

however, they do have a lot of options for ramen, many interesting flavors to try. i tried the cilantro ramen, which was good, but i felt like i didnt taste much in the broth b/c not only was the cilantro very strong as a topping, the broth is a bit bland and too salty. however, the noodles were chewy and delicious. 

i wont crave this place, but if i ever need to grab a quick dinner or lunch, maybe i'll stop by again
author: Joyce C.

description:
This small corner shop in Japantown San Francisco is my favorite ramen shop (7/24/2009).

The service can be slow, but I'm willing to wait as I love their spicy neghi ramen. Their gyoza dipping sauce is delicious (mildly spicy).

Although the spice varies from medium to hot. I usually like it hot and ask for more extra spice.
author: Myles U.

description:
Karaage ramen is okay. Not special.

I added a lot of seasoning since it tasted a bit bland for me. Next time, I'll stick with katana-ya.

Service isn't something that i appreciate. I knew that they're closing soon but was it my mistake that it took them forever to cook my ramen? They didn't refill my tea, gave me the check while I was eating and stared at me, waiting for the check to be paid as if I wont pay for the food. Ckckckck...

my recommendation in nearby area: tanpopo
author: Cliff T.

description: No more unagi.  & $1 extra for 2 stale pieces of nori... You gotta be kidding me?!  So sad, it does seem like there has been a change of ownership.
author: Miss K.

description: Not bad. Not bad at all...Got to go with the combination to get the most bang for your buck.
author: Monte M.

description: Ramen is over cooked and it is not authentic. This place doesn't seems like is run by Japanese but if the food is authentic I don't have any problem with it. I also got soba with tempura. The tempura is very soggy and powdery. Soba is over cook and the noodle sauce is just bad.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Came here last week for the first time and I wasn't really impressed. I ordered the Toyko Ramen and was a little disappointed with the broth. It lacked flavor and substance. It just wasn't hardy enough, like how a good ramen should be. Japantown has a wide range of great restaurants so I probably wouldn't come back here again.

The Good: Location is right below Sophie's Crepes
The Bad: Average ramen
author: Yan W.

description: The food is not as good as I expected but what's worse is the attitude of the waitresses here. I have been here twice and I encounter waitresses with BAD attitude both times!!!!! It sucks!!!
author: Jessie W.

description:
Had the Spicy Negi. Very spicy! Let a sip of ice water every other bite spicy. But the wait wasn't too long for a Saturday night, service was good, and overall it tasted yummy.

First time I had a non-spicy ramen and that was good, too!
author: Anita C.

description: Never order any curry dishes. Perhaps it's my fault for ordering curry at a noodle house but the tiny sliver of katsu (pork) on my curry was offensively tiny for $11. About 3 bites worth.
author: Max C.

description:
I eat here maybe 3 or 4 times a week. This is not the greatest ramen in the world but its definitely the best in the San francisco (unless there is some secret place i don't know about)

5 stars for:
Fast, helpful and polite service.
Consistant quality
Comfortable environment
Great ramen
And you get a lot for your money. I usually spend about $11 including tip and I get huge bowl of ramen and unlimited tea. 
Always satisfied.
And the new hours are great!
author: Claudius P.

description: I will give it 3 stars since it wasn't terrible but it also wasn't great. It was eh. I've had better especially for the price. It was a bit oily greasy for me and I have no idea why because it shouldn't have been. Also for what they gave you there was no seaweed with the ramen! what is up with that I thought it was a give that you would get a piece of seaweed with your ramen... you had to pay extra. The place is also wicked small. I didn't have anything else but the ramen and some edamame but I don't know if I will go back there. The waitresses were nice though I will give them that at least!
author: Tina D.

description: Bf liked it but I didn't... Service is not that good either.  they made us sit on the same table with 2 others we don't know.  it was so akward.  we were there right before the restaurant opens... and when everybody has taken a seat, everybody got a menu except my bf and i.... about 10 mins later my bf managed to call someone to get a menu.... im not coming back.
author: R F.

description:
My favorite Ramen place in the City by far (if you know a better spot, please tell me - I'm always willing for a better experience).

A few winters ago, the BF and I ate Ramen once a week in the City, searching out a go-to spot...we were spoiled by having both Santa Ramen and Oidon down in San Mateo and wanted a place to go in the City when craving Ramen. 

This place is very tasty, though not as bowl-you-over-good as my favorite place in San Mateo (Oidon) - I get their dinner combo or Ramen with a little starter of raw salmon over rice. It's reasonable-priced...I think they are listed as a CheapEats spot. There is usually at least a bit of a wait and I am usually the only caucasian in there...both good signs that the eats are GOOD at an Asian restaurant!
author: M B.

description:
I'm pretty surprised at some of the top reviews here giving Suzu only 3 stars.  Makes me wonder if Suzu has turned down Yelp on its advertising program.
Anyways, I think this place so far makes the best ramen I've found in the city.  In Japan, I was blown away by the ramen.  I never knew ramen could taste so good, and I've been searching San Francisco for good ramen places ever since.  Suzu is the closest I've found, even though it isn't quite the same.  I plan to go back Thursday, so maybe I'll post an update.
author: Cami B.

description:
The best ramen in San Francisco.  At present this is my favorite restaurant in the city. Near perfect execution.

Get there early as the place is tiny and popular.
author: Tamir S.

description:
When I crave ramen, this is the place I crave.  I hate it that this place closes so damn early (9pm!), and they stop seating at 8:30 because there's usually a wait.  But, despite their hours, I didn't dock any points because.. their spicy ramen is really really good, and I've tried many other places (I love ramen), and this place is usually my first choice.  And I go to other restaurants only as last resort.

I am a creature of habit... I haven't ventured off past their spicy ramen... but the fact that there's always a line for this place, they've gotta serve decent food overall.  Their noodle itself, by the way, is the best in J-town.
author: Samson F.

description: Seems fine - not really a ramen connoisseur, but it seems decent. Service, food, price all seemed pretty average
author: Victoria K.

description:
I normally do not write reviews without speaking to management, but no one was available.
First off, I love noodle soup.  I go a least 2-3 times a month.  This place is hit or miss.  I often do not go here because the service is not great.  Today as I approached there was party of 6 deciding if they wanted to eat there.  They did sign up but left.  I approached and was told I needed to sign in with no one else waiting in line.  There were 2 single tables open and the women that approached preceded to clean a four top for the 6 folks that left.
Another server came out, greeted and told me to sit where I would like.  This server was very attentive, had a sense of urgency and was smiling! She was fantastic throughout my whole dining experience!
I do have to say a couple came in right after me and first server immediately sat them (very interesting).
I would like to ask that you have consistency in your customer service with everyone.  One server really looked as if she did not want to be there while the other showed the meaning of customer service.
I have listed a 3 because of the attentive server.
author: Sunni M.

description: Ramen broth lacks flavor and noodles not that fresh, meats?  What meats,  so little.  Service sub par, they really don't like their duties.  Was a lot better a few years back.
author: Jay M.

description:
The service here was painfully slow - I noticed the kitchen would only make one table's order at a time, with about 10 minutes between each table.  We were the third table seated after the restaurant opened and by the time we left there were still tables that had been seated minutes after us that still had no food, and this place is tiny.

The food was so-so but I think I've made better ramen at home and the tempura was sort of mushy.  Also, the only to-go containers they provide are the Chinese take-out boxes.  Why wouldn't a noodle place have adequate containers for left over noodles and soup?  The waitress gave us major attitude when we asked for an extra take-out box so we could double them up, since the ramen broth was still very hot and could make one box very flimsy.  There are plenty of other (better) noodle joints in Japantown.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Typically, i feel that the ramen only deserves a 2... BUT, they do have good lunch combos. 

Not much of a back story to tell here, other than... 
For the first couple of months, living in SF and trying to "experience" the ramen culture of the city, yelp brought me here. 
For the first couple of months, i thought Suzu was going to be my ramen of choice. I mean, the reviews weren't bad, the ramen wasn't bad, the ... everything just.. wasn't bad...which meant it wasn't good either. 

Dominus Ramenus Points: 
+ really close to my home (5 min walking distance) 
+ reasonably priced lunch combos ($10 for ramen and side) 
+ it is located inside a mall-type area, so you can walk around the little shops while waiting 

- everything is relatively bland: noodles are whatever, soup is whatever, 
- toppings are lacking (very minimal) 
- portions are small, every time i finish, i cant help but think... that's ALL?!? 
- place is super small = wait time 
- place is understaffed and the servers always seem pissed off and are not friendly or openly nice (like they should be...) = LONG wait for food 

Overall, 
I don't like completely bashing this place, because its just...so...NOT memorable... i mean.. i am just indifferent about this place. If i wanted to appease the ramen stomach of mine without driving, this is 1 of 3 places i would go (genki delivers and Tanpopo has friendlier staff and better ramen)
author: Dominus S.

description:
Delicious!  

We were lucky enough to not have to wait for a table in this little restaurant tucked away in the downstairs section of the Kintetsu Mall. This place is seriously small, with a max of 30 seated people inside and a couple of tables outside. 

Location bonus: live Japanese music is performed in the area right outside the restaurant. Not sure if it's everyday, but we went on Sunday and had some lovely music that drew quite a crowd.

I had the unagi don combo with ramen noodles and hubby had the curry karaage with rice (comes with miso and salad). YUM. That was some of the best curry ever! (Hubby agreed, and he's not a huge curry fan.) The unagi was flavored well and the ramen portion was very generous. Broth was tasty, but I did find that some soy sauce and white pepper added nicely to the flavor.  And for $20.00 for both of us, we'd definitely come back!

Tiny place in the first floor of the Kinokuniya building, but it doesn't have the tiny ramen place appeal (i.e. a bar, television, and watching them cook in front of you). It's just a small restaurant with some overflow onto tables outside. They also seem to have the strangest hours, I know they have the schedule, but why are they always closed when I come to Japantown?

In the few times I've been able to eat here though, they've actually served up pretty good bowls of ramen. A good variety, enough to satisfy most tastes, but not so many that you worry they're spreading themselves too thin. Plus they also do a mean bowl of udon and soba, not usually my first choice for Japanese noodles, but very well done here if you're craving it (a step up from the generic Japanese restaurant). Their lunch combo also looks pretty respectable as well.

I've also never had problems with service, they look busy, but despite the small wait staff on hand, I've gotten my bowls with a good quick turnaround. This usually is my second choice in noodles when I come to Japantown, if for some reason I'm not feeling Tanpopo (or just too lazy to hike over there from Kinokuniya).
author: Roland C.
