description: Kevin felt like ramen for lunch and wanted to try this ramen house.  Little did he remember that we had eaten here before.  So I reminded him that he wasn't too fond of the food the last go around.  When we got there we signed our names on to the wait list and waited about 15 min for a table.  We ordered the ramen along with the chicken kaarage & agedashi tofu.  Once again, not too impressed.
author: Stacey L.

description: YUM! What a menu. Perfect for a cold, rainy night or quick dinner before a movie. The menu is full of hearty, tasty, slurpy noodle bowls and other soba dishes. Tons to choose from. I love any place where I leave satisfied for under $25 (for two!). Can't wait to keep coming back. Shwing!
author: Meredith R.

description:
On a Friday afternoon, my friend W and I decided to hit up a ramen joint for a late lunch.  At approximately 2 pm, there was one table for four available, and we took it.  

Now, keep in mind that my friend W is  the one who I have repeatedly claimed has no taste buds.  He eats virtually anything, and if it's food, he'll consider it to be anywhere from "decent" to "good".   A taste of the most wonderful thing - and he'd nod and simply comment, "Yeah, it's alright."  Give him a taste of something awful, and he'd nod his head and state, "I like it fine." 
Like I've said, when we're on our way to a new restaurant that I heard about, and he says it's really good there, I usually have an overwhelming urge to screech into a U-turn.

That said, I am not the quickest cookie in the jar, and on this afternoon, not having a specific craving for anything, I let him pick.  It was only at the entrance that it struck me - -  I did it again, I let him pick the restaurant.  

When will I ever LEARN?

Well, folks, even a broken clock is right twice a day.
Suffice to say, I was quite pleased w/ Suzu.

We ordered two bowls of "spicy scallion" ramen and he suggested that we request EXTRA PORK.  We also ordered a plate of Gyoza.

I wasn't too impressed with the Gyoza - it was just typical, but the ramen was actually really good!

First, the extra pork slices were not just tender but extremely flavorful.  I'd definitely recommend requesting extra to almost any of the ramens available here.  The scallions were not super-spicy, but notably spicy enough to make a difference.  For Koreans, it was the taste of "Pa-Kimchi", laid atop your noodles.  The noodles were cooked nicely, and the broth, while still a bit on the oily side, was outstanding.  The only ding, perhaps, was the size.  For a bowl of ramen, it was on the smaller side, at least compared to some other joints.

Our ramen was $8 each, give or take some cents - and it was well worth the price - and while I don't know how much the extra pork or gyoza cost, the total bill came to $27 or so by the time tip was included.

In my eternal quest of a good bowl of ramen in San Francisco - - Suzu rates up there for the moment.  I'd eat here again, with pleasure.

Like I said - even a broken clock is right twice a day!  Go figure.
author: Grace K.

description: Ain't easy finding a really really good bowl of ramen in this City.  Suzu is that place.  Small joint with a long line.  The Tokyo Ramen and Mabo Ramen are my faves.
author: Robyn C.

description: Mmm, nothing's better than warm, delicious, SALTY noodles on a windy afternoon. If you get here at standard meal hours the wait is ridiculous- they ask that you add your name to a list and I've waited up to an hour to be seated before. With that said, they provide a very tasty, quick meal and the restaurant is in a little shopping area so you can browse through interesting stores while you wait to be seated.
author: Inna T.

description:
:::::::::::::::::::::RESTAURANT HOURS::::::::::::::::::::::

Open for lunch Monday, Wednesday through Friday from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m.; open for dinner Monday, Wednesday through Friday from 5 to 10 p.m. Open Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 10 p.m., Sunday until 9:30 p.m. Closed Tuesday

Crazy schedule, but here you are!
author: liz L.

description:
Right before we ate lunch there, my friend sent me an article about Suzu, when they were named Best Japanese Noodle House in 2006.  Although we are not a city known for our noodle houses, I still had high expectations.

The place was packed on an overcast Wednesday afternoon.  We both had the lunch special with tempura and two kinds of noodles - soba and green tea.  The tempura was OK, and the noodles were very good - but I could not rave about them enough to give the restaurant a "Best of" status in my book.  The nice thing is that they were very light, so we didn't feel overly full afterwards.

If you feel like slurping down some noodles, and are already in the neighborhood, it's a decent choice, but not one to get overly excited about.
author: Liz S.

description: Ever since I went to Japan last year I've been craving a good bowl of Ramen. I finally got myself over to Suzu before seeing a movie at Kabuki and it certainly didn't dissapoint. I got a veggie ramen in a miso broth. While I didn't expect it to match Japan exactly (and it didn't), it was really really good, and definitly the best I could have expected. I obviously enjoyed it because despite it being a huge bowl of noodles I soon found myself with an almost empty bowl. Very reasonably priced, the wait wasn't too long, and very yummy. I'll be back for sure!
author: Lindsay A.

description: Had the miso ramen . It was good! The gyoza was not what I expected ... Wouldn't be ordering that again . No complaints and it satisfied the ramen fix !
author: Judy C.

description: Spicy tofu kimchi ramen is da bomb @ $11.95.
author: C L.

description: My Favorite Noodle place in Jtown !!! (I work in jtown, and I'm Japanese American, trust me, it's good). I would stick with simpler dishes, but all are good.
author: Phillip O.

description:
Apparently Suzu's popularity is going strong, a crowd of loitering hungry people outside the restaurant eyeballed us as we approached to put our name to the waiting list, and there was no let up in the number of impatient hungry the entire time we were here.

That said I was less then thrilled with the pork and veggie ramen - the noodles themselves were still very good, but the veggies were comprised of mostly cabbage with just one or two tiny florets of broccoli and a snap pea or two, and the pork was all odds and ends, little nubs and random fatty pieces that were not close to the quality of the slices you get in the standard ramen. The broth was also very fatty, great big islands of it floating and making your lips sticky, while at the same time it was bland and not nearly as flavorful as the other ramens I have had here.  Other then that the gyoza was still good and the basic udon seemed to be much the same as before.

It was a let down to see that while the restaurant has made improvements and updated the menu the quality of this newer dish was lacking, and the added insult to injury was that the price is a step up. 

PS: FYI they no longer offer food to go, am now on the lookout for a replacement for my ramen fix take away needs.
author: GIR ..

description:
Located in the heart of Japan-town in Miyako Mall, East Building. I was happy to try a new place out. I usually hit up Tanpopo, but I'm always down to try new places. This place is a solid 3 star establishment. Food was good, but not incredible. Karage was yummy and fresh tasting. I ordered a combo special with Spicey Chosu Ramen and Chicken Curry. 

The Ramen was ok, Noodles were a little big for my tastes, both noodles and broth kinda gave me a Udon feel, although noodles weren't that big, but I kept switching to a Udon experience during my food trip. Now it looks like the place just started offering "spicy" as almost every dish that had new by it was a spicy dish. Now the "Spicy" I got here was a bit surprising to me. I say this because usually when I ask for spicy in a Japanese Noodle House (AKA Ramen Shop) I'm thinking of getting a Chili-oil based sauce. at Suzu I got a very SE Asian style hot sauce. It was good, don't get me wrong, but I'm not sure it's the right kind of Hot and Spicy I was going for. It is Spicy though. I liked that, I just think it was a interesting Fusion, I wasn't necessarily trying to get out of my bowl of Japanese Ramen.

Everythign said, sure I'd go back, service was good, drinks were your average price. Nothing to call out for good prices there, however the combos prices were very well-priced.
author: Paul V.

description: This is one of the best Ramen spots in SF in my opinion. I ordered the Chasu Ramen and the broth had a lot of flavor to it without it being too salty. It tasted very fresh and the pork slices were also very tender. Way better than Genki Ramen (EWW)! I will definitely come again!
author: Tida P.

description: Ordered the ramen that was topped with crispy fried chicken. Asked them to leave out the bamboo shoots since i hate that stuff. They did leave out the bamboo shoots, but must have accidentally left out the 2 pieces of pork as well :'(. Still loooved the ramen here. I thought the noodles were sooo good!! I've tried lots of great ramen places and I think this place has the best noodles. Broth was also good, and loved the crispy fried chicken. Usually I don't see this as an option at places, but the crispiness adds different texture as you eat the ramen. Since the fried chicken is immerse in the broth, it does start to lose its crispiness, but since it's so good, I'm eating it all up fast anyway so it doesn't really have time to get soggy. LOVE!
author: Liwei Y.

description:
After searching for our friend's lost dog on Saturday (Thank god we found Nala! or rather, Nala found us! She found her way back at our friend's apartment safe and sound), we decided to go to Suzu. 

I have been here twice now. The noodles are decent. I had the spicy negi ramen this time. I wish there was some kimchi in there, but that's the Korean in me coming out. 

Appetizers we ordered were croquettes(veggie) and tuna sashimi. Croquettes were good and nicely fried, but very hot! So be careful! The tuna was fresh, according to my dining companions. 

Cheap dinner for 3, total bill about $45.00. Pretty fast service. Very clean establishment as far as I could tell. 

A solid 3.5 stars.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Uh.........no.

I'm pretty upset about losing my 11 dollars (including tip) over this, I can't really even explain myself. 

I could've bought 11 packs of  shio ramen and had this crap 11 times over. Sad. 

I had the Karaage ramen, waitress said she really liked it.... she was obviously blowing smoke up my big ass... thereby making my hole bigger. Thanks. 

Service, besides continuous pouring of tea, was not what you usually expect from Japanese establishments. Every japanese establishment I've ever gone into always had a very courteous, friendly, and polite waiting staff. Obviously, what I'm getting to, is that this place wasn't like that... at all. The waiting staff all had this kind of "ugh, i have to be here again," face. Really annoying. 

It was pretty empty today, and yet, they were rushing me the check and trying to shoo me out. WTF. 

They probably knew I was going to write a bad review. HAH! you guessed right.

Anyways... you can buy this and cook it in a pot yourself. Just go buy those shio ramen packages at mitsuwa or some japanese market. 99 cents man, 99 cents.  

Broth = not flavorful, but salty. Heart attack salty. Almost like.. sea water. "MmMm!" if i was a fish. Sadly, I am not. 

Fried Chicken bits = only 3? And one was only batter + fatty bits! Cheapos

Green onions = Man, they really are stingy. There were only like 5 little hula hoops in mine. 

sea weed = same amount as you would find in a tiny tiny bowl of miso soup.

The only good thing I can say, is that I'm SO glad I didn't waste my monies on gyoza and dessert; that would've sucked. 

What they could improve on? Better recipes and being less skimpy. 

I don't pay 11 dollars for people to show me their "ugh" face and noodles I can make at home in less time. 

1 star! i wish I could give it 0....
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
Food was pretty good. Service was below average and a little weird. They were a tad nazi-esque with the seating. 

We came in, and were seated at a small table for 2. We asked if we could sit at a bigger table, and the server said the bigger tables were for a party of four or more. OK, no problem. No big deal (for us). Another party of two came in. They really insisted on sitting at a bigger table because the place wasn't busy. The server kept forcing them to move to a smaller table, for what felt like 5 minutes, until another server interfered and asked her to just let it go. LOL...

All in all, it was average. I still like Katana-Ya better.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: Upon arriving during peak weekend brunch time (11-ish), we encountered about a 20 min wait for our party of 3.  Suzu has very fresh ramen and "sharp" broth!  The noodles seem like the Japanese version of "al dente" and is very tasty.  The broth is described as "sharp" on the menu, which we're not sure of what they meant, but we found it to be delicious.  We ordered 3 bowls of ramen, gyoza and tempura.  It was all fantastic, but be careful with the dipping sauces.  We avoided a minor accident with bleach.  For some odd reason, we kept smelling bleach and discovered it was in the gyoza sauce.  The waitress was extremely apologetic and quickly removed the sauce and offered us another one (without bleach).  To be honest, this incident has not made me wary of Suzu.  The ramen bowls out-shined the minor bleach episode and I would come back to try out other items.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Tiny, cute JTown shop (it used to house an adorable mochi shop) that serves up udon, ramen, soba and donburi.  Gotta love the neon "noodle" sign. 

I thought by coming early (before 6 PM) we could avoid the lines.  The place was packed and we still had to wait.  Wait staff passed by with trays of noodle soup, croquettes, and rice dishes.  Everything looked really good - nice presentation, lovely Japanese ceramic dishes.

In the end, the highly anticipated spicy-negi ramen was slightly above average.  The noodles were  firm/al dente and chewy.  The dark soy broth was too salty but with good flavor.  I wouldn't call it spicy.  However, they did serve it piping hot.  The overall portion size was smaller than average.  Skimpy ingredients: I received one slice of pork, abundant green onions, and a few bamboo shoot slivers.  It was simple and satisfying but not crave-worthy.  

Most of the tables are for two people.  I wouldn't come with a large group (over 4 people).
author: Lolia S.

description:
modest noodle shop.....inners of kinokuniya....limited seatin'....ramen rumored to be "good"....tempted by words..."they have good chashu"...

miso ramen..extra chashu...slightly salty yet manageable....decent broth...noodle perfection...hint of al dente...minimal elasticity....soft snap...."jjor-geet...jjor-geet".... tender pork slices (chashu)....taste of salt deep within the meat....simmered in salt?....quite good for patrons fond of salty goodness.....paired with karaage chicken...thin 'n' lightly battered...golden fried perfection...tastes of ginger....small, but above par in taste...

sake and beer pairing available to dilute the salt....pricing odd....recommend ordering small beru bottles if wanting more for the buck....$3 for 12 ounces (small) asahi....$6 for 21 ounces (large) asahi.....do the math....
author: Hen A.

description:
we usually see this place packed with people, and the one night we wanted to come it was closed. Anyhow though we came back the next day.

We sat outside which I thought was nice because the inside of the restaurant seemed pretty stuffy. The only downside with sitting outside is taht you dont get such attentive service as the others would do on the inside.

The ramen overall was good, I would suggest they add more pieces of cha-shu to their "tokyo" ramen. There was only one slice of cha shu which kind of seemed cheap. Just first impression. The kaarage ramen was good, with 3 pieces of chicken kaarage..

Overall 3 stars seem to do enough justice for this place.
author: phillip w.

description:
There was a line.  After my suggestion that "it's ABSURD to wait in line for ramen!" is rejected, we wait.  And wait.  And continue to wait.  Finally, a table opens up and we sit down for some good old ramen.

On first opening the menu I notice something a bit odd -- $9 vegi ramen.  Really Suzu?  You really want to have me pay 9 bucks for vegi ramen?  Really?  When it's just some carrots, potatoes and noodles?  Really?

Ok lets try it, maybe it'll lead me to the greatest epiphany known in the western world.  Needless to say my ramen was oily, overly chewy and simply not worth $9.  Maybe $5.50, maybe $6, but surely not $9.

The other fun little aspect of Suzu: the food itself is SLOW to arrive, yet our happy little check came before my bowl of oil was half empty.

Will not be coerced into returning again.
author: jack p.

description:
Listen all you ramen snobs!  Did you ever think that it's hard to make AUTHENTIC Japanese ramen because the ingredients are limited in the US?  You guys piss me off!

This noodle house makes a really great curry udon and even if the ramen is average, it doesn't mean you can't try their other dishes.  My girlfriend and I love the area, the atmosphere and the service we get from this charming noodle house in J-town and I'm sure anybody who isn't a stuck up "This isn't like the ramen in Japan" a**hole would appreciate what they do offer.

Again, try their combo special with the salmon sashimi don and curry udon.  Their soba is delish too if you don't feel like ramen or udon.
author: Keika L.

description:
spicy negi ramen - it doesn't seem spicy at first, but it slowly creeps up and puts up a small fight. actually, it tastes pretty salty. the broth is very light, could use a little more work on that. however the noodles were delish. perfect al dente, thick chewy yellow goodness. mmmmmmmmmmmmmmm


but WHY DOES IT TAKE SO LONG!? are you grinding up the flour in your kitchen? are you picking the green onions from a backyard somewhere!?
author: Susy C.

description:
I have been to Suzu a handful of times, and each time I have been here, I have ordered the same thing.

You know how the old saying goes, if it ain't broke, don't fix it.  I take that advice to heart when I come to Suzu.  

I think this is the case because Suzu was the first time I had ever had chicken karaage ramen.  I've had other types of ramen before, but never this kind.  Long story short, this version of the fried chicken ramen blew me away.  And since chicken karaage is not typically offered in many Japanese restaurants, this experience has stuck out in my memory.

And it also sticks out as the only thing I ever want to order when I come to Suzu.

Now if they could only find a larger space.  Then again, if a larger space meant ramen that wasn't as awesome, don't expand.
author: Michael C.

description:
Brownian miso,
swirls through oil textured broth,
heaven in a bowl.

When you take an authentic Tokyo salary man out from the hazy, rain-swept neon-clad warrens of Ueno and sit him in a ramen joint anywhere on the planet more than ten blocks from the deafening din of a smoke-blurred pachinko parlor, you had better pray that the beer so cold it burns and the noodles have been blessed by the spirit Juzo Itami's Tampopo or you will find yourself facing THE most severe (and ironically, politest) dressing down of your life.

Suzu passed the bar in this case, and now is officially sanctioned by not one but TWO of Tokyo's least sophisticated, yet remarkably critical gourmands who entered with great apprehension and left with smiles and full bellies.  Well done, Suzu!
author: Mason G.

description:
I had high expectations going to this small noodle specialty restaurant in Japantown as it seemed to have the right character to serve THE ramen of the town.  I ordered their Chicken Karaage Ramen, which I've never seem anywhere else.  It turned out that it was ramen "with" karaage on the side.  I've tried putting karaage in the ramen, but this didn't seem to make any sense, so I enjoyed quality karaage by it self.  Crispiness is the life of karaage and soaking it in ramen broth didn't add any value.  Problem was, without tossing karaage into the ramen, there wasn't much of a topping in the bowl.  Some negi(green onion) and wakame (seaweed) was about it.  No chashu(pork slices), bean sprouts, eggs, menma, nor "character."  Soup lacked the addictive taste, but men (noodle) was pretty good.  Overall, it wasn't bad ramen, but it didn't drive me crazy over it.  $8 = 1000 Yen, which is kind of pricey for a bowl of ramen.  I've tried their gyoza, which was home made, not a frozen Ajinomoto, hence pretty good.
------
Update (19 May 2006)
SF Weekly in Best of 2006 edition selected Suzu as Best Japanese Noodle House.  At first, I said WHAT?!?  But, then realized that I couldn't think of any better choice in SF.
author: トモ T.

description: Something was weird about the noodles here... they were almost like slightly thicker versions of yellow instant noodles that I used to eat in college. The ramen broth was ok, but I was a little disappointed, as this was my first time in Japantown and I was expecting something much closer to real authentic Japanese ramen. Maybe I'm just a hipster food-snob now but my expectations have been raised since my most recent visit to Japan and this was a huge let-down. C'mon guys, at least get the noodles right and I'll give Suzu another chance!
author: Captain Z.

description:
Ramen is one of those dishes that people get all crazy - up in yo- bidness about. From time to time... I do to, but not tonight. 

Every now and then you want fast, courteous service in a clean and simple environment. And that is exactly what I found here.

We arrived and there was a 15 minute wait. The hostess brought us some tea and water while we sat and perused the menu. The location is in the J-town Mall so you are generally pretty comfy hanging out waiting for a seat. 

I had the tempura udon and was very happy with it. The dashi (broth) was on the sweet side, but I like it like that. My hubbs had the ramen and he liked it the same. Not crazy aobut it but it was good. 

The portions of Hiyayako (cold tofu) and croquette were admittedly on the smaller side, but after finishing off my noodles and the appetizers, we were pretty full.

No question... I'd eat there again.
author: Stephanie I.

description: I've been coming here for years and for the first time, I was disappointed with my ramen.  My sisters and I all had to send back our ramen because our noodles wasn't cooked all the way thru.  When we all bit into our ramen, we could still taste the flour of the uncooked noodles.  I don't know if this was because they had just opened and was busy feeding everyone at the same time.  We sent back our noodles and when we got them back, they we're better but still not the Suzu ramen I loved.  Hopefully next time I go back, my ramen will be cooked right so I don't have to return it.
author: Stella L.

description:
Ra ra ra. Yes, the ramen is divine, but don't forget the udon. One of the best Japanese noodle joints I've found in the city thus far. But a pointer: if the small restaurant is crowded and/or you're forced to sit outside, good luck with service. The waitresses have gotten better, but they are still space cadets. I think they're channeling Atom Boy somewhere far far away. Moshi moshi?

Closed Tuesdays.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
I came here with my bro-in-law to get my ramen fix before heading out to Hukilau for sweet Hawaiian music live.  The ramen was good, not fantastic write home to mama good, but good enough.

The portions seemed small to me -- for eight/nine bucks I would expect more.  The chicken karaage was moist and okay, the gyoza was okay...

Okay okay, I guess this place was just okay.  Good enough but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.  But if you're in J-town, why not?
author: Bryan K.

description:
Most of the time I've eaten in the J-town area my friends have wanted sushi, so I came to Suzu without them specifically for a change of pace.  Yesterday our order consisted of two different ramen bowls and an order of tenpura.

All the food was fantastic: The ramen was perfectly done, with just the right amount of bite to the noodles, and the tenpura we ordered was cooked exceptionally well.  I notice quite a few reviewers complaining that the broth doesn't have enough punch, but I appreciated the fact that the broth was very clean and light, with clear, wakame-hued flavors -- not the usual salt-fest most ramen-ya fill your bowl with.

The portions were a bit smaller than for the same dishes at Sapporo-ya upstairs, but they were also more than a couple of dollars cheaper and the execution of the dishes were several notches better.  This is the first Japanese place in a while that I've been to where even the tenpura impressed me; whoever's cooking in the back is doing a fantastic job.

(Why I'm not giving five stars: They were a bit stingy with my dining companion's ramen, giving him only one tiny slice of chashu.  I appreciate a place that gives proper portions and doesn't supersize everything, but this was just plain stingy.  Also, we had barely finished the last of our ramen when the waitresses descended, quickly began snatching away all our dishes, and robotically intoned "thankyouokaythankyoubyebye" before we could even blink.  It's a small space with people waiting outside and so I know they want prompt turnover, but it was a bit much.  If you want to linger in the restaurant, eat slowly.)

Overall I'm definitely happy with this place and will be going back for sure.
author: James L.

description:
Suzu is ok.  Given the dearth of top-quality ramen houses in SF (recommendations, anyone? please?), we checked out Suzu on a chilly November night - perfect for a steaming bowl of ramen.

Having been spoled by Ramen Halu in San Jose, and Himawara in San Mateo, Suzu's ramen is a 4 out of 10 I'd say.  Suzu is that girl/guy that you meet in a bar that could go up to a 6 if you drank enuf, thus putting her/him in the "i won't feel too bad about myself tomorrow morning" category.

Dropping the human mating dance analogy, Suzu's ramen noodles were pretty good.  Broth, meh.  Kinda bland.  And toppings?  Non-existent.  But, their vegetarian croquettes were fresh and yummy, which helped fill me up.

Would I go back to Suzu?  Maaybe.  Certainly if I didn't have to wait for a table.  And definitely if I was trashed.
author: brian w.

description: I was under the weather and got the Cha Shu Ramen a few nights ago. The pork is amazingly tender, unlike the overcooked, dry, thin slices of pork usually served at most ramen places. At first I thought I would not be able to or want to finish the pork and even offered some to my dining partner, but by the end of the meal, I was wishing there had been more! The noodles had a great, chewy texture, and the broth had just the right amount of salt and density. For $10 a bowl, this place is kind of really awesome.
author: Jen Y.

description:
smallish, decent ramen place in japantown.  suzu gets pretty packed, so i suggest going before noon on weekends.  

i had the ma po tofu (MPT) ramen.  it was rather spicy and a bit different from the traditional ramen with the half hard cooked egg, bamboo, chasu pork, and seaweed in it.  i'll probably order it again, but maybe i'll try the MPT on the side.  i feel like the MPT and ramen combo makes the soup a bit too thick for my taste.  

my cousin had the cilantro ramen, which was really watercress.  he liked it, but just know that its def. not cilantro when you order it.
author: Wendy S.

description:
I went here when they first opened and frankly, didn't think much of it.  I decided to give it another shot after it was recommended by a japanese girlfriend of a friend.  

I must say, the food has vastly improved since the first time I went as evidenced by the wait when we got there.  The wait was not that bad (~15 minutes) but I think we happened to get there just as the first wave was finishing up.  I had the nabeyaki udon and my friend had the tokyo ramen.  We shared a chicken karaage and katsu don.  We both thought the udon had a really tasty broth.  I love tofu and thought it was great there were two large slabs in my udon.  Definitely one of the best udon's I've had...be patient though and let it cool though.  I burnt my mouth cause I couldn't wait.  Can't comment on the ramen since I didn't really try it.  I had a sip of the broth and it was pretty good.  

The karaage was good but we thought there weren't enough pieces and they were a bit small.  We ended up ordering a katsu don since we were still hungry and we're pigs.  Katsu don was very good but we were disappointed that they didn't have oyako don on the menu.  We asked if they could make one since we're both huge oyako don fans but they wouldn't do it.  

DSKO favs: nabeyaki udon, katsu don
author: Dik Shun K.

description:
The restaurant is in J-Town in a shopping centre. The interior design of the ceiling is very industrial; looks like they haven't touched it at all, lots of blue painted tubes floating in the air. In case if you'd like to look up for a moment to have this experience with the tubes prepare for the powerful spotlights above the table will give you a gentle warn to do not try look up again by burning out a little bit of your retina in your eyes at each attempt. The color and surface of the tables reminded me to the sad, failed period of the 80's Eastern-European failed socialist society research, and combined with the ceiling I've had an impression about the whole restaurant it was maybe just unpacked from a huge box overnight and can be carried away to an another mysterious shopping mall at any time.

The staff is super friendly, and they won't let you starve to death until you're waiting for your meal. Beware, objects in menu are smaller than they appear! Expect huge tasty dishes for a fairly good price. Try the ramen. The selection of food represents a cultural fusion as it's an interesting mixture of Italian, Japanese and Chinese kitchens, from pastes to sushis. In case if you can't read, you'll find helpful pictures as well in the menu, and don't forget they also have a bar at the front.

A nice place to hop in with friends on a rainy day.
author: Tamas K.

description: Suzu used to be a good place for ramen. I'm so sad to say NOT ANY MORE. Only OK now. The texture of the ramen was too soft but the chashu too hard. Luckily the soup was still good. Not sure what happened to the kitchen. Maybe they forgot how to cook good ramen with such long lines everyday.
author: V L.

description:
I've heard so many stories about this place, so a couple friends and I went to try it.  This was not the first time I have attempted to try this place.  The first time, we were rejected because they did not accept people 20 minutes before closing =(.  The second time, we decided to try again, just to give it another shot.  We waited and waited and were starving.  Once we ordered, I assume that the Ramen would be good, especially since I was starving. 

The original Ramen was quite bland.  The Miso ramen was a little bit better but still, it was not spectacular.  Sorry, I would not come back here again.
author: Carmen C.

description:
This is definitely a place worth visiting if you're in the SF area and want something absolutely delicious and amazing. It's a small little place located inside a small shopping mall in Japantown. The atmosphere is casual.  We went on a Friday afternoon and had no problems getting seated right away. Make sure you note the hours as they are closed for a little while between lunch and dinner time each day.

If you want to experience what REAL ramen noodles are supposed to taste like, Suzu doesn't disappoint. The broth is sooo soo good and I drank up the whole thing. The noodles are perfect and the fresh vegetables really add to the awesome flavor. The pork is soooo tender and delicious.

My husband and I loved everything about this place and will definitely visit again the next time we are in the area.
author: Anna C.

description: Yummy - not expensive -- great service -- noodles just the right flavor and tenderness. Definitely a place to sit before a movie.
author: Dan E.

description: The restaurant of Suzu had some pretty solid tasting noodles. Food was not bad, but the service deserves a 1 star. Not once had I gotten a refill on my water and the server had never asked if we needed anything. We had a party of 5 and apparently we had to pay 18% of gratitude towards the server which had not even once helped us in any sort of way? Nowhere in the restaurant had it said that parties of 5 or more had to pay 18% of gratitude. The 18% of gratitude was added onto the grand total, which made the total $89.72 instead of $76.04 (before tips). In the state of California only with parties of 6 or more is a 18% gratitude asked. We only had a party of 5. The server gave us no choice but to pay the gratitude along with our total before tips. Never have I experienced this sort of problem and I hope not to ever again because this was just absolutely absurd. If this gratitude problem had never happened, I would give this restaurant a 3.5 star rating since the food was pretty good. Next time i come here with a party of 5 or more and i don't get good service or much less any service, I'm paying the total and not the tips. Be warned
author: Darren K.

description: Not as good as before...something is different about this place. I think they might have changed owners recently. Not sure if I'll be coming back. It's literally just ok. :(
author: C B.

description:
The food is pretty good. I would give the food a 3 to 4 star rating. The service I give a negative review. The spicy ramen is a little oily and I had a side of the tuna don. Price is reasonable. Place gets packed, and it's awkward of you stay longer because people stare at you. Won't be coming back because the waitress said there are many customers waiting and they need our table!!!
How rude is that!!!!
author: Russell T.

description:
I hate to complain, but---

1. they brought out my ramen 10 minutes before the appetizer, and we still had to wait another 5 minutes for the other person's ramen

2. the noodles weren't cooked fully.  They tasted all chalky, and they were obviously from some cheap packet because they were clumped in the shape of a square.  I can make shitty packet noodles at home without paying $7.50 

3. Only one piece of pork.  No scallions, no little fish thing...very disappointing.  Most ramen places give you all of those things, plus 3 or 4 slices of meat.  What the hell?

4. The pork was all dried out.  I bet it was from the pig's ass.

So in conclusion---go to the places upstairs.  They are much better, and probably more authentic (everyone here was Korean).
author: indojin i.

description: Their Ramen Noodles are so yummy! Slurp Slurp all the way. Especially their soup.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I was so hungry so we stopped by here, the prices seemed reasonable.  We ordered a karaage appetizer and split the tempura soba.  It was okay.  The karaage was a little bland and not crispy like I like it.  The soba was good, but you ca'nt really screw that up.  The tempura was so-so, nothing spectacular but you get 2 pieces of shrimp, and a strip of zucchini, carrot and pumpkin.  

I didn't know that this is a ramen place so I'll have to come back and try it.
author: Emiko M.

description:
The ramen here was just "alright" for me. I don't understand why there's always a huge line. It might be because there aren't any great ramen houses in the area, but I woud not wait to eat here. Luckily when I tried this place it was 2 in the afternoon and the place was barely full. 

If you have the time to wait an hour, drive to Santa Ramen in San Mateo and that will be worth it.
author: Tracy L.

description:
I have been to Suzu a bunch and always loved the spot, until recently..Bottom line, their customer service when dealing with a customer with a food allergy (gluten) is very poor and my experience was so bad that I will never go back. In fact, I will not be able to recommend this little joint anymore because it is very clear that they do not value their loyal customers.

Longer story if you're interested..I have a gluten allergy and had been advised (for a year of going to Suzu) that I could sub in soba noodles and enjoy the ramen broth. This worked out nicely because I am not able to eat the fish sauce that the soba noodles come with, and actually like the ramen broth better anyway. They were always so kind about it and made me feel like it was no problem to make the change. The last time I went in (a week ago) I was informed that they would no longer make any substitutions, regardless of food allergy. I gently asked to speak to the manager, just to see if we could strike a deal, and they came back to the table to say that they would make an exception "this one time, but never again". So, I got set to have the last bowl of soba ramen at Suzu, when another waitress came out to say that the owner's wife disagreed with her husband's response and they would not make an exception and would not serve me what I'd ordered. 

This in itself was a poor experience, but the waitress proceeded to tell us all about the owners and how they always disagree on things, and were particularly cranky on this day - all of which did not make me feel any better. She told me that the way I ate the soba noodles with ramen broth was actually wrong and didn't taste good, and then accused that I probably didn't care about Japanese custom (which I do! I just CAN'T eat gluten). She then said she'd be more than happy if we decided to leave, which we did. Its was the most blatant disregard for a gluten allergy that I have seen in SF, or anywhere I've ever traveled (even outside the US!). Not going back.
author: Rachael S.

description:
A bit of a wait during lunch... but so worth it!

Combo meal. Choose any "don" item (smaller size)  with a ramen (full size) for $10. I'm sold! Yadayada mean?!

I got the chicken curry don with a spicy negi ramen. The ramen broth was flavorful but a bit greasy with the noodles al dente to perfection. The ramen came with a spicy green onion concoction, chasu, and bamboo shoots.

This ramen place is more on the greasy side than MSG side.
I was told that they make their own noodles too.
author: Anna S.

description:
Good ramen noodle and soup!
I love that they have combo menu for lunch time.
For instance you can choose a noodle out of RAMEN, SOBA or UDON with a small donburi/rice bowl. 
The lunch combos seem to sell alot !

They also have all vegetarian soup for the noodle dishes, if you like to make sure the soup isn't animal based, just  ask!
author: Chacha M.

description:
Hip-Hip Hooray for tasty ramen!

Suzu features te-zukuri menrui (hand-made ramen, soba, and udon noodles), which is not altogether common in SF, even in Japantown.  This tiny and casual, but clean and comfortable noodle shop is in the Kinokuniya building, right next to the Kabuki movie theatre and downstairs from the fantastic Kinokuniya bookstore.  

I recommend first trying the standard, the classic cha-shu shoyu ramen (ramen with roast pork in soy-based sauce).  It's quite good here.  When you're feeling adventurous or want something different, try the ma-bo ramen.  It's the bastard combination of ramen with spicy ma-bo tofu and pork.  A little unusual, but tasty!  I wasn't a big fan of the kara-age ramen, the fried chicken gets a little soggy in the soup, so maybe ask for the chicken on the side.

I wouldn't say that Suzu does anything incredibly spectacular or wonderful, but it's a decent ramen shop with fresh noodles, conveniently located, inexpensive, and tastes like the real deal.
author: Todd E.

description: Chewy ramen noodles and always packed! Come early and come hungry :). But still not as good as santouka ramen ... Sigh
author: Janice M.

description: This review is just for the ramen. It was ok but nothing spectacular. I enjoyed my Sophie's crepe way more afterwards.
author: Helen Y.

description: I came here after being turned away by the Seating Nazi at Tampopo.  There is no crazy seating rule here.  Their ramen is above average.  Their chicken karaage is the best I've ever had.
author: Khac L.

description:
After much ado, I finally came here to check out one of the "best" ramen places in sf. *sigh* I'm still searching. 

The noodles are gummy. I don't really like this texture in my noodles, but my friend who went with me did. So to one his own. It wasn't so gummy that you could taste flour or that it would remind you of an italian pasta, but it is a gummy noodle. This is probably my one and only gripe that doesn't make this a great noodle shop. But to one his own, again, my friend thought it was great. 

They have mapo ramen! Yum. I like my mapo ramen with a thicker soup (just like I like my curry udon with a thick soup) but if you can't have the real thing, I'm happy to have something in the same arena. There isn't much tofu in this mapo which was also disappointing. But th soup is very good. Just spicy enough to remind you that you're eating mapo but not overwhelming. Also not super oily. Very tasty. 

We also got the agedashi. It was OK. I think I'm going to give up on the quest to find a better agedashi than gombei. Nothing seems to compare. 

Will I be back? Yes! Not for their ramen, but to try the karaage curry. That just sounds so delicious. Also, I'll be back on a really hot day for the soba which I almost got, but it was a chilly night and I wanted something to warm me up. 

Price was also reasonable. I'm not sure what people are expecting to pay for ramen but for being under 10 bucks, this is a pretty decent price.
author: Tray I.

description: Had the Mapo Ramen - kinda salty for my taste but I was so hungry I finished everything...it was tofu and ground pork sauteed and put into bowl of ramen - I personally don't like this type of noodle at Suzu but it was still good. I want to try the cilantro ramen next time if I go...Cilantro ramen sounds interesting...
author: Jamie T.

description: I just stopped by tonight to try out their Torikraage (fried chicken) ramen, and mabo ramen.  Both were very ordinary in my opinion.  San Francisco must be extremely ramen challenged if Suzu is considered one of the best in the city.  The only plus I could see in their ramen is that they seem to be quite hot when served, unlike some other places which serve lukewarm soup ramen.
author: Jim J.

description:
Eat here now.  Spicy mabo tofu ramen.  Go alone, so you can sweat and sniffle and be mildly embarassed in front of strangers - rather than a date, or well-mannered friends. 

I was recently stationed at the Kabuki theater for 2 weeks of film fest work, and ate many forgettable noodle-centric meals before managing to hit up Suzu during their sporadic hours of operation.

I now dream of porky chili-slicked broth and noodles.
author: Erin K.

description: Real good ramen.., will be back for sure. Price was a little on the high side.. Wish they have some combos that comes with a sides . Good place to have lunch
author: Fian A.

description:
guess the bowls should say how much chashu comes in it.  got the cha shu ramen and had like 5 extra pieces (vs the others with just one)
got a combo with mapo tofu, and the ramen bowl was just the right size vs. regular ramen order is quite large with a lot of noodle
the mapo tofu side bowl was strange -- like tea flavor initially, sweet, and followed by the spicy, but way too much corn starch thickening.
the ramen broth is solid, and the noodles are straight but thicker than average, thus a better bite.  overall, is satisfactory.  best ramen shops are not the city though.
author: Rob C.

description:
I ordered a bowl of vegetarian noodle soup and it was fantastic.
The broth was delicious, the tofu was smooth and perfect, the fresh vegetables were cooked to perfection, and at the bottom of the bowl an abundance of flavorful soba noodles.

5/12/06: We came back on a busy day with 3 times as many people and the waiting staff overlooked our name on the list and seated smaller parties who came later instead of us. We waited at least an hour before we were served, which was terrible. I think it was a mere oversight on their part, but be sure you keep them on their toes. At least the food was still just as good though. I'd still give them 5 stars for their food though but 4 stars now for that recent glitch in service. I'll be back for sure to give the benefit of the doubt.
author: Victoria F.

description: Since my original review, prices have gone up slightly, and portion sizes of sashimi have gone down, but it's still great food and a bargain compared to a lot of places in the city. I recommend it, but not as enthusiastically as I once did.
author: Emma L.

description: One of the best places to get ramen in the city.  Their chicken karage is really good too.  It's crispy on the outside and the chicken is juicy and tender.
author: Karen W.

description: Friendly and fast service. The fried chicken app was delicious...I slurped down my entire bowl of spicy ramen in less than 2 minutes. Either their portions are too small, or I am just scary...I think their portions are too small.
author: Mimi T.

description: Pretty good considering the location. The portions are big and for the price $8.95-$9.95 average for their ramen dish, you can't beat it. The establishment is a little small, and the wait can be long if you come after 6:30pm. Well, worth the wait and the staff are very polite and good service.
author: V. P.

description:
A bowl of noodle with ONE slice of pork??!!!  WHAT?!!  and I keep coming back....

WHY? Because the broth and the noodles are soooo darn good that it doesn't need more meat to make up for it.  Like my girlfriend often says, I wish they could give us more green onion....  

A spicy negi ramen and a bottle of Asahi were everything I needed on a cold rainy night.
author: Gigi T.

description:
I like Suzu because they offer not only Ramen, but a combo bowl with rice for under $10! I got my "Tokyo Ramen" with a Unagi Don on the side. The wait time was much shorter than the list of names posted. I think they left to go shopping in the plaza. You snooze, you lose!

Anyways, the noodles here are advertised as "hand made". They seemed like it. It was a little thicker than your standard ramen noodles, but it was good! They weren't too soft, and they had a nice chewy consistency. The soup broth was tasty, and to me, tasted more flavorful than most places (Tanpopo for one). There was a slice or two of Chashu, some bamboo shoots and some green onions. Tasty!

The Unagi don was, well.. you can't really mess up a Unagi Don, especially if you're a Japanese restaurant.

Over all, I had a great experience! It's a tad bit small, but I enjoyed the atmosphere. We were sitting on the outside of the restaurant, but passerby's just walked by us without stopping to stare or anything.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Very good lamen and takoyaki! The noodle could be a little harder but overall the taste was very good. Service was just ok.
Small restaurant so you will probably have to wait some 15 - 20 minutes to be seated.
author: Jack C.

description: Though it was a Friday evening, it was still relatively busy (it's always busy at this place).  We sat down after a 15 minute wait, which wasn't too bad.  I grabbed an order of the udon + tonkatsu combo.  The udon was pretty good, though the tonkatsu was kinda meh.  I do like the service and the atmosphere, as it seemed to be pretty chill amongst how packed it was overall.
author: Ren L.

description: Have heard about this place for a while and was warned about long lines so we were happy when our wait was only about 5 minutes.  I had the udon and unadon combo - very happy with the texture of the udon and the unadon was delicious too.  Even the house red wine wasn't terrible.  They forgot to bring our edamame out and charged us for it, but other than that, the experience was positive.
author: B. Y.

description:
I'm always a little afraid of the places in Japantown, but I decided to drop in.  it's very clean, reasonably priced and although there was a wait, everything moved a long quickly.   I'm leaving a little room for improvement as I felt that my ramen could have had more meat and stuff in it and the Udon could have been more flavorful, but I'll be back.

** Edited to add**Had to deduct another star as everyone I ate with suffered  GI problems that night (and the next day) and this is the most likely culprit...
author: She-Ra ..

description: This is the way a ramen house in Japan would make it. Authentically delicious.  Hand made noodles and rich, savory broth made from scratch.  Although at first it may seem like they are a little skimpy on the meat, you realize by the time you're done with your bowl that you are filled and satisfied.
author: Rita S.

description:
OK, so I'm not some Japanese uber ramen connoisseur and this is probably not *the* best ramen place ever... but what can I say?  I like it here.

And judging from the long line on Saturday mornings (many of the folks Japanese, older ladies with impeccable hair out for noodles with their bosom buddies, teenagers, some families with small children), I'm not the only one.

It's clean, the ramen is fresh, the broth is hot with those oil jewels floating on top next to the pork slices, the presentation is simple.  I like the warm decor, the beautiful wide bowls the noodles come in, and the price is right (you can get out for under $10 at lunch).

I always get the same thing:  Spicy-Negi ramen, sometimes with a maguro-don for the lunch special.  

This is a good hangover fix, by the way.  Stagger out of bed, get yourself there, and hold your head in one hand as you feed yourself with the other.  Don't be afraid to get close to the steaming bowl.  Take it all in.  Bask in the aromatic ramen facial.  You'll feel better soon.  I promise.

Arrive at 11:30 (e.g., before noon) or else get stuck in a long line; the place is small (maybe 12 little tables or so) and people take their time eating.
author: Coleen B.

description: I thought it couldn't get better than this, but ramen is "meh".  anyone know if the ownership has changed??  When I order seaweed salad, I want seaweed, NOT cheap lettuce mixed in with seaweed.  Trying to make more $$ and giving less food?  And please, please...teach the ladies who seat patrons that 2 people at a table for 4 really doesn't make people waiting happy...especially if the 3 people right behind the 2 has to be seated at the table for 2!  get it together!
author: Sonia C.

description:
3.5 stars

I like this place because they have Ma Po Ramen and being a big fan of Ma Po Tofu, the spicy broth hits the spot. 

I like the place more than the other J-town spots and so did my friend but it's still not all that.

Restaurant is small and I'd guess fits about 20? so you'll most likely have to wait on the weekend. They also have tables outside but not the best atmosphere.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description:
I came here last week with my friend, on saturday afternoon, and to no surprise, I had to wait.  I put my name on the list, which surprisingly went pretty fast.  

The place is a bit small but cozy.  There are seats outside and in.  The waitress seemed as though she came right from Japan, which added to the experience.  

I ordered the CURRY DON (rice and curry) and RAMEN (delicious) combo for **GASP** $9.99 only!  

The Curry was the best I have ever tried.  The Ramen was just as good!  I will come back here again and often.
author: Nick L.

description:
This place and Katanaya are my 2 favorite ramen places in SF.  The broth is fantastic, and the portion size is just right.  I generally get the spicy ramen with tofu and it always hits the spot.  Their broth has a deep, rich flavor and the noodles are the perfect size and tenderness.  Highly recommend it. 

I've had various sushi don, which have also been very good.  The fish has been consistently fresh and the rice is perfectly seasoned.  Just writing this review makes me want to go back!
author: A J.

description: Had the Spicy Ramen...the broth was spicy, tasty and good.  The sliced pork that is included in this dish was a bit saltier than I like.  The noodles were nice and chewy the way I like it.  Overall a good dish and I would recommend it.  The service is good and attentive.  I would come back and try this place again.
author: Mao K.

description:
Got there at 11:40AM and still waited for a table.  The staff already looked tired.  The place feels dark, cold and uncomfortable.  

Ramen and broth were tasty, but not quite enough to make you feel satiated.  Gyoza side dish came out 20mins after our Ramen.   

If this is the only Ramen joint in JTown, ok.  However, I think Bush-Tei Bistro's Ramen is much a much better option without the wait.  It's just around the corner from Suzu.
author: I have something to say... A.

description: This place used to serve a very decent ramen. Somehow the quality has gone down hill.  I had the Ramen Combination with Katsu Don.   The ramen broth was salty and flavorless,  It almost had the taste of instant ramen. The katsudon was good but very heavy. My wife had the udon combination with  Ton Katsu. The broth was also very salty and the udon noodles had also the instant udon  texture. The Ton Katsu was average . I believe Katana-Ya downtown is now a much better choice for ramen in San Francisco.  It is a shame, as the service and the ambience  at SUZU  is still very good.
author: Victor S.

description:
Its cold outside and no one knows your name....
What do you do?

Go to Suzu!

Great ramen and donburi combos at lunch for $9 and worth every penny, me laddy.
author: Tak H.

description:
Mugicha. Delicious fatty eel ontop of excellent rice. Rockin karagee chicken. Homemade ramen in a mild wonderous broth topped off with bits of fatty fried pork fat (which I would ask for on the side because it tends to get soggy rather fast). Great price, hot meal, rock. Oh also it's very small so you might have to wait a bit..

Not the best ramen I have ever had..the service was decent-ish..I give it 3.5 stars - worthy of going back to if only for that eel..man that was yummy
author: Natalie G.

description:
Hands down, the best Japanese noodles I've had in town. In J-town, for regular J-cuisine, I would go to Kui Shin Bo, but for noodles, I go here. 

The soup is definitely above average, maybe even great. But I am so mesmerized by the quality of noodles I chew in this place. Both udon and ramen noodles have very good quality here, so almost every time I pay less attention to the soup if it's a noodle soup.

One thing sure about the soup is that it was not impressive like Seafood Udon in Kirala.

I've ordered only 2 appetizers so far, and they were pretty good. But it was a little pricy, so there is 1 star deducted. Another reason for 1 star gone is some waitress wanted me to sit outside a couple of times, and it was just annoying.

But again, both hot noodle soup (udon and ramen) and cold ramen are great here and probably noncomparable to others in the town.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Went here after a spontaneous adventure to SF with some friends.  The wait is a bit long, but it is definitely worth it! 
I had the miso ramen and it was delicious.  My friend, who loves anything spicy, had the spicy ramen and was worried about it not being hot enough, but was definitely happy with her food.
Definitely a place to go back to
author: Kristen D.

description: Do not come at 8:31pm or later. Terrible Suzu during closing hour! First time and wanted to try this joint out. I got here right at 8:35pm on a Fri night (last night) and the place was full. When I was about to write my name on the waiting list board, it says CLOSED in big letters. I look at the waitress and asked if they are closed. Both looked at me and said we're closed. WTF!!! You refused service before closing time. Its only freakin 8:35pm! It says you're closed at 9pm! Horrible horrible service. I mean...its only a noodle joint. People eat quick. This is not a steak or fancy restaurant where there's a long wait. No one was on the waiting list when I walked in. Never had this happened when they refused service 25 minutes before closing. But I guessed only Suzu does. Even though I haven't tried their noodles. Never ever coming back. Stupid for closing early. Suggestion for the owner : most restaurants closed later during the weekends Fri & Sat. You should reconsidered and get more business.
author: Amy H.

description:
The good - excellent noodles. I had the spicy ramen, hubby had the Suzu ramen. Both were perfectly al dente with excellent broths.

The bad - they totally skimp out on the meat. Each of our bowls had exactly 2 small slices of pork in it. Mine had 2-3 bamboo shoots and 1/2 an egg. I guess it must be a very high margin business..
author: Priya K.

description:
I guess it's PMS time because I'm craving salt. When I crave salt I CRAVE ramen. It's like a ramen demon enters my body and all I can think of is ramen.

So far, I have not found a place to satiate the demon that is PMS. I thought Suzu would do it, but no. The noodles were nice and firm, but the broth was pretty bland. I got the chicken karaage ramen so I can't judge them on their pork in the ramen. The chicken karaage was good, they serve it separately in another dish.

I also ordered the gyoza - pretty good, nothing special though.

Hubby got the oyako donburi - man that was awesome! Good sauce. It's on the sweeter side but it was really good. If it hadn't been for this I would have given it two stars. 

The bill came out to around $30 not including tip. For ramen I guess that's expensive, but for a dinner out in San Francisco not bad. 

Service was good and quick. Would I go back? I don't think so. The search goes on.
author: Wendy B.

description:
This is sad.  I don't remember much about this dining experience...and it's only been a week and a half.  I had a bite of my mom's Tokyo ramen.  Ehh, it was okay. Not good enough for me to crave it like I crave Koraku in LA. I had the udon and unagi-don combo.  Again, not too memorable.  I think I inhaled it because I was starving after the 20min wait in this rinky-dink joint.   

Ah yes...now I remember why I wanted to write this review.  The bf found a hair in his cold udon.  Not just any hair, but the kind you really don't want in your food.  That was enough for me to not want to go back.  

Oh and the service?  Let's just say despite the hair incident, I probably won't go back for that either.
author: Yvonne C.

description: Lots of choices for ramen but if you have a bigger party than 2; expect a wait.  The soup is flavorful and the ramen chewy; the chicken kaarage was delicious!  I've also tried the chasu ramen and they are not skimpy with the chasu.  Can't wait to go back!!!
author: judy l.

description: Awesome Ramen or Udon!  My husband and I just love this place, okay-so does our 2 yr old, ha. There is a steady stream of people who come to eat here. That to me says how good the food is.  I am thrilled to live walking distance to this place. I love SF's Japan town, this place offers steaming hot giant bowls of heaven, filled with fresh veg, meat tender noodles, tasty broths...comfort! A great compliment to our cool-foggy days, oh- yes please!
author: Jeneal J.

description: I tried the mapo tofu and it was really starchy.  I'm not a big fan of starch covered food so the texture turned me off.  Flavor was good, spicy and salty.  I think you can get much better elsewhere.
author: Frank M.

description:
Here is the deal.

Who does not like ramen from the package? It's my guilty pleasure- however, at Suzu it is the real deal. 

Great place to go before catching a movie at Kabuki. 

Service:
Although there tends to be a line- the service is quick and the food comes out fast so the line never seems to last more than five minutes.

Atmosphere:
The place is small and in a mall. Don't let that detour you. The restaurant is dark and has a nice black decor. You don't realize the place is in a mall at all. (I feel a little like Dr. Seuss).

Price:
$8.75 for ramen- most dishes come with chicken or pork and vegetables. You can order a side of rice and appetizers for a very reasonable price. The ramen portions are large enough to share.

Parking:
http://www.japantownparking.com/Rates/

Enjoy!
author: Aaron A.

description:
(Rating is for the ramen.)

Why aren't there any decent, dedicated ramen-only joints in SF? I have my conspiracy theories on the matter, but that's beyond the scope of this review.

At any rate, I've basically given up on eating ramen in this fair city, but I let my guard down the other day and checked out this restaurant in a moment of low blood sugar level induced weakness.

The broth was a big letdown for me. For me, this is the litmus test part of the ramen experience, apart from the noodles themselves.

The shoyu-base soup tasted like it was made from a commercial base. It didn't have the complex depth and character that would come from hours of cooking ingredients in a gigantic stock pot- a common sight found in typical ramen joints in Japan.

The eggy ramen noodles were fine. Nice and predictable.

The fixin's like the chashu and menma were regulation issue. Nothing to write back to mom about (besides, I wouldn't recommend this place to my mom).

I didn't try out any of their garden-variety soba/udon/donburi dishes. I'm sure that they're nice (how can you mess up simple dishes like that?), based on seeing other happy diners chowing down on them at the restaurant.

Bottom line- don't go to Suzu for their ramen if you're expecting a lot from your ramen experience.
author: Bono B.

description: Good ramen, they have a good variety of ramens and other various soups and donburi's. The portions of the ramen was pretty filling. I ordered the Suzu, assuming this is there best one considering they put their name on it. It had bamboo, scallions, wakame, boiled egg, pork, fried Gyoza and fried chicken. Love me some fried, so it was great in the soup. Also I ordered spicy, which can be pretty intense for some but it was great for me. Overall it's a good place if your in japantown town.
author: Christopher P.

description:
On certain cold, misty San Francisco summer nights, a hot bowl of Ramen can really warm you up. This restaurant is small and there tends to be a wait, but it is very convenient to eat here prior to a movie at Kabuki.

I ordered their Pork and Vegetable Ramen. I liked how there were fresh veggies, tofu, and lots of pork in the huge bowl. The broth was much too salty and (msg?), so that was the only downfall. 

Overall, I'd come back here for a pre-movie meal on a foggy, cold night. The portions were large, service was friendly, and prices were very decent.
author: Laura D.

description:
Half hour wait at 2pm.

Hostess' black shirt read "hooters" in fake rhinestone.

They fucked up our order (brought us an extra veggie ramen) and the calculation of the bill (too little... but we were good citizens and corrected them... because...)

Best ramen of my brief and ignorant life!

I had the spicy negi (green onion) and my two friends had the shio (tart and zestFUL) and karaage (fried chicken).  Each of our broths had a completely different flavor.  Karaage was a little more default, though I suppose this was to appreciate the texture of the tempura chicken more.  Mine was super spicy as I'd hoped.

Each of the non-chicken ramens only came with one slice of pork.  Other reviews lament this - to me, it made me appreciate it just that much more.  And it was a delicious mf tender piece of pork, too.  The fishcake thingies were perfectly resistant to the tooth and bursting with flavor.  The noodles were perfectly al dente and smooth as hell.  They came out all neatly arranged too.  

Would definitely jump at an opportunity to visit this place again.
author: Doug B.

description: This is my first time eating ramen noodle in Japantown. Compared to some other places I ate ramen at this place was pretty good. The noodles were chewy it gets softer chewy after leaving in the soup a while. The soup was great, felt it was a bit oily tho. Other than that I would recommend this place to go to if your ever in Japantown.
author: Allison W.

description: ramen and gyoza. pure food. the ramen broth served here is excellent. chicken karaage is very good too. i am reminded of the multitude of awesome ramen restaurants in Honolulu because of the quality of food here. a great newer restaurant in J-town!
author: Jeff W.

description: Good broth for the ramen - not too salty.  The place is clean and consistent, and the portions are just right.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I was expecting a lot more from this place knowing that it's in Japan Town and it's a noddle house but darn, what was I thinking????

Worst ramen I had ever in my life.  After having tasted kick-(_x_) ramen from Ippudo and other places in NYC, I was extremely disappointed with the broth and a roasted pork piece.

I doubt I will ever come back here again.
author: Ernie K.

description:
The summary:
Ramen is good and very hot, waitlist on a Friday evening is over 40 minutes to get in on the 8-9 tables they have there.   Service is very slow and overwhelmed as there are inexplicably only two waitresses there on weekends.

The Details:
Prices are quite reasonable, only 6.50 for a bowl of veggie ramen.  
9.95 or so for the combo Udon Donburi with a huge bowl of Ramen that accompanies that, so that's what I picked.  Trick is, the donburi had very little rice in it (I guess I am now used to American sized portions at the other 88% of Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area)., but yea, the Bowl of Ramen noodles was very tasty - excellent HOT broth and the noodles were of a nice consistency that I expect of hand-made noodle  shops.  The side of Sashimi (Maguro and Salmon) was small but good - reminds me of those authentically sized portions in Japan.

The Gyoza we ordered was tasty and good, but a bit on the greasy side.
 
Suzu is better than Santa Ramen, which is often slammed rightfully for the MSG, but well, just to even things out, here's a message to Suzu's management:

Suzu needs the following:
1) More waitress staff and more tables on weekends.   

2) You are wasting a good 25% of your precious floor space with that 12 foot long  blue corian counter that is just for looks.  Put some tables there, and hire an additional waitress fercryinoutlowd!!
 
OK.. back to the review.. 

No detectable MSG overload here at Suzu.  I still like Ramen Club in San Mateo better.  Koji is the MAN @ Ramen Club..

So there ya have it.
author: Harry W.

description:
Best noodle shop in SF, IMHO.

It's not big on atmosphere though.  My preferable way to enjoy this place is sitting by myself with a book.  Being a loser. That's right.
author: Matthew R.

description:
Ordered the chashu-ramen.  Thought the broth and the noodles were okay, but the pork was dry and tough.

This is still one of the better places to eat in Japan town so I'd still come back.
author: Lenniebelle E.

description: The noodles were nice and flavorful. A little to simple for me but my 18 months daughter loved it! The curry was not that nice. The staff was really nice and helpful.
author: Maria C.

description: Excellent Tokyo Ramen and Sea Salt Ramen ... But I think they use msg, which is unfortunate...
author: Thor Z.

description: Service here was horrible. One of the waitresses had a bad attitude with my group. She kept trying to rush us to order and was getting a little too impatient when it came to closing time. They even closed earlier than the closing time, so some customers were turned away from service. So the waitress was practically kicking people out when it came to closing time because she really didn't want to be there I guess. The food was mediocre. My ramen noodles weren't even mixed. It was still in a packaged form like the cook just dumped the pack of noodles in the bowl with the soup. They also don't do takeout.
author: Alicia L.

description:
Used to be - for a time - one of  the best Ramen in the city. 

Not anymore. Went there today and the Gyoza was still frozen inside. Mentioned this to the waiter and the gyoza came back soggy greasy and over cooked - they hadn't even bothered to give us a fresh batch. I passed - my wife ate one and was ill inside of the hour. 

The ramen was over -cooked and the hard boiled egg was cold. ...can't ever make fresh eggs in the morning...? 

This is on a slow Wed lunch so there was no 'we were really busy ' excuse possible.

Bottom line: Don't go. They got staff and health problems.

Really too bad - they were legit once. Time to find a new place.
author: Charles S.

description:
After several attempts to finally go to this place, it was open!!!  This place has weird hours.  It always seems to be closed.  It might be best to call ahead of time.  

Small and cozy, but I have to admit the ramen was darn good.  Its homemade ramen and broth.  Can't beat that!  Service was a bit slow, but its well worth the wait.  Great lunch and dinner specials.
author: Gina S.

description:
ANOTHER DISAPPOINTING S.F. RAMEN-YA

This might be a nice restaurant for other meals but I went specifically to test it out as a ramen spot, hoping that FINALLY, S.F. would get a halfway decent ramen restaurant. 

Not to be. 

It wasn't the worst I've had but it was decidedly mediocore. I got the karaage ramen lunch special (i.e. a bowl of plain ramen plus a side of karaage chicken).

First of all, the karaage was practically room temperature. That soured the experience right away, especially since the restaurant was not that busy when I got there. It wasn't inedible or anything but luke warm fried chicken is not a great look for the kitchen (or service...it's not clear whose fault it was). 

Second of all, the ramen noodles were fine, likable even. But the broth...a simple shoyu preperation...was dull, disappointingly so. A good shoyu broth should have be clean, with just the right amount of saltiness, and just a touch of richness (nothing approachicng a tonkatsu broth, but still, savory). This had none of those qualities. The first spoonful fell short of potential and it only went downhill from there. 

Alas, the hunt for the proper S.F. bowl of ramen continues.
author: Oliver W.

description:
I got the miso ramen.  The noodles were cooked just right: not too soft, not too hard.  The broth was great: tasty and hot.  Everything was great, except for the toppings and meat--which were skimpy (in variety and quantity).  It wouldn't break the bank for them to be a little more generous in this area.      

The tea was weak but free.  The service was fine on my visit. 

I've also been to Katana-ya and thought this was better.
author: David L.

description:
My latest stop on my Ramen quest led me to here. I was coming down under the weather quickly and convinced the gf that we should eat a hot bowl of noodles to make me feel better. It didn't work.

The place is small but not cramped. There were about 4 waitresses working and each one looked as if she hated her life, her job, and everyone else. Could a small smile really kill you? Apparently here, looks CAN kill. 

I ordered the chashu ramen and she got the usual miso. I had lots of cha shu but it just really didn't impress me. The noodles didn't have that bite, and the broth just wasn't what I expected. It was kind of plain. Only thing I really really like is that they give you the seasoned pepper to add. I don't exactly know what's in that can but damn once you add it to the soup, everything wakes up. And I had to add a lot of it, The gf took a single sip of soup from my bowl and wound up coughing her lungs out.
author: Derrick L.

description: This is my favorite ramen place in Japantown. Some people are more finicky about the broth, and some more with the noodles. I'm a noodle-person, and this place makes their own noodles, which gives it a fresher taste and more al-dente texture--just the way I like it. I usually order a shio broth whenever I eat ramen anywhere, and this place has the broth down. Not too salty, but hearty and warms you up from the inside out. :)
author: Emy s.

description:
Great noodle place with on-tap Asahi beer. Huge selection of different combinations of noodles,add-ins, spicy to plain, tempura and other add-ins. The Suzu Ramen or Tokyo Ramen with Tempura-don are our favorites. Very reasonably priced. 

Be prepared to wait 20 minutes on a light evening and 60 minutes at peak - they don't take reservations and the list can get long. Great desert place upstairs for afterwards...
author: Douglas K.

description: Both their udon and ramen are delicious. I just wish they wouldn't cheap out on the kamaboko (that pink and white fish cake thing)  and chashu (pork) pieces. For the price you pay, they should give more meat. The nabeyaki udon came with one piece of tempura shrimp, one piece of eggplant, and one piece of carrot. C'monnn.  Wish they validated parking here.
author: C. Z.

description:
At first it seemed kind of expensive (over $10 for udon??), but my friend and I were devoid of any new, fresh choices in j-town.  We picked Suzu because we'd both never been there, and we were both in a ramen mood.

Their dinner specials are a LOT of food - a hefty bowl of ramen (only a bit smaller than the regular bowls) plus something with rice and a choice of unagi, tuna sashimi, etc.  I ordered the maguro don combo, which was the fish, rice, and ramen (not.. combined in a bowl).  My friend ordered their Tokyo ramen, going off the theory that the first listing is usually their "signature" dish.

The ramen was pretty good - not as good as Tanpopo, but for the price (a meal around $20) + both of us really full = a good place to go back.
author: Tori S.

description:
My visit to Suzu had a rocky start. 

After waiting for about 20 minutes, the waitress called my boyfriend's name. We walked up to her, but the waitress, instead of guiding us to our seat, just looked at us, turned, and walked back inside and all the way into the kitchen. My boyfriend and I weren't even sure if we were supposed to follow her in or what!

After awkwardly standing around in the middle of the dining area for a minute or two, the waitress came back out so I asked her where we were supposed to be seated. She gave me a suspicious look, like she thought I was trying to cut in line or something. "Are you James?" she asked me. I pointed to my bf. She nodded curtly towards one of the tables, so we sat.

The same waitress then went outside again, brought another party in to be seated, handed them menus, brought them water and began taking their order... all before she'd even bothered to give my bf and me OUR menus! wtf! I ended up having to grab our own menus, since it was so difficult to get that dumb waitress's attention. 

Once my bf and I were ready to order, we once again had trouble getting our waitress's attention. She returned to the other party several more times as they added more food to their original order (twice!), and still we couldn't even get a glass of water or anything. By this time, I was trying to decide what would be more insulting to them--if we walked out, or if we stayed but left a $0 tip. 

I was beginning to lean towards the latter, when another waitress noticed us getting impatient and rushed over, apologetically thanking us for our patience. After that, I noticed this new waitress took some pains to give us proper attention, probably to make up for her associate's neglect, so I decided to forget the whole no-tip thing and enjoy the meal.

Which I very much did! I ordered the karaage curry, and my bf had the shio ramen. Both excellent. 

I liked that the karaage was very obviously homemade--and very hot and crispy too!--not like the frozen storebought kind that Shabu-sen peddles for a 200% markup. The chicken pieces were big too. One of them was as big as my hand. The portion size on the curry was good too. Combined with the salad and soup that came as part of the meal set, I couldn't even finish 2/3 of it. And my bf enjoyed his ramen. =) 

If there didn't always seem to be a line for this place, I'd definitely prefer this place over Sapporo-ya, for the karaage curry alone. But as far as the ramen goes, to be honest, I can't really tell the difference.
author: Yuffie G.

description:
I'll start off by saying how shocked I am to be seeing so many positive reviews for this restaurant.  We ventured in because it was abnormally hot day and the rest of the complex with stuffy and unventilated.

First off, service was extremely slow.  How long does it take to cook two bowls of ramen?  

What is even more shocking is when you see the contents of the bowls of ramen.  We had one order of the Shio Ramen where there was 1 tiny slice of pork, half an egg, half of a bok choy, and a few pieces of bamboo shoots.  The other order was for the Karaage Ramen which came with 3 pieces of chicken that were soggy despite being in a separate bowl and it also had the fried fatty parts that i wouldn't even feed to a dog.  Seriously though, how much does the other half of an egg or bok choy leaf cost? They can't spare enough to put in another piece of pork or chicken?  I seriously doubt the noodles cost a lot to produce....

I also noticed how many people have raved about the ramen.  Well our noodles came out all clumpy making it very obvious that it was not fresh.  The msg soup was also SO salty that I suffered from thirst for quite a while after I had the meal. I usually prefer the cloudy, natural broths.

When we finished the meal, i also felt the feeling of being rushed out.  I barely even had the chance to put my chopsticks down and the waitress was already clearing my bowls away. 

One little side note, we noticed there was a sink in the corner of the dining room.  It seemed very out of place being out in the open so close to a dining table.... but yes... this will be our first and only visit.  There are way BETTER ramen restaurants in San Mateo.
author: thb t.

description:
BAD!

I'm getting into these one word reviews, simply because I get too wordy otherwise.

It was so flavorless and the service was so rude that the lines to get a table are simply baffling to me.
author: Abby Z.

description: Had buttercorn ramen.  Bland, and hard boiled egg (I like the half-done ones).  If I want ramen again I'll go to Waraku, or until I find a better one in Japantown.
author: Peggy M.

description: Vegetarian noodle lovers beware, Suzu is not the place to get your fix. (I am sure the menu is fantastic for meat eaters as the place is always packed) There are 2-3 veg options on the entire menu, only one of them being a noodle dish. I ordered it, double checking to make sure the broth is not made with meat. I was assured it wasn't, only to receive something that looked exactly like chicken stock, bright yellow and greasy. Amidst the noodles were a few sad carrots and zucchini pieces floating in a heap of cabbage.
