I asked the server if the broth was for sure vegetarian, she kindly took it to the back to double check with the chef only reveal that what I am probably tasting is the MSG. Enough said.
author: Kylie S.

description:
I think that this is one of the best Ramen restaurants in SF.  
I did not give 5 starts because their foods are a bit salty for my taste.  However, great food for the price and good service.
author: Leo P.

description: 1st time we went, it was so yummy, so I went back again w/ a friend. Horrible. They have updated the menu so u can do combo. My friend had the Mabo Don. The sauce was like this weird jelly texture. There was globs of jelly like pieces. Must have been that the cornstarch wasn't mix in completely with the sauce. The ramen pork was extremely salty & the broth had no depth to it. No next time for me again.
author: Erica B.

description: This place is very good.  The wait can be a little long and they don't take reservations.  I'm not Japanese but my Japanese friends all seem to prefer this place over the other ramen houses in SF.  Wish they had a place like this in Oakland.  Guess I have to settle for the Vietnamese Pho (which is also pretty good but I digress)
author: Brian Divina M.

description: Overall my favorite ramen house in bay area so far. Ramen is always tasty, my favorite is the spicy Mabo ramen with tofu. Gyoza can sometimes be a little burned and the agedashi tofu was a little bland. Its a small restaurant and fairly popular so be prepared to wait especially on weekends. They do one thing well and that is the ramen.
author: Belle Madamoiselle Z.

description: Solid 3 stars . The food here is alright but not good enough for me to want to come back . I've had the mabo ramen , spicy ramen , and spicy negi ramen . All three seemed to lack flavor . The spicy ramen wasn't really spicy .  The noodles were alright but failed to impress me . I've also had the soba which tasted weird . I think soba tastes better cold versus warm . The soba tasted terrible ... it was super salty ! I ordered the soba with the salmon don which was no good . Both the salmon and the rice did not taste good . The rice was cold and did not taste fresh . The salmon was mushy . The gyoza was very disappointing . They were super small and did not taste good at all . The chicken karaage was good but a little too oily .
author: Eileen L.

description: I have been going to Mifune for roughly 35 years and I just tried Suzu, the soup flavour is superior. I just wish they had more beer selection. If you go with kids, go early so you can score a table, the place is small.
author: Sarah S.

description:
My favorite ramen place in the city. It's very small and gets busy on the weekends, but it's definitely worth the wait.

I always get the regular ramen and order appetizers on the side (the chicken karaage is my personal favorite). They are a little stingy with the edamame, but at least they're served hot and with a lot of salt. Who doesn't appreciate sodium? 

The service is sometimes on the slow side, not because they're unattentive, but because they often only have one or two waitresses at a time. 

And no matter how full I get, I always head up to Sophie's Crepes afterwards!
author: lindsay w.

description:
In my previous review, I said I'd like a little more variety.  It'd been a while since I've eaten there, and they've added more noodles.  Or maybe they added some, and I just never took the time to look, just sticking with my standard, spicy negi.  In any case, I went today and noticed  Shio and Tokyo for the first time.  From the description, Tokyo looked like it might be actually tonkotsu (which isn't from Tokyo at all!), but it was something else.  But, both of the additions were delicious.  Still sticking with the same subtle style.

The sad part is, it seems like the word is getting out, and there's always a line when I go by.  So, if you read this, go, but get in, enjoy your noodles, and get out.
author: masa s.

description:
Only one thing going for this place, really: it's close to the front door.

The noodles and broth are acceptable. Everything else is well below par -- stringy, low quality chicken in the karaage, gyoza not fit for a restaurant, etc. Small amount of broth, so don't expect to be full on one bowl if you're hungry.

These are Chinese people serving Japanese food in the Japan Center(why??), and sadly they really don't care about the quality. Go to katana-ya instead.
author: Nick C.

description:
MAY 2012...

NEW owner, NEW menu, new REVIEW...equals minus tree stars

don't do it....the shrimp was the worst part and it just is NOT the same deal..but
the crowds are gone so...get a table and check it out yourself....


*********
Thought i'd reviewed this place already, but here's the quick:
good al dente soba (not overcooked and soggy like MIFUNE)

good separate plating of tempura (not the yummiest, but ok)

broth...ok.

Service...expedient...they want to churn those tables quickly.
author: miriam b.

description: One of my favorites! Service was quick, and ramen was delicious. Great broth, great noodle, but it was hard to find as it is inside the mall. I actually prefer Suzu over Tanpopo, which is just down the street!
author: D C.

description: A great place to get a noodle dish.  The ingredients are extremely fresh and the food is very flavorful.  It's a small place so expect to wait if it's prime time.
author: Mark G.

description: I'm not speaking for anything other than the ramen because that's all I travel over the bay bridge for, to get my fix of Suzu's Chasu Ramen. Very few things provide good enough reason to drag my family through the inevitable traffic and ungodly $5 toll to get to San Francisco, but Suzu is nonetheless a staple of our restaurant repertoire. The noodles are hand made and have an amazing texture that makes each bite so enjoyable. The broth tastes clean and is jam packed with beautiful porky flavor. The restaurant does have some down sides: It's tiny! so you will always have to wait and the service can take some time because it's so busy in there.
author: David Y.

description:
I love Suzu. The space is small and serves noodles hot or cold. Your noodle choices: ramen, udon or soba. 

Appetizer: The chicken karaage is fantastic.

Best thing on the menu: Lunch combination. This is the best value! For 8.95 - get a regular sized serving of ramen, udon or soba and a side of donburi with your choice of tuna or salmon sashimi, pork cutlet, curry, or unagi.  At dinner you just pay one more dollar for the same thing. Its awesome!

Yes the broth is salty - so drink plenty of tea and water in the hours after eating at Suzu.
author: Judy L.

description:
finally got around to trying this place.  Everything is really just okay from the food to the service to the price.  Ramen soup was mediocre.  Not great, but it doesn't taste nasty.  We could finish the entire bowl, so it wasn't that bad.  
I had the cold ramen with pork and the pork was actually pretty good.  Crispy with a little bit of fat in it to make it juicy.  It was also fried to the right crispiness.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Suzu is by far the best ramen I have had in  the Bay Area.  Their Tokyo Ramen was just what I needed on Saturday afternoon - tasty, clear broth, chewy noodles, charsu meat that melt in your mouth, accessoried by a few braised bamboo shoots and half an egg.  My only complaint is their stinginess on the meat.  It was literaly one slice of 2x2 inch,  1 mm thick of meat.  What a teaser!  

Nevertheless, I love this place!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
On a cold Saturday, my friend and I were on a hunt for a hot bowl of noodle soup. We passed by this "noodle house" because it was cheap and empty. We both ordered this iron pot dish with udon and fish cake galore. The picture in the menu was so enticing. But the flavor was not so much. Aside from the noodles being incredibly overcooked (seemed like those cheap packets of udon you can buy for $0.50 cents), there was this one fish cake with a gooey white inside that reminded me of a man's orgasm wrapped with tofu skin. It coated my mouth in a very unsatisfactory manner. Not even semi-luke warm tea could wash it away. Sure, the iron pot dish offered a variety of fish cakes but that was all it offered. 

Now to the worst dish of all. I ordered some "steamed shrimp dumplings" and instead got store bought and over cooked chewy dime sized dumplings. I've eaten these before when I bought a packet from 99 Ranch because they were on sale for $1.99. They were so disgusting. Best part? They charged you $6.00 for 5 little tiny dumplings.

I won't go into the terrible service because the food says it all.

After we sat down and started eating, we noticed a huge line outside. I don't know why this place gets crowded. Oh yeah, there are like no seats in this small "restaurant." They could barely handle two parties of 5. Thankfully, they're out two customers. I'm never coming here again.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Best ramen I've had in a while and the service was fast. No complaints here ! Would definitely go back again.
author: Nelson T.

description:
So I kept hearing hypes about this place, and I finally had the chance to try it the other day.

I can definitely say that this is the best place for ramen in J-town.  However, it remains 3 stars, for many reasons.

1) I went there around 12:30, on a weekday and I had to wait almost 25 minutes.  There were 2 girls waiting the tables, and somehow, considering how small this place is, they seemed to be overwhelmed and having a hard time keeping up with the turnover of the tables.

2) There were many party of 1s and 2s... however they would seat a party of 2 on a 4 ppl table and would not ask or offer to share the table with another couple.  It's a pretty common thing to do in many small and busy eateries, but not here... you gotta wait in frustration as you stare at the old ladies chatting and sitting there 20 minutes after they finished eating.

3) I accidentally left my cell phone on the windowsill of one of their "outside" tables.  I noticed and headed right back, and asked one of the waitresses if they've seen it.  She goes "what kind? Oh, no, sorry" without checking with the other girl, the table I was at, or in the back.  I looked around myself, emptied my purse to confirm I didn't have it, and went over to her again so I can at least leave my contact info in case they found it.  The other waitress overhears this and she goes, "oh, cell phone?" and pulls my phone right out of their security/lost and found box.  You'd think the other girl could've been nicer and at least followed protocols and check in that box? Duhhh.

4) I ordered ramen & tuna bowl combo lunch.  When I ordered, I asked the waitress if the rice for tuna bowl was seasoned or not.  She said that she thinks that they use seasoned rice for tuna bowl... which is why I ordered this set.  WRONG!  Ramen was pretty good, but tuna bowl was a tiny bowl of steamed, somewhat mashed up rice (NOT seasoned/sushi rice) with pieces of tuna (and they had the stringy part of the fish) with soy/mirin "sauce" drizzled on it.  

Now, as a Japanese, I have some pet peeves about the way they serve these tuna bowls.  Plain steamed rice is sometimes used... but mostly when we make them at home in busy households when they don't feel like seasoning it or don't have the time to.  If you get good tekka-don at good restaurants, the rice is seasoned.  Just like sushi.  Even if it's not seasoned, we Japanese (at least Japanese from Japan) are really anal about the quality of rice.  It needs to be not too hard, not too soft, and we should be able to see each grain of rice  all shiny and perked up in the bowl.  So when I get a bowl of rice with some mashed up parts, it makes me cringe... because it means that they either do not understand the nature of rice, do not respect or take pride in what they are presenting, or, they do not know how to fluff the rice properly once they're steamed.

Then, the whole pieces of tuna with sauce on top thing... in my book, tekka don is made of soy/mirin marinaded tuna called "zuke".  Literally means "to soak".  Tuna is supposed to sit in the marinade for a bit so they have good saltiness of the soy sauce and sweetness of mirin infused in the fish before they put them over rice.  Marinade for a couple of hours would be great, but even 30 minutes will really make a difference.  So when I got pieces of tuna with some "sauce" on top, it felt lazy to me.  Also the tuna pieces... You know how there are yummy, perfect textured tuna that's all red, and then occasionally, there are those that have more stringy/fibrous look?  Well, this on was the latter.  When I shop for tuna, I specifically look for ones that don't have these white striped look, as they can often be chewy and not as good as the consistent looking ones. I only care to buy the striped looking ones if I was gonna cook it, i.e. a tuna steak.  So having this quality of tuna served raw up in a bowl was a no-no for me.

In short, I will come back here if I am in J-town, craving ramen, and willing to wait a long time for it.  But I will not recommend getting their dons involving raw fish... and if I weren't in J-town, I would be going to Katana-ya in downtown instead and would not bother coming to J-town just for the food at Suzu.
author: Sascha O.

description:
suzu is so-so.  i prefer katana-ya.   got the tokyo ramen with tofu instead of pork slices.  noodle texture was good, broth was just fine.  i would've really liked more seaweed and bamboo though - although they were fairly generous (for a ramen shop) with the tofu.

gyoza were tasty, but not extraordinary.  for what you get, the prices could be cheaper ($40 for 2 people).
author: Priscilla T.

description:
numerous friends have told me this is the best ramen in japantown.  i beg to differ.  i haven't found the best ramen in japantown yet, but suzu isn't it.  

Every time I've come here the restaurant has been full, so we've had to write our names on the list and wait 30-60 min. for a table (everyone wanting to eat here should mean it's the best, right?).  They have a fair number of choices, and I've sampled about 5 of the ramen options by now.  They're decent.  The homemade noodles may work for you, but I found them too thick and eggy in at least one of my ramens.  The sauces for some of the options are pretty bland, which is fine if that's what you're in the mood for and want to concentrate on the flavor of the other ingredients, but I like my broth with a little kick.  The broths that do have a kick, though, don't necessarily blow me away on the flavor.  

At least the portions are plentiful.  And one time we were excited by the fact that our hard boiled egg halves were a matching pair!  yes, we are a fun lunchtime crowd.

waiting an hour for decent ramen isn't worth it to me, so alas my search for the best ramen in the city continues...
author: Anne Marie B.

description: They should change the name of this place.  Everything is different.  The noodles are NO LONGER MADE IN HOUSE.  Horrific though pleasant service.  Brought out my friend's ramen before tofu and kimchi appetizer.  My dish came out 15 min after the ramen of my friend.  Soba was generic.  Suzu is dead.
author: Sam V.

description:
My friend took me to Suzu noodle house for my bday dinner because this place was recommended to her by her friend.  We got there on a Thursday night at 8:30pm.  There was a waiting list and we were about to put our names on the list when a waitress came out and told us they are closed.  The waiting list even said closed.  We looked at the times and it said the restaurant closed at 9pm and it was only 8:30pm.  

We pointed this out to the waitress and she said we can put our names on the list and wait for a table but she can't guarantee that we will get a seating.

We decided to wait.  During our wait, there were at least 10 people who walked by and wanted to put their name on the waiting list and they were all turned away.  It wasn't even 9pm yet.  It was around 8:40pm. They were turning away potential business!

All the workers looked like they wanted to go home and didn't want to serve any more customers.

Also, during our wait, the waitress came out and took our orders so that by the time we sat down, we would have our food.  We were seated at about 8:50pm and our food came out quickly after.  We even got our bill right after we got our food because they said that they are closing their cash register so we had to pay right away.

Again, more people wanted to eat at the restaurant because their sign said they closed at 9pm!!  

In the end, the cha-shu ramen wasn't that good.  The pork was hard and dry and looked like it was stuck in a microwave.  The ramen broth wasn't even that hot and was warm.  They obviously rushed the preparation because everyone wanted to go home exactly at 9pm.  I was really disappointed in this place.

My friend gave them a 30 cent tip which was worth more than they deserved.  I recommend skipping this place.  They obviously don't care about customers and turned away business.
author: Chloe A.

description:
I used to live in Japan so I'm always looking for a good ramen-ya. This place did satisfy, not exactly like a bowl of ramen in Japan but good and one of the better I have found in this city.

CAUTION: I had the spicy ramen, it was good! But because I ordered it with the veggie broth, the price was almost double increased. 1 bowl of spicy ramen with miso veggie broth was (ouch!) $16.00! I was happy with the ramen but a simple bowl of spicy ramen shouldn't cost $16.00! :(

Also I added green onion - that turned out to be a $2.00 charge (???) in Japan a bowl of ramen always comes with green onion - here they charge $2.00? Someone in charge of pricing food units isn't using the formula all restaurants use, they are just coming up with prices arbitrarily and gauging customers. That never feels good. I would say the noodles were good but I didn't like the surprises on my bill at the end. :(
author: lydacious p.

description: I don't write reviews often but had to in this case. Suzu used to be one of my favorite ramen/udon spots to go to. They changed ownership. Not sure when, but I asked the waitress to confirm it. Food is way less fresh and authentic now. I won't be going back unless someone points a gun to my head.
author: justin u.

description:
Mediocre ramen at best. The broth selection is pretty limted. Most of the noodles come with the pork & chicken broth which is not memorable at all. 
The big disappointment was that the noodle didn't come with all the ingredients listed on the menu. I ordered the Karage Ramen which should come with Japanese friend chicken, sea weed, bamboo shoot, BBQ pork and boiled egg. And since I don't like soggy friend chicken, I asked to have the friend chicken on the side.

When my order arrived, I noticed that my BBQ pork is missing (yes, my meat is very important to me) and when I asked the server, she basically told me they never put BBQ pork in the noodle and walked away. 

Well, if the noodle doesn't come with BBQ pork then you should probably not list that item on the menu or at least cross it out if you no longer serve it. 

And when my bill arrived, I noticed I was charged 50 cents extra for my noodle, so obviously I asked the server why the price difference and then she proceed to tell me that they charge 50 cents for everything that's asked to put on the side.

And again, if you are going to charge something extra, you should probably either list it on your menu or at least inform the customers about the extra charge when you are taking the order. 50cent is probably nothing but it's not a good feeling that they charge you extra for pretty much nothing!

So my conclusion is, I would not go back there any time soon for their average so so tasting ramen.
author: S L.

description:
Came here once after happy hour on market in a famished state.  I had seen it so many times in passing thru Jtown and it always seems busy.  My thoughts were that it must be good, right?  But then again, none of my friends had ever recommended it.  All I ever heard of was Santa Ramen in San Mateo.
Well, I finally got to try it.  It was tasty.  Price is ok I suppose.  And certainly it was filling.  But it doesn't compare to Daikokuya in Little Tokyo in LA.  That place is truly the bomb for me still.  But i would still come here again!
author: Cary L.

description: Me and the manfriend came here for ramen after I had an interview in SF. Honestly, throughout the whole interview, the only thing on my mind was eating ramen. I came here once before but I wasn't Yelping at the time. I totally reclaimed this place with Leejay. He ordered the Buttered Corn Ramen. I don't even have to say anything about that. Just look at all the other past reviews & you'll see what all the hype is about. Buttered Corn Ramen. Just the name sounds delicious. I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen which is the one with the creamy broth. This was super tasty. Comparable to Shin Sen Gumi (which i love!). The serving was a good size, too. Alongside our ramen, the gent suggested the Mabo Tofu Donburi. I've never had this before, but I am so glad I did. I love spicy food, so this really hit the spot. It's basically spicy tofu w/ minced pork in chili sauce served over rice. Agh! I could really go for some of that right now.
author: Krystal A.

description: Suzu noodles... How much longer can you really last? We ate a few bites n had to just pay the tab n leave. Well, I had a few bites. My date didn't even want to take a bite. A SUPER thick layer of oil in the soup, a different staff, a different attitude, a different recipe, a different menu. Even your appetizers were not mediocre enough to be served.  Ika tempura... it was more like onion and red bell pepper tempura.  Furthermore the temperature of you oil must have been a bit off because it was awfully oily.  You ran out of beef... didn't know that would be possible given that it is one of the main toppings offered.  The bamboo shoots... someone tell me that I'm wrong because I swear the bamboo shoots looked rather rotten... black?!?!  And there was a horrid stench.  You must've bought the restaurant but failed to get the proper recipe from the orginal owner... Furthermore it is clear that you are using noodles way inferior to the previous ramen. You need to change the name of your ramen shop because it's doing a huge injustice to your predecessor.  If there was any way to give less stars you'd definitely see it.
author: Colin M.

description: I love the noodles there!!!! The noodles r on the chewy side, but it is still good texture. The broth is sooo good, mayb its alittle salty, but it went well with the noodles!!!
author: Shawn I.

description: I don't know what everyone is rambling about but the Tori Udon I ordered was great. Udon noodles in general is one of my favorite foods. It had enough pieces of chicken in the soup to satisfy me and the noodles itself was great. I kinda like that seaweed thing they had in the soup. I'm not that great with chopsticks but I made sure I finished all the noodles and pieces of chicken. It was that good. PS it's not that uncommon to see cooks that are not of the ethnic food in the kitchen...
author: Gerard Y.

description: This is my go-to noodle place!!  I always bring out-of-town guests here, and they always love it!  Pretty much everything is good.  I love the Kara age ramen, but then again, I love just about every ramen!  There's a wait a lot of the times on weekends, but it's worth it.
author: Vero K.

description: This will always be my favorite ramen place. The texture in the noodles does not compare to any other place that I have been to. Service is always super regardless of how busy they can get. I came in here swasted after the xox experience event, and the waitress was still nice to me even though i asked her a stupid question haha.
author: Toro C.

description: perfect hangover remedy. the chicken karrage is my jam. i want it now.
author: Shayna M.

description:
Difficult to get a table, show up right when they open and you'll be a-ok.

I stick to the basic ramen everytime I come here. Can't go wrong with it. The thing that sets it apart from other places for me is.... THE NOODLES.

Be cautious with the spicy ramen, it is no joke.

If you've got room for other food, the combos are fun. You can get a side of another entree in addition to your ramen. They're not as good as the ramen, so don't get your hopes up.

I can't stress enough that key is showing up right when they open. Otherwise make sure that you're not starving because you will be waiting.
author: Angela T.

description:
(+) side:
clean place, nice dining space and lighting even if small
freshly made noodles with good texture
nice waitstaff

(-) side:
slow food, don't go during dinner rush (like when i'm most hungry)
soup was lukewarm

summary- overrated. go somewhere else nearby, lots of places serve good hot noodles w/o being an actual noodle house.
author: Loocha L.

description:
Every time i come across Suzu there are many people are waiting. if during dinner rush you should wait at least 20 mins. Then place is crowded.
i ordered a combo special. there were Ramen and tuna rice. taste is not bad. it is enough for a girl who are really hungry. i will visit again.
author: C.H H.

description: Wow, their ramen ROCKS. The best in the Bay Area. The texture of the ramen is outstanding. The wait may be long, but well worth it. Their $ is not bad for restaurant in J-town. Suzu is my ATF ramen place.
author: Will H.

description: Loooove this place! the Ramen bowls are sooo big and well priced too--especially since one is about two meals for me. ^-^ The food is delicious and they have a really good lunch special-- bowl of ramen and your choice of a smaller bowl of any don you would like.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Pretty good ramen and quick food on the ground floor of the Japan Center mall. Atmosphere is nicer than the upstairs noodle place, and the service is very sweet. 

They'll let you order the lunch specials at dinner time -- a small portion of things like tempura-don or katsu-don, plus a giant bowl of noodles (your choice or ramen, udon or soba) bigger than your head -- for an extra $1 more. You'll have more food than you can eat for under $10!
author: anita c.

description:
Exactly what I needed on a cold sick day...some warm ramen with very tasty broth!

It was my first time trying this place and I think it's pretty good. I ordered the Tokyo Ramen which came with chicken and pork broth, half an egg, 2 pieces of pork, green onions and one veggie. The bowl was a decent size since I got full off it, but it was mainly noodles and broth, not much meat or veggies. We also ordered the gyoza which came with 5 small potstickers- nothing that really amazed me though.

This place may be a bit skimpy on the meat and veggies, but the broth is sure good and satisfying!
author: M W.

description:
This place has some good ramen,  I went wit a buddy of mine and we both got combo lunches.  I had the Ramen wit Curry and man was the Curry great.  I loved both tho.   It is good for small groups but not huge groups since it is a little cramped

Small place but it gets busy at lunch time

not too pricey  and the portions fill you

only disadvantage of this place is the wait time
author: Jonathan W.

description:
OK, ramen-philes, I feel that I should preface this review with this disclaimer: I'm an Asian-American that grew up in the Bay Area and have never visited Japan. I'm sure that's enough to have you skip over my review but ya know, whatever.

Ramen-fest 2008 kicked off here before forging its way down to the South Bay but that's a whole other story, so just follow along.

Suzu is the only ramen place that I've eaten at in San Francisco. I know, I know, how does this qualify as Ramen-fest then? The fest is still in continuation, that's how.

ANYWAY, Suzu's strongest point are their noodles. They're thick, fresh, and lovely to eat. I believe they're homemade and it shows. Perfectly cooked and not mushy. Nice and hearty. Some of the best ramen noodles I've ever tasted. 9 points. 

The broth is definitely their weak link but it's not bad. At least it has some flavor and is pleasant to put in my mouth from a spoon filled with noodles and seaweed (also known as an "ultimate bite"). 7 points.

The meat is delicious but perhaps because the economy is bad, they now only give you one skimpy piece. ONE! What a joke. So sad.

Extras... The gyoza is ok, nothing particularly spectacular. Same goes for the karaage. Small portions.

Value... I LOVE the combinations! You get a small bowl of goodness (usually rice / sashimi or katsu) plus a bowl of regular ramen! Only $1 extra to sub any of the other ramens. Good deal, in my opinion. I am always filled to the max. Although, I should mention they used to give you a FULL bowl of ramen, now it's just slightly smaller. Probably a good thing for me. As if I need any more carbs.

The service is decent and the ladies are nice. A little bit slow and forgetful at times but always friendly. Lots of variety on the menu which is another plus.
author: Salina Z.

description: Seafood ramen was OK, not great. The broth in the end by itself was good.
author: Yelp R.

description:
I walked past here randomly at 3pm on a Saturday, and there was a crazy long line. So I made a mental note to try this place.

Bottom line: tasty noodles but not super-noteworthy. There was nothing on the menu that was unusual or special, the prices were fine, the selection was good, but there wasn't a "wow I feel like standing in line for this place when the place 30 feet away has plenty of tables free" thing. You feel me?

Kim Chi - good, but what's it doing on a Japanese noodle joint menu? Oh wait, this isn't a purist's place, and that's fine by me.

Chicken/Veg Ramen: ok, so it's not the hardcore porky broth that everyone loves, but we were feeling chickeny so that's what we ate. Good broth, large-ish portion, but not enough veggies.

Cold Soba w/ Tempura: great chewy noodles. Tempura was crisp & light, just not enough of it.

So it's fine, but there are better places in Japan Center if you ask me. Admittedly, I should eat more dishes before I pass final judgement.
author: Al M.

description:
This place was a bit hyped-up for us so we ended up being disappointed. One of the waitresses was very dismissive but a younger one was fairly attentive.

I wasn't exactly impressed by the ramen, I actually prefer Iroha.
My love-buddy says nothing compares to the ramen stands in Japan but he was happy to see the female sous chef in the back and said the food was decent and tasted home made.
author: JaM W.

description:
Every time I've been here, which is about once every 1-2 yrs, things have been pretty tasty - I usually stick with the soba and udon soups which are pretty good, and their salmon sashimi don.     A friend who lives nearby seems to think they had a dip in quality over the past couple of  years but recently have been getting back to their early, hi-flying days.   

No experience with their ramen....
author: Tyler C.

description:
I'm ambivalent about this place.
Although it's not fair, I have a bias against Suzu because it happened to move into the space that once occupied a lady I dearly loved and fondly called "the mochi nazi".

Those of you who love manju+mochi (Japanese confections typically made from rice flour) know what I mean.  Not many places still take the effort to hand make this stuff anymore.  Most manju is usually imported from out of the country or made in factories with funky preservatives and chemicals to extend shelf-life (nasty).  On a tangent, one of the few places in SF still hand-making manju is Benkyodo (also in J-town).  As much as I like Benkyodo now, I never used to visit it very often because my loyalties always went to the mochi nazi.

She was an ancient Japanese lady who ran a manju shop where Suzu sits currently.  I would describe her as 4-foot nuthin', aged somewhere between 90 and 120, and all business.  Usually wifey and I would walk into her shop an order very quickly before that stone-cold glare would penetrate our skulls.  Typically, we'd have no idea what we ordered because we didn't want to dilly-dally in her presence and suffer her wrath.  She'd carefully hand-wrap our morsels in a plain cardboard box and send us off before we bothered the others in line.

I miss that dear nazi!!

What? Oh yeah, Suzu.
Went here a few months ago and then again recently.  They have a spicy tofu ramen on the menu and that combo always gets my juices going.  My first impression of Suzu was okay, that's why I came again to confirm.
Noodle consistency and quality is good.  Broth is a bit of a disappointment though.  Too salty and lacks complexity.  Their spicy tofu ramen is much too oily, a few slurps and my cholesterol shot up 30 points...

In short, Suzu might have scored higher if they hadn't displaced my beloved mochi nazi.
You heartless bastards!!!!!!
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Lovely miso broth; I am definitely a fan. 

But annoyingly their policy is not to take orders over the phone. That means they'll get a lot less lunch business from me, and I could do with more tasty ramen lunches in my life

Maybe we could start a Yelp movement to find Suzu an intern who'll staff the phone?
author: Juan C.

description:
That's some damn good ramen. I got it paired with Una-don, something that's not available everywhere. It was delicious. No complaints. Other combos enjoyed at our table included katsu-don and mabo-don all of which were delicious. 

They lost a star because they forgot our tempura appetizer. Shame shame. But they were very apologetic and wiped it off the bill with no fuss.
author: Dave S.

description: My man and I love coming here weekly, especially on cold summer nights My favorite is the Miso ramen but sometimes I opt for Veggie. Portions are big, gyoza and agadashi are a must. Only downside is they don't take reservations so be prepared to wait around.... overall, best noodles we have found in SF!
author: michelle h.

description:
Best Ramen in Town! Believe me, between me and my husband, we could eat ramen anyday of the week! Even his screen-name on some online forum is "noodle-eater" 

The consistency of the noodle itself is perfect. Not too chewy, not brittle, tasty enough, and compliments the broth.  Ok, imagine the taste of water mixed with soy sauce only. Got it? Well, this is faaaaaaaar from it! :p The broth is light and delicious, full with flavor. 

My husband always order the spicy Negi Ramen, and me the karaage ramen. Oh, you gotta order the Chicken Karaage (Deep fried Chicken nuggets). ... mouth watering,,,, *drool*..... :O~  
(Why you think I order the Karaage Ramen? ... so I can have more karaage chicken ;p )

The place is small, so understandably, you have to wait for a bit if it is mid-lunch-dinner time. (Just for fun, why don't you go play with the instant picture machine accross the restaurant while waiting?).
author: Kat S.

description:
Stopped in for lunch yesterday... And while the food was quite tasty, I was rather disappointed by the service.

I put down my name for a table for two... About 20 minutes later, they crossed my name off of the list and asked if we wanted to sit outside. I said "No thanks, we'd rather sit inside". So one of the servers wrote my name again in the same space. Some more time passes... and the party of three that was after me gets seated by a different server. Hrm. Something smells fishy here... So when they call the next party of two, I tell them that I'm still waiting to be seated, inside the restaurant. More time passes... and we're finally seated. The left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing.

You'd think this would easily corrected by allowing a space to write down "inside", "outside" or both, but that would be too easy. And yes, if I ever go back I'll do just that, but I was running on about 2 hours of sleep at the time and was just decidedly unamused.

Once the food arrived, it was good. The maguro was tender and the warm soba was a nice addition. If I ever venture back, I'll have to try the ramen. The food is worth 3.5 stars easy, but the service snafu knocks it down a full star to 2.5. Unfortunately, Yelp won't let me give half-stars, so I guess I'll be nice and round up to an even 3.
author: Albert C.

description:
Wait was a bear on a Sat night.  Somehow I missed my name being called even though I was right in front of the restaurant.  It's a small place, so ended up waiting a good half hour to forty five minutes.

I had the curry w/pork cutlet.  It was great.  The curry was spicy enough to enjoy without drinking a gallon of water and the pork cutlet was perfectly cooked.  Crispy and still tender on the inside. 

I sampled some of my friend's ramen.  Good, but how hard is it to ruin ramen?  8)

Service was good.  Waitress was cute.  A very good night...
author: H C.

description:
Sum up: A bunch of Korean people bring in good food to calif but forget they are serving people in the USA!! The food is not that bad, but highly NOT advised with that sort of service and attitude! Your $$$ can be better spent somewhere!!

**Okay food. (Tons of other better Ramen places in Bay area!) (i.e.: Ajisen Ramen on Warm Spring or Ramen Hulu on Saratoga Ave.)
**Long hours of waiting (aint' worth it! it ain't any 3 stars restaurants!)
**Lukewarm service 
 
I believe there is something called "Customer Service" in California; but obviously this thing doesn't exist in this Korean-waitress-ran Ramen place. This is the first time we actually step into that place.   We weren't really sure what to expect for our orders. (other times we just gave up on the wait, and it is our 2nd wait that finally got us in, [the 1st time for 30 minutes: in vain] During the dinner, my friend found out she got a wrong order and said that she would like to have it returned, but they said that sorry it's her fault, they couldn't return it. So my friend had to order another noodle to go with her wrongly-ordered food. (In fact, I don't recall the waitress repeat her order to us either...even though she claimed it that way.)

My poor friend waited for another while, but by the time that most of us are done with our meals, there's still no sight of my friend's food. So my friend went to them again and wanted to cancel her food. Although she got to cancel her order,  the reaction she got from the worker is "Are you serious??" right in her face. (Thinking of that just made me angry!! You can say your complaints to your coworkers or boss, but not to your customer!! ) 

I guess the only reason why it's always seems to be full with people is because it's a tiny place. This place really doesn't deserve its fame. period.
author: Melody Ishin H.

description: This is definitely NOT the best ramen I've had.  I ordered the Suzu Ramen, which I thought included BBQ pork, but instead it was only fried chicken and fried potstickers (for $12.90, I want EVERYTHING!).  The broth was watered down.  We also ordered the tempura appetizer, which was disgusting!  The sauce that went with it tasted more like soy sauce than the usual sweet soy sauce dip.  Go elsewhere.
author: Tiffy G.

description:
One of the best non-sushi restaurants in SF. It's very small so the wait times can be long and they don't do reservations or take out. The pot stickers.. just thinking about them makes me start drooling. Also highly recommend the miso nabe yake udon.
Closes at 9pm, not recommended for parties larger than 4-5..the place is small!


Update: Yes, they do take out but the line can be long still.
author: Snuggie L.

description: The noodle is okay, which is chewie and different from other ramen.  The soup base is too salty as well as cha shiu, the egg is over cooked.   I am kinda disspointed with this high rated Noodle place in SF J town.   Maybe try undon will be better choice?!   Dnt know, but I know I wont come back for it.
author: Jessie K.

description:
It's funny that Karen W and I have almost the same icon.  

For the substantive info: I would not advise going to Suzu.  The ramen is average but the service was awful.  Even though there were three empty tables when I got there, and three groups of people to fit those three tables, it took the waitresses several minutes with their heads together to figure out how to work out the logistics.

Upon being seated, my dining mate and I promptly ordered and waited, and waited, and waited some more for the food to arrive.  Goodness, how long does it take to cook them noodles folks?

Ebisu is the far better bet.
author: Helen C.

description:
Just to vary my Clement Street dining excursions I decided to head to Japantown to get some non-Chinese Asian food - and I'm glad I did. Not  being overly fond of ramen in the first place, a little adventurousness on a seemingly unadventurous day does go a long way....

I had a ramen revelation -  the noodles were fresh and al dente-ish; the broth (I'd chosen miso) was delectable, complex and had different layers of flavor. The juicy slice of pork had a flavor distinct from that of the broth - it was so good that I ordered more pork (5 slices for $2) to have with my soup. I kept on lapping up the broth till there was none... but all yummy things must come to an end. I was tempted to ask for more but my sense of propriety held, even under such circumstances.

With my ramen I had tendon - tempura over rice - which was delightful. Perfectly crisp (for my fondness for fried food: see review of Ocean) pieces of shrimp and vegetables lightly slathered with a thick sweet soy sauce. Perfect counterpoint to the liquid goodness of the ramen.

I've since gone back two more times and each experience was just as tasty and satisfying as the first. The Chicken Kara-age (side of crisp and juicy chicken morsels and not served over rice)/ramen combo is great if you want to put the brakes on the carb intake; a companion had unagi over rice with hers (loved it - and this coming from an unagi fiend). The price for this ramen with side/over-rice combination? $8.95, or $9.95 if you opt for the miso broth  (otherwise they serve it with shoyu-based broth).  I suggest the miso upgrade with the extra pork (which you can share) for $2. 

The gals running the place are very warm - if not wholly efficient  - and are always willing to explain the selections on offer. Again, maybe it's just me, but I don't expect a whole lot on this front from a mom-and-pop establishment, just as long as they're generally warm and if the food's good.

Note: I've been salivating the entire time I was writing this. Now, that I'm' done with this review I'm headed there.
author: Es E.

description:
A pretty decent ramen house.  I was wandering around J-town the other day and really wanted a bowl of noodles.  My friend introduced me to Suzu one day and I thought that would be a good place to go to satisfy my craving.  When I arrived, there was a wait, but I couldn't really tell if they were going according to the name list at the front, or if they were just kinda keeping track of everyone.  But I put my name on the list anyway.  I waited about 5 minutes for a table and had their Mabo Don combo.  

The ramen was good.  Noodle consistency was perfect for my taste and the broth was good.  I always add the togarashi, so that alters the dashi flavor a bit.  Then came the mabo don.  This was on the salty side and something was wrong with their rice.  I couldn't quite figure what was wrong with it though.  Maybe it was old.  Who knows.  Therefore, I didn't finish it.  Which is fine, since the ramen was filling enough.

Overall, the ramen's good for satisfying a craving.  Stick with the ramen.
author: Alison N.

description: Suzu is the ramen house I love to go to when on a Japantown outing!  It's so tiny in there but so delicious and steamy that it's okay for me to cramped and bumped into.  I've never had to wait more than 10mins for a table but maybe that's b/c I've gone on Sunday at a random time? Whatever the case is, I've tried the Soy flavored Ramen and loved it!  The broth looks and tastes cleaner than some of the other rich flavors.  This will always be my #1 choice when visiting Japantown!
author: Tracy N.

description: Hands down the best ramen in San Francisco!  Thisis their specialty and they do it well.  I've tested other ramen noodle places and nothing comes close.  Perfect broth over petfect, freshly made ramen noodles.  Just honest, good food.  There's always a waiting list nut it's totally worth the wait.  I LOVE this place.
author: Alain T.

description:
Love this place; not so much the wait. 
Have to concur with some that customer engagement could be better. Still, I WILL return.
author: Marcel C.

description: Delicious Miso broth and crispy croquette with the smooth potato inside! I love it here. The pork was a little dry in my miso ramen so I took one star off, but the broth is really really worth it. Staff is very friendly too, if a little brisk since they are always busy.
author: Christine C.

description: It's decent but the ramen lacked the excitement of Katana-ya. I'll go to Suzu Noodle House if already visiting Japantown but won't go out of my way just to eat here. Service quick and not expensive. Two people, we ordered two bowls of ramen, one sashimi appetizer, two draft beer came out to approx $40. Tip $10, so that's a total of $50. On the positive side, we didn't have to fight for parking like in downtown and had the option to stroll in the mall after dinner, with an abundance of dessert places to choose from!
author: Sassy G.

description: Yes, it's on the ground floor of a mall, but this mall has cute shops to occupy your time while you wait for a table (just make sure you can hear them holler your name). The place has about 15 (?) tables, and even though I went on a Thurs night at 7'ish, I still had to wait for a table for about 15 mins. The service wasn't as bad as suggested by some  reviewers. The food was OK. Not the worst and certainly not the best ramen I've had (I have Ippudo in NYC). I ordered the char-shiu ramen with a tiny bowl of katsu-don. I got a LOT of noodles, and enough pork to satisfy me. The pork was a bit too salty (and trust me, I love salt). The broth wasn't as rich as I would have liked. The noodles weren't anything to write home about, but for a cold night, it made me happy.
author: Graciete L.

description: It's more like 3.5 stars.  I had the miso ramen ($8.95) with additional chashu (3 pieces for $1) and the tempura don ($3).  We also ordered kakuni for an appetizer, which was delicious but not that tender.  It was surprisingly great ramen, and I finished the whole bowl, including all of the broth - perfect size.  They forgot the additional chashu - right when the bowl arrived, I swirled my chopsticks in it to count the pieces of pork and alerted the waitress when there was only the default 2 pieces.  She apologized and quickly brought me the 3 extra pieces on a plate.  I wish the egg was medium boiled instead of hard boiled, but all of the ramen joints in the bay area that I've been to like to use a hard boiled egg.  The tempura don wasn't that great...it came with the sticky sweet sauce poured on it.  I'm used to being able to dip my tempura vegetables in sauce, so that I can control how much I use.  Also, the rice didn't taste that great.  If I go back, I'll still probably get the miso ramen by itself with kakuni for an appetizer.  I'd also like to try the chicken karaage.
author: Barbara T.

description: We are a regular here. It's always a very long waiting list, so you really have to be there early or else expected to wait an hour or more. I love their sake don, kargage, and spicy ramen All in one meal, because they are so good.
author: Leah C.

description: Rushes you by giving you the check early and saying "take your time".  If this place does so well and gets so many reviews, how come it doesn't expand or move to a different location where it is bigger and you don't have to rush people.  Good ramen noodles, but small place.
author: Willie Y.

description:
Such a cute little place in Japantown!  I love the fact that it is small and cozy, but not claustrophobic feeling because of the big glass windows.

I had just returned from Hawaii and was craving some gool ol fashioned ramen.  I ordered the spicy miso and my friend got the regular miso.  both broths were extremely delicious-- not too salty like most ramen places can be and not too bland and watery.  It was a great consistency for a cold day out in the city.  The veggies were fresh and crisp and soaked up the flavor of the broth.  My favorite thing was the noodles.  It's so hard to find noodles that are the right texture!  It was chewy rameny goodness! 

I definitely can't have Hawaii ramen all the time, but Suzu will do for now =).

Only thing bad is the wait, so you have to either come early or late!
author: jessica l.

description: eh, wanted to get some good ramen, and found this place.  Looked good, nice place and all...but it wasn't the greatest.  had the char siu ramen (they spelled it differently though, or maybe i don't know the proper spelling).  the broth was a little salty, but still not bad.  probably just a little too much ajinomoto.  noodles was all right, tasted homemade, but i don't know.  price a little high for what you get...i'd prefer a good hole-in-the-wall place and get probably better ramen for cheaper.
author: Jason Y.

description: Suzu has a comprehensive menu with combination sets that allow you to try noodles in combination with dons. However, I found their ramen to be alright. Nothing spectacular and hence not worth the wait.
author: Catherine T.

description:
I eat at Suzu weekly. The soups are outstanding and reminiscent of meals I have had in Japan.
If you want delicious , authentic Japanese noodle soups, Suzu is the place.
author: Eric P.

description:
I thought I would try this place since they seemed to attract many customers.  I was disappointed as I continued my quest  for the good ramen restaurants in S.F.  The broth was full of msg.  I ordered port katsu-don on the side, it was burned.  I had to ask them to take it back.  When it came,  not only was the egg not smooth but overcooked, there was no onion and no sauce to speak of.  I don't see anything special about anything that was served.

This restaurant may be good for people who have never had the real Japanese food but I will not be back.
author: L. H.

description:
The Noodle here is really good, but don't try the curry. 

The staff are pretty good, but the problem with this place is that it is small so there is OFTEN a long waiting time (15-30 minutes), not for those who are hungry and can't wait. Fortunately, I am only hungry.
author: Bai Z.

description:
Such an adorable, cute, cozy little noodle house!  It's look like a cabin from the outside filled with wood.  No reservation of course but the wait isn't that long since hey, can't take people that long to slurp the noodles down. LOL.

I never been to Japan so do not know what authentic ramen takes like but I liked what I had there.  The soup based was tasty - chicken/pork broth.  I also had their fried oyster - yum!  Light and crispy that comes with this interesting aioli like sauce.  Service was great -- quick and attentive.
author: Lily W.

description:
Great noodle joint for quick weekday dinner. 
Reasonable price, fresh noodle, and good variety of choice. 
Order tempura or croquette as appetizer before you dive into noodles. They have one of the best fried concoctions, and croquette taste very home-made. 

I never waited in the line. Then, I always go rather late during weekdays.
author: Angie Y.

description:
This place is cute (aka small)...so don't bring your ninja asassin squad!

The ramen was good to okay...the broth needed more character and the karaage (battered & fried meat) was decent but not quite as good as what you get at Katana-Ya. I think Suzu is also a little stingy on the fixing that go into my ramen, comparatively speaking. 

My friends mentioned that the karaage curry was excellent!
OHHH, go upstairs to the crepe place for dessert, delicious!

Did I mention that it's cheap so if I'm in the area I would certainly come back and try something new.
author: Venatius P.

description: Never coming back here again. I only tried one thing which was supposed to be the most popular ramen that they had and it was gross. I was hungry but had barely ate it because it was so bad. The broth had no taste, there was tons of noodles but it was terrible too. EVERYTHING about the ramen was horrible. Oh yes, service sucked and it's always busy. Shrug. Go figure.
author: Mayana P.

description: o.k. well this will be my 2nd low star rating only because i found a piece of hair in my soup. I'm not one to complain and didn't want to make a scene out of it, so i soldier it up and ate it (pulled the hair out of course) convincing myself that, that's what i just have to expect eating out. Of course i will not go back because there are other noodle places in the shopping center that's very good. so sayonara Suzu House. Arigato but no thanks. I'm very much turned off because since it was my first time trying the place out.
author: zoey x.

description:
one of us got a spicy ramen, the other got a not spicy ramen. 

the spicy was so spicy it hurt. the not spicy was so bland it was sad.

we combined our broths and both were made palatable, but neither dish was great. nothing really stood out beyond that - not the meat or the noodles or the service. 

won't be back.
author: Will R.

description: Okay, I see that maybe the broth is a little one dimensional as some folks have noted, but I still love Suzu's noodles.  They even let me sub in soba noodles for regular ramen.  Two bowls of noodles and one sake were over $40 with tip which seems a bit high.  Factor in the wait, and the servers that try to rush you out and yeah, it's probably not the best option.  It is my favorite NEARBY option, but I'm looking forward to trying Katana-Ya to see what all that hype is about.  Maybe then I'll be reminded of how good I have it at Suzu, or maybe I'll be moving on to greener pastures.
author: Jennifer D.

description: I've been here 5 times since I discovered it less than 2 months ago. I really can only review one thing because I've ordered it every time I've been: spicy tofu ramen. SO good. I get sad when it's over, because I just want more. It's truly amazing. I'm sure there are other great things on the menu, but I'll stick with my favorite.
author: Kelsey M.

description:
i have found my tanpopo replacement.  tanpopo's health inspection score really scared us off.  but this noodle house has good ramen and the broth was pretty flavorful.

the service wasn't so hot.  our waitress forgot to put our order in and we sat there waiting for 15-20 min while she was no where to be seen, and then finally she came back and said she forgot our order and took it down again...granted she was very apologetic, shit happens i understand, but this was very sloppy.  they have 3 waitresses for a very small restaurant, it could have been prevented.

never the less a good noodle house with easy parking is hard to find, there is no good ramen as far as i know in the east bay...so this place will have to do.
author: ML ..

description:
I went here in summer.  My boyfriend and I did a lot of waiting--waiting to get seated (fine), waiting to get orders taken (it was a Saturday night), waiting for soba (um my ramen came out way before his soba), waiting for the check (ugh).

The ramen was alright, but here's the kicker--boyfriend's soba was UNDERcooked.  I didn't think that was possible...ever...nevermind this entree came out several minutes after ramen.  He had green tea soba & regular soba--the regular soba was undercooked.  Also the portion was pretty small.  Normally I prefer a smaller portion, but for the price we paid for everything, I don't even think he got a bundle's worth of the two sobas combined (y'know, the bundle sizes packaged dried soba comes in).  

I think Yelpers overhyped this one, sorry.  I'd rather go to Tanpopo.

Veggie 411 for those who care:  not all that vegetarian friendly.
author: Veronica R.

description: I just found out about this place, and it is fantastic! If it's a cold day outside, you can get some great noodles and soup here. I have gotten the hot soba noodles made with fish broth, and it is delicious! My mouth is salivating just thinking of it now. Give it a try, you will not be disappointed.
author: Saskia S.

description: It's usually crowded around dinner/lunch time. Spicy ramen was decent. Corn ramen was decent. It's nothing super special, but it's warm and salty on a cold day.
author: Annie K.

description:
Re: the ramen

A bit on the expensive side: apparently you only get one slice of pork with the regular order, and it's $2 for four extra slices (go for the extra slices). The meat however was really salty, and the broth has chicken broth in addition to pork for some reason (cost?). Still, a tasty meal and the noodles were legit.

Though small, is apparently muy popular, but that's probably due to location at the mall entrance by the theater.
author: steve m.

description:
Excellent noodles. Firm, bouncy, good chew.

Broth is just ok. A bit thin for my taste. I prefer my ramen shops to offer thin, medium to rich broth options.

Atmosphere is good for a tiny noodle joint. 

Lines - can be overly long. might not be worth the 40 minute wait. best to come during off hours for your first visit, to determin if the wait times are worth it to you in the future.

CONCLUSION: Worth while visit for ramen lovers.
author: yutai l.

description:
I honestly don't think ramen should be that difficult to make good. So I'm a little unsparing for this one. While the ramen here is pretty standard, I find the single slice of meat a little disappointing. The place is pretty small and cozy, which I like, but the service often awkward and lacking. The portions are fine, but I'm still upset about the one slice of meat thing... I mean yeah the food is tasty, but it's pretty difficult to mess up miso based broth for ramen. 

The only reason why I keep coming back to this place is because there aren't that many places dedicated to ramen and get it right. And while this place gets it right, I need more meat in my bowl. I'm a growing boy afterall.
author: Joey W.

description:
How about a 1 inch wire coil with that delicious ramen?  I wasn't even going to mention it to the waitress, but when my boyfriend stopped the waitress to point this out, we just got a long excuse about how the dishwasher must have dropped it in there.

Normally, such mistakes warrant a comped beer, appetizer, something, anything.  Instead, we were overcharged!  The situation was actually so absurd, it was laughable.

Pity, because their food is actually quite good.  Sans wires.
author: Sue K.

description:
Great noodles.  The miso ramen is amazing.  I wish I could eat it every day.  Plus there's a combo where you can get unagi donburi and ramen for something like $11!

The food is just delicious.  

The only downside is the sake.  They only have one and its no good but you can eat your noodles and then go upstairs to Festa for some sake that's as good as the noodles at Suzu.
author: Margaret G.

description:
Yummy yum yums.  My sister suggested this place, and she says there's always a line/wait.  But we came on a Monday night, and there was an empty table... 

I had one of the combination items.  I think it was the Maguro donburi.  It was some kind of raw fish on rice.  There's only one of those on the menu, sorry I can't remember the name!  Anyhow, it was good.  Nothing amazing, but good.   I also had the cold soba noodles, which were awesome.  I love cold soba- so refreshing and light.  We shared an Asahi.  I was bummed they didn't have dessert here though.  

My sister had the kimchee ramen which was really tasty.  I think the soups are where it's at here.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Top notch Ramen where waiting is half the battle.  Love the combination meals -- Unagi don and ramen for $9.95 is such a deal.  Of course any place that serves karaage curry is fine by me.

Always order the Karaage separate from the Ramen along with a side salad and kim chi.  It'll make the whole experience so much better.
author: Dee Dee N.

description: I used to think this place was decent until today. The rice under my chicken katsu was mush, and after being asked if everything was ok, I told one of the waitresses about the rice. Then, another (our) waitress came back and asked us what was wrong, and I repeated, the rice was really mushy. She then tried to explain that Japanese rice is sticky, and so it's supposed to taste like that. I AM Japanese, and I've had Japanese rice before, and this lady is trying to tell me (without inspection) that I don't know what I'm talking about? She then tries to explain how the rice is made in a rice cooker and that some parts may be soft - but I tell her again, no, it's just MUSH today and clearly, it was cooked with too much water. Look, I don't need to argue or prove that I know what rice is supposed to taste like. Next time, don't bother asking. I won't be back again.
author: Cheri S.

description: This place looks always busy but that's because tge place is quite small. Once I came and ordered a noodle with miso soup base. The noodle was good, but for the soup part I think I still like Iroha better as far as Japantown restaurants are concerned. Still I'd probably like patronizing here again.
author: H K.

description: Hands down my favorite place to get ramen in SF! While I've tried many of their verities of ramen last time I went I got the Suzu Ramen (everything you could ever want in a bowl of noodle soup: seaweed, pea shoots, green onions, bamboo shoots, hard boiled egg, bbq pork, chicken karage and fried goyza!!!), it was amazing, a month later drooling all over my computer just thinking about it. Their ramen/noodle specials are a good deal and all the donburi options look delicious, I want to try some of them next time I go but it will be hard not to get the suzu ramen. It may be small and there's usually a wait, but it's worth it!!
author: Sophie C.

description:
You guys can't be serious??? Maybe I ordered incorrectly, as I didn't order noodles, but if it's on the menu, it's fair game. I ordered some sort of chicken with rice, actually I'm still not sure what I ordered as the waitress was no help at all. She just wanted me to order something quickly as a couple tables sat at once after a movie. 

When my food came out, I was so sorely disappointed. The rice was a soggy mush and the chicken left much to be desired. The two others I was with, their food look like a pile of slop as well.

Honestly, I would never go back to this place under no circumstances. Period. I eat out every meal of every day, and that is one of many pleasures living in San Francisco. There are so many good restaurants, that if your food isn't good, you will not survive. Survival of the fittest is what makes dining in San Francisco so awesome. How this place is in business is beyond me.

Again, maybe the noodles are better, but if that's the case, take everything else off the menu.
author: Sean S.

description: The boyfriend and I always end up eating here whenever we come to Japan town. The wait usually around 15 - 20 minutes. He usually gets the udon and i get the ramen that comes with the sashimi on rice. The broth of both tastes just right. This is probably one of the best ramen places i've eaten at in SF. I've been here several times and each time it has not let me down!
author: Jessica C.

description: Went here for the first time.  Ordered the lunch special ramen with tonkatsu.  Definitely would come back here.  Food, service, and location was very satisfactory.
author: JACOB L.

description: This is my go to place for ramen in SF. I've tried my fair share of ramen joints in SF, some of which include Tanpopo, and Katana-Ya. Tanpopo use to be great but changed owners and now are okay to good. Katana-Ya makes certain ramen good and others shitty, not to mention their noodles are 3 star quality. They also use a lot of MSG. How do I know? My friend is the chef at Katana-Ya. Suzu, however makes a pretty good all around bowl of ramen. BUT, be WARNED, their service is crap. Every time I go there the waitress is inattentive and depending on who waits on you seems to not care about the customer.
author: Nick C.

description: The noodles are really good, but the pork was REALLY salty. I tried my friend's fried chicken nugget ramen and it was really good-- so I guess i just ordered the wrong thing.
author: Christine A.

description: This place is decent, tho I don't think I would stand in line unless the wait was really short. I got the Spicy Ramen, extra spicy with agedashi tofu for an appetizer. The agedashi was nice, better than some other places I've had it, but not as good as Sushi Koko's. The spicy ramen was spicy, but not spicy enough, even at extra spicy. The broth was good, tho; nicely flavorful without being salty or too heavy. The spice gave it heat, but didn't provide much else which made me sad. The toppings were standard: chashu, seaweed, bamboo, green onion and tea (?) egg. The chashu was all right, but the egg was over done. I prefer it a little softer boiled. The noodles were nicely firm with a good chew to them. Oh, and the bowls are BIG. It was a satisfying meal, but not one I would brave the parking hunt around Japantown for.
author: Myrna A.

description: This place is decent. I don't say this place serves excellent Ramen, but at least it is edible and you don't feel disgusted afterwards. Pretty decent, but not high quality. If you want a good Ramen, you have to drive down to San Jose. But you get ok experience here. Not too bad.
author: M N.

description: This place is not as everybody though it is. This is my first time to go to this restaurant and the food is not great at all. It's pricy, and the service is bad. I'm not a big complainer and I usually keep quite when restaurants fell short but the staff is very unaccommodating to customer's needs.I could have done better going to other restaurants in the mall. I can't wait to get out of that place and warm other people who's looking at the menu not to come in.
author: Topsy C.

description:
Don't expect much in the way of service, but the noodles here are incredible. I can't tell you what it means to have found a good restaurant near Kabuki. 

This place isn't quite as interesting as Cha-Ya, but very well done for what it is. If you're a vegetarian, definitely expect to get the vegetable tempura - it was crisp! And had actual vegetable flavor! Yay! 

I had a bite of someone else's ramen, and while it was delicious the stock tasted awfully chicken-y, so...word. The staff here might not be especially upfront about veg versus non. 

The plum wine isn't too shabby either. Crisp and not too sweet.
author: H. S.

description: Is it a cold Sunday afternoon? In the City that's probably 75% of the time. And on this afternoon do you find yourself at Japantown and looking for something to warm yourself? What about a steaming bowl of noodles in a comforting broth? I thought my ramen-eating days were over when I graduated from college, but after eating at Suzu that may as well be history. I had the ramen with fried chicken cutlet. It wasn't as oily as I thought it would be and it hit the spot. It's definitely not a fancy restaurant and not very large so expect a bit of a wait. Anxious patrons on the other side of the glass walls made it feel like I was in a goldfish bowl, but it helped make service quick.
author: Joel B.

description:
Best ramen is the city. Hands down.

I usually get the spicy negi ramen or the cha shu shio ramen. The wait can be a pain in the culo, but I think it's worth it. People usually complain about the portions, but I rather have a small bowl of good ramen then a big bowl of mediocre ramen *cough* Sapporo Ya *cough*.
author: Mojo L.

description: This place has the best ramen ever! Okay, I say the same thing about other spots, but this place really does have one of the better tasting ramen. I like Genki ramen too but the broth at Suzu way better.
author: Jb M.

description: A little hole in the wall in the heart of Japantown. Surrounded by competitors, this place is always packed. The ramen doesn't get much better than this.
author: Russell H.

description:
Quick service, solid ramen and udon, and warm and toasty tea on a cold day.  They give you healthy portions of noodles and the broth is tasty without being overly salty.  A good choice for noodles.

Just be sure to go there on off hours - it's a super small place and the tables fill up quickly.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I have been going to Suzu Noodle House for a few years now, and once there, I always order the Mapo Ramen, which is mapo tofu (ground pork in spicy sauce with cubed tofu) over ramen noodles.  The broth is just right, tasty, deep and not too salty, and complements the perfectly cooked ramen.  Once finished eating, my remark to myself is that ramen is "nourishment to the soul." Also try the gyoza, a light side dish to the ramen.
author: Pendragon D.

description: Had the tonkatsu ramen and side order of chicken curry.  Both dishes were ridiculously salty.  I wish this place had left a better taste in my mouth because then I'd have a good dinner spot to go to before going to Sophie's for dessert!
author: Stef H.

description:
I seek out ramen noodle houses wherever I go.  The best I ever had is this hole in the wall right off a subway stop near Shinjuku Station in Tokyo.  It's funny how Japanese takes even something as everyday as ramen (which originated in China no less) and perfects it to an art form.  

Suzu is good but far from great.  It is conveniently located as I can walk there from my apartment and I have eaten there more times than I remember.  But it is not ramen to write home about.  Still, all in all, I am thankful I can get a ramen fix with so little effort.  For truly good ramen in the Bay Area, head towards San Jose.  

One pet peeve...they need to get rid of their Charlotte Walker CD.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I can only compare this with Maruichi and Ryowa in Mountain View.  It was decent if you have a ramen craving in San Francisco.  The miso broth was a lot richer and flavorful than the standard broth - I'd get that next time with a side order of the karaage chicken.  The noodles were good but not great.  The portions are a bit on the small side.  

I'll have to try to negi (spicy) ramen next time, so I guess that means I'd go back.
author: Ben K.

description:
Frequently went here ever since it first opened because of a rumor I heard from a friend. Supposedly one of the owners of Katana Ya was helping out in the kitchen so I figured It's worth the try. Ramen broth was clear and light very delicious. Different from Katana Ya. No MSG hang over after the meal surprised me. It seemed to me the owner or chef  wanted to bring his broth and noodle out to the point they didn't want extra toppings to get in the way. Tempura was beautiful, almost text book looking picture perfect. The komoro (batter) was light, fluffy, and retained its crunch even after sometime.

Why do I speak so highly of the place and only give it two stars? I go back and the tempura was not the same. Ramen was still good but I had an experience another yelper had.

THE NOODLES TASTED LIKE AMMONIA. 

First bite, tasted like MOLD. Okayy maybe its just me..... Continues eating.... Windex???? 

I was upset and the server threw me for another loop. 

R.S. ( In a quite tone): Ummm this tastes like ammonia. Maybe  your noodles are bad.
Waitress: Okay one moment. (Takes to back, comes back) This is Japanese Ramen soup taste.
R.S. (Japanese) : Ummm not the soup the noodles.
Waitress: Okay one moment. (Takes to back, comes back) It's Fine.

At this point I pay for my cold tea and leave.
author: R S.

description:
I would come here if I ever get a craving for ramen because it is indeed the most reasonable choice in J-town.   However the quality has been somehow inconsistent.   There are times when miso ramen tasted as good as those in Mountain View Ryowa, other times the broth was way too salty.  The portion is getting smaller over time, and the vegetarian ramen has always been a disappointment every single time.
The staff is friendly and service rather fast and thorough.  A good quick eat place.
author: Stacey F.

description: Since my first visit, I've been to Suzu three more times. The texture of the noodles are chewier but I'm starting to appreciate it.  I like the Shio ramen with extra meat.
author: Susie S.

description: We had quick dinner on New year's eve. We waited for about 15 mins. to get inside. The food came out pretty quick, but the service ( our waitress ) was not so good. She was always looking down without eye contact even when she talked to us. I asked her for some more tea twice, but never brought it to me. I had cha shu ramen, and my husband got miso butter corn. They were pretty good, though he thought that the noodle was a little undercooked. Our waitress was not friendly at all and never said thank you when we paid, but another waitress seemed to be very nice. When we left, she gave us a big smile saying " A Happy New Year!" I do not know any better ramen shop, so I will go there again for sure.
author: Foomin U.

description: One of the best noddle houses in the Bay Area in my opinion. Located in Japantown, the parking and wait time could be terrible at times. However, if I stil lived in San Francisco...I would overcome it. The only drawback to the taste component is that the broth is a bit salty (drink plenty of water) but if you get the combination with the rice dish (I usually pair up my soup with unagi or the spicy ground pork), you'll be fully satisfied!
author: Rod L.

description: With the rainy weather of late, I've been having mad cravings for ramen. We stopped in Suzu just before closing time and found a dozen people waiting outside for their name to be called. After 15 mins we got in and quickly ordered. I had the chicken and vegetable ramen and the boyf had the miso pork ramen (which was far better than mine). Note to vegeatarians- there are very few vegetarian items, none which are ramen. Suzu makes a note that their ramen has a pork broth base. Although I don't typically care for pork, the ramen broth is delicious. Go for the gold here and try something new, you'll be glad you did.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I was going to give this place one star, but realized I was pissed off because of what happened to us.  This place is great...but beware of bad service during busy hours.  We waited for 30 minutes and the waitress called on the party of 5 people after us.  When I approached with her mistake, she said "sorry". I was pretty upset as they didn't try to help the situation. So I had to talk to the manager and advise them that if this happens again the next time, then he should ask the party to give up their seats and explain their mistake. 

They knew I was pretty angry and they ended up offering an appetizer for free.  I know it was a peace offering, but just didn't like the way they handled it.

The food is okay.  Been here about 3 times, and probably won't return since I feel traumatized.
author: Bernard H.

description: Great food - minus one star for almost no vegetarian options, and minus another for using shrimp shiu mai from Costco - blech! That being said, really loved the veggie noodles I had (add spicy negi - yum!)
author: Lis W.

description:
Most terrible service ever. 

Never in my life did I ever have a hostess give me attitude before I even set foot in the restaurant. Long story short, the almighty hostess decided that my friend and I were not deserving of being seated because we made a restroom run during the long wait and was not back in time when she called our names. She basically hinted to us that, "I'll seat you again when I feel like it". 

That's fine. I'll take my business somewhere else. Your oily broth isn't worth it.
author: Melvin Y.

description:
It's hard to find a good ramen place.  This place does not have the best soup, but menu covers pretty much everything.  Vegetarian Udon noodle, various ramen noodle, soba, donburi, and small plates. Perfect for a quick bite. 

I go there alone sometimes for a quick bite.  It's rate to find a restaurant where women can go without feeling bit off.
author: Rie H.

description:
If you want to taste authentic Japanese Noodle & Ramen, go here.
I think it's a not bad for a soup noodle during cold days you want to go here.
Mostly all the noodle soup here are very tasty. So go ahead try everything! My fave is the karage ramen & vegetarian udon. FYI vegetarian people; the vegie udon is not really pure vegetarian, but the broth is already a mix of meat & pork broth. So, no it's not for vegetarians here.
Reasonable price, nice taste of soup, fast service!
Just put your name on the list of the paper provided, & they'll seat you whenever the seat is avail.
it's alaways a full house here, cuz the place itself is very small.
author: Ms C.

description: Some of the best noodles I've had in Japan Town and by far the best in the J-Center, but I always seem to show up when they are closed, or the wait is astronomical.
author: Quinn S.

description: Came here with my bff because we have heard many positive things about this place. It was ok.  My friend had the karage ramen, and she said there was no taste. She kept putting pepper and salt in it. And it didnt help too much. I forgot what i got, but it was decent.  The noodles seemed  a little on the chewy side... were they homemade? not sure... bottom line glad we tried, but probably wont be going back!
author: Shelley N.

description: One star up from my last review.  Went there last week for a quick dinner.  The waiting is reasonable.  This time I ordered the Cha Shu Ramen which is better than the Tokyo Ramen than last time =)
author: Mimi W.

description:
So far the best place to eat between the two main buildings in Japan town. I know i know, not saying much but it's good to have something to fall back on. If only they weren't closed from 3-5pm every day, dang. 

I'm not a ramen or japanese food connoisseur, but at least i know when something tastes good and has good service. Noodles weren't instant, prices weren't outrageous, servings sizes were appropriate for the price and the waitress was nice (there was something in my friend's water and there was no snarkiness in replacing it :) ). 

I actually couldn't finish my bowl of ramen, and i distinctly remember lamenting that there was just so much meat in my ramen and asking someone to finish it for me, that's pretty rare.  To be fair i don't eat much anyway, but I've been places that charge $10 a bowl and that DIDN'T fill me up, so i thought it was a worthy thing to note. 

Tempura was light, not greasy. Noodles had all the fixings. I mean yea, there just wasn't anything to complain about. It wasn't holy-crap-amazing either but honestly finding a place that has tasty food that isn't a huge rip off in a touristy weeaboo area is good for me. I'm definitely going to try to hit this place up every time i go to japan town instead of gambling at other places where i've had so-so food.
author: Susan L.

description:
