This is a relatively new establishment in Japan Town. For whatever reason, it seems like ramen is winning over people these days. A bunch of new ramen places have opened up everywhere, and this is one of the new ones in J-Town.

The restaurant is pretty small. There are only a few tables, so waiting for a table is not uncommon. The food was very good. I had a hearty bowl of Karaage (Japanese fried chicken) ramen, and it was excellent. The noodles were clearly fresh and home-made, and the Karaage was sumptuous. The best part though, is the soup. Unlike many other places, the soup here is not overly salty. It didn't leave me thirsty for the rest of the evening, which is a good departure from most other ramen places.

I'd come here often if I were to live closer. Suzu is excellent.
author: Barn M.

description:
I must have ordered the wrong type of ramen.  I had one of their roll+ramen combos, which came with a teeny weeny roll (albeit taste), and a very plain (aka bland) fistful of ramen noodles in clear pork broth and ONE slice of pork.

Really?  ONE slice of pork?  For $12?  At that point, I knew that Suzu and I - we're sooooo over.

Metallic seems to be the flavor of the day.  I could've forgiven the ONE slice of pork if the ramen was awesome or if the broth knocked my socks off.  Let's just say, apart from the bland broth, the ramen itself was bland and had a metallic aftertaste.  Why??

The Asahi beer on tap was metallic tasting.  So really, I had nowhere to hide.  Perhaps if the rest of the Japantown building burned down, and I was starving to death - MAYBE - I'll give Suzu another try.
author: Hoola H.

description: Ramen makes me very happy especially if it's tasty! This place is pretty good but it doesn't compare to Katana-ya' s heavenly bowl of goodness - why? I prefer katanayas broth for some reason. I do still love Suzu and will still keep coming back.
author: Christian S.

description:
When to this restaurant around 2 p.m. last sunday and there was still a line of people waiting to be seated!  Hmm...must be something good?  There were only two of us and we were seated pretty soon.  We even get to see the kimono show.  Back to ramen, they are very good and I can tell they made it fresh.  Fried chicken nuggets were very good, too.  I had a chia-shiu ramen.  They made their chia shiu soft and tender, which is good.  unlike some restaurants in the same shopping mall where their chia shiu is dry and hard, probably from left over a few days ago.  
I can't give it a 5-star because the soup, although very creamy and tasty, is a bit too salty to taste.  If they can tone it down, I'd give them 5 stars no questions asked.
author: F L.

description: I like it here because it is cheap and they make pretty good udon.  Anything else other than soup is just whatever.  However, the combos are cheap.  I usually get the udon and tekka don or unagi don.  The place is really small so I prefer to sit on the outside tables (2).  The staff is pretty friendly as well.
author: Sonja P.

description:
a tiny eatery that serves greasy broth that 's quite acceptable when you are starving and having a bad case of cold. 

with it's insufficient area, they could only afford to have 7 tables that could either seat 2 or 4 people. they can't even manage to have their very own washroom on their premises, but instead you'll be directed to the mall's public restroom conveniently located next to the restaurant.

the chicken karaage and gyoza was passable and everything was eaten on that plate. satisfying indeed!
a spicy negi ramen, unagi don buri and curry udon was ordered and it took them quite awhile to prepare it.

the ramen was oddly served in it's "packaged form." they could have at least separated the noodles to have a fresh, natural appearance.
the unagi was generously portioned to a good big size and it was savory (thanks for a satisfactory teriyaki sauce).
the curry udon was just average, i had better. 

but then, it's a tolerable place to have some soup.
author: Nelle A.

description:
I've been here once a few years ago, and I too will never go back again.

A tip from a chowhound.com post brought me here, with reviews claiming Suzu served fresh or in house made soba. We tried one zaru soba with tempura, and one of their ramen.

Soba was a little on the cold side, not done "al dente" like good fresh pasta. In fact Mifune upstairs does much better soba (they probably use dry packets to start as well). Fresh soba is out of this world, especially if made in house from scratch (Yabusoba in Waikiki did this but they closed, but according to Dan V there is a new business in that location that does the same thing). But we don't have that luxury of FRESHLY made soba here. All we can hope is that some competent chef takes the dry packet, boils the water and cooks the soba for long enough time, and here's the next important step...take the noodles and dunk it in cold water or a mix of mostly ice and some water, then DRAIN that water away. There may be other steps but these are the bare minimum to get the soba to have a bouncy texture towards the teeth. Timing is also critical. Miss any of these steps and you have ugly brown noodles that don't taste good.

The worst was the ramen. It had some weird ammonia taste to it, like a cheap bowl of Hong Kong style won ton egg noodle soup off the streets (those usually have some ammonia taste to it too), and to top it off that bowl of ramen costs more than won ton noodle soup!!!
I bet I got charged extra for the Windex solution they poured in. 

This place would fail the Japanese department store basement food quality test, in Japan, Hong Kong or Taiwan. Eeeeek!
author: Ken K.

description:
Perhaps one of the best ramen (aldente) noodles outside  of Japan...  along with tasty broths...  I highly recommend the salmon don combo... fresh salmon, slightly seasoned over rice... very delicious...
It's a busy place and waiting 15-20 is normal here... The staff does a wonderful job taking care of you...
author: William W.

description: I've walked past this restaurant many times and noticed it's always pretty busy, so I finally decided to give it a try. It's small and busy, so I went before noon and was promptly seated.  Service was excellent. I had the spicy ramen, which I thought was good.  Definitely spicy, but not so much so that I couldn't taste the other flavors in the soup.  The noodles were a very good texture and the meat was flavorful.  I would definitely go back and try some of the other menu items.
author: Eve C.

description:
Big udon fan here, and Suzu had AMAZING udon. The noodles were perfectly cooked and the broth was just spectacular. I got the udon with tempura, and that was also great. 

I will be back, again and again and again!
author: Joe G.

description:
Always a waiting list so many times we passed this place up but this past Monday we finally got our chance.

I ordered the Chashu pork ramen.  The meat was like eating my rubber boots,  the broth and noodles were ok  but I love chashu and it's was makes the ramen for me and It was just totally disgusting.  

Funny thing is they are so stingy 3 of my 6 pieces of pork were cut so thinly it was about thick as my finger nails and it was still unchewable.  How can you be so stingy on garbage meat? lol.

I was going to ask to exchange my meal but didn't bother to try anything else.  To add insult to injury, I put my napkin and garbage in my ramen bowl barely taking a sip of it and the waitress picks it up right away knowing I didn't eat any of it and didn't even bother to ask what was wrong.  She took it away just to get rid of a view that didn't look good for the restaurant.  

My bill was 21.26 including my friend and after tip we left leaving paid that exact amount.  I am a tipper but for the first time ever I left not leaving a dime.
author: frank s.

description: Texture of ramen was way too hard, broth way too salty.  Service was ok. Portions were small. While it wasn't a horrible dining experience, theres nothing about this place worth coming back for.
author: Anderson L.

description: Sizzling hot today in the City and wanted some Sorba noodles to cool me down and take away the hunger after working a volunteer shift at the San Francisco International Film Festival at the Sundance Kabuki Theatre.  Everytime I have wandered into the mall I would see that this place was always packed.  It's very small, maybe seats about 30 people inside max and 2 tables for a couple outside of the restaurant.    The service is quick once you sit down.  A cup of tea is offered and  some pickled vegetables and a mountain of wheat sorba is served on a beautiful rattan woven tray.  I always ordered a side of Karaage (fried chicken-boneless) $4.95.  This Suzu is my secret gem for a quick bite and soothing atmosphere.
author: Marian G.

description: I wish I could slurp here more often but I think the salt, though delicious, would be bad for my health!  My husband and I love coming here for their udon and ramen bowls... I also like their chicken karaage.  It's definitely worth the wait if there's a line.  The people are very friendly, too!
author: Neda B.

description: The ramen epicenter in the bay area seems to be further south than SF - with places such as Ramen Halu, Santa and Maruichi located throughout the penisula. Fortunately, I've finally found a ramen place that stands up to those aforementioned places - Suzu. At Suzu, the minimalist Japanese decor goes well with the delicate flavor of their soup base and homemade noodles. I'm a big fan of their chashu (pork slices) and I tend to order extra since they can be skimpy on their chashu portions. I've also had the gyoza and karaage, both of which are excellent. If you're still hungry afterwards, be sure to head upstairs and get a sweet crepe from the place next to the bookstore.
author: Neil K.

description:
suzu is one of our "go-to" places in the mall for ramen.

my recent favorite is the Hiyashi Chuka.  cold ramen in a sweet soy vinegar sauce, with salad tempura sliced bits of stuff and karaage chicken.  sooooo good!  i could eat that everyday almost.

their tempura is very nice.  its hard to get good tempura, its a delicate art.  theirs is pretty good.  good appetizers, the agedashi is not too bad and the karaage chicken is very nice, one of the better ones out there.  the curry is just out of the bag, like a lot of places that have curry but dont specialize in it.  but its tasty, and paired with some cold soba is a nice meal.

so bottom line is that its one of the better ramen places in japantown, taking into consideration the quality, variety, price and portions.  sometimes the service can be slow but whatever.

FYI - this place is at the bottom of the stairs, down from the bookstore/crepe place.

FYI - my "go-to" curry place is On The Bridge.
author: Junglist S.

description: This is worth waiting for. The ramen itself has a good texture and tastes fresh. The broth has a lot of flavor. The fried chicken in my fried chicken ramen was well seasoned. It's better than tanpopo.
author: Wesley C.

description: I like their Mabo Tofu Ramen which is spicy tofu & pork.
author: HY L.

description: Ramen are not fresh like they claimed they were, it was so stiff and hard to even chew. Maybe it was the day I went but I am not coming back for sure. I ordered the Tokyo ramen, soup base is good, but one small piece of meat and some ramen that isn't even fresh just ruins everything. I also ordered gyoza but it came toward the end of our meal, when we wanted to eat it first.
author: Willa L.

description: This ramen joint is consistently delicious, from the fresh noodles to the tasty broth.  Today, I tried the beef and vegetable ramen, and made a request for it to be spicy.  My hefty bowl of ramen contained tofu, cabbage, broccoli, slices of beef, and green onion that looked like it had some chili paste on it, which apparently was the spice I had asked for.  I added the chili powder for the ultimate spicy broth to my liking.  I have also tried the spicy mabo ramen, chicken karaage ramen, and the chicken curry in a lunch combo with ramen.  All of these selections were very satisfying with fresh noodles every time and broth that is full of flavor.  This is the best ramen spot I've been to so far and hope for more tables or a bigger space in the near future.  However, the ramen is well worth the wait!
author: Linda P.

description: I am a HUGE raman fan and Suzu serves up the third best ramen I have ever had.  The best was a tiny little place in a Tokyo suburb.  Second best was homemade by a local restauranteur who sadly does not offer it at their restaurant.  Third is Suzu.  This is as close to authentic as I have tasted.  The noodles are fresh and a bit al dente.  The chasu was the right cut of meat and tender.  Bamboo shoots floating in a sublime broth complete the fantastic gastronomic experience.  I havn't had the miso nor the nengi but even if those arn't that great i'll still give this a fiver for their basic shoyu ramen.
author: Calvin N.

description: I came her for dinner with my girlfriend.  We heard about this place from an old co-worker of mine so I decided to give it a shot.  We both love ramen noodles so it was perfect.  We got there and there was a lot of people waiting.  I put our name down on the list and decided to walk around Kinokuniya to kill some time.  Well as we were making our way back to the restaurant, the server called our name.  Perfect timing on our part.  My girlfriend had the Karaage Ramen (fried chicken) and I had the Chashu Ramen (tendor pork).  The broth was really good, and each of the respective meats were superb.  I am pretty sure I will be there again.
author: Philip L.

description: I've only had their Kara-age ramen and Spicy negi-ramen, but I like it better than all the ramen places in the bay area.  Halu in San Jose, Santa in San Mateo are good, but they don't have the same consistency in the noodles that Suzu has.  There isn't anything too special about the broth, but there in lies the beauty of simplicity.  Why Kara-age in ramen? why not. its good.
author: Yumio S.

description:
thursday nite, 700 pm, spent 20 mins walking up and down post st just looking for the neon-noodle sign stuck on the window.  the shop was actually in the japantown center, at the bottom of the steps from sophie's crepes.  shop has about 11 small tables, packed for dinner of course, but just a 5 minute wait for my group of 3...

complimentary hot tea:  nice!   free refills:  yeah!
the thing is, i've been to a few other japanese restaurants that charge 1 or 2 bucks for hot tea.  that's bull$hit!

my Spicy Negi Ramen, $7.50, one slice of pork, spicy green onions, seaweed.  soup was tasty, not overly spicy.  the noodle quality had just the right texture, not too firm or wriggly like cheap bag/cup ramen.  i squinted, looked closely, and lo and behold, the noodles have texture and indentions in them!  my friend confirmed this as well.  does that mean its handmade fresh?  i have no freakin idea, but i was considering a 2nd Spicy Negi Ramen after downing the first, totemo oishii desu!  

but a rule of thumb:  it takes 20 mins for ur stomach to realize its full from eating.  better option: walk south on fillmore to tapioca express for cold drinks and chill.
author: Ethan L.

description: I love ramen, and I haven't found great ramen in Houston yet.  So on our visit to San Francisco I was determined to find delicious ramen because I  figured if any place would have it, it would be SF.  Suzu Noodle House didn't disappoint.  I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen and the soup base was delicious along with the noodles.  Now, the noodles were what ramen noodles should be, which really helps make the whole dish.  Go early if you can because the place is small.  The place opened at 11:30 and we arrived at 11:45 and the place was already half full.  Fifteen minutes later there was already a line outside waiting for a table.  Don't waste your time ordering the other menu items because I don't think that's what they're known for.  We got the Agadashi Tofu  and the Chicken Curry Donburi and neither were good.  But try the noodles, they're definitely worth it!
author: Cindy W.

description:
They close on Tuesdays and they don't let you in shortly before they close (around 8:45pm)

My fav is the miso ramen + fried chicken!
author: Amy C.

description: BRAVO!!  I love their ramen broth especially the one with Mabo tofu and grounded pork sauce!  The ramen is al dante the way I like my pasta.  I can't wait to go back and try other items on their menu.
author: Gina W.

description: i would consider Suzu is a hidden gem in the Japan Town.  I passed by several times but never gave it a try.....until last week.  I was not disappointed at all.  I ordered the beloved spicy negi ramen.  It's a little smaller than other ramen, and i wasn't very impressed by the soup base; but texture of ramen is VERY good, and it was VERY fresh. I also tried the cha-shu ramen, and that was delicious!  It has a LOT of tasty cha-shu, and yummy ramen in a bigger bowl, and the soup base is very good.  I find bay area people tend to consider Santa ramen has the best ramen, but during our trip in Japan, we found out fatty soup base is not determination of good ramen.  The best ramen i went to in Tokyo in 2008 was seafood based.  Suzu make all their noodles fresh daily.  If you consider yourself as a hardcore ramen fan, you should give Suzu a try.
author: Sophia L.

description: This was my second trip to Suzu.  There is always a wait - know it, love it and know that it is worth the wait.  The staff is very friendly and is knowledgable as far as helping me to sort out the menu.  It is not that it is that complicated, just new to me.  The key is that the Ramen noodles are house made and are excellent.  I highly receommend the spicy broth - it is rich and peppery but does not overpower the other flavors.    I have not tried nearly enough on the menu, but have enjoyed the things I have had.  The BIG surpsie is how excellent the little bit of sushi they offer is.  This is not a sushi restaurant - and yet the tuna roll is outstanding!!  Get the dinner combo with noodles and a roll and enjoy.  Also the time spent waiting allows for a trip to the funny Manga bookstore on the same floor.
author: Bill G.

description: Slurp!  Yummy ramen found here.  There's always a bit of a wait, but it's worth it.
author: Lisa L.

description: Good ramen too!..I wish they have a bigger place so they can accommodate more customers.  Their ramen is delicious. My favorite is mabo tofu ramen...very nice!
author: Pikachu P.

description:
suzu, i got mad love for you. korean/japanese/mexican it's all good. i can't really tell the difference anyway. the soup is still great. 

don't listen to the haters. you know you are the best ramen joint that could be found in the city anyway. 

i'll slurp on your noodles anyday suzu. anyday.
author: Renae C.

description:
The second time I ever went to Japantown was during the Cherry Blossom festival (really fun, except I was practically melting in the heat). It was 4 of us having fun, walking around. Eventually we did get hungry and went in kintetsu mall to see where we should eat. Most of the restaurant were packed and we went downstairs and waited at Suzu's. None of us went there before but the food looked good.

We were starving so the wait seemed like forever but probably was only 10-15 minutes. We were seated, gotten our menu, and the waitress gave us water. Suzu is best for couples/dates, not really groups. For Suzu, the max you should have in your group is 4, that's how many there biggest table can fit. The waitresses are nice, not grumpy or very impatient.
Never had Japanese food before so I didn't know what to get and just thought I'd wait to get crepe.

1. My girlfriend ordered Karage ramen, which was ramen in a miso broth(?), and it had fried chicken in it. My girlfriend liked it and said it was good. It was only $9.50(?)
2. My friend ordered (I think) spicy ramen. It was a big bowl, looked spicy, however she said it wasn't spicy at all. We each took a bit and 1 of my friend said it was, but me and my girlfriend said it wasn't spicy at all. There's a kick but it wasn't spicy. A disappointment. $???
3. My other friend ordered Udon with unagi over rice. She got a bowl of udon in a reasonable size bowl that does fill you up. She also got a nice small bowl of unagi over rice. She liked her meal. $10.50
4. I saw my friend get the udon and realized I wanted the same except karage over rice. In my opinion, I like there udon the best here at Suzu's. The fried karage over rice I like a lot. The sauce they used was really good. $10.50
+ 2 sodas (soda i think is $1.50 (?))

Total + tax =about $50

I come back. There food is good, not amazing but it's good.
author: Priscilla S.

description:
the edemame was fine, but nothing special.

the miso ramen base was very savory and delicious. it comes with some BBQ pork slices, which are also good, but nothing special. i ordered the additional pork and a hard boiled egg. the additional pork is pork belly, which is totally awesome. it tasted excellent (better than the slices). the egg is exactly what you'd expect.

overall, based on the quality of the miso base and the fact that the extra pork is pork belly, i rate this place highly. would definitely go back.

PS the spicy ramen was also very tasty, but i just have to have that miso umami flavor.
author: Justin S.

description:
chicken curry don + ramen combo = $9.95. off the heezy, son! nuff said!

service was pretty awful since i sat outside. i'm sure they forgot about me. cuz i waited FOREVER for my fucking check. but the food makes up for it.  i'll definately be back!
author: B B.

description:
I'm a fan.  Generally the service is really friendly and the food is prepared with a bit more care than other restaurants in Japantown.

Try these guys out, but go early or plan tp put your name on a wait list.
author: keith t.

description:
i ruv. 

chewy udon, salty broth, crispy tempura, and since i onry have half hour for lunch, burnt tongue.
author: Winter R.

description: They had the best, most clear-tasting ramen without being too bland. We had to wait for the longest time for a table to open up, but I'll just blame that on luck. The restaurant is very small, so you should expect some wait unless you can avoid peak times. But the simple, well-prepared ramen noodles were impressive. Not too sodiumy, and the balance of all the ingredients were executed with confidence. You can tell if the chef(s) know what they are doing or not. I think I had the more spicy ramen than the normal one, and that proved me right. Comparing it to my friend's I could tell mine was more impressive.
author: Inbae L.

description:
Great noodles, good broth, bad service. 
I'd only recommend coming here as a party of 2. If there's a line, they seat parties of 2 at the big tables even when they know they have big parties waiting. Then they skip the big parties when the smaller tables open up and seat more 2 tops. Every other restaurant I've seen seats big parties at big tables, small at small when there's a wait. Suzu should do the same. 
Also, even when you're there, the service is very slow and inattentive. However, if you're patient, the ramen is quite good!
author: Paul A.

description: the mabo tofu soup is great.  their fresh noodles are a treat.
author: jane d.

description:
Wow, now I know why people say Yelp's rating is not trustable, this place is a 3.5 star??!!
It proves there're so many people out there who knows nothing about Japanese food and are still happily being ripped off by these kind of wannabe Japanese restaurants.

it was a big mistake that i even gave them a chance, i knew it's not gonna be good...... with the english only menu, in japantown.....

opened by some ignorant owner, which I'm sure is not Japanese, since their menu "Hayashi cold noodle" is wrong, it's should be  "Hiyashi"

I tried their Tonkatsu don, they just put the Tonkatsu on a large bowl of steam rice, with NOTHING ELSE in it. I was like Oh My God, what kind of cooking sense is that. And the portion of rice was so much that there's no way anyone could finish it with that amount of Tonkatsu in it. And it's $9.

Then the Vegetarian soba, they put soba in a soup as if it's a ramen, A BIG NONO. what in the hell they learn that from, soba is NOT ramen. and just a bunch of vegetable dumped in there, with a soup that's same as those come with instant noodles. $9 for this crap.

Again one of those restaurant opened by non-japanese trying to make some more money because they can charge you more for Japanese food.
Absolutely in my top 10 worst food I had in this country.
author: Kevin L.

description: I never know where to eat in Japantown because there aren't very many compelling places to dine...but I tend to think of Suzu because I know the food is good and it's pleasant and the value is good.
author: Debbie Y.

description: After Tombo closed in San Mateo, I was lost when it came to a good bowl of Udon.  That was until we tried this spot out.  It is what I think Japanese food is all about.  Nothing in excess, just the right amount of food.  Their lunch specials are a small rice bowl of your choice and a medium size bowl of noodles.  It is a small place, so don't bring more than 4 folks with you and I think they are closed on Tuesdays!
author: Jason A.

description: I was shocked to see the average for this restaurant was 3 1/2 stars.  I have always had the best ramen here.  I just took my boyfriend and he loved it too.  Prices are wonderful and so is the service.  I will definitely keep coming back here!!!!
author: Aimee G.

description:
every time i go jtown i've never made a stop to eat here.  i always would go to mifune and have their ten zaru~  love it!  hehe  since it was a cold evening me and bf thought we give this place a shot since the times we come its usually packed and long lines.  we ended up waiting for about 20mins not to bad.  

ordered spicy tuna roll and it was alright not that great.  i've had better.  the ramen definitely made it up.  the soup base was yummy!  sorry can't remember what i ordered but it was good to the point i've finished the bowl minus drinking all the broth.  hehe
author: mea f.

description: I went to this place with my coworkers for dinner on Thursday night.  It was a bit crowded and we had to wait about 15 minutes.  I ordered Shio ramen, which was good/okay.  My coworkers ordered Miso ramen and Udon, both of which seemed fine.  Not great but okay.  I might come back when I am nearby.
author: M Y.

description: Good ramen, but watch out for the spicy ramen.... it was SO spicy, that it was inedible; my entire mouth numbed up (and I am normally spicy-tolerant).  Otherwise, the noodles are tasty, but the service is slow and there is limited seating so the wait can often be long...
author: Grace M.

description:
As you can probably already see from the picture, this place is T-I-N-Y.
So it may take a bit of time to get seated. But let me just say that it will be worth every second of the wait! 

I tried the Unagi Don ramen a couple of days ago and it was very, very, very delicious. Maybe because I'm a huge fan of unagi and noodles in general that I liked it so much but  nonetheless this is definitely one of the better noodle places in San Francisco I've eaten at. The noodles are made daily- fresh, soft and chewy.

So in short: small place, may have to wait awhile to be seated, but great food and friendly waitresses.
author: Anthony J. C.

description: The best Ramen I've had in SF - the closest to what I had in Tokyo.  The only thing is that they have weird hours - don't try going for a late lunch.  The last 2 times I tried to eat there I came too late and the disappointment was to much to bear.
author: Gabriella K.

description: Wow. We've eaten at this place a good dozen times now and everytime we've left pretty satisfied. We've tried all of the ramen and some of the udon and soba. It's all delicious. It gets a star taken off because of the inconsistent service e.g. four of the five times we've ordered appetizers, it's come out after the noodles which is really frustrating.
author: Andy L.

description: Really tasty, very filling, reasonably priced Ramen.  Exactly what I wanted!  The downside - we had to wait about 40 minutes to be seated (2 people).  Apparently this is a happening spot.  It was around 2 pm on a Sunday though.  Anyway, I really enjoyed the food and experience once we were seated.  Service was attentive but quick - it definitely felt like they were trying to turn tables (and rightfully so with the long line behind us...)  We had a chicken ramen and a pork ramen - sadly, I cannot remember the exact names.  But my boyfriend's ramen was some kind of a fried chicken combo - and the fried chicken was delicious.  They both had hardboiled egg in them - yummmm.  Décor is minimalist, ambiance is no frills.  I have never had Japanese ramen anywhere else except for in Bangkok, Thailand (which was spectacular) - Suzu wasn't up to par with that experience, but I did enjoy myself all the same.  I'll be back.
author: Jenna C.

description:
The ramen here is pretty awesome, filling & reasonably priced!

On rainy days, I'll come here and get a huge steaming bowl of ramen!

It's small so depending on when u come, u might have to wait

they leave a notepad on a stool by the door, just put ur name down.

I now prefer Suzu to my old usual noodle shop upstairs, Sapporo-ya.
author: Kristin Z.

description: Our favorite noodle joint in the city. I usually get a big tasty bowl of vegetarian udon or ramen, my husband always orders the spicy negi ramen. The gyoza and shumai appetizers are both good, and the edamame is just salty enough. Obviously it's tiny so avoid the movie rush-hour on weekends. On cold or rainy nights, you can't beat underground parking and comfort food. We're only ever disappointed when we forget that it's closed on Tuesdays and have to eat at any of the other restaurants in Japantown.
author: guinevere h.

description: So... by now, if you had a chance to see my other reviews, you know that I love to eat ramen. I fell in love with ramen at a young age and have always been looking for the perfect ramen... It is a hard quest, I have traveled half the globe to find that ultimate taste that brings you closer to heaven with each bite... ok I lie... I think I rip that off a manga somewhere, but makes a great introduction eh? Anyways, this place is pretty basic, exactly what a ramen house should be. I had mapo ramen which was delicious, every single bite of spicy tofu beef made me euphoric. :) The major pet peeve that this place is tiny. Like 20 people tiny. :( I was almost dead with hunger by the time I was seated, and I slurped down my ramen without having a chance to enjoy it. Maybe I should go back next time after snaking first. :P
author: Tsu C.

description: Came for a late weekend lunch. Got cut by a retarded couple who claimed they didn't know about the sign up sheet. Tip: When you walk away from a place with no sign up sheet, that means you are no longer in line. Had the regular ramen with Katsu side. It was good enough to get me out of my funk staring at the retard couple. Watch out for the slippery floors here.
author: Randy K.

description: What a great place! Fresh noodles and creative options ranging from your standard udon to a curried edition.  They also have GREAT Ramen. Get there *before* they open at 11:30 or you'll be waiting. There was a large line which drew us to try it out in the first place. We were lucky that we got in immediately. Price was reasonable too.
author: Sheree E.

description: love love love this place...4 stars only because we always have to wait FOREVER for a table...not their fault though...they are just sooo good and busy all the time...my favorite is the vegetarian ramen with one raw egg on top....ummmm....yummy....had have almost everything on menu and luv it all...yumms...cant wait to go again...
author: Lisa F.

description: Ramen is great here and the combo is a good deal.  Wait can sometimes be a while.
author: Justin F.

description:
oh this is a great ramen place that nobody knows about. i can't wait to yelp about suzu -- or so i thought. damn it, there are already 17 reviews on suzu. once again, i'm humbled by yelp...

my friend and i stumbled upon suzu only because mifune and other japantown restaurants were closed on monday nights. suzu is smart for staying open on mondays. anyhow, my oh my, now this is ramen! it's one of the best ramens i had in a very long time. the ramen noodle was chewy and the broth was quite flavorful. it was so delicious that we slurped and sucked our way throughout the meal. um, we were somewhat embarassed by our lack of table manners, but i'm telling you it was that good. ok, we'll behave next time. 

for those who believe ramen is about top ramen or cup o' noodles, that's like comparing taco bell to papalote (insert your favorite burrito places here). you have no idea what you're missing. so please do yourself a favor. jaunt over to japantown while it's still around and have some delicious ramen.

* i believe suzu is closed on tuesday nights.
author: frisco j.

description: If you are jonesing for some ramen, get here early.  They've got a hot, tasty bowl waiting for you.
author: Tim G.

description: Pure Crap. How disappointing. I keep looking for ramen that even resembles anything in Japan and not a thing has come close so far. Someone recommended Suzu so I tried it and I'm sorry but this is not good ramen. Uncooked noodles and bland soup. Meh. The people waiting there clearly have no clue what good ramen tastes like. It's frustrating. True Japanese ramen would clearly take over the city if someone offered it. Why no one does is beyond comprehension
author: Gregg T.

description: Just ate here the other night  with a friend before we saw "(500) Days of Summer" (pretty awesome movie btw) and I must admit that the ramen noodles are pretty tasty.  Toothsome and fresh are other words that come to mind. I had the one with pork (so tender and flavorful and plentiful) and my friend Mike had the salmon ramen combo (not as exciting by the looks of it).  I've also had their udon here and they are very silky delicous!
author: Joe O.

description: Finally went to Suzu after hearing so much about it. The wait for lunch is loooong...so don't go here if you are in a hurry. Here's how to handle the wait. Put down your name on the list and then wander around in the Japan center, browse through the antique shops (if you break, you buy) and the bookstore and the flower shop next door. And then when you get back to waiting outside the restaurant because you are scared they will have called your name already, spend another 20 minutes staring at the people eating inside trying to get them to leave. And then, your turn finally arrives and you get seated in the small space. By this time, you have read the menu posted outside 5 times already and have decided what you want and changed your mind 4 times as well. So you are ready to order as soon as they bring your hot tea. I got the ramen and the mabo don combo - the food is definitely good. I spent a lot of time perfecting my ramen eating technique, sneaking looks at more experienced veterans and using my chopsticks and soup spoon to get the right ratio of noodle and soup into each mouthful. Again, the food is definitely delicious. All in all, an enjoyable afternoon Japanese meal.
author: Abheek G.

description:
so why the low rating? Well, it's hard to be positive on a restaurant that consistently closes upon their discretion and without communication of that decision to people waiting in line.  Many other posters have commented that Suzu consistently has a line but what most do not mention is Suzu's arbitrary cut off times when they decide they don't want to do anymore business but don't tell the people waiting.  The simply write something on the list and if you're unlucky enough to put your name down below someone else who didn't notice it, well then too bad for you.  Bottom line is that they have don't seem to have any interest in honoring the opening times they post on their door.

This has happened twice where, like idiots, we arrived 30-60 mins before the designated closing time only to wait for 5-10 mins with our name on the list before they had the "courtesy" to brush us off and tell us they were closed -- including 8:30 on a Friday night!

The catch here is that the ramen is very good but the service is generally very slow and unfriendly - as if you're intruding on them to be there.  So go if you want to try some of the best ramen in the city but be forewarned that the you may walk away disappointed that you didn't get to try it...
author: Jason M.

description: I order the Negi (spicy) Ramen and Miso Ramen. Delicious! Great prices, under 10$, and filling. Small place so go with no more than four in your party. They do take out, too, thank goodness!
author: Coco K.

description: American people don't know what they are talking about. Suzu provides the one of the best noodle and the soup in San Francisco. (well really there aren't other competitors...and other places in the city just sucks period) Train your mouth and visit there again.
author: Takahiro K.

description:
never not full , it's a small place, and i'd say probably not the best place to bring the kids considering there is so much boiling hot liquid going around. but the noodles are DELICIOUS! yummy salty goodness.
i had the shoyu ramen with pork, and it was awesome.
author: jane k.

description: I bookmarked Suzu Noodle House in January, 2008 and it took me a year to actually try it out, but I'm a fan! There always seems to be a long wait but thanks to plenty of no-shows we were seated almost immediately. My udon was excellent and the ramen received two thumbs up. Quite a bit better than Katana-Ya I'd say!
author: Will A.

description: This is a nice safe bet when in the area.  I went  with my kids before heading over to Yoshi's to see Oregon perform one of Yoshi's Sunday Matinee for Kids shows.  The kids both had vegetarian udon and to be truthful, we could have just had one order as they are pretty substantial and the kids were unable to eat it all.  One bowl would have been enough.  I had Kraaage Ramen and it was good, a bit too salty, but still pretty good.  Staff were nice, friendly and efficient.  We'll be back!
author: Ron T.

description:
I'll say it - best noodle house in SF! It's a great casual spot for delicious fresh ramen, udon and soba. My husband calls me a certified noodle-a-holic and this is my first choice when I get that noodle craving. 

The steaming bowl of ramen with chicken kara-age (order it appetizer size, otherwise the serving is kind of small) is my favorite - the ramen is the perfect balance of toothsome softness and chewiness, while the light, sweet broth is redolent with sweet flavor of pork and green onion. The combo is also good, their sake (salmon) and maguro (tuna) sashimi is also good, albeit a bit small. The prices are right though - for less than $10 per person, it's a great deal.
author: Dara Z.

description:
just got back from dinner there. i got the chicken curry udon, which was tasty. unfortunately, i didn't get it until my friends were halfway done with their noodles! i'm usually pretty patient, but this was ridiculous...plus, this place isn't big, it's not like they couldn't notice that i was the only one out of the three of us without a large bowl of noodles in front of me. when i finally asked, they just kept saying 'it's coming, it's coming, sorry.' hmm...i just want my noodles! 

my cousin had the shiyo ramen, which was had a tasty, light broth, but a little on the salty side. we also got an order of edamame. it came with salt on the outside, which usually i kinda like, but these were really salty. we also got the hiyayakko appetizer, which was really just a piece of tofu with some chopped green onion on top, hmm...i could make this at home. and we waited about 20 minutes for these apps, how long does it take to cut some tofu and chop some green onions? 

anyways, i would maybe come back to try it again, just because it was tasty, and i like me a bowl of hot soup noodles on a cold day. i'll just have to be prepared to wait awhile for my food...
author: Angela W.

description:
This was a solid ramen place, not the best.  There was a line when I went there so I had to wait 15 minutes.  We got a chasu ramen and a tokyo ramen.  The noodles tasted ok, but nothing special.  The brooth did not have enough flavor.  The prices are reasonable, but I would not come to San Francisco just to eat there.

For some other choices, I recommend Santa Ramen, Maru ichi, or Higuma
author: Raymond K.

description:
for some reason i had thought this place was called zuzu.  but i think it is because i was reading the name from the inside of the glass and they write the s with the same corners as the z.  or maybe im dyslexic.  anyways ...

we got here at around 8:30 on a monday night and the place only had one table open.  we were seated promptly.  the service is a bit weird.  the waitresses kept looking at me funny.  i have no idea why.  do i have something on my face?  anyways again ...

we both ordered nabeyaki udon.  me with the oden one.  my friend with the beef one.  both were kind of small for charging $12something for it.  you eat oden with mustard.  when i asked for it.  guess what they brought me.  on a little soy sauce plate.  as if i couldnt tell.  guess what?  heinz mustard!!!  wth.  they didnt have the japanese mustard?

the udon noodles were chewy and not mushy.  i like them that way.  but im not asking for mustard there again to eat with my oden.  maybe im not getting oden there again.

i came here again on a second try and actually got so infuriated with the seating situation that i left but i cant remember why now.  i remember asking the hostess if i could sit down and she said no or something.  last night i went back and noticed that they seat people first come first serve regardless of table size.  for example if the next names on the list were john 1 and jane 3 and the next open table was for 4 people they would go ahead and seat the one dude john at the table for 4.  

this time i got the hiya yakko tofu, edamame, and pea shoots ramen.  sometimes im a picky eater.  i wanted a certain broth (shio) with certain toppings (chicken and veggies) and she had to go into the kitichen and ask.  it took her a good 5 minutes.  AND it was an $1 to make THAT ramen $12.  WTF??  its not like shio broth is more expensive.  i was like nm and got the pea shoots ramen which they call cilantro but it isnt really cilantro.  when it came i was a bit shocked, the pea shoots were raw.  i pushed them underneath the ramen but they were still raw when i ate them last.  ugh

and theres a big sign that says they dont do take out anymore

i really want to like this place .. but theyre making it hard
author: claudia y.

description: we were just passing through japan town to see how it compared to l.a. j-town. this area is real nice, better then i thought it was going to be. theres a lot more restaurant options then l.a. j-town. we both had a craving for japanese food. decided on ramen here. we both had our share of ramen back home, so this place had to meet high expectations.  she had the miso ramen, while i had the spicy ramen. we liked both very much. my ramen could have been hotter but it hit the spot. we both shared an order of tempura which was also good. the only thing i could say negative is the portion size. i think the ramen places back in l.a. serve bigger portions. but we both left with smiles on our faces and we would definitely come back again when were in s.f.
author: Joey H.

description:
real good ramen, great svc, nice joint. i feel comfortable there.

FOOD: ~i was very happy w/my shoyu ramen, nice satisfying bowl of noodles & good broth. however, they only gave me 1 slice of char siu like katana-ya. is this normal?! i had stomach flu so couldn't eat much else. UPDATE: after my j-town ramen tour this wk, suzu will probably be my go-to ramen spot. i'll order the char siu ramen to get more of the delicious meat next time & ask if they can add some kamaboko & i'll just pay extra. i'd also like hard-boiled egg, but that's probably asking for too much.

SERVICE: the svc is awesome! truly sweet girls. reminds me of me, & hey u can't beat that j/p. even tho i sat @ the small table outside, which usu makes me worry i'll be forgotten about, they were super attentive.

DECOR: warm & comfortable. nothing fancy, just very inviting.

BATHROOM: in j-town kikokuniya bldg.

OVERALL: would totally go back again & again! beats the hell out of sapporo-ya.
author: miss b.

description: I really liked the consistency of the noodles, better than Sapporo-ya upstairs.  Nice and firm with some bite.  Has interesting enough menu that makes me want to go back.  I like the comfortable minimalist atmosphere.  I like the ramen best at this place, of the places I have found in the city.
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description:
I ate here recently after eating ramen at a few other places --- this place really has some of the best noodles around. The flavor and homemade egg noodles are so much better than other places I've been to recently. 

A great, affordable place to get a big bowl of noodles and broth. Mmmm. 

-------------------------
Yummy noodle place in Japantown mall. Try the Karaage Ramen if you like a little fried chicken (japanese style of course) with your noodles. I've tried a lot of the dishes there -- from the tempura ramen to the gyoza -- and all have been solid for the under $10 prices. Thanks for JYW for reminding me what this place is called.
author: J K.

description: Okay place to go for okay food.  They certainly give you good portions for the $8.95 that you are paying, but it's all noodles and broth and not a lot of toppings.  My miso ramen came with one small slice of pork and a couple of bamboo shoots and some green onions.  The broth was tasty but not amazing.  We also had the potato croquettes to start, which was also okay.  Seems like a good stand-by if there aren't better options around (I saw there were several other ramen places close by), but I don't think I would go out of my way to go there.
author: I-Chant C.

description:
word on the street is that Suzu went under different ownershit. yea, ownerSHIT basically because it is SHIT. the past two times i have been there my party was refused a table because they were closing. the first time it was lunch and they close at 3:00 and we got their at 2:30, what the hell kind of service is that??? the other time was the same time difference but for dinner. 
the service and the whole restaurant is a LAZY POS. we ordered some ramen to go and they said they didn't do "to-go" (this was before they put up that sorry "no to-go" sign in the window) and when they finally did they put the ramen in the broth- OK, any logical person knows that the noodles need to be separated from the broth for to-go orders. 
 they either have a lot of money and don't give an eff or they are lazy. i will go with they are lazy and I'm not going to eat their greasy ass ramen anymore.
author: andree t.

description: 4.5 stars.  I've eaten a lot of ramen in Japan and in the states, and I thought the cha shu ramen at Suzu was really good, especially for the price.  The waitresses were really friendly as well.  I haven't tried other items on the menu and I went at a off-hour (so now wait) so maybe my good experience today won't be consistent but I will definitely be going back there to find out.
author: yohans w.

description: This place has gotta be one of my favorites. the wait can get to be a little much, but i gotta say its worth it. i love their spicy ramen. the place is elbows touching tiny. but if you want good ramen, go to suzus! i still need to try tanpopo apparently.
author: tuna t.

description: Simple and tasty Ramen, perfect for a cold foggy evening
author: Insi L.

description: My husband and I were visiting from Chicago and we were craving homemade ramen noodles.  I did some research and we went to Suzu.  I had the regular ramen and my husband had the spicy ramen.  It was sooo good.  The next day, all my husband could think about was ramen so we decided to try another place.  It did not compare to Suzus so a few hours later, we went to Suzus and we were both satisfied.  If Suzus was open earlier, we probably would have eaten there before our flight the next day.
author: An A.

description: I was a regular here(when they still had the planter in the middle of the dining room) until they got too popular and the lines got me trying other places. But I guess I chose a bad night to come back. The person who does the seating had our group of three squeeze into a two person table since they had a four person group coming in but when that group didn't show  I asked if we could move to that table the hostess said they had already seated the next group. Okay that was fine. But then when another 4 person group didn't show and the next was a group of two and the host seated them at that table it was just the last straw. And when someone from our group asked the hostess a second time she refused us again! And who do you think had the heart to help us out? The group of two who they seated at the 4 person table overheard my friend talking to the hostess and they told the host that they would be happy to exchange with our group. (whoever those two girls are, thank you thank you very much! You are angels that made a bad night and a bad mood turn around! Peace and love to you!) And then not even a hint of an apology from the hostess. I have to be fair though Suzu's food is top rate it's just the horrible customer service that ruined the whole dining experience. It will definitely be a long while or when that hostess is not on duty until I try Suzu or even recommend it to anyone. (and I'm considered the nice one in my circle of friends!)
author: Zac C.

description:
Ever since Tokushima Ramen in Saratoga closed, we have been searching for a ramen house that is remotely as good or better. Our search had not been fruitful, and we found the worst at Suzu. 
We judge ramen according to several criteria: broth, noodle, cha-shu, garnishes and overall balance. 
We ordered 2 bowls of Cha-shu ramen (which was the closest thing to a shoyu ramen) and 1 bowl of shio ramen. The first sip of our respective broths showed promise, but I know something was wrong. It seemed the broth was very very well seasoned, which was an indication of whatever you were eating would turn out to be too salty in the end. It turned out the problem was not the broth but the cha-shu. The meat slices were super salty; so salty that they made everything else salty. Forget about other criteria, the saltiness was bad enough to ruin everything! Now here is our problem with the service. Never once did the servers come by the check on the tables. Never once did the servers do anything when I told them about the food was overly salty. I am not the type that will find a flaw in a meal, complain about it and except to be comped. This is not my style, but I DO expect some sort of, "dude, we are sorry, we screwed up." Maybe I am just sick of poorly ran restaurants where the managements are nonchalant about complaints, and servers are afraid to apologize for the kitchen. But worst of all I had to continue my search for the next best ramen house. 
By the way, two of us ran to the bathroom about 8 hours after our meal and nothing solid came out, which is a sign of at least a mild case of food poising, and the only person did not run to the restroom had not touched the cha-shu.
author: Marco C.

description: Terrible service. I have a party of six at a half full restaurant and they refuse to seat us. The waitress said we don't seat parties greater than four and we don't move tables to seat you. I will never eat here again and advise others to stay away.
author: Calvin K.

description:
yummy ramen! lots of ramen choices and some non-ramen dishes like donburi....taste is similar to katanya ya if you get the spicy version..

i usually come here on weekdays, and there is never a line, but i went once on a weekend around lunch time and it was packed ( 40+ wait)
author: krystina ann r.

description: Some of the best noodles in Japantown and I lived in Tokyo for 3 years. However it can be hit or miss at times. Also the staff could take some lessons on seating optimization as well as service.
author: Brian Y.

description: Something about this place changed.  We used to come here, and it was great.  Last night we went, and it was different.  The menu is different, the presentation changed, and the bowls they use are not the same.  Also, the ramen is not nearly as good as it once was.  The broth was thin-tasting, and there were way too many noodles to the amount of broth they served.  Also, the tea tasted acrid, like coffee.  I think they use toasted rice tea, and it didn't taste the way it should taste.  We're not coming back.
author: jessica d.

description: very friendly spot, super fast service! if you like ramen on a cold night in SF then come here! make sure u sign the list to get your name as often there are people waiting but it goes quick. Props for having a truly vegetarian ramen in a vegetarian (no fish or meat broth) BUT it was pretty bland, so maybe add a miso base or shitake mushroom base to make it more flavorful. But honestly i add some soy sauce and hot pepper and it tasted pretty good.  I think so far though Genki's vegetarian curry ramen takes the cake. But give this place a shot, i've heard most of the other items are SUPER yum! Also, really friendly and sweet service!
author: sue c.

description: Really good ramen. The broth is very well balanced. One of the best places in the city.
author: Svet V.

description:
Wow! Good real Ramen Noodles.  Made fresh too.  If you are a noodle person, this place might do you good.   I had my first real bowl of ramen noodles there, and I love it.  It makes me constantly think about noodles, dreamed about it, and tried to re-create it at home.  
Bad thing about this place is that, there is usually a looooooooooooooong waiting line if you go there during the weekends and Fridays.  The restaurant is very small.   Some people may not pay $9 dollars for noodles.
I would go there again.
author: Megatron D.

description: This place is one of my favorite places in the city. I used to come here quite frequently when I lived closer. The food is delicious and priced well. Wish it was closer so I could eat here more often. Perfect place to eat when it is chilly out.
author: CaliGirl S.

description: Japanese noodles made fresh daily... it's hard to beat.  Go for the well-proportioned combos.  You'll never have noodles at Mifune again.  :)
author: Chris M.

description: I love this place!  Best shoyu ramen - It's simple, authentic (perfect soup base), with a little spicy negi on top.  I love it!  Good service, simple and comfortable setting (little stack of books to read is a nice touch too.) My favorite ramen place in the city.
author: Haru K.

description:
I have tried many noodle places in Japantown and throughout San Francisco and few of them hold a flame to Suzu.  My personal favorite is the combo ramen noodles and salmon don (salmon sashi over rice).  It is a pretty hearty portion for a decent price (around $10).  They have a fairly wide variety of noodles to choose from--udon, ramen, soba, somen--and have fairly authentic tasting dishes.  Also, the ramen with kara age chicken (japanese fried chicken) comes highly recommended.

The only drawback is that the restaurant is very small and they don't take reservations so you usually have to wait.  But it is definitely worth it!
author: Karisa L.

description: Not bad... but not great.  I was hoping something in a neighborhood called Japantown would blow my mind.  Meh.  I like the noods at the Porter Exchange better.  Maybe i went to the wrong place? Next time I'm in SF, i'll have to do more research.
author: luke b.

description: It is good for what it is. A quick, relatively inexpensive tasty meal of ramen. The Karrage Ramen was quite good. Will definitely come again when in the area.
author: Doug M.

description: Suzu simply has the best ramen in the Bay Area. It is even better than Santa Ramen.  I have tried some of the best noodle houses in Tokyo and I know Suzu is almost as good.
author: Tony Z.

description: Came here with a friend after reading all the good reviews on Yelp, left very disappointed. First of all, the waitresses didn't even speak Japanese -- that was worrisome. We tried the tempura hiyashi (tempura with cold noodles) and the miso ramen. They were both decent, but neither were worth the $8.95 price tags and the time it took to get to the restaurant, especially given the paltry servings. Granted, I haven't visited any other noodle houses in San Francisco, but I'll be sad if this is the best there is.
author: Ryo M.

description: To date, the best ramen I've had in the city.  The noodles and broth are both great, and there's a decent selection of other stuff on the menu.  I like the negi ramen.
author: Ficus K.

description:
I love soup...especially on the many cloudy/foggy days we get down here...

So I FINALLY was able to try this place after 2 tries where we go shot down by long lines. The place is small but really nice.. I ordered the "Mobo Ramen" (Ramen noodles with spicy ground pork and tofu) and we had some fried oysters, some sashimi and gyoza. The noodles themselves are really good, they seem freshly made. The broth was a bit more salty than I prefer but still very good. Gyozas & oysters were really good as well and shashimi fresh and tasty. Prices are average for this type of fare....I would definitely go back!
author: Steve K.

description:
2.5 stars 

i found myself in j-town today, a bit cold and cloudy, so a bowl of ramen seemed like the perfect thing. based on the hype i've heard about this place, it's been on my list to check out.

i ordered mabo ramen (tofu, ground pork in a special broth) and a side of kaarage (fried chicken). waaaah! i am so disappointed. so disappointed...

the breakdown:
- i arrived around 5:30pm so the wait was not that long. good.

- since it was myself, the server asked me if i wanted a table outside. i actually like these tables, and i didn't feel boxed in by the black walls, so if you can get these tables, i would highly suggest. good.

- service was attentive, honest and excellent. i asked if they made their gyoza, and she admitted no, so she steered me towards the kaarage which they made in house.

- side of kaarage. absolutely delicous! light, crispy and flavorful. kind of reminded me of fried chicken you get at korean restaurants which was not a bad thing in my book. however, the pathetic little iceberg lettuce salad served with it is so bland throwback from the 50's, it needs some help. all in all, i rate the kaarage as very good, and worth ordering.

- mabo ramen. house specialty of special broth, tofu cubes and ground pork. i'll say off the bat that the ramen noodles, themselves, were tasty and had a nice, springy texture. however.... the broth and all the fillings were so bland, so unnoticeable, so wrong, i couldn't believe that they thought this ramen was even worth serving.

i hate to be so harsh, but a ramen restaurant the size of a pillbox with a small menu should be churning out decent ramen. that means focus on the whole package: the noodles, the broth and the fixins'. my mabo ramen was packed with tofu, but barely had any ground pork and the taste of the broth was practically non-existent. i swear it tasted like they might have thinned it with a lot of water and some salt. there was like a "hint" of broth.

i had to come home and check nobu k's review to make sure i'm not crazy. i also agree with him as to the confusion of all the other udons and soba dishes here. i wanted ramen and only ramen, and only found a few items on the menu as such. oh well, i guess you've got to please the masses.

i feel a bit bad about reviewing so low after one visit, but i will come back here to try other dishes, and will make sure to check yelp first for recommendations.

lastly, my service was excellent, so a side of 4 stars for the waitstaff.
author: Antoi C.

description: My first time having ramen and I really enjoyed it.  Even though its in a mall - it's family owned place and feels like it.  I had the Tokyo Ramen which comes with pork, half a boiled egg, bamboo shoots, seaweed and lots of noodles...yummy.  The wait was a bit long though, as this is a very small place.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Maybe because it was nippy and in the mood for something in the form of a soup...well alas!...my cravings were answered having frequented this establishment on a chilly Friday afternoon. I knew something was up when I noticed a line of anxious customers waiting deligently to enjoy their steamy dishes. I had the Spicy Ramen Soup accompanied with potatoe pot stickers while my friends had a chicken and salmon dish respectively...prices were reasonable and we enjoyed our lunch...indeed!
author: Dennes H.

description: Overrated? Expected too much? I don't know, but it seems to be so. I've heard Suzu was supposed to be good. I tried coming here before, but it was crowded and the lunch list just ended, so I decided to go elsewhere. I was finally able to try Suzu yesterday for lunch with Eugenia G. We got there around noon and it was already packed and in addition, a list. Like Eugenia G. stated, the workers looked extremely tired and lacked energy. I ordered the salmon don with ramen combo with extra cha shu. The waitresses emphasized "it will be extra". I thought that was pretty rude... The ramen was decent, not the best I've had. I believe it was the hype that got my excited about this place in the first place. The salmon was actually pretty delicious, but the waitress was VERY skimpy on the wasabi. What's up with that?! I asked for additional wasabi and I got maybe a LITTLE bit more. Other than the tea and salmon, everything was OK at best. Cha shu was very thin and even with the extra cha shu, I did not see a difference. Like some people say... Yelp over hype some of these restaurants. To stay respectful, I will not name other ramen restaurants in my Yelp.
author: Edgar G.

description: I love how they give you hot tea once you sit down! And the pork and chicken broth was very good, but the ramen noodles themselves were just OK. I still plan to hunt around for a better ramen place. I spent around $13 with tip, so not bad.
author: M H.

description: Well. Lucky for Suzu we were pretty hungry (and disappointed Sushi Bistro was closed) and it was the first place we saw out of the Kabuki garage. We each got a lunch combo, reasonably priced at $8.50. Combo 1: tempura don and ramen, Combo 2: chicken curry rice and ramen. Both good, just-right portions, though the "chicken" curry came with one piece of chicken. The noodle quality was above average, with one slice of roast pork and the broth a bit on the salty side. Decent, good service, but not much more.
author: Maximillian M.

description: If you get the Ramen with the fried chicken ... the fried chicken is great and only thing worth rating. Service was okay, a bit slow maybe because we were seated outside in the patio. The noodles had a terrible texture that can only be described as rubbery and inconsistent. The broth was only okay.
author: Natasha S.

description: The food here is really good. I usually like to get the combo with ramen and curry since I'm quite fond of their curry there. The noodles here are really yummy. Personally, I'm not a huge fan of the broth but my siblings love it. The place is cramped though and wait times can get pretty bad. Service is a bit lacking since there's only two waitresses and at times they do forget things.
author: Julie L.

description: Our office ordered to-go from here last week.  It was quite an ordeal as I think they get really busy and don't always answer the phone so it took a number of tries to get through.  Very reasonable lunch prices.  I got the lunch combo of ramen and unagi bowl.  The unagi bowl portion is pretty small but they give a very generous container of ramen.  The ramen was so-so.  I think maybe one of the reasons is that they didn't separate the noodle from the broth, thus leaving the noodles to just soak.   Hopefully, they are fellow yelpers and will consider separating the two after reading my review.
author: Stella C.

description: I love these noodles. I'm surprise Suzu has such low ratings. I thought the fresh ramen with veggie and tofu was excellent. Also, fried tofu appetizers were delicious too. Not much service, but seems like a quick bite to eat kind of place. Sit down, order, eat, and leave.
author: Royce L.

description:
its ok. average, clean inside, that sink seems out of place.
nice presentation when your food arrives.
seems to be getting more busy.
author: JASON L.

description: This place is great for a quick light meal. The noodles are a great hang over cure. They're also a good cure if you feel a cold coming on. Cap a meal here with the crepes upstairs and you're all set. Get there early though because the seating is limited and it fills up fast. Oddly, they're closed on Tuesday.
author: Richard S.

description: I was craving for ramen. Ever since we moved to SF, we haven't found any ramen place that is comparable to the ramen we love in Hawaii. Anyway, my Japanese GF took me here for dinner. Must say that the service was good, but the ramen was okay- I ordered the spicy green onion ramen- to me it needed more salt. The place is very small that they have a long line by certain time. So, be sure you come early! However, the price is very decent, no cheap enough, but it was okay overall. Don't know if I would come again, maybe I could find a better place for ramen.
author: Daisy S.

description: This small casual noodle place in the ground floor of the Kinokuniya Building in the Japantown Center really fits the bill when you need a quick bowl of hot or cold noodles. The mabo ramen my friend got was extremely delicious - with rich, savory broth that warmed you all the way through. My cold ramen noodles with tempura were simple and tasty, though not as impressive a dish overall.  I will absolutely go back to sample more from the menu - there was plenty there to whet the appetite!
author: Aimee G.

description:
they gave our table away THREE TIMES (almost four until we told them forget it). 
didn't apologize, didn't even acknowledge that they had done that. 

no sense of customer service, won't try to eat here again.
author: Kelly C.

description: Worth waiting for if its packed. The place is located inside Japantown downstairs where it is small and packed. Their sobas are great, but not worth jumping off the bridge for.
author: Prescott T.

description: My hubby and I came here for lunch today and it was packed! We waited for about 15  minutes and finally got a table.  I had the Tokoyo Ramen and my hubby had the udon & unagi combo.  We thought the food was good and the service was great.  The only problem was that the restaurant is so small there was just a huge line!  I would definitely go back again...maybe not during peak time :)
author: JenJen W.

description: I used to do the rounds at various Japantown ramen joints (Iroha, Sapporo-ya, Tanpopo, etc.), but once I found Suzu, I'd found The One. Suzu's is the most consistent shoyu ramen to be had in SF. A little skimp on the fixins, sure, but the broth always has the right salty zing and the noodles are perfect and supple. Can't comment on styles other than shoyu, since that's what I always order when I get ramen.
author: Calvin L.

description: My friend took me here because she likes their ramen. I've heard of the place on yelp so I wanted to try them out. We got there at 4pm so we had an hour before they would reopen for dinner. We walked around Japantown and came back around 5pm. There were a few empty tables so we got to sit right away. There was the option to sit outside but we decided to sit inside. We waitress was quick to take our order and the food came pretty quickly too. The ramen on the menu pretty much comes with pork and a choice of a side dish. I thought that was pretty neat since no other place that I know of does that. My friend highly recommended the potato croquettes so we ordered that and shared a tempera pork ramen ($10 something). The potato croquettes were pretty good but not amazing. I noticed the ramen only came with one slice of pork. Just one and a thin one at that! Come on...and the broth was not too good either. What determines a good bowl of ramen is mainly the broth and this place did not cut it. I was disappointed. Take your business to Tanpopo instead. I also realized later that they did not offer any broth options - salt, soy sauce, miso, etc. So that's another thing I did not like.
author: Helen L.

description:
Despite the recent ramen boom here, Suzu is the best ramen place in SF. Namely, the miso ramen and tempura donburi combo for lunch. The broth is complex, the miso is tasty and good quality, the noodles are chewy, and the portion is just right. (The only other miso ramen we crave is at Miso-ya in front of Nagano station in Japan using Shinshu miso.) 

The tempura in the donburi has a good variety of veggies,plus shrimp for such a small bowl, and a drizzle of their signature sauce rather than the traditional broth, which we like, though a tad too salty. I'd skip the shumai, which taste like frozen and microwaved.
author: Debbie B.

description: by far my favorite ramen in sf. the broth makes me feel like home. i dont really know what that means, but to me, no other ramen in sf compares.
author: Lia A.

description:
came here quite a while ago with a group of 5. we were seated and served promptly. all i remember of my bowl of ramen was that, other than the quality of the noodles and the fixin's on top, it tasted like a packet of top ramen. the broth tasted very msg-heavy and somewhat synthetic, like nachos or something.

on the plus side, the pork on top was decent, the noodles themselves were cooked right, and the portions were massive. also the pickles they brought at the beginning were pretty tasty.
author: Dana D.

description: The udon and soba noodles are very good... however 12.50 is steep!  The big drag to the restaurant is the long wait list to eat- since there are no reservations.  I waited almost 45 minutes to get seated and then the service is somewhat typical (terse yet efficient).  With two apps and two entrees and one large beer the total came up to 65 dollars!  65 dollars to get udon and soba noodles?  Look, go to Mifune upstairs and get that same fresh noodles for half the cost.
author: Anne L.

description: We always go for their shoyu ramen and gyoza. Probably the best tasting in the SF Bay Area. Their portions, however, are not the greatest. The gyoza comes in 5 pieces and is definitely on the small side, along with the dipping sauce that comes with it; and the condiments in their ramen feels like a half-order compared to the noodles. I must say, the presentation and texture/taste of their ramen noodles are bar-none, the best I've eaten to date. If you go, go early because there are only 12 or so tables and the lines to get in are notoriously long...for good reason!
author: Akira K.

description: I love Ramen, I love Sashimi and I love Japantown. Suzu's is my absolute favorite restaurant in San Francisco...I'm become a regular... =) This is the only place that has Ramen and Sashimi combos, all located in an area that's clean and has parking....Service is great, Fish is fresh and the Ramen is to perfection!!!
author: Winnie L.

description: This hole-in-the-wall ramen stand can offer spotty service and the atmosphere is more train station than restaurant, but the noodles are wonderful with good texture.  There's sometimes a long wait--sometimes over 30 minutes.  The food isn't classy, rather homey, comforting and warm--the perfect antidote to a cold day.  Fitting for the Japantown center.  My favorite is the mabo dofu ramen, which has just the right amount of spice.  Having gone there weekly for several months, I think the food is consistently good and reasonably priced.
author: QuodE D.

description:
Wow, I couldn't believe how small this place was. There was maybe 6 tables inside and 2 more small ones outside. Fortunately, we went early for dinner and didn't have to wait too long. The food was great. I had one of their hot pot udon dishes and both the noodles and broth were excellent. There was some tempura in it as well and the squash tempura was very tasty. 
The only drawback was that the service was rather slow. I think they only had 2 waiters and they were doing some cooking as well.
author: Olivia H.

description:
Suzu is my regular ramen house in San Francisco.  It's serves up the best actual ramen type noodles in the city in my honest opinion, & I've tried many ramen joints here searching for good ramen.  Of course you've got to wait during peak times.  That's inevitable, for there are only about 10 tables, including the 2 out in the mall area.  But I think it's worth the wait.  The noodles are home made, fresh, and have great tooth.  I go for the basic Tokyo ramen.  I'm no nonsense about ramen.  After all, ramen is all about the noodles.  The broth is for flavoring; if you drink it, you may end up with a belly ache - it's way too fatty to absorb without digestion issues.  
     I've had some items on the side once in a while.  Karaage, sashimi, tofu, seaweed, etc.  Not very often, however.  I usually order my bowl of ramen as I'm sitting down to a table.  "Tokyo ramen & hot sake."  Followed by Sapporo.  Hai, dozo!
author: Roland C.

description: We got to the restaurant at 6pm tonite, before the dinner rush. The restaurant is essentially a single room, so seating is tight. We got an order karaage (japanese fried chicken) to start, and I got the Tokyo Ramen and Tony got the Shio Ramen. According to the menu, the soup is a chicken and pork broth. Both dishes had a piece of fatty pork, some baby bok-choy, some pickled radish, half a boiled egg, and some seaweed. The ramen was ok. The soup was very salty, which didn't balance well with the saltiness of the pork and pickled radish. They flavors didn't blend well.  As you all know, the soup is a huge part of teh ramen experience. In J-Town, I prefer Tanpopo or Iroha (for their gyoza ramen), or even Sapporo-Ya.
author: Annie Y.

description: Nothing spectacular about the ramen broth but the noodles are nicely-done--chewy and resistant to the bite.
author: Hopia M.

description:
i'd seen long lines for a year so i was really mystified when i finally ate here.  was this one of those san francisco places that was all buzz and no content? i think so.

the waitress who seated us after a 25 minute wait in line was pretty surly and disinterested.  i knew we were in for disappointment when the $9.95 sashimi platter arrived...4 pieces of tuna, 4 of salmon, each piece the size and taste of a tiny eraser.  we also tried a noodle dish for the famous udon.  while the noodles themselves were firm and delicious, the broth was like dishwater.  my friend couldn't even eat it.

the tasteless minature sashimi, the blah soup broth, and a highly oversalted edamame came to $30.  on a good day at mifune upstairs it allwould have been $10 less and much much better.

plus no line.  and sweet waitresses.
don't bother on this one.
author: T S.

description: My wife and I love the spicy negi ramen.  Noodles are fresh and broth is great.  Chicken karaage and agedashi tofu appetizers are good.  Almost always long lines but at least they quickly take your order and serve you.  Combos are good deals.  Tried nabeyaki udon once which was just okay, so now I just stick with spicy negi ramen.  Service for tea refill and water can be iffy.  No options for different types of broth.
author: L S.

description: Make sure you arrive before the dinner/lunch rush or else you will have to wait. I ordered the chicken Katsu ramen which was really tasty and i loved the noodles. Im coming back here for sure. The servers were very friendly.
author: Jay M.

description: I ate here right after it opened and I thought it would end my quest for ramen-in-the-city.  The noodles were fresh and al dente, the broth was good, and the prices were right.  Unfortunately, every subsequent visit has yielded smaller portions (until I got only one nugget of chicken in my karaage ramen) and saltier broth.  Why did you have to fail me, Suzu?
author: Janut B.

description: By far one of the best Ramen spots in the city.  They are both friendly and efficient.  Yeah, there is better Ramen to be had in the greater Bay Area, but definitely not as cozy and comfy as this.  Suzu is one of the few noodle houses that make me finish both all my noodles and broth.  The wait is fairly decent (15 - 30 minutes) and the parking slightly difficult.  The space is comfortable despite the fact that you're in the Japantown mall.  Suzu is a place that I plan to frequent because of the quality of food and the sheer glowing satisfaction that I feel even hours after the meal.
author: Darkie L.

description: The next stop on the Ramen Noodle Express brough my dining companions to Suzu.  Present were the Flaming Carrot, The Good Doctor and Susan "Sue is my name and Pork is also my name" Pork.  We all got the standard ramen.  The broth was incredibly flavorful with those glistening droplets of pork fat.  The flavor was rich and the meat was tender, although the porktion was a bit skimpy.  No egg, either, but the price more than made up for the lack of dead chicken.  This is definitely going to be a favorite spot!
author: Frankie D.

description: The itty bitty noodle house that could. This petite corner spot was very impressive in both service and presentation We ordered the salmon sashimi/ udon noodle combo and were not disappointed. Fresh, buttery sahimi with perfectly textured rice and rich udon broth (loved the crispy onions in that bowl). Feeling really spoiled right now as I've been to J-town 4 times within the last 2 weeks. I could go there every day.
author: Sandrita R.

description: Quaint and small joint.  Definitely one of the best noodle places in town - it's all made there and fresh.  They even have some sashimi and the way they present them and how it is cut is really cool. YUM!  I almost always eat here after treating myself at Kabuki Spa.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Suzu is a simple, small ramen place. The fried chicken appetizer is very good. I ordered a vegetable and tempura udon noodle bowl. Very good flavor...simple miso broth. The udon noodles were perfectly cooked. The charsu meat was very good. Has the "authentic" ramen house feel, seems like they have 1 cook in the kitchen, and 1 waitress.

This place would be an excellent place to come when the weather cools down. Warm noodles on a cold day, does it get any better?
author: Matt K.

description: I came here a couple weeks ago with my friend on one of those cold San Francisco days. I haven't had much experience with fresh ramen, but this place was definitely a good start!
