I ordered the chicken karaage ramen, which only had a few pieces of karaage, but definitely plenty of noodles and broth. The noodles were good and broth flavorful.  I'll have to go to another noodle house to compare, but I think the ramen's great here.
author: Jane K.

description: what a hype!!! since we were staying in japan town, decided to go to suzu noodle since it got good reviews on yelp. Well.. not worth it. I can't believe I paid $12 for some average, no tasting tokyo ramen. Not impressed. At least the samauri noodle in seattle is only $7 for bowl of ramen with 3 huge pieces of pork. I really think all the restaurants in japan town are overpriced and average. will not be coming back for sure
author: Shy z.

description: Really good! A great variety and decent atmosphere and service.
author: jamie c.

description: Worth the wait.  Hold the appetizers and save that appetite for the soup!
author: F D.

description: Pretty fresh noodles is all I really have to say. The bbq pork in the ramen was very "umami." Service could have definitely been better....
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
Did anyone read a discreetly posted sign from the health dept. on their lower left window?  It's right next to their high score report also from the health dept. Check it out next time you go. It reads something like the food and beverages they serve might cause cancer, birth and reproductive defects. I had to read it several times to comprehend because I guess I didn't believe what I was reading.

I was waiting outside their entrance when I noticed it.  The sign didn't deter me from eating there because I really liked their tempura udon.  What drove me away was the waitress's reaction.  I wanted her to explain the sign and settle my unease.  Maybe it was nothing or perhaps it was some Japanese ingredients that the health dept. didn't understand.  So when I asked the waitress what the sign meant and she pretended she didn't know what sign I was talking about, my alarm went off.  I pointed the sign to her and she brusquely responded by showing me to my table.   At the table, I asked her again what the sign meant and she said she didn't know.  I thought with that reaction, it must be something, so I left.  I still can't find a tastier tempura udon place, but I'll keep looking.
author: Lisa F.

description:
this one is an okay ramen place.  it tastes like the noodles are store-bought rather than home-made.  soup is okay.  personally i like tonkotsu style, which suzu does not have.  this place does not have the true japanese style ramen- a mere imitation at best. 

i'm still searching for a good ramen place in the city.....
author: E S.

description: The place is small and always crowded with a waiting list. The broth is good if not a little too oily and salty. If you like fatty pork, you'll like theirs. They've got lunch combination sets that my parents like to get, so they can try new things. For me, this place is not worth the wait it usually is when I never have to wait at Iroha.
author: Tiff L.

description: It was 4 in the afternoon on a Saturday, we were in Japantown, and we thought we'd try that really good ramen place in the Kinukiniya building. We were directed to a table, sat down, and were absorbed in our conversation. After 10 minutes or so, we realized that we were not given menus, tea, or any attention at all. So we made eye contact with 2 of the waitstaff, and were still ignored. So we left. Fuck you, too, Suzu.
author: Bruce M.

description: call me crazy but i actually like this place better than santa ramen.  i got the chicken and vegetable ramen and it was soooOoo good.. the broth was yummy and seasoned just right.. (not hella salty like santa ramen where you can't even drink some of it).. plus. its in jtown center so you can grab a yummy crepe at sophies =)
author: JUDY L.

description: One of the best noodle places in Japan town. I really like the kara age ramen. Often a wait to be seated though!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
came here  with my coo coo mama and my old man.  we got in during the end of the lunch shift.  although it was not packed, the tables all turned at once, so the servers were scrambling to bus and and take orders all at once. 
I swear, the older my mom gets the more obnoxious she is in public.  She was waving with her chopsticks,(ohashi) "herro! menu kudasai!  oh gosh, i apologised, and although the cute waitresses seemed understandably irked, they came around when i apologised and thanked them over and over.  i love my mom, she cracks me up.
ok, the food.  i had ramen with the pea shoots, my mom and old man had  chashu.  Oh so onolicious!  ooishii!
noodles were so robust, substancial and chewy, they were manly man ramen noodles!
the broths were seasoned well, my shio was subtle and sexy.  sometimes it is just a turn off when broth can have too much going on.
the chashu was the best i've seen anywhere yet.
lastly, i am officially obsessed with pea shoots.  so perfect in my ramen.
i buy them by the huge bagful at new mei wah market on 7th and clement and make my own ramen or tofu or whatever.  my friend has been sauteing them with heirloom tomatoes.  
i digress.  i can't wait to go back!  the waitresses were so cute too!
author: yayoi s.

description: This restaurant is a joke. You only get ONE tiny piece of pork for Chasu Ramen. What a ripoff!!!
author: D'Andy C.

description:
The best ramen in the city.

Bad thing is the place is so small that it fills up quickly.  I had the tokyo ramen.  the noodles tasted fresh and it was chewy.  The broth was salty but all broths for ramen are salty.
author: kenny l.

description: Life can't get better than Chashu Ramen at Suzu, Period.
author: Theo F.

description: They do ramen right.  Great noodles.  Good soup.  Also one of the few places in the city that does shio ramen.  The only downside is the wait - which has driven me to make bad choices like Sapporo-ya in the past.  Don't do it - the wait is better than the alternative.
author: Klaus M.

description: I love, love, love Suzu! Sure, it's in a mall--not the classiest of locations. Sure, it's tiny. But I love the noodles, especially the hot Udon noodles with the chicken katsu curry on the side. A perfect amount of food! And it's pretty inexpensive too.
author: Anna G.

description:
Excellent!  I went with 3 other friends on a week night.   After about a 20 minute wait we got seated, which is understandable for how small the place is.  It was well worth the wait!  Would definitelyrecommend this place...great value!  

One thing to note, they have weird hours on the weekends.  I live in the area and have tried to go here before but it was closed.  I believe they close between 2pm-4pm on the weekends.
author: Kim S.

description: this has been our definitive ramen place in j-town since it opened.  granted the place is small and they struggle to handle the long line of customers.  nonetheless, looking past this, the ramen itself is good.  I am not sure if the noodles are home-made (in fact I dont think they are simply becos they are too chewy) but the broth is good (some say it could be on the salty side) and so is the overall menu options.  quite frankly, I cant think of another ramen place to rival them in J-town hence we'll have to put up with the long waits until they decide to expand.
author: Teresa T.

description: I've been here twice and I honestly don't understand what's so great about this place. The broth is bland and uninteresting and the noodles, even if they are house made, are just noodles. And service is terrible. People mill about outside waiting and waiting while there are empty tables. Perhaps its so crowded because of its strategic location?
author: Michele F.

description: the udon with shrimp tempura is sublime. all of japantown can be considered my happy place, and this is truly one of its crown jewels.
author: Sally R.

description:
I ordered Kara-age ramen. It's a ramen with fried chicken on the side.
I'm a very small person, and cannot eat a lot of food in one sitting.
Well, the portion was so skimpy, I was still hungry after I finished eating. 
Kara-age was yummy (again, very skimpy portion...4 little pieces of chicken), but the soup was kind of off...tasted like there was something missing. Noodle was kind of flat, too.
I won't go back there again.
author: M K.

description: If you like ramen, this place serves up some good noodles.  It's a small place in J-town and usually there is a line.  I only order ramen here so can't tell you much about the other offerings.
author: Yen T.

description: Delicious, inexpensive bowls of udon or soba.  Good tempura.  I did not like the ramen, but overall, a good standby for a quick meal in Japantown.
author: erika s.

description: The Broth was wasn't special, but the Noodles really were special. The Broth was good, but the noodles had more of a chewy texture so it was better.  I like Suzu Noodle House!
author: Shawn I.

description: I've been to Tokyo many times and Suzu is really good.  Try the cold soba.  It's fresh, pure tasting and delicious.  Soba is tougher than it looks to make. The curry is very good as well.
author: T D.

description:
I've always passed by Suzu while I'm in Japantown, but the line is outrageous.  I'm also really picky about Japanese food since I lived there.  But when a Japanese friend told me the udon and dashi are pretty good at Suzu, I decided to give it a chance.  The wait was a bit long because it was Friday night.  Nabeyaki udon is my favorite and I tend to order it at every Japanese restaurant that offers it.  So I was happy to find there were a variety on the menu.  I was a little put off by the price though.  Although it's not grossly overpriced, it is definitely on the higher end.  The other udon dishes and combinations are a better value I think.

I ordered the Chicken Nabeyaki Udon. The udon was pretty chewy and had the thickness I love.  Unfortunately, the service was ridiculously slow and it wasn't just for us.  The surrounding tables were looking even more impatient than we were.

I would come back here for a bowl of udon.  Hopefully the wait and service won't be so slow next time...
author: M C.

description: Every time I walk by and think about going - including weeknights - there is a line out the door - have never been able to actually get in! with so many other good options in the Japan Center - its not worth the long wait in my book.
author: Michael C.

description: its ok. nothing wow. its like plain ramen.
author: Cindy L.

description: Pretty good, better than most ramen in Japantown, cleaner tasting than Tampopo. But if you want real ramen take a drive to the South Bay.
author: Linda Y.

description: Delicous Noodles on rainy day or not!  This place is always pack.....so come early and try their Tokyo Noodle Soup. Yum!!! Pair this with chicken karaage.
author: mary l.

description: Best Udon in town but the place is small and usually a long wait before seating.  The Udon there is so good!  I think it might have changed hands recently and the food quality has slightly suffered.  Still not bad though.
author: Nicholas W.

description: love the noddle, it is delicious and a super big bowl. though i think the downstairs one is better
author: Carol X.

description: Oh what a disappointment- to be a ramen house in JAPAN TOWN and to not use good ramen noodles and not have creamy pork broth!  Don't go out of your way to eat here, but if you're in the neighborhood and you're not a ramen snob, you'll be happy.
author: Beth L.

description: I was surprised when I ordered the miso ramen.  The dish reminded me of a ramen house in Japantown, Los Angeles.  Home-made chewy noodles with a savory miso soup base.  I was lucky to have been able to drop in while I was in-between appointments.  Definitely worth checking out.
author: Mara O.

description: yum... i heart noodles. but i only heart not-overcooked, al-dente noodles. 4 of us came here before a movie next door. i had the yamakake don - tuna with grated potatoes - which i was excited to see on the menu (fyi, if you don't like slimy things, don't order this.) it was good with an extra dash of soy, but i like things saltier than others, i think. others had spicy negi ramen, udon w/ a side of karaage, and soba with tempura. i tried the ramen and udon and both types of noodles were perfectly cooked. i now heart suzu.
author: Angi C.

description: Awesome ramen joint.  Fresh noodles, interesting combinations (try the Karaage chicken!).  Whenever we are in the mood for ramen, this is the place for us.  We just moved from NYC where there is arguably some of the best ramen in the country and this place stacks up nicely without some of the hullabaloo that is involved with the popular ramen joints in NYC (I'm talking to you Ippudo).  Although there is usually a wait, it is worth it and usually not more than 20 minutes.
author: bill l.

description: Now that I work and no long live that savage college life style.  I can spend 8 bucks on real ramen!  No more of that 10 cent instant MSG rush in a little plastic bag that comes with bits of noodle chips.  This place has the best ramen ever!  Even Naruto would love this place!  It also won't dent his frog wallet much either.  The ramen is about 7.50-9 bucks.  I got the spicy Negi ramen (which wasn't spicy at all).  Ya that's right, they have a ramen that sounds like Neji... the naruto character.  This place is pretty tiny and it barely sits 20 people or so.  My friend suggested giving this place 1 star to prevent people from coming here....but I can't.  This place deserves 5 stars hands down.  The brooth and their noodles were spectacular.  I liked this place much better than Kitana Ya in downtown Geary.
author: Nelson W.

description: Ramen is good here but Katana-ya is better.  If you find yourself in Japan Town and wanting a bowl of Ramen, this is the place.  The Ramen texture is chewy and the broth is yummy.  My husband tried the Udon and like it as well.  The menu is limited but I think they added on a little more variety now of the way you can order your Ramen or Udon.  The wait is often very long and service could be slow at time.  Will I go out of my way to come here and eat Ramen......the answer is no but if I am in the neighborhood......Yes!
author: Mel T.

description: I tried the tempura and ramen lunch combo and the cold udon and unagi over rice combo.  The tempura was pretty good.  Nice, crisp veggies, nothing to complain about there.  The unagi was pretty standard, was not disappointed with that either.  My ramen noodles were pretty good.  They had that certain chewiness that I feel really distinguishes well-made ramen.  It could have been a little bit firmer, but I should have asked the waitress for that.  The broth was a little bit disappointing.  It lacked complexity.  I can't even remember what else was served with the ramen.  All I remember about it was the noodles.  The cold udon was probably my favorite thing there.  It was chewy and firm and the dipping sauce was simple and delicious.  I would definitely come back for the noodles, but maybe try a different kind of broth for ramen (like maybe miso instead of shio) or just go straight for the really simple stuff that focuses mainly on the noodles.
author: Linh N.

description: suzu by far has the best soba noodles in japantown... they don't take reservations, but the wait is usually pretty short and definitely worth it... every time we're in japantown, this is a must restaurant for us to dine at... h-100...
author: Herb F.

description: I was expecting the ramen to be really good but was somewhat disppointed.  The portion was really small and the flavor was ok.  I doubt I would go back to this place.
author: Mary L.

description: unagi. that's all you have to say to get my attention. and at Suzu House, a bowl of unagi don comes accompanied by a bowl of your choice of udon, soba or ramen, for less than $10! if you're there at lunch time, that is.  wash that all down with some sake and you're ready Kabuki (theater that is...).
author: ray e.

description: Suzu was quite disappointing.  Noodle portions were small and a bit under-cooked.  Pricing was not competitive.  Not sure why there is a wait at that place all the time.  On top of it, very few selection on side dishes.  We got the tuna.  Not fresh at all.  I would go to Tanpop down 2 blocks then this place any time.
author: grace C.

description:
good
- spicy mabo ramen!!!
- tempura and other noodle soups are all good
- you can get a gelato or a crepe upstairs afterwards

bad
- some of the non-noodle stuff (gyoza, etc.) is not great, but it's not a gyoza house
- a little small inside, so sometimes you have to wait
- portions are not huge, but it's Japanese food...
author: Anthony W.

description: I couldn't decide if I should write them a crappy review so that I wouldn't have to wait in line all the time...or a good one so they never go out of business.  But since they have been good to me, I am giving them five stars.  They're always friendly and conversational, and they always remember me and what my dad wants, though I guess it would be hard not to, since we go there almost twice a week.  My favorites: vegetarian udon (I get that in ramen form, though), salmon sashimi, salmon don, vegetable tempura, unagi don, and their ramen--all y'all who don't like their ramen are CRAZY.  This is the only ramen in town I'll eat (though someone mentioned that there was egg in their noodles, so that would explain everything since i am an egg lover).  It's nice and al dente, and I love the soup (my dad says it tastes bitter, though, and prefers Sapporo-Ya upstairs).  I often get it as part of their lunch combo (some kind of rice bowl + ramen) because it's so cheap I'd feel stupid ordering just one item for almost the same price, but I really shouldn't because there's just too much food and somebody else has to finish my ramen every time.  What else...oh, they're always coming around with hot tea refills.  I have never had to ask.  And there's a little sink in the corner for you to wash your hands before you eat.  They've been closed now for the past week, though, and won't be open again until the 18th.  What is going on??  If anybody knows, please message me, thanks.
author: Janice C.

description: I don't think the ramen's that great but because there isn't anywhere else to go in the city....I keep coming back! ARGH! The bf always gets the karage ramen and I always get a combo......I just wish there was some decent ramen competition around.
author: Emily W.

description: We ordered the friend pork with eggs over rice and fried chicken with ramen. I've had freshly made ramen before and this comes pretty close.  The place is pretty small and luckily we got there before the crowds.  We were 2nd on the list and still had to wait about 10 min to get a table.  I would give the ramen a 4 star rating.  It was decent and the chicken was cooked well but it just didn't seem all that flavorful.  It wasn't too salty so that's a big plus.  The noodles seemed like they were frozen after they were made.  Just didn't seem as fresh as the ramen I've had before.  Overall still a good bowl of ramen.  The pork and eggs over rice was alright.  It was too salty.  The taste was a salty, sweet mixture that worked well if only it were less salty.  I would only give it 3 stars.  The service was decent.  Very professional but not overly friendly.  They were there to give you food, tea and the check.  I've also been to ramen club in burlingame and that place is better.  The service is about the same but the ramen tastes fresher and the soup more flavorful.  Also, it took quite a while for the food to come out.  You would think at such a small place with a line you would want to get people in and out asap but they didn't care too much.
author: Ken W.

description: The lunch combos are a good value, and the ramen is basic but very tasty. Santa in San Mateo is still the best but Suzu is not far behind, in a different sort of way.
author: Patrick A.

description: I usually go to Tanpopo for ramen but decided I needed to shake things up. So I came here for lunch today with a friend instead. It was both our first time here and there was no wait. (around 1:30-2) I ordered the unagi/ramen lunch combo. Now I'm not a picky eater nor do I know anything about ramen but it was pretty decent. Two dishes for $10 is pretty cheap. I was full and satisfied. The only thing that really annoyed me was that the waitress was hoovering over me while I was writing down the tip. UGH How annoying. Other than that..I will definitely come again.
author: Jess L.

description:
ramen - nothing special. 
chicken karaage. pretty good.
author: Diana L.

description: Eh, the place was a bit too small and stuffy. I chose a window seat, which was a big mistake because this couple sat right on the other side which was awkward. The seating was a bit cramped and the tea smelled like cigarettes. Miso soup was okay, not too great. The ramen was great and worth the wait. Curry with rice and chicken wasn't bad. First time eating curry, and I don't like it.
author: Peyton L.

description:
This place was pretty good. BF and I stopped by on Sunday afternoon around 4:45pm because he felt like ramen. It was closed until 5pm, so we decided to wait 15 minutes. They were a few people standing around waiting already so I suggested that we wait there too. (BF wanted to go look at the bookstore and come back at 5). Thank goodness we waited because a line formed behind us. We were 3rd to enter the restauarant. They seated us right next to the sink thats in the dining room (which is weird in itself, and possibly unsanitary). Luckily, the waitress took our order first and we were first to get our food. I had the karage rame and BF had the mabo tofu ramen because he likes spicy. Since this was technically our late lunch and we were eating dinner later, we decided not to get a combo or any appetizers. I liked my karage and BF's was pretty spice (which he likes). I like the noodles, which are supposedly home-made. We even paid and left before some people who were seated at the same time as us got their food. I guess you can say we got pretty lucky.

I would definitely come back again to try some of the other dishes. I heard the nabe udon was supposed to be yummy too.
author: T C.

description: Although the restaurant decor isn't much, the ramen noodles are worth the trek.  The prices are cheap, the proporations are big enough (but not so humongous that you go home feeling like a slug) and the homemade noodles and broth are better than the average "Japanese noodle house".  Go for the "ma-po" ramen!
author: Hannah H.

description: A small, intimate restaurant on the lower level of the plaza. Perfect for someone who is looking to have a quiet dinner or just a spot to unwind after a long day. By far, one of the best places in the city for ramen. You can't fade their dashi. It's perfect!
author: Kacey K.

description: oishi.  one of the better noodle spots in j-town.  they serve good ramen, but this ain't a ramen joint.
author: mark l.

description: referred to me by a friend who swore the ramen was the proverbial shit - and he was right.  noodles are top notch.  the service stinks, but not for lack of effort.  it's just that, for some reason, management made the brilliant decision that only two waitresses are needed during weekend dinner hours.  bummer 'cause you need about 10 glasses of water to rehydrate yourself from all the msg you ingest.
author: J M.

description: My friends and I were deciding where to eat and as we were reading the menu of this place it looked like a good choice. The service was nice but after we ordered our food, the food took forever. Everyone else around us had their dishes. Finally, the food came out and it was good ramen. But as I ate more and more I grew tired of the ramen, I dont know what happened. But I am willing to give it another chance despite the slow food, the waitresses were very nice.
author: jenny c.

description: went there 5 minutes after opening at 5pm and the place was packed. since we were the last seated, it took a while for our order to get served. there were four pretty ladies rushing around serving tea and food and two cooks hidden in the back of the kitchen. the stylish decor of the place was nice to look at and reminded me of tokyo restaurants except with more space. The problem with good ramen seems to be the same with this place. A professional ramen cook can only cook for about 6-9 ramen dishes at a time since it is about not letting the noodles sit in the broth too long. hence the long wait and small number of customers at a time. when the shop first opens, all the orders pretty much come in at the same time so it can take a while to make all the dishes. overall, the place had a nice atmosphere, ok price and tasty ramen. will definately have to try some of the other dishes. Tokyo ramen was yummy but would have liked maybe 2 or 3 slices of the tasty cha shu pork. bamboo shoots were very good.
author: tomohisa w.

description: Went back to Suzu yesterday. First time in over a year. Always liked their ramen. Something has changed. Well, the service has always been neutral to indifferent, so that's the same. Tried to order the Chashu Ramen and was told they were out of Chashu (odd, since that's like one of the main varieties of ramen noodles, but OK) so ordered the Spicy Ramen. Holy Mother of Ramen! The broth was so spicy, it was inedible! Diners at next table noticed that I was STRUGGLING with the soup and commented! Did the kitchen accidentally give me double dose of spicy?! I can handle spicy, but not this one. I should have said something, but sometimes I wimp out and hate myself for wimping out. But, that's what I did. (OK, maybe I could have said something but just got the feeling the waitress wouldn't really care. That's my interpretation though.)  I don't think I will return. Oh, had the Agedashi as a starter, and it was OK. As I was fleeing the restaurant, I noticed that Bushi-Tei Bistro next door serves ramen with a choice of side dish for much less $ than Suzu. This was such a negative experience that I joined yelp to review the place and to save others from the mouth burning torture.
author: Dedicated E.

description: I went here with a group of friends last Sunday, and was looking forward to trying another ramen place in the city. The food was okay, but I was very disappointed with the service. I had ordered one of their lunch specials, curry rice with ramen, but when it came out, I noticed that they had instead given me tonkatsu over rice. I asked the waitress about the order, and she went and brought out the bill which indicated that she wrote down the incorrect order.  However, instead of correcting the order, she emphasized that she had repeated the order and would not do anything about my food.  Now, I may have misheard her when she repeated the order, but I was very surprised that she would not do anything about the situation.  I even asked for some curry so I could eat my rice, but she refused to do so.  After reading some of the other reviews on the site, I definitely agree that customer service is not one of this restaurant's strengths.
author: leo k.

description: this place has good ramen.  not the best i've ever had, but good.  the noodles taste fresh and the broth is decent.  i'd say its a little over priced, but not outrageous.  the place is small and there is usually a wait.  if u are as impatient as i am, i suggest goin early to avoid the rush.
author: Jeremy N.
